article.article_title: How to Pay the Bills If You’re Too Sick or Injured to Work
article.meta_description: Disability insurance can provide a financial safety net for you and your family in the event of a debilitating illness or accident. Here’s how it works.
article.meta_keywords: disability insurance, Michael Rubenstein, Taylor & Taylor, Ray Taylor, Aaron Schindler, Wealth Advisory Group, American Society of Media Photographers, American Photographic Artists
article.article_text_abstract: Disability insurance can provide a financial safety net for you and your family in the event of a debilitating illness or accident. Here’s how it works.
article.article_text:
Photographer Michael Rubenstein was thrown 100 feet from his motorcycle three years ago, after an SUV T-boned him at an intersection. The accident broke all of his ribs on the right side, punctured a lung, and shattered his right leg, arm and shoulder. “I was in an ICU in Blatimore for three or four weeks, then they flew me to New York, where I was in the hospital for about another month,” Rubenstein says.

Out of work for two years because of lingering neurological damage, Rubenstein exhausted his savings and then went “tens of thousands of dollars” into credit card debt, just to pay his basic living expenses. “I didn’t have disability insurance,” he says. “My mother had told me to get it. I said, ‘What do I need with long-term disability insurance? I'm fine. I'll be fine.’”

He goes on to say that had he only taken his mother’s advice, “It would have made a huge difference. I would have had money to pay my rent, and for food, and bills.”

Injuries or illnesses capable of putting you out of work for extended periods are more common than you might think. Twenty-year-olds have a 30 percent chance of becoming disabled for 90 days or longer before retirement, according to the Social Security Administration. And the average duration of disabilities doubles from about 2.5 years to about 5 years by retirement age, according to insurance industry statistics.

The consequences of disability can be financially devastating. While medical insurance covers healthcare expenses, it won’t pay the mortgage and utilities or put food on the table while you are unable to work. That’s where disability insurance comes in, but most people, including photographers, aren’t adequately covered.

“Any photographer who doesn’t have disability insurance is running a risk,” says Ray Taylor, CEO of Taylor & Taylor, ASMP’s preferred disability insurance broker. “Several hundred photographers around the country are insured through us, and there’s always someone who gets in trouble.”

Social Security, by the way, doesn’t provide much of a safety net. You have to be so severely disabled to collect Social Security that upwards of 80 percent of applicants are rejected. And even if you’re application is approved, payments max out at about $900 per month—hardly enough to cover the expenses of most people.

For adequate coverage, you have to buy a private policy through a licensed insurance broker. Coverage options vary widely. “Buy as much disability insurance as you can get, and do it while you’re young and healthy,” advises Wealth Advisory Group managing director Aaron Schindler, who is the preferred disability insurance broker for American Photographic Artists (APA).

How Much…and Who’s Eligible?

Various web sites can help you figure out how much coverage you need (Google: “disability insurance calculator”). Costs vary, but it is pricey: expect to pay around 3 percent of your gross income for coverage. Eligibility depends upon various factors, including your age, your health, and your specialty. Generally, coverage is available to photographers 55 and younger who can prove they’re in good health, and whose photographic specialties don’t put them in harm’s way. But eligibility standards have become more stringent, as fewer and fewer companies continue to offer disability insurance. “You have to have a cleaner and cleaner health history” to get insured, Schindler says.

When applying, you’ll be required first to disclose your medical history in detail. You may also be required to provide certain medical records. Some underwriters require blood and urine samples, and perhaps even an EKG depending upon your age, says Schindler.

If you have pre-existing medical conditions, insurers may refuse coverage, or offer it with exclusions for any disabilities stemming from those pre-existing conditions. “Diabetes, heart disease and cancer are obvious bugaboos,” says Taylor, but also expect exclusions for back-related disabilities simply for having visited a chiropractor for “adjustments,” Schindler warns. And if you’re on anti-depressants, chances are you won’t get insurance at all, he adds.

If you engage in activities such as sky diving, auto racing, SCUBA diving, or rock climbing, expect exclusions for those things. And, says Schindler, “The more physical your work, and the more you travel and encounter dangerous situations, the pricier the policy and the less likely you are [to get insurance].”

Table top photographers have the easiest time getting insured. Photojournalists traveling to war zones are unlikely to find coverage at any price. Editorial photographers and location shooters may have to hunt around for a policy, because insurers have become more risk-averse, and some underwriters now offer insurance only to studio photographers, Schindler says.

What To Look For

The primary factors to consider when buying insurance are the so-called elimination period, how the policy defines disability, and the benefits provided in the event of a claim.

The elimination period is the time lag between the onset of disability and the start of disability payments. It may be 30, 60, 90, 120 days or even longer, though the cost of a short elimination period can be prohibitive. A 90-day elimination period is typical. (Obviously, it’s important to have enough savings to cover your living expenses through the elimination period.)

Insurers define disability in two ways. “Own occupation” policies pay out if you are too sick or injured to perform your duties as a photographer. “Any occupation” policies, by contrast, pay only if you are unable to do any job at all, whether it’s photographer or desk-bound clerk or anything else.  

“Nobody wants an ‘any occupation’ policy,” advises Schindler. “You have to be so screwed up [and therefore unable to do anything at all] to get it to kick in.”

Monthly Payments: How Much?

Monthly payouts in the event of a disability typically range from 40 to 65 percent of your income at the time you purchased the policy. Some underwriters impose maximums. Policies available to ASMP members through Taylor & Taylor max out at $4,000 per month, for instance. (The reason underwriters don’t insure your entire income is to limit their exposure, and to give you incentive to go back to work as soon as you’re able.)

One problem with the percentage-of-income formula is that self-employed photographers often use various accounting tricks to minimize their income on their IRS Form 1040. That reduces tax liability, but it also lowers the monthly disability payments you’re eligible for, because insurers look at your recent tax forms to determine your income.

Another difficulty is that if you buy disability insurance when you’re young, your income is likely to be relatively low, so disability payments might be insufficient to cover your expenses if you become disabled in middle age.

To compensate, you can buy an inflation rider, so your coverage rises with inflation. Another option is to buy a so-called future increase option (FIO), which allows you to increase your policy’s monthly payment provisions by up to 100 percent as your salary increases.

“I advise people to buy the FIO because it’s cheaper than the inflation rider,” says Schindler.

Payment Duration

Besides the monthly payment provision, the other critical benefit to consider is the duration of payments in the event of a disability. Historically, the three common options were 5 years, to age 65, and lifetime. Unfortunately, though, lifetime policies are nearing extinction. Policies that provide “own occupation” insurance to age 65 are also becoming scarce.

“Normally you’re insured for two, five or ten years at your own occupation, and then after that you’re covered only if you’re unable to perform work for which you’re reasonably suited by education, training, or experience,” says Taylor. For instance, if you’re in a wheelchair and can’t work as a photographer, your payments would stop if you were able to do things such as photo editing or teaching photography. And some underwriters are willing to help you transition into a suitable career by offering financial assistance for re-training, Taylor notes.

Another way insurers limit their exposure and keep premiums affordable is by issuing policies that reduce benefit payments by the amount you may earn at another occupation, no matter what it is, according to Schindler. For instance, if you’re disabled as a photographer, but then start to earn money as a lawyer, your disability benefits will decrease accordingly.

There’s no such thing as a “standard” policy, though. Underwriters all offer different options, at different prices, so it pays to shop around.

Special Riders

Worth mentioning are so called “partial” or “residual” disability riders (additions to a policy) that allow you to collect a portion of your monthly disability payments if you are able to work part time. Partial disability coverage may be useful, for instance, while you are transitioning back to work. Without partial disability protection, you’re disability payments end when you go back to work, even if aren’t able to earn your full income.

Some insurers also offer social security riders, which reduce your monthly payments by the amount of Social Security disability you are able to collect, if any. A Social Security rider can save you money, but will reduce your monthly income if your disability is severe enough to qualify you for Social Security. “I recommend social security riders only to my most budget conscious customers,” says Schindler.

Filing a Claim

Insurers are obligated to pay claims when your physician declares you too injured or ill to perform the duties of your occupation. But some underwriters are more apt than others to contest claims, so it pays to inquire about the underwriter’s record for paying claims.

Michigan photographer Jay Asquini, who could no longer work after shattering his spine in an accident in 2001, says he had to fight for months to get his insurance company to pay on his disability claim. Part of the problem was that the extent of Asquini’s cognitive disabilities weren’t immediately apparent, and he was in a Catch-22: he was too disabled, he says, to make the case that he was disabled.

“If you need to make a claim, get someone—a forceful relative or a competent attorney—to make it for you,” he advises.

But the most important thing, he says, is to live and work safely. “But accidents happen. I was lucky that I had insurance.”

For his part, Michael Rubenstein says he’s rebuilding his career and can’t yet afford disability insurance. But as soon as his finances allow, he says, he’ll be shopping for a policy.

article.article_title: Combining Still and Video Productions: Danielle Levitt for I-D Magazine
article.meta_description: Levitt explains how she runs her productions so she can shoot video and stills without compromising.
article.article_text_abstract: Levitt explains how she runs her productions so she can shoot video and stills without compromising.
article.article_image_caption: For i-D Magazine, Danielle Levitt shot a series of videos called Tribes, sponsored by Marc Jacobs, each profiling a particular subculture, and couldn’t resist shooting stills as well. “I love filmmaking,” says Levitt, “but my instinct is always to take pictures.”
article.article_text:
As more photographers move into motion and promote their skills as directors, they can sometimes find themselves pulled in two directions on assignments, when the client wants them to deliver great stills as well as high-quality video. According to veteran photographer-directors PDN spoke to, the first step in managing a combined production is to separate the shoots for stills from the shoot for the video—by carrying them out at different times or in slightly separate locations. To ensure a smooth workflow, photographer-directors also have to adjust their lighting, the planning of their shots, and their directions to their crews. In part one of this three-part series, Danielle Levitt breaks down the planning and production of recent still-video assignment for I-D magazine.

Levitt's experience is part one of a three-part series. In part 2, here, Katrine Naleid and Stephen Austin Welch share with PDN how they planned and produced a shoot for Elmer’s glue.

n part two of this three-part series, Katrine Naleid and Stephen Austin Welch explain how they planned and produced a shoot for Elmer’s. Read part one of this series, about Danielle Levitt’s shoot for I-D magazine, here. - See more at: http://www.pdnonline.com/features/Combining-Still-and-Video-Productions-Katrine-Naleid-and-Stephen-Austin-Welch-for-Elmer-s-15292.shtml#sthash.LPkb9RqC.dpuf

For photographer and director Danielle Levitt, shooting still photos is part of nearly every video production she does, whether or not the assignment brief calls for it. “I’m a photographer first and a filmmaker second. I love filmmaking, but my instinct is always to take pictures,” she says. 

When clients don’t give her a request and a budget to shoot stills, Levitt has to steal time for it—without compromising the video production, of course. She and her producer manage it by running tightly organized productions, working with a seasoned film crew, and setting up a portable studio adjacent to the film set, so Levitt can shoot stills at any spare moment.

“Flexibility is king. You have to figure out how to do both [still and video], and have your instincts be super sharp, so nothing gets compromised,” she says. “It requires a lot of energy and a lot of focus. You’re basically doing two jobs.”

Last year, for instance, she produced a series of three videos called Tribes for i-D Magazine. Sponsored by Marc Jacobs, each video featured a different youthful “tribe,” including a rockabilly crowd, a group of thrashcore musicians, and a group of BMX riders. 

The client hired Levitt for video only, but she also delivered stills at no extra charge because she found the subjects so compelling.

“I love what I do and I know there’s value in it, but I just wanted to give. I can’t say I always do, or always will,” she says.

She shot the videos in a loose documentary style, pre-interviewing the subjects about the places they hang out, and the things they do. She then created storyboards for various shots around locations where she could prompt and then shoot authentic action. She says, “When we get to a location where we are there long enough, I set up my studio kit”—a white seamless backdrop and a few lights. She also has at least one photo assistant and tech on stand-by, just to help with the still shooting.

For the rockabilly video, she had the portable studio set up in a parking lot near the last location of the day. Because the rockabilly “tribe” is nocturnal, the production went well past midnight. Levitt started pulling her subjects into the studio for quick portraits as the film crew was wrapping up. By that time, she had spent 17 hours with them. “I knew them, they were warmed up, and you have that dynamic [of rapport] you want for stills, because you have only a moment to capture it,” she says.

The BMX production, which involved stylishly dressed youth riding BMX bikes through city streets, took place during the day. On that shoot, Levitt also pulled subjects into her portable studio for quick portraits. In addition, she wandered around the film set all day with camera in hand, giving the talent a few quick directions for on-the-spot still images, and grabbing “beauty images,” says Stephanie Porto, who has been Levitt’s full-time producer for the past five years.

Levitt says she’s often shot a few stills while her film crew is occupied with its preparations, such as laying dolly tracks, changing camera lenses, or adjusting lights. That’s how she grabbed still photos on a recent production for Smoke x Mirrors Eyewear. Levitt says her photo assistant had set up her portable studio on that shoot, “but the wind came along and knocked it over, and we didn’t have time to set it up again.”

For every production, Levitt and Porto allot a specific amount of shoot time for each scene on the video storyboard. To meet the schedule, “you staff up” as much as the budget allows, Levitt says. Her sets include a director of photography—she often works with David Raboy—camera assistants, grips, and gaffers—enough people to break down and set up quickly between one location and the next. (If she has a budget for still photography, she’ll bring as many as three assistants just for that, and sometimes schedule a day just for a photo shoot.)

On set, Porto minds the clock, and gets the crew to step up the pace if production is falling behind. “That’s the hardest part: making sure the film doesn’t take more time than you have,” Levitt says. The shoots are also organized so she has to spend little or no time between scenes giving directions to the crew, leaving her a few minutes to shoot instead. For instance, crew members are briefed in the morning, given a printed schedule, and during each scene, the upcoming scenes are announced. 

Occasionally Levitt is able to shoots stills while Raboy, her DP, is shooting a video scene. They’ve worked together on a number of productions, so he knows what Levitt expects, and she trusts him. “When he’s shooting [a scene with] someone over here, I can shoot [stills of] someone else over there, because I know he’s got that. We’ve mapped it out. He’s running it, so I’ll go take that picture on the side.”

Levitt says she has no difficulty switching mental gears from video to stills, because shooting stills has become instinctual for her. The real challenge is carving out time for both. “You have to be really organized, you have to know what you want, and you have to have a strong team in place.”

article.article_title: Unusual Assignment: Inside a Global Shoot of 2,100 Portraits
article.meta_description: How Goodrich Visions, a three-person company in New York, coordinated 34 photographers around the world to produce visually consistent portraits for a global law firm.
article.article_text_abstract: How Goodrich Visions, a three-person company in New York, coordinated 34 photographers around the world to produce visually consistent portraits for a global law firm.
article.article_image_caption: Photographers set up identical studios at law offices around the world according to exacting specifications.
article.article_text:
For creative services agency and production company Goodrich Visions, an assignment to produce portraits of more than 2,000 attorneys for a global law firm was a logistical tour de force. “It was the biggest project our little firm has taken on, and it could have come apart at the seams any time,” says principal Matthew Goodrich.

The law firm was re-branding, and wanted to update its website with clean, visually consistent portraits of all its partners and associates. Goodrich had previously worked with the firm’s global director of creative services. “When it came down to the comparison between multiple vendors I felt confident to go with the team I already knew and trusted,” she says.

The brief called for black-and-white portraits set against a background of the city where each attorney works. (The firm has offices in 39 countries.) Goodrich, who was the executive producer of the project, says it took months to work out details, estimate the costs, and nail down a contract. “It came down to how we would handle the production process in each city.” The plan was to use local photographers—they ultimately hired 34 of them around the world?—so getting a consistent look across so many sets and subjects remained a big challenge. 

Goodrich’s wife, Tami Goodrich, served as the project’s creative director. With more than 20 years of experience as a photo art director for fashion and outdoor lifestyle retailers, she oversaw all the art direction and styling. The third member of the team was Robert Staley, a Los Angeles-based commercial lifestyle and catalogue photographer.    

Originally, they planned to scout locations near the firm’s offices and shoot outdoors. Figuring out the logistics for that plan took three months. But when the firm learned that its attorneys would be away from their desks for 45 minutes each, plans to shoot outdoors were scrapped because the loss of billable hours revenue was too steep.

So Goodrich Visions figured out how to set up studios inside the firm’s offices, and rely on a retoucher to make the portraits look like they had been shot outside. Besides being able to move attorneys through indoor sets twice as fast, Goodrich Visions didn’t have to worry about variables such as unpredictable light and weather. 

“We needed to simulate an outdoor shoot, so we created a lighting diagram for all the photographers to follow with a rim light off to the side, to make it seem like the sun was shining over [the subject’s] shoulder,” Goodrich explains.

They did a test run at the Los Angeles office of the firm. “We worked through some of the kinks, and figured out efficiencies that could be put in place,” Goodrich says. For instance, they figured out exactly how much time the photographer needed with each subject (20 to 30 minutes) and the minimum crew—photographer, photo assistant and groomer—required to make the set run smoothly. The pilot shoot also included a post-production test for three different companies bidding for the retouching work. 

On the basis of the LA shoot, Goodrich Visions came up with a detailed styling and technical guide that ran more than 20 pages. It served as template that other photographers hired for the job had to follow. It included an equipment list, a lighting schematic, and instructions on where to place the tripod and camera for the proper scaling. It included directions for styling and posing subjects, and included sample photographs with the words “I want this” or “I do not want this” written next to them, Tami Goodrich says.

“Some photographers wanted to put their spin on it, but I didn’t want them to put their spin on it. I wanted them to follow [the guidelines] to the letter,” she says.

Goodrich Visions also used the LA shoot as the basis for an estimate for the entire job. The contract for the job ran 20 pages, and took a month to hammer out.

Staley and Tami Goodrich worked as a team to shoot the portraits in all the U.S. offices of the firm. In New York City, they had two sets going simultaneously, and shot 40 attorneys per day. With photographers hired to shoot portraits at offices outside the U.S., they had pre-production Skype calls to make sure everyone understood the details. They scheduled the first overseas shoots in smaller offices of the firm in order to further test and tweak the production procedures.

The hired photographers were required to scout the offices before the shoot day. “We had follow-up calls once they did the scout,” to head off potential problems, Matthew Goodrich says. Photographers were also required to send test shots of their assistants before they started photographing the attorneys, to make sure the lighting and camera positioning were correct.

Goodrich says he and his team were on call 24/7 throughout production, in order to check the work while photographers were still on set, and to trouble shoot on the fly. “By the time we were half way through, we had it dialed. We learned a ton.”

In all, there were 130 shoot days over a period of six months. Working with project managers in each of the firm’s offices, Goodrich managed all the shoot day scheduling. For that task, he used Sales Force, a project management platform. “At any time, I knew where each [attorney] was in the process. I could track everything through post production and delivery,” he says.

The photographers shot a total of 59,000 images, or 25 to 30 frames per subject. By contract stipulation, each attorney had final approval over his or her portrait. Goodrich says that stipulation added another two months to the project.

Tami Goodrich edited the frames of each subject down to seven frames. “We used a star system to rate the selections,” and help subjects make the final image selection, she explains. Once subjects made their selection, it went to the retoucher to be recomposed as if it had been shot outside, rather than in a conference room.

The firm’s director of creative services praises Goodrich Visions for being “organized, trustworthy and low maintenance. Issues were handled before I even knew they existed, which is the best type of vendor to partner with.”

Now that the job is finished, “it will be much easier for us to deconstruct [similar] projects, and streamline operations” for other global firms, Goodrich says. “If we were approached by another corporation with 10, 15 or 20 offices, we would have no trouble stacking [the shoots] to minimize delivery time.” The company has no such assignments pending, but Goodrich says he’s pursuing several leads.

article.article_title: Ayana V. Jackson Confronts Racism With Recreations of Historic Images
article.meta_description: Using her own likeness, Jackson reconstructs images of blacks by whites in an effort to keep those pictures—and their inherent racism—in the public consciousness.
article.article_text_abstract: Using her own likeness, Jackson reconstructs images of blacks by whites in an effort to keep those pictures—and their inherent racism—in the public consciousness.
article.article_image_credit: © AYANA V. JACKSON/COURTESY MARIANE IBRAHIM GALLERY
article.article_image_caption: Ayana V. Jackson’s “Does the Brown Paper Bag Test Really Exist? Would my Father be Proud?” 2013.
article.article_text:
The term “archival impulse,” first coined by the art historian Hal Foster in an essay in the Fall 2004 edition of the art journal October, can be applied to any artist who mines documents and objects from the past in order to transform “excavation sites” into “construction sites”—or, in other words, to create a more balanced and fair-minded history from a biased past. In her series “Archival Impulse,” photographer Ayana V. Jackson, who splits her time between Paris, New York and Johannesburg, is concerned with reconstructing the history of black bodies as captured by white photographers and photojournalists throughout the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. “I’m reclaiming the legacy of those images,” she says. “I’m attaching new meaning to them.” 

In the series, which was on view at Mariane Ibrahim Gallery in Seattle this fall, along with a related series, “Poverty Pornography,” Jackson recreates images of nude African women, starving children and colonial servants she culled from sources such as “Human Zoo: Invention of the Savage,” an exhibition she saw at Paris’s Quai Branly museum in 2011; and the Duggan-Cronin archive in Johannesburg, an extensive collection of photographs of migrant workers and “natives” in South Africa taken by an Irishman who worked for the DeBeers diamond company at the beginning of the twentieth century. She uses herself as the subject, taking self-portraits in her studio using natural light and the timer on her camera. To adjust her poses to match the original subjects, she reviews the images sent from her camera to her computer in between takes. To make group shots, she clones images of her body in Photoshop and collages them over backgrounds—often these are travel landscape shots she took in Rwanda, Kenya, Mexico, Morocco and Paris. She describes her work as performance rather than portrait-making. About her decision to use only her own body, she explains. “I want to draw attention to the content rather than the individual.” Also, she fears that if she worked with models, she would be re-creating exactly what she is critiquing: the exploitation of another person’s body for social commentary.   

Jackson, who received her B.A. in sociology from Spelman College in Atlanta in 1999, and took courses in photography at the University of Art in Berlin in 2005, creates strange, uncanny images that jar the viewer. In “Devotees and Demons (2012),” for example, she stands in the center of the frame—wearing the white dress and straw hat of a Victorian-era missionary—at the surreal apex of a pyramid of dozens of nude self-portraits. The original image is of Alice Seeley Harris, the English missionary and documentary photographer, standing amongst a group of semi-nude schoolchildren in the Congo in the 1890s. Seely’s image was intended to shed light on the horrors of slavery in the Congo under King Leopold II of Belgium. Though it was intended to raise awareness, it operates within the colonial lexicon of “otherness.” Harris is not one of the children—in her pure white dress, at the top of the mound, she is, on many levels, symbolically dominating them.

“What is the Alice Seeley Harris photograph telling you?” Jackson asks over the phone from her studio in Johannesburg. “This was one of the first images a European may have ever seen of an African body. Look at how the missionary is clothed, and the ‘savages’ are unclothed.” She pauses. “Now, look at my image, and tell me, who is civilized, and who is savage?”

Jackson’s point that black bodies in photographs have historically been relegated to the realm of “savage”—and in turn, “sexual,” “pitiable,” and “primitive”—comes across strongly, and evokes outrage. The effect is similar in “Dis Ease (2011),” in which Jackson recreates Kevin Carter’s famous 1993 image of a vulture watching over a starving child in southern Sudan, using her nude body in the positions of both the bird of prey and the preyed upon; and “Diorama I (2012),” which shows the artist assuming the position of a white-bearded anthropologist, as well as the nude Andaman children he is studying, from a photograph taken in 1869. 

In Jackson’s images, there are no “others”—there is just the artist, and the discomfort in seeing a black woman pose in a manner that, even today, could be considered exploitative. 

The power of Jackson’s images lies in that point of discomfort. She refuses to let the visual legacy of racism, slavery and oppression remain in the past. This commitment is especially important in her adopted homeland of South Africa, where she has kept a studio since 2007. “In South Africa, there is a rising generation that for the first time is experiencing freedom,” she said. “When I look at them, I see that they are like my father’s generation in the United States—he was born in 1951. He had to participate in the Civil Rights movement. A lot of people are fighting for that here now.

“I’m watching a place become itself," she adds. "There’s a need for someone to deconstruct the stereotypes and misunderstandings. A need not only in South Africa, but also around the world. We are still trying to understand the original sin of racism.”

article.article_title: Advice for Estimating and Pitching Advertising Assignments
article.meta_description: Tips on presenting creative ideas and accurate budgets to clients so you get the job.
article.article_text_abstract: Tips on presenting creative ideas and accurate budgets to clients so you get the job.
article.article_image_caption: A still by Stephanie Rausser from an assignment for Mini Boden; her DP shot video. Because her lifestyle work demands time putting her models at ease, Rausser says her video work is better when she has the resources to devote time and a DP to the video side of her assignments.
article.article_text:
In a competitive marketplace, many factors influence why a client or ad agency chooses a photographer for an assignment. We rounded up advice from photographers, reps and an art buyer about how to handle the bidding and estimating process, and how to effectively present your ideas to a client. You’ll find more advice about writing treatments, showing storyboards, and putting your best face forward during creative calls this month on PDNOnline.

Bidding and Landing Ad Assignments: An Art Producer’s Perspective 

Amy Salzman, who works as a freelance senior integrated art producer, says the triple bid is a useful process that can help clients understand what the production they want demands. She also notes that it’s not always the lowest bid that lands the job. “It depends on what the difference is between the high, middle and low bids. It also depends on which photographer you think is best for the job. Do low bids tend to look better?  Absolutely. But do they always get the job? Not necessarily.” If she or the creatives like one photographer’s ideas, she says, “I’m not going to tell a photographer how to produce the job but if there’s someone we really want to work with, but they’re way out of the range, I’ll say, ‘We really want to work with you, but you’re way out of the range,’ and let them re-try.”

10 Questions to Ask Before You Bid on an Ad Assignment

Listening carefully during the creative call with a campaign art director and during pre-estimate calls with the agency’s art buyer is essential to creating a successful bid. After hearing what the creative director wants, the photographer or producer can follow up with questions—about scheduling, logistics, budget limitations—with the art buyer. That’s when it’s important to get detailed information about the size and scale of the project in order to complete a realistic estimate. It can be helpful to have a list of questions written before the call. While every shoot is different, reps and producers who talked to PDN said there are certain questions they always have to ask. 

Making Videos Clients Will Love With Budgets You Don’t 

One of the challenges of shooting motion is squaring clients’ high expectations for production value with their tight budgets. Many clients still see motion as an add-on to a still shoot, with little understanding of what motion production requires. “We hear over and over that motion is secondary,” says photographer Jim Hughes. “I tell them, ‘If you want A-level production, here’s what you’re going to need.’ I hold the integrity of pricing,” he says. Photographer-directors PDN interviewed discussed their make-or-break budget requirements. For Stephanie Rausser, it’s money to hire a DP. For producer Jesse Scolaro of Bend Creative, it’s a digital tech to manage media, secure files and check camera cards.

James Worrell: Sketching Concepts for Editorial Clients to Gain the Attention of Ad Agencies

Photographers have to find a way to show the ad agency (or the client) that they understand what the brand is looking for. Different photographers PDN interviewed have different approaches to this. “Once I get someone interested in a particular project, I offer to make them sketches of my ideas to add to their ideas—because everyone usually has a rough idea of what they want to do. And if they are a first-time client, they might not know that I like to brainstorm and expound upon an idea,” says James Worrell, who also creates specialized booklets of specific types of images he’s done. 

Joey and Jessica: Using Personal Work and Mood Boards to Get Clients Excited About Their Vision

The lifestyle photography duo of Joey and Jessica (aka Joey and Jessica Seawell) create a mood board for almost every advertising bid they are asked to submit. “We really look at having a strong, creative, visual foundation,” the North Carolina-based photographers say. Once they get into the triple bid phase they’ll put a PDF together, which usually contains a more fleshed-out, color version of the sketch; the bid and cover letter; what their approach to the campaign would be, including possible locations, photos of models and wardrobe they would like to use; an explanation of how they’ll approach the shoot; and why they’re excited about the campaign. That PDF “becomes the whole backbone [of the shoot], the booklet that we would have on set that the stylist, the producer and everyone would have,” they explain.  

Diana King: Showing Style, Illustrating Her Estimates

When a client called fashion photographer Diana King about a holiday campaign, she listened to the initial idea, and realized the budget wouldn’t be enough to cover location shoots and permits. To suggest a more cost-effective alternative, she used a mood board to show how she would present the “hip, artistic” feel that the client had told King he wanted, while using one lighting setup and one indoor location. She adds that in talking to the art director, “I listen for the buzzwords of how they want to show off their brand and who they want to sell to.”  

Video Production 101: How to Estimate the Cost and Fees

We asked two photographers to break down, line by line, the estimates they submitted for video projects for advertising clients. One estimated for a combined still-video shoot for a local health industry client—who changed the scope and size of the production after selecting the winning bid. The second shot a Web video for a national brand in the food industry.

article.article_title: Andrea Bruce Explains Her Approach to Romania Sex Trafficking Story
article.meta_description: Andrea Bruce photographed, reported and wrote a story for Al Jazeera America on sex trafficking in a country that has turned a blind eye to the problem—and its victims.
article.article_text_abstract: Andrea Bruce photographed, reported and wrote a story for Al Jazeera America on sex trafficking in a country that has turned a blind eye to the problem—and its victims.
article.article_image_caption: Supporting her family by selling her body on the streets since the age of 14, Christina has reportedly fallen into the hands of traffickers since this photo was taken in February.
article.article_text:
In Eastern Romania, young women are now conspicuously absent from many towns and villages. “Nobody talks about it. It’s like a huge elephant in the room,” says photographer Andrea Bruce. But she’s determined to talk about it: Her recent story called “Romania’s Disappearing Girls” explores how a mixture of poverty, shame, and corruption has enabled sex traffickers to lure so many women into slavery.

Published online by Al Jazeera America in August, Bruce’s photographs capture a sense of foreboding and shame in the quiet, picturesque Romanian villages, and emptiness and despair in the streets of Bucharest, where many victims end up trapped behind locked doors. She also reported and wrote the accompanying story. 

Sex trafficking is a global problem, but journalists often sensationalize the story by focusing on sex clubs and female victims going through the motions, says Vaughn Wallace, deputy photo editor at Al Jazeera America. “Andrea’s work is humanizing. She was really interested in photographing these young women to explain to a larger audience [what] they’re facing.”

Bruce spent more than a decade covering the effects of war in Iraq and Afghanistan, and has lately turned her attention to other stories. She began work on sex trafficking after her agency, NOOR, got grants from Lexis/Nexis and Nikon to produce a group project about modern-day slavery.

Researching the subject, Bruce came across the work of Benjamin Skinner, who wrote about sex trafficking in Romania in his book A Crime So Monstrous. It caught her interest because of Romania’s status as an EU country and a gateway for immigrants heading to Europe. Bucharest has also become an epicenter of sex tourism that Romanian and European Union officials seem uninterested in acknowledging, much less shutting down.

Bruce went to Romania with “a long list of things I could cover in different ways.” It included visiting the villages, seeking out victims by hanging out on the streets of Bucharest with staffers from NGOs who pass out clean needles and condoms to prostitutes, talking to police, visiting strip clubs and massage parlors, and approaching known traffickers.

Skinner introduced Bruce to some local journalists who have been investigating the story. Among them was a young female journalist Bruce hired as a fixer, to help navigate the bureaucracy, write letters of inquiry and serve as a translator.

“Every aspect of the story was so hard. Even taking pictures in villages is difficult,” Bruce says. Because public officials were mostly uncooperative, she had to report around them. “The people who would talk about it all gave me a clear idea of how [the sex trafficking] works. But it never happened in front of me,” Bruce says. “There’s nothing I can prove on paper. It’s really frustrating.” 

They found a few anti-trafficking police officers who were willing to explain how traffickers worked. (Those street-level officers also said they were under-funded and ignored by higher-ups.) In search of traffickers to interview, Bruce and her fixer sent letters to prisons all over Romania. They finally found one trafficker who was willing to talk and be photographed. “In his mind, he didn’t do anything wrong,” Bruce says. “Traffickers think that if it weren’t for them, these girls would just starve in the countryside.” 

They also asked owners of more than two dozen strip clubs for permission to photograph. One finally said yes. “He was proud that his business was doing really well, and he insisted that there was no trafficking happening there,” Bruce says. But none of the girls they met would talk about their past, or say whether they were under the control of a trafficker.

“My fixer and I came to the conclusion that if they had access to their own Facebook [account], they weren’t being trafficked,” Bruce says. By that standard, Bruce suspects many of the girls she met in clubs were trafficking victims, not prostitutes. 

Traveling to the villages where many victims came from, Bruce and her fixer approached people working in fields. They talked to bartenders, school teachers—anyone they could find. Most who were willing to talk at all were in denial about the sex trafficking. “The villages are very religious, and very conservative,” Bruce says, but adds: “You find out the truth after you dig and dig and dig.”

In one village, Bruce was able to photograph a teenager whose mother turned her to prostitution. That teenager was determined not to fall into the hands of sex traffickers. The photographs show her at home, preparing to go to work, but also show, through details in and around her family’s house, what her life is like. “The details encourage the viewer to recognize the dignity of the subject she’s photographing,” Wallace observes.

In the accompanying story, Bruce explains that traffickers lure the girls by professing love, wooing them with gifts and promising a better life elsewhere. The girls often fall for the ruse. They quickly end up turning tricks out of a sense of loyalty and obligation, then find themselves trapped financially and physically in Bucharest, too ashamed to return home. 

Meanwhile, their families also feel shame and guilt. “They don’t want the neighbors to know, so they don’t talk about it. The girls just disappear,” Bruce says.

She worked tirelessly to find the anonymous apartments around Bucharest where enslaved girls live and are forced to work. But she ran out of money—and time—before she was able to gain access to those places.

By then she had made two trips to Romania, spending a total of four and a half months on the project. Hoping to find a media organization willing to fund another trip, Bruce started pitching the story. The European publishers she approached weren’t interested. Sex trafficking is underreported, Bruce says, but people often confuse it with prostitution, which has been getting a lot of coverage in Europe. 

But Al Jazeera America is always looking for issue-driven stories “centered on people whose voices are not as amplified as they should be,” Wallace says. Bruce’s ability to write a story to go with the photographs helped get support for publication from Al Jazeera America’s features editor and editor-in-chief.

Bruce says she’s still hoping to go back to Bucharest to interview more traffickers, accompany police on raids, and spend more time in the streets trying to meet people involved in organized crime and prostitution. For now, she has put the project on the back burner, while she works on other assignments, and looks for funding and new leads to resume her work in Romania.

Viola Tudor, a convicted human trafficker, sits in the visiting room of the prison where he served his sentence. Not shy about his role in trafficking, he claimed that he helped the girls he sold, and bragged about the profits he made.

In Bacâu County, an Orthodox church holds services in a community almost absent of young women. An air of shame and a culture of privacy prevents most communities from confronting the traffickers who lure away so many girls.

article.article_title: Sharing Expertise: John Keatley On the Advice from Chris Buck that Changed His Career
article.meta_description: Sharing Expertise: John Keatley On the Advice from Chris Buck that Changed His Career
article.article_text_abstract: Sharing Expertise: John Keatley On the Advice from Chris Buck that Changed His Career
article.article_image_caption: A recent ad Chris Buck shot for database company SAP Hana with creative director Kleber Menezes of BBDO. Buck says the advice he gave John Keatley about writing a detailed and accurate estimate was just “information gained through experience” estimating and producing advertising jobs.
article.article_text:
Photographer John Keatley, interviewed in “How to Make the Most of a Creative Call and Write a Successful Treatment," is one of many photographers who generously provided business advice in our “How-to” issue. 

He has been inspired to share his knowledge of estimating, brand building, licensing and marketing in seminars at PhotoPlus Expo and the Survival Guide weekend workshops he holds around the country because, when he needed it, New York City photographer Chris Buck gave him help writing an estimate. “He saved my career in a way, and he gave me lessons I’ll never forget,” Keatley says.

In 2009, Keatley, who is based in Seattle, got a call to shoot the cover portrait for former vice presidential candidate Sarah Palin’s memoir, which was to be published by HarperCollins. “At the time, my experience was in shooting corporate or editorial work,” Keatley says, and he had no framework for estimating a big production. His business had been slow following the financial collapse of 2008, he says. “I was just excited to take pictures. I hadn’t really thought long term, or about building a foundation.” For the Palin shoot, he submitted an estimate for some forseeable expenses and a creative fee that was fine for editorial work, but low for creating an image to be used in national advertising. Then plans for the Palin shoot and the use of his images “just kept growing,” he says, and he knew “I was leaving money on the table” with the estimate he had submitted. The art director gave Keatley a break: He told the photographer to raise his creative fee, and revise his estimate to reflect added expenses. 

Feeling overwhelmed, Keatley called Buck, whom he had met only once. Like Keatley, Buck had started out as an editorial portrait photographer, but had produced his own shoots and, by 2009, had bid on and won many advertising assignments. Buck recalls, “He asked, ‘Can you help?’ and I said, ‘Sure.’” Keatley says of Buck, “He spent several hours on the phone with me. He was helping me on that specific job but he was really teaching me how to bid, and giving me real-world numbers.” 

Buck walked Keatley through every line item, including travel days, taxis and the cost of getting equipment to Palin’s home in Alaska. Keatley recalls Buck noting, “If you’re taking a celebrity outside you should really have a motor home and security.”  By the end of the call, Keatley says, his original estimate of $25,000 had grown to $95,000, “and I said, ‘Chris, I’m not going to get this job.’” Buck recalls, “My answer to that would be, ‘You don’t want to do this job for less than that, because you’ll lose money.’” 

Helping Keatley “seemed like a reasonable thing to do,” Buck tells PDN. When he was a new photographer in Toronto, veterans like Brian Smale and Deborah Samuel answered his questions. These days, Buck says, he’ll give feedback to any photographer who asks him specific questions, as long as the photographer “seems serious.” He adds that Keatley sent Buck and his wife a gift certificate to one of New York City’s most acclaimed restaurants. Buck says, “He was thoughtful enough to remember and give back.”

Keatley says that at his Survival Guide workshops, he meets many photographers who are in similar situations to the one he was in when he called on Buck: “The difference between thriving and going out of business is sometimes really simple pieces of advice.” Buck says he now asks advice of Keatley and other photographers he’s helped through the years. Buck says, “You succeed by being humble and recognizing that you can learn from other people, who may be younger than you and also smart.” 

Related: What Susan Middleton Learned from Richard Avedon About Reaching Audiences

Can Photographers Be Engaged Fathers and Have Successful Careers, Too?

article.article_title: Caleb Cain Marcus's Goddess Investigates the Seen and Unseen Along the Ganges
article.meta_description: To create his new book, Marcus used India's legendary river as raw material to make images that encourage a different understanding of how we experience physical space.
article.article_text_abstract: To create his new book, Marcus used India's legendary river as raw material to make images that encourage a different understanding of how we experience physical space.
article.article_image_caption: An image from Caleb Cain Marcus’s new book Goddess, which explores, through photographs of the land and people surrounding India’s Ganges River, how we experience physical space.
article.article_text:
Why is it that some places feel different than others? Are we simply reacting to what we see and hear around us? Or does the space—the air—carry something we can’t detect, something we don’t even think to search for? In his new book, Goddess, published this fall by Damiani, Caleb Cain Marcus uses photography to question how we experience space and color, and how both the seen and unseen may influence our lives.

To create his images, Marcus spent 44 days in India, from December 2013 to January 2014, collecting material, traveling the length of the Ganges River from its origin in the Himalayas to its mouth in the Bay of Bengal in Bangladesh. He then spent more than a year working to create the final prints for his series, sometimes producing as many as 20 proofs as he adjusted the color and contrast of his images in small increments. The resulting images are hazy, full of muted hues and small, sometimes subtle hints of color—the green of patches of grass in an otherwise muddy field, or the vibrant clothing of hundreds of people gathered on the tan and gray bank of the muddy river.

Marcus’s fascination with India began at an early age, hearing his parents’ stories about the country as “a magical place,” he recalls. He’d visited India before, but when he began following the Ganges, it was the first time he chose to work there. His impression of India as a spiritual, mystical country where many believe “there’s something beyond what we can prove scientifically,” made it seem like the ideal place to continue the investigations of space and color that he’s carried through his projects, which include A Portrait of Ice, a series of photographs of glaciers. 

Marcus chose to follow the Ganges River because he “needed a path” through the large, diverse country, and because of its central role in the Hindu religion as a physical manifestation of the goddess Ganga. 

But Marcus wasn’t interested in a literal representation of the river or the landscapes and people that surround it. “I’m interested in the potential way that space can be experienced,” he explains. “So the photography is a way both for me personally to explore that, but also hopefully that other people become maybe more aware or sensitive. It’s a way of sharing another possibility of the way to experience space.”

We don’t often think of air as something we can see, unless it’s carrying pollutants. But Marcus wants the haze in his photographs to encourage us to consider air’s “substance and weight. It has a quality and texture to it that can transmit some kind of data,” he says. For instance, when we enter a space after something has taken place, there is “some kind of residue” left after the event. “I don’t know how long it lasts. But we walk into a church—and I don’t have any particular religion that I follow—but some churches, the space is very different. And I think we can all usually feel it in many of these spectacular churches in the world. You walk into Notre Dame and there’s something about the space which is different. The air is not the same outside of the church walls. I think that’s an area where its very evident, but I think everywhere, space is almost a living entity that we disregard often.”

In this work, Marcus’s printing process was central to his effort to visualize space in a way that alters our awareness of it. “The print: that’s the work,” he says. “Whatever that is, that’s the final product. That’s where the time is spent, working to craft and create the vision and the emotional resonance that you want, or that you hope that someone is going to get through the print.”

By repeatedly outputting proofs and tweaking the color and contrast in the images digitally, Marcus realized a visual consistency throughout the body of work. This consistency across photographs—that were presumably made in locations that looked very different from one another—suggests something shared along the length of the river.  Marcus writes in his “Project Notes,” which are included in the book, “The entire length of Ganga is believed sacred. Perhaps this belief has caused space to accumulate and become more present and more definite, or perhaps Ganga is sacred because the physicality of space has always been present along her banks. Perhaps this is what has drawn people to her for millennia. Either way, her essence and that of the people lured to her banks have mixed to form a type of space that is visceral, almost visible to the naked eye.”

It’s interesting to consider how the residue of history and belief, perhaps borne by the air that flows around places like the Ganges River, may help define peoples’ experience. Through his images, Marcus encourages us to consider the space around us more closely. “I don’t know if we can see the space normally, but I think that we can definitely feel or interact with the space, and recognize different types of space that exist,” Marcus posits. “I would like to hopefully display a different sense of space than what we normally see and interact with.”

Related: Nadia Sablin Chronicles Her Elderly Aunts' Lives in a Rural Russian Village

article.article_title: 12 of Our Favorite Mobile Apps for Photographers
article.meta_description: From photo editing and sharing to unshackling your phone camera's manual controls, these are the apps we can't live with out.
article.article_text_abstract: From photo editing and sharing to unshackling your phone camera's manual controls, these are the apps we can't live with out.
article.article_image_caption: A screenshot of Morpholio's new Journal iOS app.
article.article_text:
From photo editing and sharing to unshackling your phone camera’s manual controls, these are the apps we can’t live without. 

VSCO Cam 

In late July, VSCO updated its popular Cam app (iOS and Android) with a new feature dubbed Collections, a curation tool that lets you save and share other VSCO images you discover on the service. Whenever an image is shared in a collection, the original creator is notified. The Android version of Cam now supports split focus and exposure when taking a photo, plus a modify, undo or view all option in its new editing history feature. If you have a favorite set of edits, you can copy and paste them across multiple photos. VSCO Cam’s photographic features are complemented with a social networking component dubbed Grid, where curated images are displayed for all to admire. Unlike rival services, you won’t see likes, follower counts, comments or any other hierarchical baggage in Grid on the premise that, as VSCO puts it, beautiful imagery trumps social clout.” 

PRICE: Free

INFO: www.vsco.co 

Morpholio Journal

It’s not exactly fair to pigeonhole Morpholio’s new Journal iOS app as a mere photo app (not that there’s anything wrong with those). Instead, it’s a multi-purpose menagerie housing your hand-drawn sketches, photos, drawings, notes and more. In the app, you can draw directly on images imported from your camera roll with eight pens, brushes and pencil styles to choose from using 16 color palettes. You can also append short notes to images. The app arranges your content in a book-style interface with page turning that can transition from leisurely flip to rapid-fire scroll under the guidance of your finger. These virtual journals can be hundreds of pages in length, so you’ll appreciate the blazing fast page turning as the page count grows. You can also build collages that combine photos, drawings, sketches and notes.

PRICE: Free

INFO: www.morpholioapps.com

Filmic Pro

Filmic Pro has the unique distinction of powering one of the most ambitious iPhone feature films to date: Sean Baker’s Tangerine (profiled in “Frames per Second,” in the July 2015 issue). As Baker told us, it would have been impossible to shoot Tangerine on an iPhone without the app. Think of Filmic Pro as Manual for video. The app enables iPhones to record up to 2K video on an iPhone 5 or higher with full manual control over focus, exposure, ISO, shutter speed, tint and color temperature. You’ll enjoy a range of audio monitoring tools, audio gain control and framing guides that support common cinema aspect ratios such as Super35mm, Super16mm and cinemascope. Settings can be saved as presets for easier retrieval. If you’re filming with an iPhone 6, the app supports frame rates up to 240fps. You’ll have several encoding options to choose from, including an extreme setting that captures 1080p video at 50Mbps. Filmic Pro was recently refreshed for iOS 9 to make it faster and more reliable.

PRICE: $7.99

INFO: www.filmicpro.com

Manual for iPhone 

Locked inside your iPhone is a decent camera just waiting to get out. Manual liberates it by unlocking the exposure settings advanced users prefer to adjust on their own, including full independent control over shutter, ISO, white balance, focus and exposure compensation. When you’re shooting in Manual, you’ll be able to view your exposure values, a live histogram, grid overlays and EXIF data. You can activate the iPhone’s LED to serve as a fill flash or delay the shutter for a longer exposure. The only parameter you can’t tweak is aperture, since the iPhone’s aperture is fixed.

PRICE: $1.99

INFO: www.shootmanual.co 

Replay

Video editing isn’t typically something people relish doing on mobile devices, but Replay’s simplified approach makes the task far less onerous for iPhone and iPad owners. It’s not sophisticated by the standards of desktop editors, but it does a nice job delivering meaningful features in a mobile-friendly format. Using Replay, you can merge up to 200 photos or videos from your camera roll, iCloud, Facebook or Instagram account, choose from one of 24 styles, add text and select your music (your own or a selection of tracks provided by the app). Armed with your selection, Replay renders out a video that is in sync with the music. You can take a bit more of hands-on approach to customize a few settings. You can choose between a square or 16:9 aspect ratio, trim videos, set focus points, pacing, mute the audio and more. 

PRICE: Free

INFO: www.replayapp.com

Snapseed

The Google-owned Snapseed packs a wealth of editing tools to quickly enhance your images. You can sharpen, crop, transform and perform spot repairs to remove dust and dirt. It uses Nik Software’s U Point technology to make adjustments to select areas of an image without marring the surrounding pixels. Like any mobile editor worth its salt, it has filters galore but that’s not Snapseed’s core strength. Instead, it’s the layers-style approach, dubbed Stacks, that adds value. Stacks provides a list of the filters you’ve applied to one image. Using Stacks, you can remove any filter you’ve applied, no matter when you applied it. Stacks also allows you to re-edit or copy any filter and apply it to another image in your collection. Despite fears that it would wither on Google’s vine, Snapseed enjoyed an update as late as July of this year that delivered finer-tipped brushes and deeper zooms. It’s available for both iOS and Android devices.

PRICE: Free

INFO: www.play.google.com

CTRL+Console

We have a love/hate relationship with our mouse: We love to hate it. But after seeing CTRL+Console, we may have found a more intuitive replacement, at least for video editing and photo management. The CTRL+Console app runs on iPads and offers a series of customized controls for Adobe Premiere. It syncs with your computer over Wi-Fi and offers touch-based controls that replace mouse-hunting around menus and many of your favorite keyboard shortcuts. The app itself is free but you’ll pay up to $30 for in-app purchases to unlock editing functionality, depending on the version of Premiere you’re using and the types of controls you need. The company is also working on a Lightroom Sorter that turns your iPad into a remote control for Lightroom organizing. You can quickly scroll through your catalogue with a swipe of your finger, rate images, delete them and save them. Goodbye mouse.

PRICE: Free

INFO: www.ctrlconsole.com

Photo Mate R2

Long before Android supported DNG files, Photo Mate R2 was one of the go-to apps for Android photographers looking for RAW file viewing and decoding. It’s a powerful mobile editor, capable of decoding not just RAW files from a range of cameras, but PSD and TIFF files, too. The app provides a full suite of editing tools, including sharpening, clarity, curves, layers, lens corrections and much more. Edits are applied non-destructively and while you can dial in to make very precise edits, there are dozens of presets on hand to speed things along. Beyond editing, the program can also organize, rate, label and tag images with Lightroom-friendly XMP sidecar files. Images can be filtered based on ratings or metadata and you can view histograms and EXIF data as you scroll through your collection. Photo Mate offers folder-based views of your images and you can create Smart Folders that combine images from several disparate folders into a Smart Folder without changing their locations on your drive. 

PRICE: $9.49

INFO: www.photo-mate.com

Adobe Lightroom Mobile

For many photographers, Adobe’s Lightroom takes center stage in their workflow. With Lightroom Mobile, many of the beneficial organizing, ranking and culling tasks that Lightroom performs on the desktop can be done on mobile phones. The most recent iOS update (v. 1.5.1) brings videos into the mix, giving you the ability to add, view and share videos in your collections. For still photos, there are new color tools, a new tone curve tool and adjustable vignettes. Lightroom on Android tends to lag the iOS version in feature deployment, but it is ahead of the Apple version in one important respect: RAW support. Now that Android Lollipop supports RAW files in the DNG format, Lightroom for Android can do full-blown RAW editing on a smartphone (provided said phone runs Lollipop and supports RAW capture). The Android version’s most recent update (v. 1.2) also supports copying and pasting image adjustments from one photo to another. There’s an updated cropping interface, a new auto-straighten tool and a new “Segmented view” in the Android build to organize images by time and location metadata. 

PRICE: $10/month

INFO: www.adobe.com

Pixelmator 

Packed with an impressive array of editing tools, Pixelmator is an iOS app that lets you adjust image colors using customizable presets. You can create non-destructive edits using layers, blend different images together, add text, remove backgrounds and cut-and-paste objects into photos. But it’s more than a mere editing tool. You can paint on images using textured brushes and, thanks to the app’s algorithmic smarts, effects like wetness (for water colors) and brush strokes are faithfully recreated. When you’re done tweaking your files on your phone, Pixelmator can save the finished product as a Photoshop-friendly PSD file if you need to make further enhancements on the desktop. The app can also import and edit PSDs, if you want the workflow to work in reverse. Pixelmator’s tools aren’t confined to the app itself; some of them are available in the iPhone’s Photo app if you add them as an extension.

PRICE: $4.99

INFO: www.pixelmator.com

pCam +  Digital Pro 

Unique among many of its peers, pCam has a pedigree that dates back to the (wait for it) Palm Pilot. Developed by a seasoned assistant camera operator, pCam is a go-to tool for DPs and still photographers as well, with tools that let them make critical exposure calculations on the fly. Using pCam you can measure depth of field, hyperfocal and image circle for cinema cameras. Simply select your camera model from the app’s extensive list, choose an aperture and focal length and enter in the distance to your subject and it can calculate your depth of field. A “preview” button will actually show you what the scene will look like in your camera. With 24 different tools to choose from, pCam can do a lot. 

PRICE: $29.99

INFO: www.daviddeubank.com

EyeEm

EyeEm has multiple personalities, all of them good. It’s one part image editor, one part image marketplace and one part creative community/social network. Using the editor, you can apply one of 24 filters to tweak the contrast, exposure, saturation, white balance and a few other parameters of your smartphone camera images. You can view and follow photographers on the app as well as participate in photo contests (dubbed “missions”) to win prizes and the esteem of your virtual peers. The newest feature is Market, a stock platform helping photographers monetize their work, whether the photos in question were captured with a smartphone or (gasp) a traditional DSLR. Any EyeEm user can select images in their profile to post to the Market. EyeEm splits the revenue 50/50 and images licensed through the Market are offered on a non-exclusive basis. EyeEm charges image buyers $20 per photo for a standard license and $250 for an extended commercial license. Market photos aren’t falling into a giant abyss though; they’re being judged by EyeEm’s algorithms for their “aesthetic qualities” to serve up what the company views as the best images to potential buyers. EyeEm is available for both iOS and Android devices.

PRICE: Free

INFO: www.eyeem.com

Related: 9 Video Editing Tools to Bring Motion to Life

How To Ditch Your Laptop and Make a Mobile Photography Workflow

article.article_title: How to Get the Best from Portraiture Subjects: Michael Grecco
article.meta_description: Bonding with his subjects helps Grecco create memorable portraits of celebrities and executives.
article.article_text_abstract: Bonding with his subjects helps Grecco create memorable portraits of celebrities and executives.
article.article_image_caption: A portrait of YouTube sensation Lindsey Stirling. Michael Grecco says he explains to subjects exactly what he plans to do on set, like a teacher on the first day of school calming a nervous kid.
article.article_text:
Michael Grecco, who has shot portraits of celebrities and executives for more than two decades, says one of the most important lessons he learned in a workshop with legendary portrait photographer Albert Watson was to bond with the talent before the shoot. “He would walk into the dressing room, sit down, and connect. That’s the primary thing,” Grecco says.

He explains that his initial approach to subjects is like that of a school teacher, trying to calm a nervous kid.

“Remember the first day of school, when you didn’t know what was going on? You were scared. That’s what [portrait subjects] feel. Most people don’t understand what’s going to happen, or what’s needed on set. And if it’s a concept you’re trying to shoot, they want to be sure you aren’t going to mistreat them.”

Grecco starts by explaining the shoot in straightforward terms. “I go through the day and what we’re going to do. I tell them this is what’s required, this is what I’m thinking of, this is how many pictures I’ll need, these are my concepts.”

That starts a conversation and a negotiation: Subjects usually respond by telling Grecco what they’re comfortable doing, and what they want from the shoot. “It’s important for them to know what you need, to listen [to what’s] going to work for them, and try to meet them in the middle,” he says.

Grecco says that if his subjects allow it, he’ll stay with them while they’re getting ready for the shoot. He tries to engage them in conversation about their work and their interests. “I try to find out what turns people on,” he says, noting, “You get into that makeup room, and you’re listening. You’re trying to dissect commonalities.”

To that end, it is important to research his subjects beforehand, he says. “That’s especially true for celebrities, who care about you knowing their accomplishments and who they are.” 

For instance, with a recent assignment from Forbes Magazine to photograph violinist, performance artist and YouTube sensation Lindsey Stirling, Grecco says he watched all of her videos. “That enabled me to know what the shoot was going to be and what I could get out of it,” he says.

Grecco always works with at least one assistant—even on small shoots—so he can arrive on set and focus immediately on the subjects, not gear.  Good portraits, he says, are “about being down to earth. It’s the bonding, and getting as close as you can before the shoot.”

Related: How to Get the Best from Portrait Subjects: Photojournalist Pieter Ten Hoopen

article.article_title: How to Get the Best from Portrait Subjects: Josh Wool
article.meta_description: Wool's preparation and the way he directs his subjects are essential to his soulful portraits.
article.article_text_abstract: Wool's preparation and the way he directs his subjects are essential to his soulful portraits.
article.article_image_caption: Josh Wool believes the most important part of making a portrait is keeping his subject engaged. His pre-shoot preparation allows him to focus on his sitter rather than on adjusting his lighting or camera gear.
article.article_text:
In his portraiture, Josh Wool is drawn to the tension created by a perceived “juxtaposition between what’s on the surface and what’s underneath.” Wool’s preparation and the way he directs his subjects are essential to achieving a consistent, soulful look in his photographs, he says.

Wool creates black-and-white and color portraits, and also uses alternative processes. He says that making sure his lighting setups are dialed in before a shoot helps him focus on engaging his subject. Wool, who teaches workshops, notes, “A lot of people get lost in their lighting or in their camera gear and stop paying attention to their subject. I make sure that I’m prepared ahead of time; I know what the lighting situation is going to be, I have three or four different lighting scenarios that I can pop [subjects] in and out of,” he explains, adding that he uses “a lot of natural light.”

Preparation allows him to focus on his sitter. “The most important thing is to keep really strong engagement with your subjects through conversation,” Wool says. “Some people are difficult, but you still have to keep them engaged in the moment, because the second that person gets distracted or disinterested, it’s going to be really difficult to make a good portrait of them.”

Rather than spending time trying to adjust every aspect of his subjects’ body positions, which can result in images that look “too posed,” he asks them to “move through [traditional portrait] positions,” then photographs them while they’re moving. Wool does a lot of seated portraits, so he’ll ask a subject to, for instance, “drop their left shoulder back, and bring their right shoulder forward and then look in.” Or he’ll ask a subject to adjust a hat or shirtsleeve. “I’m directing them with specific movements. I’m very direct, but I’m not overbearing,” he says. “You’re getting people to do things where you’re not necessarily telling them what you want, it’s a means to get what you want…. I’m getting people to move, but it’s that moment in between the start and finish of that move that I want, rather than just trying to set [the pose] initially. It’s not an easy thing to do, it takes a lot of practice, but it’s not that difficult either.”

Wool says he “just fell into” his way of directing subjects, because it allowed him to get what he was after without having to spend so much time positioning his sitter. He feels that when he’s making a portrait he’s “taking something from [the subject],” but adds that it’s not necessarily linked to the reality of who they are. “At least in my portrait world, I’m creating what my vision of that person is, and those moments between the moments that I catch are the ones that are interesting to me.”

Related: How to Get the Best from Portrait Subjects: Photojournalist Pieter Ten Hoopen
