article.article_title: Ewan Burns: Continuous Lights Key to Capturing Athletes in Action for Reebok
article.meta_description: Burns explains how he illuminated a large space, which allowed him to efficiently capture action action as it happened around him.
article.article_text_abstract: Burns explains how he illuminated a large space, which allowed him to efficiently capture action action as it happened around him.
article.article_image_caption: Ewan Burns needed to shoot handheld at a high shutter speed in order to follow the athletes as they moved through their training session.
article.article_text:
CLIENT: Reebok

Viktoria Wallner, Head of Global Communications; Tori Scott, Art Buyer

AGENCY: McGarryBowen

Jeremy Lamin and Frauke Tiemann, Creative Directors

Commercial photographer Ewan Burns says he loves “filling the frame with information.” He explains, “To do that you have to be surrounded by activity,” and then seek out whatever activity or arrangement piques you attention. It’s a process that typically requires some preparation, but once he begins shooting, Burns works intuitively and spontaneously. An assignment that exemplifies his style is a shoot he did in 2011 for Tough Mudder, which organizes competitive races over 10- to 12-mile obstacle courses. While other photographers were on the sidelines, using long lenses to photograph the competitors swinging on ropes or racing through muddy ditches, “I pretty much participated in the race,” the New York City-based photographer recalls. “I was getting into the mud, shooting really low so the lens was hovering over the mud.” Anywhere he turned, he could capture the action going on around him. 

Burns compares his way of capturing moments in the midst of activity to “war photography without the war.” He has some familiarity with the genre. After serving in the British Army, Burns was looking for a new career. At the time, conflict and ethnic cleansing were raging in the former Yugoslavia, “and I thought it would be a good idea if I hitchhiked my way into the war.” After hitching rides across Europe, he talked his way onto a humanitarian flight heading into the midst of the conflict by claiming to be a photographer. On the ground, however, he quickly realized he didn’t have the mettle for conflict photography. “I have absolute respect for war photographers, and what it takes for a person to do that. I’m not that person.” He went back to school to study photography, then assisted commercial photographers in London and then Los Angeles, honing his skills at lighting, directing and meeting the needs of advertising clients. 

Creatives at McGarry Bowen liked Burns’ Tough Mudder work, which he had licensed for stock usage and posted on his website. 

The work convinced the agency he was the right photographer to shoot a Reebok campaign featuring Reebok-sponsored athletes during training sessions. Burns explains, “They liked the look of the caught moments I got, and the action all around.” Burns was given instructions not to use a tripod. “The athletes were always moving and I needed to be able to follow them like a social documentarian.” Burns warned the creatives that by relying on a run-and-gun shooting technique, “There would be a lot of failure” as well as a few shots that delivered the authentic intensity the client wanted.   

Logistics

During location scouting, Burns wanted to find a space that “looks interesting and artistic” and was big enough to accommodate the athletes’ training. The warehouse that was selected for the Los Angeles leg of the shoot had windows, but Burns was primarily shooting in the middle of the wide-open floor, so the natural light was insufficient to help him capture fast-moving action. “If you’re shooting live action you are shooting at a high shutter speed to cover action,” he explains. “The lights had to be enormous.”  

During the shoot, the athletes, who had been chosen by Reebok, were taking their cues from their trainer, not from the photographer. “I guess the trickiest part of the shoot was when I realized I couldn’t direct anybody,” Burns recalls. He enjoys directing, and typically starts a shoot by building camaraderie and getting members of his crew and his subjects to work as a team. On the Reebok shoot, however, the athletes were absorbed in carrying out their training, and ignored Burns. “They were separate from me because they had their own trainer, so I felt like I was on the outside,” he says. 

He also had little chance to set up shots. At one point, when the athletes were taking a break from training, he had a group of them fan out in a hallway lit by sun from a skylight. He lay down on a dolly and, as the athletes ran towards him, his assistants pulled him backwards, allowing him to photograph from the middle of the running pack. During the rest of the shoot, however, he was moving around the gym, trying to anticipate what action the trainer would have the athletes move to next: “I’d get on the floor to get a photo and the person would jump up to move away.” 

Energies he might have put into directing went instead into keeping up with his subjects. Says Burns, “I trained for this job because I knew it would be exhausting physically.”

At one point, Burns managed to get close to an athlete as he was lifting weights, and capture his concentration. Burns notes, “He’s working his butt off, but I captured him at a moment when he’s almost dropping the bar.”

Lighting

Burns made the shot of the weightlifter at high noon, so the Los Angeles sun is visible through the windows in the background. “What you can’t see is that there are HMIs behind me,” he says. Burns chose to use continuous lights to illuminate the entire floor at once: “I wanted to just be able to move and have light that always worked.” 

He hired OTMFC, a lighting crew that brought a grip truck with a 500 amp generator and a variety of stands and lights. He set up a total of four Arri M18, 1800-watt HMIs on high rollers, so they could be easily moved as the action shifted. The lights were placed about eight feet off the floor, directed at a slight downward angle. He bounced the HMIs into 12-foot-wide square silks “to pour light into the area,” Burns says. He used a silver lame silk, “which gives a crisp, white light.”  

He notes that another, more time-consuming option would have been to light the space from above, by affixing HMIs to the ceiling of the training area. “But that would have given us less flexibility.” By clamping the lights and silks to high rollers, his crew was able to turn or move the lights if needed when the athletes moved to new training stations. 

Camera 

Burns shot with a Canon EOS-1D X and a 24-70 mm EF series f/2.8 lens, shooting 1/500th of a second at f/5.6, ISO 3200 for most of the shots in the gym. 

Unable to shoot tethered, he shot to card, and he let clients preview shots on the back of his camera and on his digital tech’s monitor. He notes, “I think I’m oblivious that there are 16 people on the set behind me, and music blaring.” 

Post Production

Burns estimates that from the eight-day shoot, he processed, color corrected and delivered roughly 4,000 images to the client, who then handled post-production.

article.article_title: What Susan Middleton Learned from Richard Avedon About Reaching Audiences
article.meta_description: Susan Middleton tells PDN how she learned the importance of balancing artistry and accessibility while working for Richard Avedon.
article.article_text_abstract: Susan Middleton tells PDN how she learned the importance of balancing artistry and accessibility while working for Richard Avedon.
article.article_image_caption: The cover of Avedon: Murals & Portraits (Gagosian Gallery/Abrams, 2012) features an image of poet Allen Ginsberg (left) and his family, which Avedon made in Paterson, New Jersey on May 3, 1970. The book showcases four photographic murals of cultural and political figures Avedon produced in the 1960s and ’70s, as well as related portraits and archival material.
article.article_text:
For photographers whose goal is to reach as many people as possible with their artwork, communication is key. In our feature “How and Why Photo Books Sell to a Wide Audience," artist Susan Middleton talks about her desire to reach a wide audience with her book Spineless: Portraits of Marine Invertebrates, the Backbone of Life. An artist whose work focuses on animals and nature and frequently carries a conservation message, Middleton learned the importance of balancing artistry and accessibility while working for Richard Avedon. “He was a great portraitist but also a great advertising photographer,” she explains.

During his career, Avedon worked in fashion, balancing esthetics and the need to highlight fashion designers’ latest offerings—and sell magazines—for Harper’s Bazaar and Vogue, where he was a staff photographer and shot every cover for more than two decades. As an advertising photographer, he created ads for Calvin Klein, Revlon and Levi’s, among many other commercial clients. But he also turned to serious subjects both on editorial assignments and in his personal work. He’s perhaps best-known for his straightforward portraits of people from all walks of life—the moneyed elite, counter-culture leaders, politicians, waitresses, slaughterhouse workers and drifters—using the same stark lighting and white seamless backdrop. The images invited viewers to meet face-to-face with Avedon’s subjects and examine them.

Middleton also wants to invite readers to engage with her subjects. “Not every artist creates work that is as accessible as mine,” she notes. Ambiguity is an important component of “a lot of really great art,” she points out, but it makes art more challenging and can limit an audience. Her more direct approach of isolating her subjects on seamless backgrounds helps her achieve her goals as an artist who also wants to educate and inform the public. “I like a very direct, literal approach to my subjects, though I do visually isolate them—so that’s somewhat non-traditional [in animal photography], although more people are doing that now,” she observes.

Middleton began developing her strategy when she and photographer David Liittschwager, another alum of Avedon’s studio, began working on Here Today: Portraits of Our Vanishing Species, their 1991 book of photographs of endangered animals. Avedon’s ability as both an artist and communicator influenced their work. “We were trying to make art, but we were also trying to make something that could communicate, with a strong impact, a conservations message about endangered species,” she recalls. “We learned from one of the advertising greats.”

Related: Mary Ellen Mark: On Portraiture and the Moment

article.article_title: How I Got That Shot: Will Deleon's Splashy Product Shot
article.meta_description: Deleon used a well-placed piece of Plexiglas to simulate an invisible barrier for shoe-protection treatment.
article.article_text_abstract: Deleon used a well-placed piece of Plexiglas to simulate an invisible barrier for shoe-protection treatment.
article.article_image_caption: Still life photographer Will Deleon achieved subtle gradations of shadow on the product by working with diffused light sources. He typically incorporates cards and v-flats to achieve greater control with fewer lights.
article.article_text:
Client: Jason Markk

Creatives: Anthony Cao, senior art director/head of marketing; Millie Rosas, special projects manager; Joe Le, art director

When creatives at Jason Markk, maker of high-end shoe-care products, wanted to advertise the company’s new stain repellent, they turned to photographer Will Deleon for ideas. Deleon, who is based in Los Angeles, has been shooting for the company since 2010, three years before he graduated from Art Center College of Design in Pasadena. Deleon started out shooting product shots for the company’s e-commerce site. “I established a good relationship with them, then the company started growing as my skills were growing,” says Deleon. After department stores began stocking Jason Markk products and the company opened its own flagship store, its marketing efforts expanded, and Deleon began shooting print, online and social media advertising. 

Deleon describes the target demographic for Jason Markk products as “the sneaker head who spends hundreds or even thousands of dollars on their shoe collections.” Loyal customers provided the concept for the new campaign for Repel, a water and stain repellent. On the brand’s Instagram feed, fans described Repel as a “force field” protecting their sneakers. Deleon and the creatives began brainstorming ways to illustrate an invisible barrier around the spray canister, protecting it from splashing liquid. After he took several test shots of splashes made with paint, soda, and even caramel syrup, Deleon says, “The team decided to use water, to keep the classic, clean esthetic of the brand.” 

Deleon’s still lifes are typically graphic, colorful and precisely lit, but the client wanted to showcase the clean, minimal design of the white Jason Markk canister. “They didn’t want to over-stylize it,” Deleon says. The creatives referenced images from his portfolio of white objects made of paper, including a paper airplane. “I defined the shape of the plane using gradients and light control, and the team wanted that same esthetic.” 

To achieve the effect, he used a small number of diffused light sources. But as in all his still lifes, he used cards and reflectors to flag and direct light with precision. Clients may come to a shoot expecting more lights on the set, he says, “but it’s all about light control. I feel that if you bring in more lights, it just crowds things, especially when you’re shooting something small.” The technique is, Deleon says, efficient as well as effective. “Deadlines have gotten much shorter. Clients say, ‘Thanks for not spending eight hours on one shot.’”

Logistics

Deleon had made several test shots of splashes and pours. “Messing around with Plexiglas and water one day, I realized that when water meets Plexi, the Plexi disappears and the water takes the shape of the Plexi.” He went to a local plastics manufacturer and had them fashion a Plexiglas cylinder big enough to hold the Repel canister. “So, when we splashed the cylinder with the water, the Plexiglass would disappear and it would look like there was a force field around the canister.”

He suspended the cylinder vertically by clamping it to stands. To create his backdrop, he placed 4 x 8-foot piece of white acrylic about seven feet away from the cylinder. He put an inflatable kiddie pool under the product to catch the splashing water, and also covered the pool and his studio floor with a black tarp, so there were no colored reflections in the shiny white can or the acrylic. 

Though he had planned to shoot as much as he could in camera, he discovered that when he hit the Plexiglas cylinder with a strobe, there was a yellowish tinge along one seam. He chose to photograph first the product alone, and then the cylinder as it was being splashed. In post, he removed the yellow seam, adjusted the color, and composited the product shot and the splash. 

Before the shoot, Deleon and his assistant tried different ways of making splashes—adjusting the speed and the volume of the splash—before he decided that having his assistant hurl plastic cups of water worked best. He notes, “I made sure the same assistant who made the test was there for the shoot, because he had developed a feel for it: His arm was calibrated.” 

Lighting

Deleon lit his set from back to front. Behind the acrylic backdrop, he placed two strobe heads. Positioned about five feet from the backdrop, the heads had 7-inch reflectors covered with diffusion material from Lee Filters, “because we wanted an even light spread on the background, with no hot spots.” These lights provided most of the illumination visible through the water splash. 

To make sure spill from the background lights didn’t hit the product, he placed V-flats in front of the backdrop. “The only light we wanted on the product was the light we intended to have on it,” he says. To adjust his exposure, he put a stand-in product in front of the backdrop, he recalls, and checked: “How are my edges? Are they sharp?”

Once the cylinder was clamped to the stands, he set up his key lights. To camera right, he set up a Broncolor strobe, which he chose for its fast flash duration, with a medium-sized Broncolor strip box attached. He placed it behind a Lee Filter 250 Half White Diffusion material that he hung vertically, “to create a big, diffused light source and create the softness we were looking for.” At camera left, pointing down, he added a spot with a six-degree grid reflector, also shooting through a diffusion panel. Deleon explains, “That gave it that highlight near the top of the can” and added highlights to droplets of water. He had his strobes running on two Broncolor Scoro S 3200 packs, and dialed the power down to the lowest settings, “because the lower the intensity of power, the faster the flash duration.”  Setting the strobes to 1/6000 sec, he was able to freeze the splash.  

To throw some light back onto the bottom rim of the can, he says, he held a shiny bounce card just below the can. 

Camera

Deleon used a Phase One 645DF camera with an IQ180 digital back and a 120mm f/4 macro lens. He exposed at 1/200 sec at f/11, ISO 100. Positioning himself four to five feet from the cylinder and product, he shot tethered while his digital tech, Yves Huy Trong, previewed the shots in Capture One for the clients. After Deleon and the creatives chose the best combination of product and splash, the photographer recalls, “We had a rough comp already by the time they left.”

Postproduction

“I do my own retouching whenever I can,” he says. “I guess I cling to my work, and feel like I should be the one retouching it.”

In addition to compositing the splash and the product, he color-corrected everything, making sure the purple logo on the can matched the brand’s specifications. His client liked one particular splash shape and decided to have him clone and mirror it on the other side of the canister. “With the water the only other tweaking I did was to warp the splash a bit and give it a little more contrast in post.”

The client planned to use the shot online, on Instagram, in out-of-home and in other print advertising, so Deleon delivered a 16-bit, 300-layered TIFF. The files he provided, Deleon says, “gave the client the latitude to move the splash and add type.”

Related: Managing Photo Tech On Location, Off The Grid

article.article_title: New Book and Exhibition Explore the Art of Air Traffic Control Towers
article.meta_description: Carolyn Russo’s photographs of air traffic control towers around the world consider the structures as architectural artworks, as witnesses to history, and as emblems of the future.
article.article_text_abstract: Carolyn Russo’s photographs of air traffic control towers around the world consider the structures as architectural artworks, as witnesses to history, and as emblems of the future.
article.article_image_caption: LaGuardia Airport, New York, built in 1964. Carolyn Russo was flying into LaGuardia in 2006 when she first noticed the tower looked “like Swiss cheese.” The realization led her to pursue a project about airport towers that took her to 23 countries worldwide.
article.article_text:
Carolyn Russo has worked with the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum since she graduated from the Massachusetts College of Art and Design in 1988. In her current job as a photographer and museum specialist, she acquires new art for the museum and curates exhibits. The unique position has also given her a platform for publishing and exhibiting her own work, while the demands of her job mean that her personal projects take years to realize. Russo wouldn’t have it any other way. “I think my projects need that time. It’s kind of like cooking, where something needs to simmer to absorb all the flavors,” she muses.

Russo’s newest project is Art of the Airport Tower, a 176-page hardcover monograph being published by Smithsonian Books this month. The book coincides with an exhibition at the National Air and Space Museum that runs from November 2015 to November 2016. 

The project was born in a moment aboard a 2006 flight into New York City, when Russo noticed something for the first time. “I was coming through LaGuardia and when the airport tower came into view, I thought, ‘Holy crap, that tower looks like Swiss cheese,’” Russo recalls. “At that time I was seeing and photographing aircraft as abstractions, so it was a natural transition into the airport tower project.” Another inspiration, Russo says, was a Hiroshi Sugimoto exhibit of blurry and ethereal photographs of skyscrapers she saw at the Hirshhorn Museum.

Russo put the idea on the back burner as she finished up other projects, until a serendipitous encounter at a Smithsonian function set the project in motion. She was seated next to someone who had “FAA” written on his nametag. “I asked him if he knew who I could speak with for permission to photograph towers and he said with a smile, ‘Aaaahhh, that would be me,’” she remembers. “It turned out I was talking to the Acting Administrator at the FAA.”

Through the FAA, Russo gained access to all of the commercial towers in the United States. She started locally, photographing towers on the eastern seaboard that she could easily reach from her home in Washington D.C. When traveling for personal vacations or professional speaking engagements, Russo would plan ahead and find a way to shoot some towers. She also traveled to 23 countries and, by her own estimate, photographed at least 100 air traffic control towers for the project. Each country had its own permissions process, some more byzantine than others. Dubai, for instance, would not consider any permission requests until she actually arrived in the country. Certain airports required a life insurance certificate worth $20 million for her to shoot on the tarmac. In one nation, Russo was required to show all her images to wary local authorities before leaving the airport. But even that encounter ended with the kind of jovial camaraderie that, in her experience, is typical of flight culture. 

Logistics were just one part of the puzzle; financing the project was its own winding odyssey. She received some funds from the Smithsonian raised from her department’s book royalties, honorariums, and a traveling exhibition of a previous body of work. (Federal tax dollars were not used to fund the project, she notes.) 

Russo’s search for her subjects was exhaustive; she spent countless hours researching prospective towers online and in the Smithsonian library. She attended Air Traffic Control Association conferences, and followed up on any leads that came her way. She soon settled on two different criteria: For the contemporary towers Russo focused on esthetics and architecture, but with the older towers, like the Ford Island Control Tower at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, she looked for historical significance. 

Russo approached photographing the towers the same way she might approach a series of portraits, trying to highlight the building’s individual traits and capture its physical presence. “I was interested in their beauty and tried to capture their power. I saw them as the choreographer/conductor for the dance of the aircraft at the airport. Of course I was focusing on the architecture, but I wanted more than that out of them,” she says. 

When shooting the contemporary towers, she pushed towards abstraction, isolating and decontextualizing design elements. Thus the LaGuardia tower is transfigured into an alien craft, and she rendered the facility at Stockholm Arlanda as twinned cylinders, without beginning or end. But with the historical towers, Russo wanted to present them in a more straightforward, documentary style, as “eyewitnesses to history,” as she puts it.

Initially, Russo worked with a variety of cameras: An analogue Hasselblad, a digital Hasselblad and a DSLR. She found the back-and-forth inefficient and decided to stick with her digital cameras. “Sometimes you had 15 minutes [to shoot], sometimes you had an hour, and I didn’t want to spend that time juggling cameras instead of focusing on the tower,” she explains. She shot most of the project with a Nikon D3 and Nikon D4, often using her smartphone’s camera to “sketch things out” before she started.

In addition to the book, “Art of the Airport Tower” will also open as a traveling Smithsonian exhibit in November 2015. The exhibit consists of 50 images, selected from the 100 that make up the book. Russo curated it with a focus on the contemporary towers, grouping the historical towers together, as she does in the book.  

The last towers Russo shot were part of the world’s first remotely operated air-traffic control system in Sweden. The unmanned tower located at Örnsköldsvik Airport is linked to the LFV Remote Tower Centre 76 miles away in Sundsvall, where human controllers are able to monitor all traffic on a 360-degree LCD screen. Part of Russo’s motivation in shooting historical towers was to call for their preservation, so there is a certain symmetry to this glimpse of the future of air traffic control. 

Related: Toni Greaves' New Book Follows the Life of a Young Nun

article.article_title: 9 Video Editing Tools to Bring Motion to Life
article.meta_description: Video tech is evolving fast enough that even as many products add 4K compatibility, at least one video-editing program is already supporting 8K video.
article.article_text_abstract: Video tech is evolving fast enough that even as many products add 4K compatibility, at least one video-editing program is already supporting 8K video.
article.article_text:
For many DSLR filmmakers, the phrase “8K” may seem more than a wee bit premature. But it’s a testament to how fast video technology is changing that at least one of the video editing programs in our roundup is supporting the resolution, even as other products are adding compatibility with 4K formats. 

Apple Final Cut Pro X

Among people who care about such things, the introduction of Final Cut Pro X several years ago was deeply polarizing, with key features being dropped in favor of delivering a simpler, more consumer-friendly program. Now on version 10.2 (or is that X.2?) Apple hasn’t done a complete about-face, but continues to build upon the reconceived video editor with new features that will appeal to pros and enthusiasts alike. Among the new features is 3D titling with drag-and-drop functionality, along with 3D title templates with built-in backgrounds and animations. For color-grading and effects work, Apple improved Final Cut’s masking features, allowing users to save shape masks as presets for later use. You can now view up to four video scopes simultaneously in Final Cut to guide color grading and corrections. Several new video formats are supported in the program as well, including Panasonic’s AVC-Ultra and Sony’s XAVC-S. RED camera users will also enjoy GPU-accelerated transcoding, playback and rendering for RAW files  from RED cameras.

PRICE: $300

INFO: www.apple.com

Blackmagic Design DaVinci Resolve STUDIO 12

Resolve 12 packs in more than 80 new features, tackling everything from media management to color grading. Moving deeper into editing, the updated Resolve Studio can now cut programs from multiple video sources in real time, syncing camera angles based on time code, audio waveforms or in/out points. The audio engine has also been revamped to offer higher sampling rates and better real time playback (including reverse playback and slow motion scrubbing). Media management tools now include a “smart bin” function that displays footage based on metadata tags for easier retrieval. DaVinci’s core strength, color grading, wasn’t neglected. There’s a new curves interface plus automatic color matching between two or more clips in addition to new tools for creating smart filters. To speed things along, Resolve Studio supports Intel Iris and Pro GPUs and can create customizable media proxies for RAW and high-resolution video files.

PRICE: $945

INFO: www.blackmagicdesign.com

Red Giant Magic Bullet Suite 12

Red Giant’s Magic Bullet Suite 12 updates most of the company’s color-correction and color-grading tools. Among the major enhancements is GPU acceleration for several of the suite’s plug-ins to deliver real-time color correction without leaving a smoldering ruin where your CPU used to be. Magic Bullet Looks, the suite’s film looks and color-correction tools, gains 198 presets derived from popular films and TV shows. Suite 12 marks the introduction of Magic Bullet Film, a film emulator that the company says mimics “the entire photochemical process” from film negative to grading, grain and print stock. Magic Bullet Film includes 22 negative stocks and four print stocks to choose from. The color-grading tool Colorista III also gets a new user interface plus the ability to leverage Adobe’s masking and tracking features. The Mojo 2.0 colorizer enjoys a 20-percent speed boost with GPU acceleration in Adobe Premiere and an 80 percent bump in Apple Final Cut Pro. It also gains the ability to render effects in near-real-time. Magic Bullet’s skin touch-up tool, Cosmo 2.0, joins the GPU acceleration parade, gaining a 20 percent speed bump in Adobe products and for the first time gets compatibility with Final Cut Pro X and Sony Vegas. Magic Bullet Suite 12’s tools are all fully compatible with Adobe After Effects and Premiere Pro, while host support for Final Cut Pro X, Avid and other editors will vary depending on the plug-in in question.

PRICE: $759

INFO: www.redgiant.com


Adobe Premiere CC

As part of its 2015 Creative Cloud release, Adobe supercharged the color-grading capabilities of its marquee video editor. The so-called Lumetri Color panel blends the color-grading and correction capabilities that Adobe had earlier introduced in its SpeedGrade plug-in with Lightroom-style tools such as sliders for white balance, exposure, tone and tint. From the Lumetri panel, you can select presets (or “Looks”) to quickly apply an effect across your frame. If you need still more fine-tuning, you can send the project directly into SpeedGrade. Also new to Premiere is Morph Cut, which helps intelligently eliminate jump cuts between sound bites through a combination of facial tracking and frame interpolation. Premiere is now integrated into the Adobe Stock marketplace so you can add assets from the Stock portfolio into your work with just a few clicks. Adobe’s Mercury Engine, which boosts the performance of the editor on PCs and Macs, has been updated to improve Premiere’s playback on high-resolution external displays.

PRICE: $20/month

INFO: www.adobe.com

NewBlue Stylizers 3 

Packed with 250 presets and up to 23 plug-ins, NewBlue’s Stylizer lets you add effects to your video that run the gamut from subtle to cartoonish. You can create flicker, airbrush a scene, simulate motion or get more surreal with effects such as halovision and impressionist. You can separate your video into individual red, green and blue color channels for making more precise adjustments. Stylizers 3 is completely GPU-accelerated thanks to support for Native CUDA, OpenCL and OpenGL graphics engines. It’s also resolution-independent, so it can tackle files from standard definition to 4K and beyond. Stylizers 3 is compatible with all the major editors as well as DaVinci Resolve.

Price: $94 (4 plug-ins); $199 (Elite, 9 plug-ins); $284 (Ultimate, 23 plug-ins) 

Info: www.newbluefx.com

FilmConvert

FilmConvert capitalizes on our insatiable desire to imbue digital files with the grainy, textured look of film. The program contains well over a dozen film stock presets, including motion picture films such as Kodak Vision 3 250D and Fuji Vivid 8543, as well as still films such as Ilford Delta 400 and Kodak Tri-X 400. It supports cameras from GoPros to Alexas and delivers several slider-based tools for tweaking color, grain, and luminosity. Three color wheels are also on hand to tackle shadows, midtones and highlights. You can select negative sizes to increase or decrease grain—smaller negative sizes yield a larger grain, while larger negative sizes produce smaller grain. FilmConvert is available as a stand-alone program or as a plug-in for the major video editors, including Adobe Premiere, Final Cut Pro and Sony Vegas, as well as Photoshop. The Mac edition of the stand-alone software now compensates for color/gamma shifts when viewing files on different platforms. The Premiere plug-in was also recently updated to support Adobe’s Mercury Playback Engine as well as CUDA GPU processing when using supported NVIDIA graphics cards—a pair of improvements that should speed editing when working with FilmConvert in Premiere. 

PRICE: Price: $99 (Photoshop); $199 (standalone or individual video plug-in); $299 (plug-ins for all video editors)

INFO: www.filmconvert.com

Pinnacle Studio 18.5 Ultimate Edition

Pinnacle’s flagship video suite supports 4K video, the XAVC-S codec and 64-bit operating systems in version 18.5. The new version uses the iZotop Music and Speech cleaner to purge audio files of unwanted noise. Also included with your purchase is an effects pack from NewBlue that contains 750 templates and 55 presets to expand your creative options. You’ll also find 17 royalty-free audio tracks from Triple Scoop music. If producing instructional videos is your thing, Studio 18.5 supports screen recording with audio. Finished projects can be burned to discs, including Blu-ray, as well as uploaded to the web and encoded for a variety of platforms such as Apple TV, Xbox and YouTube.

Price: $60

Info: www.pinnaclesys.com

Sony Vegas Pro 13

With version 13, Vegas Pro users can leverage the new Connect iPad app for remote collaboration. Using the app, remote users can jointly write comments on footage in tandem with a desktop user in real-time. They can also place frame-accurate markers and notes directly in the timeline as well as start/stop/pause video playback, all using a gesture-based interface. An offline mode lets creatives download proxy files to their tablet to mark up, with changes syncing to the project once the iPad is back online. Also new for version 13 is a multi-tool feature that collects frequently used editing tools into a pop-up box below the timeline for streamlined access. As with any new release, there’s been under-the-hood tweaks to improve performance, including the addition of an XAVC Intra Smart Render function that reduces rendering times when using templates. There are seven new video effects from FXHOME integrated into the program that leverage the OpenGL standard to accelerate rendering. 

PRICE: $600; $400 (Edit); $800 (Suite)

INFO: www.sonycreativesoftware.com

Avid Media Composer 

While many videographers and filmmakers are easing into the 4K era, Avid is looking eagerly ahead to 8K with version 8.4 of Media Composer. The newest version supports video resolutions up to a maximum of 8192x8192-pixels in frame rates up to 60 fps—specs that will have TV marketers licking their chops. These video project dimensions are customizable from 256x128 pixels on up to 8K, with an option to save your dimensions as presets for quicker retrieval. According to Avid, these super high-resolution files won’t grind your existing PC to dust provided you’ve met the minimum specs, such as 32GB of RAM for 4K editing. The newest version also adds native support for Sony’s XAVC-I codec as well as ProRes 2K, 4K and UltraHD formats. You can also mix-and-match these codecs with others from Canon, Panasonic and Avid’s own DNxHR codec in the editing timeline without impairing real-time playback. Version 8.4 delivers quicker timeline searching through a new Timeline Quick Find feature. You can use the Quick Find field to type in queries as well as access a drop-down menu to sort your search according to visible timeline text, resolution, clip name, comments and more.

PRICE: $50/month (annual basis)

INFO: www.avid.com

article.article_title: Natalie Keyssar on Photographing Venezuela's Angry Divide
article.meta_description: Keyssar went to Venezuela to cover protests and discovered a story far more complicated and journalistically challenging than she imagined.
article.article_text_abstract: Keyssar went to Venezuela to cover protests and discovered a story far more complicated and journalistically challenging than she imagined.
article.article_image_caption: A juxtaposition of images that evokes “the tension and darkness and sadness I feel in Caracas,” Keyssar says.
article.article_text:
International coverage of Venezuela’s social and political breakdown has focused on street protests, and lays blame for the country’s problems on the policies of its left-wing government, says photographer Natalie Keyssar. But after visiting the country in 2014, she says she found the narrative of the international media “way over-simplified,” and decided to spend time exploring the story herself.

Keyssar eventually pitched a story to MSNBC.com, and landed a week-long assignment last February to return to Caracas. The resulting story, called “Post-Chavez Venezuela: one country, divided in two,” featured a number of diptychs juxtaposing scenes from rich and poor neighborhoods of the capital city. It was published in early March, to coincide with the second anniversary of the death of Hugo Chavez, Venezuela’s much loved (and hated) former president.

“It highlighted the inequality, which is a big issue for us,” says MSNBC.com senior photo editor Elissa Curtis, who gave Keyssar the assignment. “And it was a chance to look at how democracy is working in Venezuela” under the leadership of Chavez’s hand-picked successor, Nicolás Maduro.

Keyssar said she got interested in the story after reading Spanish-language news accounts of the unrest. She was struck by how impassioned the government opposition seemed. “Ultimately, the protagonists are the upper class youth. What does it mean when the comfortable classes of a country are rising up against what’s supposed to be a leader who represents the poor?” she says. 

Keyssar made the first trip on her own dime. She planned to stay a week, but ended up staying for several weeks. The more she saw, she says, “the more I realized how little I knew. No sentence could sum up the political situation. There are tons of overlapping realities, depending on who you speak to.”

The poor loved Chavez because of his policies of economic redistribution. They blamed the wealthy for their privations, accusing them of hoarding all the country’s wealth and resources. The wealthy hated Chavez, blaming him for ruining the Venezuelan economy. They also blamed the poor for runaway crime—including robbery, kidnapping and murder—that has forced the wealthy to live under guard behind fortified walls.

“This was a story with no heroes. I came quickly to fall in love with the Venezuelan character,” Keyssar says. “I couldn’t take a side. I was forced to be neutral by how complex all of the issues are. At the same time, I came to really care about so many of the individuals I interacted with, from hardcore government supporters to the hardcore opposition.”

She made a second trip to Venezuela last fall, and started spending time with people on both sides of the political divide to try to understand the roots of the strife. She found it easy to meet members of the opposition movement at street protests. A lot of them became close friends, she says.

Meeting government supporters was a bit more difficult, but not much, Keyssar says. “What I found again and again is that if you approach people with open hands and honesty about your intentions” they will welcome you and open up, she says. “I was super curious about Tupamaro”—an allegedly violent far-left pro-government group—“because there’s a lot of fear of them.”

Against the advice of her friends in Caracas, Keyssar went to a Tupamaro rally, found their spokesperson, and introduced herself. “I said, ‘Hi, I’m Natalie. I’m interested in your organization. I’m an American. I’m a freelancer. Can we talk?’ She gave me her phone number and we set up a meeting.”

Keyssar says the point was to meet and spend time with people across the political spectrum, including the most radical. The challenge was the street crime. Caracas, she says, “is another level of danger” compared to other places she’s worked. And the fear isn’t just theft of your cameras, but “the fear you might get killed over your gear,” she says.

“You can’t walk around with a camera out unless you’re very calculated and have someone watching your back. You have to shoot behind closed doors, or make sure people in power in a certain area are vouching for you. The biggest frustration is that you always need to be considering security in a way that can be sort of limiting.” 

Keyssar relied on her network of local contacts to move around. Despite the social chaos, she says, Venezuelans are eager to help even strangers. Whenever she told someone she was interested in going to a new place, she’d eventually be introduced to someone who would offer to escort her by motorbike. “It’s part of the culture, and it’s what I love about [Venezuela].”

Keyssar shot with a Canon EOS 5D, two prime lenses (35- and 50mm) and a Canon Speedlite flash. “I wanted the work to have that hot white Caribbean sun feeling I associate with Caracas, and I used flash sometimes to make sure that [look] would be uniform throughout,” she says.

She avoided the most sensational images, which tend to be polarizing, she says. She also took advantage of her freedom to go beyond straight reportage. MSNBC, she explains, is “willing to combine literal, traditional photojournalism with something that’s more about a feeling.... This project was about a level of tension that you can’t necessarily take a literal picture of.”

Curtis’s suggestion to think in terms of diptychs was also freeing, Keyssar says. “I started to see the images as fragments of a phrase, as opposed to needing the photograph to always be a complete phrase. It gives you a few more notes to play. By mixing diptychs with single images, it gives me an opportunity to be more specific with what I want to say.”

The story opens with a tight shot of a crying eye on a billboard, juxtaposed with a photograph of a man standing halfway in shadow, halfway in light. “The pairing was Elissa’s, but it’s so evocative of the tension and darkness and sadness I feel in Caracas right now,” Keyssar says.

Another image, shot in a poor barrio where violence and murder are common, shows a young girl half-hiding behind a chair. It is juxtaposed with an image of a house in a wealthy neighborhood, behind a wall and barbed wire. “You look at these two photos together and it’s a real conversation about what protection and safety means and what money can buy,” Keyssar says.

Her concern while she was shooting the story was that one side or the other would feel unfairly portrayed in the end. “The purpose was to create questions and dialogue, not point fingers, and I felt my contacts from both sides of the equation got that and were comfortable with how they were portrayed,” she says.

“You’re highlighting these differences, but you’re trying to do it in a way that’s subtle and non-judgmental and honestly neutral because the idea is to make people on both sides see the other side as a little bit more human.”

Because the future of Venezuela remains so uncertain, Keyssar says she expects to return to continue telling the story. “There’s going to be a lot of change, hopefully for the good, and I want to see it.”

Related: A Photographer Explores Climate Change on North Carolina's Outer Banks

article.article_title: Create Spotlight: A New Look for Science Magazine
article.meta_description: Design director Beth Rakouskas and senior photo editor Bill Douthitt tell PDN about assigning and finding photography for the prestigious and newly redesigned journal.
article.article_text_abstract: Design director Beth Rakouskas and senior photo editor Bill Douthitt tell PDN about assigning and finding photography for the prestigious and newly redesigned journal.
article.article_image_caption: This ancient human leg bone was not in a recent story on ancient DNA’s text, but the photo was added to the package at Douthitt’s request.
article.article_text:
A little more than a year ago, National Geographic veterans Bill Douthitt and Beth Rakouskas joined Science magazine, a 135-year old publication that is half news magazine, half peer-reviewed science journal. Rakouskas, the design director, and Douthitt, the senior photo editor, were brought on as part of an initiative to improve the magazine’s visuals and more thoroughly integrate the art department into the process of telling compelling stories to readers. PDN spoke with Douthitt and Rakouskas about the magazine’s new look and their goals for the magazine’s photography. 

PDN: You two are both relatively new to Science. What brought you here, and where is it going?

Bill Douthitt: Coming in, the organization, about a year prior, had made a pretty serious commitment of resources to becoming more of a multi-platform, multimedia type of publication, not just a print magazine and a website. They hired a couple of folks whom Beth and I had worked with previously at National Geographic: Tim Appenzeller, the head of the news writing department, and Rob Covey, who is the chief digital media officer.

We talked with both of them about the desire to transform things. Speaking just for myself, I was brought in to bring in higher quality photography, whether it was from existing sources such as agencies like Corbis or Alamy or whomever, or from individual photographers, or doing something that hadn’t been done too much here: to assign people. My brief was to improve the look of the covers, the features and the special sections.

Beth Rakouskas: There was a big push, and it was all the way from the top, where they were willing to put the money and the resources, the energy, everything, towards really transforming not only the look of the magazine and the website, but just the way that we operate so that it was going digital first. They created this position—prior to me having this job there was an art director, rather than a design director, and it was only print. My role is both print and digital media. They completely reorganized many groups within Science, taking people from all different areas and creating this digital media team to best re-focus our efforts. And when I heard that Bill had been hired, I knew that they were serious about making a change. They wouldn’t bring on a top-tier photo editor to a place that didn’t care about the photography.

PDN: What’s different now about the photography in the magazine?

BD: We did a special issue on the 100th anniversary of [the theory of] general relativity two months ago, and one of the things that involved was a gigantic gravity-wave detector in Louisiana. We really couldn’t do the kind of picture I wanted to do from the ground or from a helicopter, because I wanted something that was about 50–75 feet off the ground. So I hired a drone company to do the picture. Once we got that I sat down with the head of our multimedia group, we talked about what could we do with the drone, and how could we have some fun with that on a video scale as well. It’s just a matter of coordination, but we were able to produce a point of view of that gravity wave detector that had not been done before, a low, wide-angle shot of this thing that has these two gigantic arms that go off at 90 degrees at the end of the forest. 

There was a story about one of the recently contacted tribes found in the Amazon, so in that case the writer got some support from the Pulitzer Center for Crisis Reporting to go down and look at some of the issues with recently contacted indigenous people. So we were able to send a photographer Jason Houston, to go along. This is stuff that hadn’t happened before. 

PDN: You’re a weekly. How many assignments in each week are you doling out? Is it a mix between pickup and assignments?

BD: It really varies. There are weeks when I won’t assign anything because the nature of the features is either more graphically driven or it just makes more sense to rely on existing imagery for whatever reason. On the other hand, for the July 24, 2015 issue on ancient DNA, I think we did either four assignments or five, but there was quite a bit of assigned work in that because I was after a certain kind of look to make what was really a story about bones as interesting as possible.  If we’re doing a profile of someone, more often than not we will assign those, because we want a fresh picture that has some personality to it. We want something that is storytelling in its own right.

PDN: What ethos or esthetic are you trying to achieve? What informs the visual esthetic of the book?

BR: Accuracy. 

BD: Beth is saying that light-heartedly, but I think that’s really true. This is a very well-educated, scientifically well-versed audience, and accuracy becomes a really big deal. What you’re showing is really relevant to whatever the thrust of the text is. 

I think it’s just about achieving a great deal of clarity and impact in the visual side of communication. We were looking at some of the earlier presentations from a year or so back and what strikes me is how much cleaner and clearer and more immediate everything has become. You can navigate your way through information more readily with the kinds of visuals and display that we’re putting into effect here.

BR: Now we’re adding to the story, rather than just doing point pictures that are completely the same as the text. We try to sell that way of thinking to the editorial side, that we’re bringing more to the table than just saying “This is the first thing you’re talking about, and this is what they look like.” When we do a profile, like “The King of Pills,” Ray Schinazi, shot by Michael Schwarz, it’s not just a straight portrait, or something that we took from an annual report. It’s giving the feeling of who this guy is. It has personality to it.

BD: We did a piece on ancient DNA, and the opening spread shows a human leg bone. That was actually found in a river in Siberia in 2008, and it has the oldest human DNA that has yet been found. That didn’t actually get into the text, but it was a terrific visual, so I talked to the text editor and said it could be a wonderful way to start it. It was back in Siberia, and I was able to get Alexander Maklakov, a photographer in that area who could photograph it with the right sort of light to give it a nice sheen and make it an attractive opening piece.

PDN: How do you find photographers to assign work to?

BD: We rarely have the budget as you would with National Geographic, where you just send somebody somewhere. I tend to work very location-based, and sometimes I’ll get a reference from a friend of mine who’s a picture editor, but more often than not I’m looking at the various aggregated sites for photographers or simply looking at websites of local photographers. I’ve been using Blink and things like Wonderful Machine. 

Quite often I’m hiring someone I’ve never worked with before, but they have the right set of skills for whatever it is that we’re doing, and they’re reasonably close to wherever the assignment is. That’s more the typical route than hiring someone like Joe McNally. I was Joe’s picture editor for virtually all of his stuff at Geographic, so we know each other rather well, and I will bring him in when I need something that is technically demanding, like the “Building a Better Mouse” cover from the October 3, 2014 issue.

PDN: What kind of skills are you looking for?

BD: Generally, I’m looking for a journalistically skilled photographer, because most of our assignments have a journalistic component to them and I want someone who’s used to working in a situation that is sometimes full of surprises, can work quickly and has the necessary technical skills for lighting. But it’s very location-driven. We’re also doing things that are outside the U.S. We had a cover on Cuba, and Maggie Steber, a friend of mine who’s worked in Cuba a lot recommended Lisette Poole, an American photographer working in Cuba right now. She did some really beautiful portraits of Cuban scientists the writer had interviewed. A lot of times, it’s reaching out and finding someone that I don’t know, but who is in the right place and has the right skills.

PDN: How can a photographer get your attention?

BD: Send me a link. That’s the way it goes. It’s really dependent on if I have something going on where you are. 

PDN: Your website is undergoing a redesign. What will that entail, and how will it affect the photography you publish?

BR: It has not launched yet. We’re hoping by early fall. It will definitely be a visual refresh, but the goal is that we will have more functionality, more capability, in terms of better use of slideshows and video and getting interactive graphics and other sorts of visual storytelling components in there. It doesn’t always go exactly how you plan right off the bat, so it’s going to be an evolution. But that is definitely the goal. 

One thing that we did with our multimedia team: They took a researcher’s video of a process of 3D printing, three months after we published the research paper [“Continuous liquid interface production of 3D objects,” March 20, 2015] in the magazine. They did a voiceover and put some branding on it, reposted it and posted it on social. It reached more than 10 million people and pushed over 100,000 people back to the paper. That’s just one of the models our video team is pursuing. With that success, each week we’re trying to find researcher-driven video, or if possible, commission the video, give a little context for how it is applicable to the paper and then have it link back and drive traffic to the research.

Related: Create Spotlight: Al Jazeera America's Long-Form Photo Essays

article.article_title: Leveraging an Online Audience to Attract Book Publishers
article.meta_description: Two photographers who found success turning the work they showcased online into photo books explain how they got published.
article.article_text_abstract: Two photographers who found success turning the work they showcased online into photo books explain how they got published.
article.article_image_caption: “A requiem for St. Bonaventure,” documenting the demolition of St. Bonaventure Roman Catholic Church in Philadelphia, appears in Matthew Christopher’s new book, Abandoned America: The Age of Consequences. The book is adapted from his popular website, where he shares new photos of urban archaeology and notes on his process.
article.article_text:
Is an active website the secret to landing a photography book deal? Publishers see thousands of book proposals each year. Convincing them to take a chance on an unknown photographer or a unique topic is a challenge that many fail. Spending time cultivating your social media presence and connecting with viewers interested in your work can draw a publisher’s attention, show proof of interest in your style and subjects, and assist with the marketing and sales of your book after publication. Here are two examples of photographers who found success turning the work they showcased online into photo books.

Matthew Christopher

Abandoned America: The Age of Consequences

Commercial photographer Matthew Christopher started documenting the various derelict buildings that exist across America more than a decade ago. Initially drawn to abandoned medical facilities while researching the decline of the state hospital system, Christopher soon turned to photographing factories, churches, prisons and schools. “There is something magical and mysterious about spaces that are no longer in use, where nature and time and man’s presence have combined to create something absolutely unique,” explains Christopher. He created his website, abandonedamerica.us, in 2006, and he began sharing his work on Facebook and other social networks in 2009. In addition to posting new photos, he talks about each  location and his process, and answers viewers’ questions. Thanks to a fascination with urban archaeology and to the usefulness of his tips and information, the website sees more than 700,000 pageviews each month, and he has close to 230,000 followers on various social networks.

Christopher wasn’t initially successful in pitching Abandoned America to book publishers. But his active Facebook presence caught the eye of French imprint Jonglez Publishing. Once he had the publisher’s attention, the quality of his work shone through. “I discovered Matthew’s work on Facebook. We had already published books on the same subject with Belgian photographers and I was looking for other photographers on the same subject,” recalls publisher Thomas Jonglez. “His work stood out due to the quality of his pictures but also, which I discovered later on, due to the quality of his analysis and of his texts. His social media presence was a positive factor (especially for promotion/marketing) but the real positive was the quality of his work.”

Jonglez Publishing issued Abandoned America: The Age of Consequences in October 2014. Like Christopher’s website, the book includes historical information on each site. The mix of visuals and historical detail attracted press coverage in The Telegraph, Los Angeles Times, the websites of ABC News and NBC News and in travel and design publications. 

Like Smith, Christopher strongly believes that the size and loyalty of his online audience was crucial to getting his book published. “Absolutely, who knows whether that would have happened otherwise. There are a lot of smaller publishers out there these days who are calculating the risk they are taking in publishing an author or photographer by the amount of marketing that author will do for them and their established audience.” 

Having an engaged online audience was a boon for Christopher in promoting the book, not just in selling it to a publisher. “Much of the push in marketing now falls on an author. If someone is really motivated to go out there and connect their work with people, then they are going to do much better than an author who doesn’t understand that the success or failure of their publication rests on how creative they are in getting people to look at it,” Christopher says. 

The photographer is currently working on a second book, which he hopes to publish in 2016.

Victoria Smith
See San Francisco: Through the Lens of SFGirlbyBay 

Photographer, photo stylist, former art buyer and journalist Victoria Smith started posting photos and thoughts on decorating on sfgirlbybay.com in 2006 as a fun hobby. “I didn’t really decide to start a blog—it kind of chose me, so there were really no goals involved and certainly not [thoughts of] a book.” Smith explains, “It was never meant to be my ‘day job.’” Showcasing her “bohemian modern style,” with photos of her decorating and entertaining ideas, favorite stores and, eventually, work by up-and-coming interior designers, she soon averaged two to three posts a day. The site quickly grew in popularity. Eventually, taking advantage of the rise of social media platforms, Smith worked to build up her following and expand sfgirlbybay.com’s reach. Today, in addition to 520,000 monthly visitors to her blog, sfgirlbybay.com has more than 140,000 Instagram followers, 43,000 Twitter followers, 46,000 Facebook fans, and an impressive 583,000-plus Pinterest followers (including influencers such as Oprah and Martha Stewart).

Her photography itself did not go unnoticed. Laura Lee Mattingly, an editor at Chronicle Books, became a fan. “Victoria’s blog caught my attention years ago,” she says. “Her design sense is distinctive and has a great laid-back, sunny California feel. Her images drew me in—I actually purchased one of her prints right around the time I first reached out to her around 2010. It’s still hanging in my living room.” Beyond that, it was very clear that Smith’s Web presence was more than just numbers on a stat sheet to the publisher. Says Mattingly, “She interacts with her audience, keeps readers engaged, and her fans clearly adore her. This built-in platform, combined with her visual and editorial sense, made her very appealing as an author.”

Chronicle Books published See San Francisco: Through the Lens of SFGirlbyBay in April 2015. A guide to San Francisco for visitors and locals, the book is an extension of Smith’s “Sunday in the City” column on sfgirlbybay.com. It is, in Mattingly’s words, “a love letter to the city.”

Smith says, “I don’t think I would have been approached by a publisher without a blog or social media following.” Beyond having potential book buyers among her fans were the marketing and promotion opportunities her following provided. “It’s really been beneficial to have a social media following. People who have purchased the book have been taking Instagrams of it, styled in their homes and tagging me. So it’s been great to see my readers firsthand. And I was able to promote the book via social, too, although I tried not to oversell it. Not everyone wants to see that in my feed.”
 
She also organized events for her followers that generated book sales. “I was able to host a photowalk through San Francisco where we selected attendees via their Instagram photos tagged #SeeSanFrancisco. About 30 of us walked through the city one Saturday taking Instagrams. The was a fun way to promote the book and have a good time.”

article.article_title: How to Pitch Your Photo Book to Publishers
article.meta_description: To convince publishers to take a chance on a book, photographers have to think like marketers. Book packagers offer their advice.
article.article_text_abstract: To convince publishers to take a chance on a book, photographers have to think like marketers. Book packagers offer their advice.
article.article_image_caption: The cover of Susan Middleton's Spineless.
article.article_text:
As the cost of producing and printing illustrated books has increased, trade publishers require higher sales figures and larger print runs in order to recoup their costs. “The numbers publishers now need are higher than ever,” says book packager Robert Morton. A former editor at Abrams, Morton notes that a few years ago, a photo book that sold 7,000 copies was considered a success; now a publisher would be reluctant to take on a book unless it had the potential to sell many more copies. 

To convince a publisher to take a chance on a book, photographers without notoriety or proven sales have to have an appealing subject, and evidence that the pool of potential buyers of their book “is beyond the photographer, their collectors, their grandmother and grandfather,” Morton says.

We asked Morton and other packagers of published photo books for advice on the key ingredients of a book proposal.

Identify Your Audience

“Sales and marketing departments are making more decisions than editors now about what is going to get published,” says book packager Wendy Burton, who worked in the sales and editorial departments of large book publishers, including Penguin and Abrams imprint Stewart, Tabori & Chang, before she launched her own business. 

Sales and marketing people want to know the size of the audience who might be interested in the subject of your book, and where to find them. If your book appeals to fans of a certain subject, Morton suggests finding out if there’s a magazine or website that already reaches them. “What’s the circulation of the magazine? Are there clubs [devoted to] the subject? Do they have conventions or trips?”

Research on comparable books provides valuable information for a publisher. Alan Rapp, a consultant and editor at Monacelli says providing “comps” helps your proposal in two ways. “It shows that you know your field and your place in it,” he says. “It also shows you have a viable subject matter.”

Make Your Book Appealing to Your Potential Audience

Burton recommends creating a “layered” proposal. Consider how to add content to the book that provides context for the work and makes the book a richer, more valuable investment for people interested in your subject. For one book proposal she helped package, she found vintage, stereoscopic views of similar subjects to illuminate the history of the topic. 

An introductory essay can also help explain and contextualize the photos, and having a recognized expert provide text adds authority. Morton notes, “You can have a statement from a photographic historian or curator,” to vouch for the value of the images, “and another person who writes about the subject. Both help.”

Offer Marketing Ideas

As more bookstores shutter, it’s important to find other venues where books can be sold, Morton notes. Photographers and authors are usually expected to help market the book through events or gallery openings. Through the process of researching and shooting the book, the photographer may already have developed contacts at organizations relevant to the book’s topic that may provide venues for book signings, slide shows, or public lectures where the audience has the chance to buy copies of the book. Finding contacts and possible venues before pitching the book can help strengthen a proposal.  

In writing proposals, Burton has at times provided information about the photographer’s expertise and experience giving interviews either on camera or off. This can help in pitching stories about the book or the photographer to press contacts. 

The more potential sales and marketing ideas the photographer can offer, the easier the job is for the publisher. Says Burton, “When photographers are crafting their proposals, they have to think like a sales and marketing person.”

article.article_title: Toni Greaves' New Book Follows the Life of a Young Nun
article.meta_description: Toni Greaves’s first monograph follows the growth of a young nun’s relationship with God and her community of sisters, exploring what it means to pursue what one loves in life.
article.article_text_abstract: Toni Greaves’s first monograph follows the growth of a young nun’s relationship with God and her community of sisters, exploring what it means to pursue what one loves in life.
article.article_image_caption: “Work, Cleaning 1,” 2013, from Toni Greaves’s book Radical Love, which traces the life of a young woman, Sister Lauren, who left college to become a cloistered nun.
article.article_text:
When we first meet Sister Lauren, she has just begun her new life as a nun. She is in her early twenties, but without makeup or other worldly trappings, she could easily pass for a college freshman. Her youthful fragility seems at odds with the solemn habit she wears and the stateliness of her surroundings: the columns of the monastery, the looming vault of the chapel. As we travel with her through Radical Love, the new book by photographer Toni Greaves, we see laughter and music; games, laundry and gardening; and meals taken in a cozy dining room, all the nuns seated together in a circle. Years pass—of snow angels, and chores and bible study in wood paneled libraries—as we follow Sister Lauren through her higher education of a different kind.

Radical Love, Greaves’s first book, is a stirring meditation on the journey of a young nun living in a cloistered community. The Australian-born, Portland, Oregon-based editorial and commercial photographer began the project early in her photography career, after 15 successful years working as a designer. That career change, and Radical Love itself, were both born from the tragic loss of Greaves’s mother in December, 2004. 

As she writes in the book, “To be with her when she died, and to see the shift of her being there and then not there, marked the beginning of a deeply personal path of spiritual exploration and discovery that continues to this day.” On the two-year anniversary of her mother’s death, Greaves left her design job, determined to pursue her love of photography in earnest. Fittingly, almost ten years later, she’s publishing her photographic exploration of spirituality as a monograph.

Greaves first came to the Dominican Monastery of Our Lady of the Rosary in Summit, New Jersey, on February 22, 2008. She was living in New York City at the time and accompanying a writer on a freelance assignment—an article about several young women who had recently joined the monastery after finding it online. 

“We went for a morning and I made some pictures while she did her interviews,” Greaves recalls, “then she left and I was having an amazing time, so I just decided to hang out and make more photos. I spent the day there and really had a lovely connection with the nuns.”

The experience stayed with her: The following week she approached the nuns and asked if she could return. 

For the next sixth months, Greaves continued to visit the monastery, photographing the nuns in their daily lives without any particular focus. It was only after she was able to collect some strong images that Greaves realized that she wanted to center her project on one young nun in particular. She was captivated by Sister Lauren’s energy and was interested in exploring how this woman’s journey deep into her faith could exemplify something common to all the nuns. In this regard, the fact that Greaves had begun the project when Sister Lauren had only been at the monastery for three weeks was an added bonus. 

Over the years Greaves returned to the monastery again and again, especially at important moments in Sister Lauren’s stages of formation (the process by which a would-be nun moves from Aspirant to Novitiate to full member of the monastery). Even after she moved across the country, Greaves would find a way to come calling, but not without actually calling first. “Although I have a very wonderful relationship with them, which I’m very grateful for, every single time I go there I need to get permission. It’s not assumed,” Greaves explains. “After all, they’re cloistered nuns, and their purpose in life doesn’t usually include having a photographer around.” Greaves takes a minimalist approach when it comes to gear, favoring one camera and a couple lenses. She wanders the monastery in her socks, camera in hand, using whatever natural light is available. 

When describing time spent in the monastery, Greaves is effusive in discussing the joyful, vibrant, positive atmosphere that the women have created. “You know when you have a friend and they are in love with a new person, they have that little sparkle to them? That’s what I saw there,” she says. That love is what Greaves set out to capture in this work: the intensity of these women’s relationships with God. 

It wasn’t until around 2012 that Greaves began to think about turning the project into a book. She went to a portfolio review at the 2012 Palm Springs Photo Festival with the intention of meeting representatives of two publishers. One was Chronicle Books, and as it turned out, she ended up having a meeting with the company’s owner and founder, Nion McEvoy. Although there was no commitment at the time, a couple of weeks after the review McEvoy let Greaves know that they were interested in publishing the book. 

Even now, seven years after she first encountered the Dominican Nuns of Summit, New Jersey, Greaves intends to keep going back to the monastery for as long as they will have her. “People have this idea that by them closing themselves away, they are giving up all these things that make life rewarding, but I see it as the opposite,” Greaves explains. “They have figured out what they care about, what they love in life, and that is what they are going to do. So whereas out in the world many of us are floundering, looking for a sense of purpose, they have that already.”

article.article_title: How I Got That Grant: Richard Renaldi and Gary Briechle on Winning 2015 Guggenheim Fellowships
article.meta_description: How the photographers put together successful applications for the fellowships, which support mid-career artists.
article.article_text_abstract: How the photographers put together successful applications for the fellowships, which support mid-career artists.
article.article_image_caption: “Shantelle and Lincoln,” 2013. From Gary Briechle’s ongoing project photographing friends and neighbors in Midcoast Maine.
article.article_text:
Guggenheim fellowships are expressly for accomplished mid-career artists, not precocious new talent or particular projects.  Among the 11 photographers who won Guggenheim fellowships earlier this year were Richard Renaldi, who is 47, and Gary Briechle, who is 59. Both say the key to their success was showing bodies of strong, mature work and being able to explain it in clear, concise terms.

Renaldi, who won his Guggenheim Fellowship on his first try, hadn’t thought his work was mature enough to put him in the running after Aperture published his book Figure and Ground in 2005. But last spring, he published Touching Strangers, his acclaimed book of street photos of strangers he asked to interact with each other. “Now I have more of a sense of who I am, and what my work is about,” he says.

Briechle had applied unsuccessfully for a Guggenheim years ago. Four days before applications for the 2015 fellowships were due last fall, he says, he suddenly decided it was time to try again. He has been widely recognized in the art photography world for his alternative process photographs of his circle of friends, neighbors and relatives, all made near his home in Midcoast Maine. 

“I was able to cobble it together in a few days,” he says of his application, which rivals Robert Frank’s legendary Guggenheim application for brevity, clarity and directness. 

“Most of the photographs I’ve taken over the last 12 years since moving to Maine have been made within a few miles of my home,” Briechle’s application begins. “I am known in the community and have long-term photographic relationships with many people.” He goes on to explain that the fellowship would give him the opportunity to travel and photograph beyond the local community.

“More and more I’ve noticed that I’m seeing the socio-economic aspects [of my subject’s lives] present in the background of my work. I’d like to look beyond my community in Maine and use a wider lens to connect foreground and background.”

He listed who he’d like to photograph, where he’d have to travel to photograph them, and when he would do it. And that was the extent of it. 

“Basically I said, ‘Business as usual, and maybe a little traveling to see my kids and family,’” Briechle says. “I kept it simple. Photography is a visual language, and I don’t think words equal it. If I wrote more than I did, I would be trying to talk to someone in art talk. It should be described simply.”

He took the same less-is-more approach to his portfolio, submitting 20 4 x 6-inch prints. “I figured, if they [jurors] were smart people, and of course they are, they would know I was using a good camera. I could have made big prints, but who am I impressing by making a big print?”

Briechle had help editing the selection of images from Jack Woody of Twin Palms Publishers, which published Briechle’s eponymous 2010 book. He also included a copy of the book with his application, and when he put it all in the mail, he says, “I thought: I’m an idiot for what I just did. But I felt like I did the right thing for me. I wanted to say simple stuff about what I do.”

The most difficult part of the application, he says, was getting the four required recommendations. He approached Duane Michals, who had selected Briechle’s work for a portfolio feature in Camera magazine. “[Michals] said, ‘Yeah, I’ll do it, but I’ve written 20 recommendations over the years, and not one of them has gotten it [a Guggenheim fellowship],” Briechle says.

Briechle also solicited a recommendation from the owner of a Camden, Maine cafe called Zoot, where Briechle shows his work once a year. The cafe owner, a graduate of Princeton University, “doesn’t have art credentials,” Briechle says, but he adds, “Some regular people might be artistic. I like that perspective, and she’s smart. She knew me as a person, and even though she doesn’t have credentials, she knows my work.”

For his part, Renaldi says he’d never applied for the Guggenheim previously because he was busy with commercial and editorial work, and didn’t really need the support. But the prestige and affirmation of the Guggenheim Fellowship appealed to him. “I felt like I really made a pretty important and valuable body of work and contribution [with Touching Strangers], and it was maybe my time” to apply, he says.

But Renaldi didn’t focus on Touching Strangers in the application, because that project has had so much press, he figured he didn’t need to talk about it. Instead, he focused his application on his latest project called “Manhattan Sunday,” for which he photographs people making their way home from nightclubs early on Sunday mornings. 

Renaldi approached his statement of his plans for the fellowship as an essay. “I kind of told my story, delved into my experience, and related it to the work,” he says. “I thought that would be a better route to go, than saying these are the kind of pictures I want to take, and this is how I want them to be exhibited.” 

He explained that his “Manhattan Sunday” project is intertwined with his own history and experience as a gay person who came out as a young man, and found a community in the club scene “where there’s a sense of freedom, and being accepted for who you were.”

He went on to describe how he’s trying to capture, through photography, the feeling of staying out all night, then coming out of a club at the break of day “at a magical moment when the city is totally at rest. I was there, I saw the beauty [of it], so I was motivated to photograph it.”

Unlike Briechle, Renaldi labored over his essay for a couple of months. “You have to sit on things a while, to make sure you’re not missing things. And cutting is really important for sure. Being concise is really important, and [being] on point.” In all, his statement of purpose was three pages long, he says. (The career narrative, another required part of the Guggenheim application, was straightforward, and took much less time than his statement of plans, Renaldi says.)

He also submitted a more elaborate portfolio than Briechle did: a box of 20 archival pigment prints, each 16 x 20-inches on 17 x 22-inch paper—“so the images were really prominent”—with tissue paper between each print. 

Renaldi’s advice to other photographers thinking of applying for a Guggenheim is to “know when you’re ready, when there’s a maturity to your work [and] a self-awareness” of what you’re doing as an artist. “I think that’s an important question to ask yourself: Am I ready for this?”

He also says it is important to be able to talk and write about your work in a clear, intelligent way—something he learned to do with his Touching Strangers work. “A lot of artists don’t want to [talk about their work], and think it should be able to stand on its own. But the fact is, you’re going be asked to do that.” 

You’ll certainly be asked on most grant applications. For the Guggenheim and many other grants, what you say, and how you say it, can be as important as the quality of the work you submit.
