article.article_title: How to Pitch Your Photo Book to Trade Publishers: Carrie Solomon’s Inside Chefs’ Fridges
article.meta_description: The book is one of the few cookbooks that TASCHEN has published; managing editor Florian Kobler says it has the “global appeal” the company looks for.
article.article_text_abstract: The book is one of the few cookbooks that TASCHEN has published; managing editor Florian Kobler says it has the “global appeal” the company looks for.
article.article_image_credit: © TASCHEN/Photo By Carrie Solomon, Illustration By Aurore d’Estaing
article.article_image_caption: The refrigerator of French chef Hélene Darroze, photographed by Carrie Solomon for the book Inside Chefs' Fridges.
article.article_text:
Inside Chefs’ Fridges features photos by American-born, Paris-based photographer Carrie Solomon showing the contents of the home refrigerators of 40 of Europe’s most acclaimed chefs. The book also includes her portraits of each chef, and images of dishes they make at home. Her collaborator Adrian Moore, a concierge at the Mandarin Oriental in Paris who writes regularly about restaurants and culinary trends, wrote profiles on each chef. The book is a revealing look at the chefs’ personalities, lives and tastes, as reflected in staples they stock in their fridges, from exotic condiments they brought home from their travels to their kids’ favorite foods. “Some chefs made sure the fridge really reflected their image, and others didn’t care at all,” Solomon says. Peeking inside their fridges, she says, “explains how they spend their free time: If they entertain friends or hardly eat at home at all.”

Due out this fall from TASCHEN, Inside Chefs’ Fridges also includes addresses of each chef’s restaurant and recipes for each homemade dish, making it a guidebook for food tourists and a useful tool for home cooks. It’s one of the few cookbooks TASCHEN has published, but managing editor Florian Kobler says it has the “global appeal” the company looks for. TASCHEN is publishing the book in five languages. 

“We were hoping we would attract people who want to try chefs’ recipes, and who follow celebrity chefs,” Solomon says. Solomon says that she and Moore have tried to “simplify and demystify” haute cuisine and make it accessible. Seeing that three-star Michelin chefs have plastic-wrapped vegetables or their kids’ favorite treats in their refrigerators is reassuring, Solomon notes: “Chefs are just like us.”

Solomon and Moore first met ten years ago on an assignment for a Paris guidebook. Over the years, Solomon published several books, and she and Moore had talked about collaborating on a project. They were looking for something that would feel “personal” and accessible, Solomon says. One evening, chatting at a culinary event that had attracted many of the top chefs in Paris, Moore suggested asking some of the chefs to let them see how they cook at home. Several agreed and, after some follow-up phone calls, Solomon had her first test subjects. 

Though they came up with the concept quickly, Moore and Solomon continued to refine the idea, expanding the geographical scope from first Paris to France and then all of Europe. In 2013 they created a book proposal in PDF form to submit to publishers. It included photos Solomon had made in five chefs’ homes, sample profiles, and the list of celebrated chefs they hoped to cover. “We wanted to show that we had a unique project and the gumption to pull it off,” says Solomon.

They also provided their resumes, and Solomon wrote a detailed statement about the money they would need to travel to Copenhagen, Madrid, London, Modena, Italy and other cities. Kobler says the authors’ credentials and their detailed planning helped sell the proposal. “Of course, it has to have a great idea and popular potential, but at the end of the day there are many other factors. Can they actually pull it off? It’s one thing to do a one-sheet that displays an idea, but profiles of 40 chefs over the whole continent? It’s more tricky than you think.” Solomon emphasized to Kobler that she had managed other book projects from initial idea to completion, and also worked on cookbooks for which she gained the cooperation of multiple chefs. These included Sauveurs Sauvages, the award-winning book on wild game for which Solomon made posed, formal portraits of 28 chefs. “I really learned a few things about how to approach chefs,” she says. “I knew to expect delays and cancellations, that I would have to call them over and over because they’re busy and much solicited.” Thanks to her track record, Kobler says, “We weren’t worried they couldn’t pull it off.” 

TASCHEN still had other criteria to consider. “The sophistication and simplicity of the visual language is of course a key requirement for our books,” says Kobler. Solomon’s lighting gave a similar look to all her photos, no matter where she made them or at what time of day. “The fridge was meant to be the equalizer,” she says. “You wouldn’t know if you were in a luxurious kitchen or a short-term rental apartment.” Wanting to pack light for her travels while also compensating for disparate lighting conditions, she chose to shoot with on-camera flash, and used the same technique for her portraits. 

Before each shoot, she texted the chef a production list, specifying details that would ensure consistency: Simple clothing for the portrait, plain tableware for the food shots, and dishes that could be made in about an hour during Moore and Solomon’s visit. “Sometimes I’d get there, and they hadn’t read it,” Solomon says, so the chef had to think of a new dish on the spot. “That was really interesting because it had to be something made with whatever they had on hand.”

In evaluating the book proposal, Kobler says, the biggest concern was whether Solomon and Moore had selected the right chefs. TASCHEN produces many “best of” compilations. “It’s all about the curation,” Kobler says. “Because we’re not cookbook experts,” Kobler notes, company founder Benedikt Taschen asked friends who are chefs in Los Angeles to review the list. “They basically gave it their thumbs up,” Solomon says. 

When the TASCHEN sales team reviewed the proposal, they discussed comparable books and their prices. “We know that cookbooks are more in the affordable range than high-end books,” Kobler notes. “This is a book that people will want to use as a cookbook, so we can’t go double the price range for cookbooks.” 

While TASCHEN deliberated, Solomon and Moore were also negotiating a deal with a French publisher. Then, a year and a half ago, TASCHEN offered them a deal, including an advance to cover their travel. The book, 328 pages long, will sell for $50: more than some cookbooks but, says Kobler, “well-designed and carefully put together.”

More modifications followed. TASCHEN’s sales representative for Latin America said including a chef from Portugal would help sales, so Solomon and Moore went to Lisbon to profile Jose Avillez, whose restaurant Belcanto earned two Michelin stars. 

Nathan Myhrvold, author of Modernist Cuisine: The Art and Science of Cooking, also published by TASCHEN, agreed to write a foreword. “We wanted him to geek out,” says Solomon. His essay on the history of refrigeration inspired Solomon to add a photo of the back of a fridge, showing its mechanics. 

As publication nears, Solomon and Moore are helping market the book through their connections in the food world. Solomon explains, “We both know a lot of these chefs, so we’re asking their help in putting together events and we’re hoping that a lot of them will sell the books in their restaurants.”

Bringing the book to market has been a long process. When Solomon shot the first photos for the project, she was pregnant with her first child. “She’s now four,” the photographer says. She’s shot several cookbooks on commission from publishers, but says working on a book like Inside Chefs’ Fridges is more satisfying. “I really enjoy the books that come from an idea that I’ve had.”

article.article_title: How to Pitch Your Photo Book to Trade Publishers: Christian Chaize’s Praia Piquinia
article.meta_description: Chaize’s editor at Chronicle Books says his book can appeal to a person who loves beaches or travel, in addition to people who appreciate his photography.
article.article_text_abstract: Chaize’s editor at Chronicle Books says his book can appeal to a person who loves beaches or travel, in addition to people who appreciate his photography.
article.article_image_caption: Christian Chaize’s book of images of a single beach, which were made over time from roughly the same perspective, appealed to both art and travel audiences. “The single biggest determiner of success in the trade is whether or not a photobook has a strong secondary audience, beyond a fine-art photography audience,” explains Bridget Watson Payne, Chaize’s editor at Chronicle Books.
article.article_text:
A hundred photographs of the same secluded beach in Portugal, made from roughly the same perspective over the course of eight years: It may not sound like a photo book that would interest a major illustrated book publisher like Chronicle Books, or that would find success with a general audience, but that is exactly what French photographer Christian Chaize’s book, Time & Tide: Photographs from Praia Piquinia, accomplished.

Bridget Watson Payne, Chronicle Books’ senior editor for art publishing, was drawn to Chaize’s images when she received his proposal, but photography that is merely “technically very accomplished” won’t lead to success with a general audience, she notes. “The single biggest determiner of success in the trade is whether or not a photobook has a strong secondary audience, beyond a fine-art photography audience,” Watson Payne explains. In Chaize’s case, his book can also appeal to a person who loves beaches or travel, “someone longing nostalgically for the sea or summer,” she told PDN via email. Chaize’s photographs “worked in both of those ways, and I saw a lot of potential in that, both esthetically and commercially,” Watson Payne notes.

“I never imagined that one day so many people would be interested in my study of a single beach,” he told PDN via through his agent and translator, Jenni Holder. “Aside from the individual appeal of any single image, the series is easily subject to—and informed by—the act of contrast and comparison from one image, or day, or year, to the next.”

From image to image in Chaize’s book, the tide comes in and out, the sky shifts from hazy to crystal clear, and the colors of the beach umbrellas change, as do the beachgoers and their activities and interactions. The $35 book, which was released in Spring 2013, is 156 pages, includes 100 images, and was printed at a generous 11 x 13-inch trim size. 

Chaize’s book has something other books of beach scenery don’t: A reason to linger over the pages. He chose to include details of certain images in the book, an idea he specified in his proposal. “Full bleeds of details, and alternate cropping, would offer [readers] an opportunity to experience and examine the work in a way that might only be duplicated by living with a large collection of my actual photographs over a long period time,” he wrote.

To illustrate the idea, he worked with a designer he knew to mock up pages that showed book spreads featuring both the full-size photographs and close-ups of details. (He also envisioned using gatefolds, but had to abandon that idea due to budget concerns.) The images, Watson Payne notes, are still the most important element of a photography book proposal. “Sometimes prospective authors get caught up in publisher’s submission guidelines and find themselves crafting a wonderfully detailed, meticulous and long, text-based book proposal.” She recommends leading with at least one photograph, and then illustrating the rest of the proposal with more images.

Chaize’s proposal included a biography and artist’s statement, in addition to his description of how he envisioned the design and overall experience of the book. Other elements in a proposal might include competitive title research, descriptions of the potential audience and marketing ideas. Watson Payne believes “the more of this kind of work the photographer is willing to do, the better.” She says it’s “not the end of the world” if the photographer doesn’t address these topics in their proposal, but it does make it easier for the editor to evaluate the project’s potential. Watson Payne suggests photographers ask themselves this: “Do you really want to saddle the person who is about to consider your book proposal with a bunch of work?” Plus, she points out, “photographers have been living and breathing their subject matter for ages—no one is likely to know what the other books out there on their subjects are, [or] know who the audience for their work is, nearly as well as they do. They are the experts and I want to learn from their expertise.”

Another factor that helped Chaize land a book deal is that he has gallery representation. Jen Bekman, who represents his work at her gallery and on her affordable art site 20x200, has what she calls a “constant dialogue” with Chronicle, and introduced Chaize’s work to Watson Payne. Chaize’s success selling his work with Bekman and 20x200—Bekman says she’s sold “thousands of Christian’s prints”—demonstrated the work’s ability to reach a more general audience. “I know a lot about who responds to Christian’s work because I’ve been working with him for such a long time,” Bekman says. “It was meaningful to [Chronicle] that Christian already had an audience,” she adds. “Because most photographers don’t have literary agents, I do often see gallerists acting as something like book agents for some of their artists,” Watson Payne notes. 

She adds, however, that working with a gallery or an agent isn’t essential to her. “Other factors—like having a strong social media platform—can end up having a much bigger impact on book sales,” she says. And while some publishers won’t accept proposals unless they come through an agent, that isn’t the case at Chronicle. But, as Watson Payne notes, “If someone is trying to break into a very crowded and competitive field (children’s books, for instance, or food photography); or just wants to focus on creative work and not spend time dealing with business matters like negotiations and contracts; or is really struggling developing their book pitch, then an agent can be a great help.”

In retrospect, Chaize says, he wonders if he could have done more “to promote the book in this social-media-rich environment,” or if he should have tried to schedule more book signings “to have the chance to meet more of the people who appreciate my work.” But he is also delighted by the experience of working with Watson Payne and finding a trade audience for his book.

Other photographers with projects that can reach beyond the specialized photo-book audience should be encouraged by his experience, and by the market for art books in general, Watson Payne notes. “Books by individual photographers can do very well in the trade—in fact art books as a whole are one of the most robust categories in trade publishing right now, because they are almost entirely immune to sales erosion from ebook sales—if their subject matter appeals to a broad secondary audience.”

Related: How to Pitch Your Photo Book to Trade Publishers: Susan Middleton’s Spineless

article.article_title: How (And Why) To Make Copyright Registration Part Of Your Workflow
article.meta_description: Photographer Michael Grecco breaks down his workflow for registering copyright and explains why doing so is essential to his business.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer Michael Grecco breaks down his workflow for registering copyright and explains why doing so is essential to his business.
article.article_image_caption: Michael Grecco uses a file naming system that not only keeps his archives organized, but makes his images easy to track in the event of infringement.
article.article_text:
The most effective way to protect your images against rampant theft is to register your copyrights. “If you don’t register your copyrights, you’re perpetually a victim” because you have no leverage to make infringers pay, says photographer Michael Grecco.

Registration before an infringement occurs gives you leverage, he explains, because it makes you eligible for statutory damages (ranging up to $150,000) for each image, plus attorney’s fees. Those numbers scare infringers, so showing proof of your copyright registration will typically make them willing to negotiate with you.

On the other hand, when unregistered images are stolen, infringers may be less intimidated, because you are eligible only for actual damages, which are difficult to prove in court. The most they’ll pay in most cases is a normal licensing fee, but you’ll spend many times that amount suing them.

Despite the legal protection provided by timely registration of every image, many photographers don’t bother because they figure registration is more trouble than it is worth. Grecco insists otherwise. “It’s been part of my regular workflow since 1998. I routinely register every image, all the time,” he says. 

And the effort more than pays for itself, he adds. “My collections for infringement far surpass revenues I was getting ten years ago for my syndication and creative stock, when that market was a viable market,” he says. (He uses a service, imagerights.com, to troll the Internet for unauthorized uses of his images.) Grecco’s goal is to register all of his images before they are published, and he’s built a system into his workflow to accomplish that. 

“It’s easier and less expensive to register unpublished images,” he says. That’s because unpublished images can be registered in bulk: For one fee ($65), and with one form (called Form VA), you can register online an unlimited number of unpublished images. (Once an image is published, it has to be registered individually for $35, or with other published images for a $65 fee. Published and unpublished images cannot be registered together on the same form.)

Grecco’s system for registering images is the same system he uses to archive his work. First, he collects in a single folder all of his unpublished images as he shoots them. The folder is identified by a date range, beginning with the day after his last bulk registration, and ending with the date he submits the entire folder to the US Copyright Office with a form to register all of the images in the folder. For instance, unpublished images shot between July 30, 2012 and November 26, 2012, resided in a fold titled 20120730_to_20121126_Grecco_Unpublished.

Within each folder of unpublished images are sub-folders for every job Grecco shoots, with a date, subject name, and Grecco’s initials. For instance, a folder titled 20120820_Bucknell_MPG contains images he shot August 20, 2012 for a capital campaign for Bucknell University.

Inside each of the job folders are image files that carry the job folder name, plus a unique three-digit image number. For instance, images in the Bucknell job folder are titled 20120820_Bucknell_MPG_005.jpg, 20120820_Bucknell_MPG_006.jpg, etc.

Grecco’s digital tech names the image files according to that protocol as the files are copied on set from camera to hard drive. 

Grecco stresses, “You want to name an image file one time, and register the image with that same file name.” 

He keeps track of pending publication dates for the images in the Unpublished Images folder. When any image in the folder is about to be published, he registers every image in the folder in bulk. 

Grecco filed his first copyright registration form with the help of an attorney, to make sure he was filling out the form correctly. Then he set up a template for future registration submissions. “The template enables me to easily [register images]. All I have to do is change the date range” on the registration form, he explains.

Because Grecco begins his image file names with the date they are shot, he ends up registering all of his images chronologically. That way, the registration form associated with each image is easy to find, if and when an image is infringed and he needs to produce a copy of the registration form to get the attention of the infringer.

Grecco emphasizes the importance of leaving image file names unchanged as they go to and from the retoucher, or to and from clients. (The files may be different formats--JPEGs when shown to clients, DNG files when archived.) If the names of images are changed, and versions of the same image end up with different names, you might never be able to match an infringed image with the copyright registration records.

The US Copyright Office requires digital copies of every image listed on a registration form. Grecco says he limits the size of the image files he submits to 450 pixels by 450 pixels. 

“I want them large enough to be recognized, but not large enough for someone to go to the Copyright Office and steal them,”  he says.

With a registration system built into his workflow, Grecco insists that it is much easier to register copyrights than most photographers assume it is. And more photographers need to make registration part of their workflow for their own good— and everyone else’s, he says. “People are systematically stealing, and we need to systematically defend ourselves.”

For more information, see Grecco's How to Archive blog and his video about his file-naming system.

article.article_title: How to Pitch Your Photo Book to Trade Publishers: Susan Middleton’s Spineless
article.meta_description: Middleton's esthetic approach of isolating the odd, beautiful and lesser-known animals on seamless backgrounds appealed to Eric Himmel, her editor at Abrams.
article.article_text_abstract: Middleton's esthetic approach of isolating the odd, beautiful and lesser-known animals on seamless backgrounds appealed to Eric Himmel, her editor at Abrams.
article.article_image_caption: A Pink Brittle Star. Susan Middleton’s editor, Eric Himmel at Abrams, says her work stands out as “an attempt to incorporate some esthetic values that are not simply from the realm of traditional nature photography.”
article.article_text:
In 2006, Susan Middleton began her work photographing marine invertebrates while aboard a research vessel that was exploring the French Frigate Shoals, 500 miles west of Honolulu, Hawaii. Even then, bobbing in the Pacific with scientists from around the world, she knew she was working on a book. With several previous titles to her credit, Middleton tends to be “book-oriented,” she says. 

Middleton also knew she wanted the book, which she’d eventually publish with Abrams in October 2014, to reach as many people as possible. “I really wanted to reach out to a general audience,” she remembers. “I wanted kids to be engaged by the images. I wanted to reach out to people who are passionate about photography; [to] artists, designers, fashion designers. I wanted to reach out to people who were in the sciences and were passionate about biology, and also [to] the conservation community.”

All of that is easier said than done. A number of factors helped Middleton place her book, Spineless: Portraits of Marine Invertebrates, the Backbone of Life, with Abrams and create a package that could appeal to a wide range of viewers. Her esthetic approach of isolating the odd, beautiful and lesser-known animals on seamless backgrounds appealed to Eric Himmel, her editor at Abrams. “You see that [Susan is] photographing animals that are unusual, and she’s doing it in a way that’s very difficult.”

Middleton consciously “rides the line between art and science,” in her work, she explains, attracting people through esthetics and then engaging them in the content of her images. “I’m fundamentally an artist, but I attach myself to scientists to guide what I do. I think Eric has always appreciated that sweet spot between art and science.”

Himmel says the science and nature category is “a little bit underserved” by publishers. “I don’t think [they] take it as seriously as they should.” With a greater portion of the public interested in conservation and the environment, Himmel recognizes the market for books that look in a unique way at the natural world. “Work in [science and nature] is really being done on a very high level now because of interest, because of technology; I think an urgent sense that the world is going to hell plays a role,” he explains. Artists like Middleton and Tim Flach, another Abrams author, are “operating on a pretty high level of thought,” he says, and their work “[is] an attempt to do something new, an attempt to incorporate some esthetic values that are not simply from the realm of traditional nature photography.”

Middleton submitted her proposal in 2012, after six years working sporadically on the series and thinking about how to shape it. She’d co-authored a previous book with Abrams and that contract gave them first refusal rights for her next book, but she says she prepared her proposal the same way she would have for any publisher. The most important piece was a set of 50 5 x 7-inch prints “that I felt were really strong and that represented the diversity that I intended for the book to contain,” she says. “My feeling was I wanted it to be a nice little package where the prints were big enough to be able to convey the work, but small enough that they could go in somebody’s briefcase or be shuffled like a big deck of cards on a conference table.”

She also included a CV and “several pages of how I envisioned the book.” Having spent years “eavesdropping on really intensive marine invertebrate classes” on research vessels and at the University of Washington’s marine laboratory on San Juan Island, Middleton wanted to write the text herself and had ideas about how the book could be chaptered. She also envisioned a page count and trim size. “That’s not saying that’s what’s going to end up happening,” she counsels, “and in fact in my case the page count and trim size increased once we actually got down to the final production decisions, but I did have an idea of how I thought the book could be and I expressed that.”

Himmel says he’s seen proposals of all shapes and sizes in his 35 years as an editor, and he “doesn’t have a prescriptive format.” But, he adds, “a good proposal should be clear and lucid about the purpose of the book and its main focus, and convey the writer’s understanding or belief of why people would be interested.” Photographers should include “a reasonable amount of visual material.” He doesn’t want to see finished layouts unless they’re done professionally. “We work with good book designers and we have a lot of experience making books, so when faced with images and text, we can imagine what a book could look like,” he says.

The author’s name recognition, exhibition and/or publication histories, and marketing hooks are all important. “We need to get some sense not just of what the material is, but who the person presenting it is,” he says.

Middleton’s affiliations with science museums and conservation groups “that you could look to to help promote the book when it was published” factored into Himmel’s evaluation of her proposal. He also had in the back of his mind another book about deep-sea creatures that he’d passed on, which sold tens of thousands of copies for another publisher. “In an editor’s life, when you pass on something that then goes on to show that you made a big mistake, your antennae are up,” he explains.

Himmel says he doesn’t expect authors to submit comparative title research with their proposals, but “comps” are key to demonstrating “to colleagues who are not in the editorial department why you think a book will sell.” (This is part of the reason it’s difficult to publish photographic monographs, he adds: “It’s very hard to point to comps.”) “The old joke is that the perfect book is the book that’s completely original that’s really like something else that was very successful,” he laughs. Spineless can be seen as that perfect combination of unique photographs in a category that has been successful.

When PDN spoke with Middleton in late July, she was on San Juan Island for an artist’s residency. A new museum was showing her marine invertebrates work, much of which was made at the research lab nearby. Though the world of marine invertebrates is little-known, they are essential to ocean and terrestrial ecosystems, and they are also very sensitive to climate change and ocean acidification, she says, so her work “ends up having a resonance that goes beyond just pictures of a little-known realm of life.” As a longtime conservation photographer, reaching a general audience means exposing people to an essential category of animals.

“In the end, I think what really grabs people is just how bizarre they are, how interesting they are, how beautiful a lot of them are, and how unexpected they are,” she says. “One woman [at] the exhibit the other day—she didn’t know I was the artist; I was being incognito—she looked at me and she said, ‘These pictures make humans seem really boring.’ And I said, ‘I know, that’s the way I feel.’”

article.article_title: 1st Amendment Watch: Will Police Ever Get the Message That Photography is Not a Crime?
article.meta_description: Press advocates say there are signs that police are easing up on photographers, but that there is still much room for improvement.
article.article_text_abstract: Press advocates say there are signs that police are easing up on photographers, but that there is still much room for improvement.
article.article_image_caption: A Los Angeles Police Department officer confronting photographer Shawn Nee in 2014 for photographing an arrest. Nee was briefly detained for interference before being released without charge.
article.article_text:
Despite a series of legal victories for photographers over the right to photograph police doing their jobs, harassment and arrests have continued all over the country. Which raises the question: When will police stop viewing photographers with suspicion and hostility?

“I still hear about photographers being interfered with and/or arrested on almost a daily basis,” says Mickey Osterreicher, attorney for the National Press Photographers Association (NPPA). 

And yet, there are signs that at least some police departments are getting the message. Osterreicher has traveled to Ft. Lauderdale, Dallas, Indianapolis, San Diego, Los Angeles and other cities to lead workshops about photographers’ rights with various police departments. “Initially they’re skeptical, but by the end of the session, they get it. But taking the message to 150 officers at a time might take me three or four lifetimes” to change police/photographer dynamics nationally, he says.

American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) attorney Peter Bibring is cautiously optimistic about signs of change, at least in some places. “Anecdotally, it is a mixed bag. We know it [arrests and harassment] still happens,” he says. He recently helped San Diego photographers Shawn Nee, Greggory Moore and Shane Quentin win a $50,000 settlement against the Los Angeles County Sheriffs Department for unlawful detention while they were photographing in public places. Bibring adds that some ACLU offices around the country still report getting complaints “all the time. But others say, ‘No, things are better.’”

Los Angeles photographer Hal Bergman, a Getty contributor who specializes in images of industrial sites and infrastructure—a specialty that arouses the suspicions of law enforcement practically every time he goes out to shoot—says, “Things have improved dramatically” since he started shooting around 2007. The default response of police back then was to handcuff him and throw him in the back of a cruiser. But it has been a few years since that has happened, he says. “The tone now seems to be: Let’s have a nice conversation, and see what [the photographer] is doing.”

Bergman surmises that police respond more rationally to him at least in part because he’s changed his own behavior. He doesn’t answer suspicious officers by immediately asserting his rights. He notifies police in advance when he’s going to be photographing in areas like the port of Los Angeles. And he carries his portfolio on an iPad so he can show any suspicious police officers what he does. 

But Bergman says there’s also a lot more awareness on the part of police “that you’re allowed to be there. I think they realize [that to] investigate anyone with a camera is not an appropriate response.”

Court rulings over the past few years in favor of photographers have almost certainly had an effect. The message the courts are sending is that it may cost taxpayers a lot of money if police violate citizens’ civil rights by interfering with photographers. 

For instance, the City of Baltimore agreed in April 2014 to pay $250,000 to settle a claim of unlawful seizure and destruction of cellphone videos belonging to Christopher Sharp, who allegedly recorded police arresting and beating another person. The Baltimore Police Department also agreed to adopt a comprehensive written policy intended to protect the rights of citizens to photograph and record police activity from anywhere those citizens have a legal right to be.

Suffolk County, New York agreed in June 2014 to pay $200,000 to settle civil rights claims stemming from freelance news videographer Philip Datz’s unlawful arrest for recording police activity in 2011. Suffolk County Police Department also instituted a training program for its officers to safeguard “the constitutional right of the public and press to observe, photograph and record police activity in locations open to the public,” according to the settlement terms.

Elsewhere, the town of Weare, New Hampshire and the City of New Haven, Connecticut, agreed last year to pay $57,000 and $18,500, respectively, to settle civil rights claims of unlawful arrests of citizens taking photographs of police.

In Austin, Texas, a federal court judge rejected an argument last July that the right to photograph or videotape police officers “is not recognized as a constitutional right,” clearing the way for a citizen’s civil rights claim against the City of Austin, its police chief, and various Austin police officers. The plaintiff, Antonio Buehler, was first arrested in January 2012 for photographing a traffic stop. 

The NPPA’s Osterreicher has described the arrests of photographers in one jurisdiction after another as “a game of whack-a-mole.” But the court rulings in photographers’ favor are having an impact, he explained, because they are slowly but surely eroding the “qualified immunity” defense of police officers around the country.

The doctrine of qualified immunity protects government officials from liability for civil damages unless they violate laws or statutes that are clearly established. Osterreicher says the right to record police activity is now clearly established by court rulings in the First, Second, Fourth, Fifth, Seventh, Ninth and Eleventh circuits. (The aforementioned Texas case was a rejection of the qualified immunity defense. Texas is in the Fifth Circuit.)

The U.S. Department of Justice has also helped photographers’ cause by weighing in for citizens’ rights to record police activity, most recently in a scathing report about the operations of the Ferguson, Missouri police department. The DOJ report said Ferguson police  officers “frequently infringe on residents’ First Amendment rights, interfering with their right to record police activities and making enforcement decisions based on the content of individuals’ expression.”

The DOJ report cited several examples, and went on to recommend a series of police department reforms. One of the DOJ recommendations called for the Ferguson police department to “develop and implement policy and training regarding appropriate police response to activities protected by the First Amendment, including the right to observe, record, and protest police action.”

Previously, the DOJ had urged various courts and police departments to safeguard the free speech and due process rights of photographers, as well as their rights to protection against unlawful search and seizure. For instance, the DOJ intervened in the case of Sharp v. Baltimore Police Department by issuing a blueprint for police department reforms.

The Washington D.C. Metropolitan Police Department adopted that DOJ blueprint in 2012, to settle a right-to-photograph lawsuit filed by an aspiring photojournalist and the ACLU. In adopting the DOJ recommendations, the D.C. police department issued a general order stating that “a bystander has the right under the First Amendment to observe and record [District police officers] in the public discharge of their duties.”

Despite all those signs of progress, photographers’ advocates expect the conflict between police and photographers to continue. 

Attorney Mary Borja, who represented Sharp in his claim against Baltimore police, says: “In a post-9/11 world, there’s a lot of, ‘Well, it’s the Patriot Act,’ which is the crutch [police] use to justify improper activities that interfere with journalists doing their jobs.”

The ACLU’s Bibring also says police interference with photographers “flowed clearly from counter-terrorism training.” The message of the training has been that photography should be treated as suspicious activity, because photographers could be terrorists surveying targets. 

“We’re still seeing [photographers] getting stopped,” so the problem isn’t solved, he adds. “I don’t know what the problem is. I think it is that police really don’t like to be photographed.”

Bibring notes that even if police do get the message that citizens have a First Amendment right to photograph police activity, that right isn’t absolute. It is subject to time, manner and place restrictions that are open to interpretation by police officers. 

Specifically, police officers can order bystanders out of the way so they aren’t interfering with police activity. “There’s going to be a tension between officers asserting obstruction” and photographers asserting their rights to photograph, Bibring says. “If an officer tells a photographer, ‘Turn it off,’ that’s a clear violation of the law. But if an officer says a photographer was arrested for being too close [i.e., interfering with police activity], it becomes a he-said, she-said situation.”

Which means, of course, that tensions between police and photographers may diminish, but never completely disappear, forcing photographers to periodically defend their civil rights in court.

article.article_title: How To Light Subjects That Move
article.meta_description: How photographers and a video director light splashes, pours, car shots and video productions.
article.article_text_abstract: How photographers and a video director light splashes, pours, car shots and video productions.
article.article_image_caption: On video productions, filmmaker and educator Eduardo Angel recommends continuous lights with adjustable color temperatures for balancing mixed lighting.
article.article_text:
Photographers and video makers have shared their techniques for lighting moving subjects. Their advice covers not only how to choose lighting that can freeze a splash or capture action on location, but also advice for getting believable, consistent and cinematic lighting when working on a video production. Full interviews with these photographers, and other step-by-step details on lighting still and video productions, can be found at PDNOnline.com/features/lighting.shtml.

How I Got That Shot: Capturing Perfect Scoops of Ice Cream

Beauty and still-life photographer Lisa Shin frequently lights luxury items and cosmetics in a way that creates “sexy, dramatic shadows and glowing highlights.” For a campaign for Haagen-Dazs, creatives at Team One hired Shin to apply the same technique to shooting ice cream. The job required her to capture a pour of chocolate syrup and bring out its sheen, shooting at 1/7500 of a second. “It’s very much like photographing a shiny, metallic mascara bottle,” says Shin, who explains all the steps she took to freeze each flavor of ice cream at the proper temperature, and make sure her products didn’t melt on set. 

5 Lighting Design Tips for Video Productions 

Photographer and filmmaker Eduardo Angel shares his tips for lighting videos, including his favorite methods to maintain consistency when shooting over extended periods of time. That typically requires him to minimize the effect of the ambient, natural light on the scene; he explains how he and his crew do that.  

How Storyboarding Can Make Your Video More Cinematic

Cinematographer Ryan E. Walters says that one of the most important steps in the pre-production process leading up to a video shoot is creating a storyboard based on a careful location scout. He explains how he evaluates the light available in the location and how it might shift, and the apps he uses to map the sun at any location. This information goes into a detailed, frame-by-frame map of all the shots he needs to fully tell a story with video.

Christa Renee’s Sun-Chasing Kit

Advertising photographer Christa Renee is known for her lifestyle shoots for swimwear, travel, fashion and athletic brands. She describes the essential gear—including lights, light modifiers, lenses, plastic bags and weatherproofing—she packs for her action-filled shoots to ensure she can bring back the shots her client needs, even when a sudden downpour ruins her best-laid plans. 

Photographing a Shiny New Ferrari

Tim Damon has been an automotive photographer for 25 years, but he says being given the keys to a new Ferrari for two days with instructions from the client to take “cool pictures” was “a dream job.” In addition to making shots outdoors and in his own shooting bay, he also photographed the car in a dark parking garage that he transformed into a studio. Using multiple lights and a camera rig of his own design, he shot a long exposure that showed the contours of the car in detail, but showed the dark walls around it as a blur. That required adjusting the lighting to accommodate the car’s movement. “When you’re doing a rig shot you don’t put a light here and there,” he explains. “The only way you’re going to get it is to start doing your exposure, and then moving your lights. It sounds tedious but it’s fun.”

How I Got That Shot: Creating a Question Mark Out of Champagne

Bill Cahill has extensive experience shooting liquids and splashes. Creature in Seattle hired him to shoot an ad for the Champagne Bureau, the trade association, that required him to sculpt the effervescent liquid into the shape of a question mark. He worked with a prop maker who crafted tubing, and tested different splashes as well as lights and cards. He was most concerned with lighting the outline of the model and bringing out highlights in the droplets on the edges. He notes, “Champagne is a fairly pale color liquid. It generally just looks like bubbly water against black if you don’t light it properly.”

article.article_title: How to Find a Sponsor for Your Photo Book
article.meta_description: Photographer Jonathan Mehring turned a chance meeting with a Levi's marketing exec into a sponsorship, convincing National Geographic to publish his skateboarding book.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer Jonathan Mehring turned a chance meeting with a Levi's marketing exec into a sponsorship, convincing National Geographic to publish his skateboarding book.
article.article_image_caption: As a former staff photographer at Skateboarder magazine, Jonathan Mehring looked all over the world for his feature story backdrops. Above: Skater Michael Mackrodt executes a frontside blunt in Dong Hoi, Vietnam.
article.article_text:
Due out this month is photographer Jonathan Mehring’s first book, called Skate the World, featuring images he’s made over a period of 15 years of skateboarding in unexpected places all over the globe. The book, published by National Geographic Books with sponsorship from Levi’s, is a case study in the challenges of shaping, pitching and funding a book, as well as the importance of personal relationships—and luck.

Mehring and Susan Hitchcock, the senior editor at National Geographic Books who championed Mehring’s work, hit one obstacle after another over the five years they tried to get the book published. “I can’t believe it’s actually coming out,” Mehring says. “It’s all about relationships. It’s who you know. And a lot of it has to do with timing.”

Publication finally turned on a chance meeting Mehring had last year with Erik Wolsky, Levi’s senior global marketing manager, in La Paz, Bolivia. Trying to earn goodwill within the skater community, Levi’s was building skateparks for underprivileged skaters in places around the world. The company had hired Mehring to document a construction project in La Paz.

“Erik was there, and we were hanging out a lot,” says Mehring. “I was like, ‘This is a perfect fit. You’re trying to promote the sport. My book takes a global view, and Levi’s is taking a global view. And he was like, ‘Yeah, cool. I think it will work.’”

“That meeting between Jonathan and Erik flipped the switch in National Geographic’s book division,” Hitchcock says, “because once we know we have even a small contribution for a book, we can move forward.” 

But what a long, circuitous road it was. The idea for the book came to life in 2009, when Mehring and Hitchcock ran into each other at a party. A long-time friend of Mehring’s parents, Hitchcock says, “I’ve been watching his career develop, and he started telling me about the trips he’d been taking.”

At the time, Mehring was a staff photographer for Skateboarder magazine. He was traveling the world with pro skaters, looking for ever more out-of-the-way skating venues as backdrops for his shoots. One trip was along the Trans-Siberian Railway. Another was to Astana, the capital of Kazakhstan, which has been rebuilt since the fall of the Soviet Union with some of the world’s most outlandish architecture.

“These former communist capitals are built with a lot of granite and marble, so they’re conducive to skating,” Mehring says.

Hitchcock says that as Mehring was describing those adventures, she thought: This is a book. “There was a theme, which was skateboarding around the world, and as we got to talking, there was a message there, which was that skateboarding ends up being a universal language,” she explains. And Mehring, she adds, was going beyond skateboard action photography. “He was getting interested in the local kids he would meet in Brazil and Thailand, and how they were figuring out how to skateboard without parks and equipment that American kids have.”

She pitched the book idea back at the office. Editors invited Mehring in to present his work. He showed up with a Kodak photo paper box full of about 50 prints. “I didn’t see it as a pitch. I was clueless,” says Mehring, who was 28 or 29 at the time. “They said, ‘We’ll get back to you.’”

Hitchcock says the book needed some shaping, as well as more photographs to represent the six most populous continents. Mehring continued traveling the world for Skateboarder magazine, filling the holes. (In the end, 30 percent of the photographs were sourced from other photographers, mostly to cover skateboarding across the continent of Africa.)

But Hitchcock was having trouble getting a green light for the book. “Skateboarders don’t buy books: That was one big message I got,” she says. She also says, “I don’t think they thought of skateboarding as a  National Geographic sport. We do mountain climbing and deep sea diving.”

But as editors came and went, she kept pitching the idea. “I definitely championed it because I knew Jonathan. I also thought it was a cool thing he’s been doing for the past ten years. I love pictures of kids from all over the world with skateboards built with pieces of lumber and roller-skate wheels,” she says.

Around 2011, the idea started to get some traction inside National Geographic. But the publisher didn’t want to assume all the risk, so Hitchcock told Mehring he might improve chances of publication if he found a sponsor to help defray costs.

Hitchcock says National Geographic occasionally asks author/photographers to find sponsors for their books, and typically seeks sponsorship contributions totaling $100,000 in those cases. That amounts to “a good half of the budget” for photography books, she estimates, explaining that the costs reflect the larger dimensions and higher paper quality of photo books, compared to non-photographic books.

Mehring wasn’t given a sponsorship dollar amount, or any promises the book would be published if he did find a sponsor. But he had nothing to lose by trying. “I reached out to a couple of brands I thought might have an interest”—shoe brands in particular, he says—“and I got no response.”

Then, in 2013, he had a chance encounter with Levi’s on a trip to India with some pro skaters. “I heard that Bangalore was an up-and-coming tech center. I figured there would be new architecture, and thought it might be conducive to skating,” he says. “While I was there, [Skateboarder’s] ad guy said, ‘Levis just hit us up about advertising. They’re in Bangalore right now working on a skatepark project.’”

Mehring contacted the production company Levi’s had hired to document the project, and got hired to shoot some photographs of it for advertising, PR and social media. While he was there, he met people from the Levi’s marketing team.

“They ended up hiring me for their next project. I was enthusiastic about what they were doing, and I was into documenting the local scene and local people,” he says. That second project was in La Paz, where he met Erik Wolsky, and made his successful pitch for help with his book.

Mehring says that as part of his pitch, he offered to include positive stories in the book about a couple of the Levi’s skatepark construction projects. “Each chapter has a local story about how skating is benefitting the community,” he explains. The Levi’s projects fit the narrative.

“For me, [the book sponsorship] just made a lot of sense because a big chunk of the book would have to do with projects” for skaters at the local level, Wolsky says. The benefit for Levi’s of sponsoring Mehring’s book, he explains, “is really to take stories we’ve told already and give them a chance to be told again through a different medium, to a wider audience.” 

Levi’s didn’t ask for any editorial control over Mehring’s book, nor does National Geographic cede that to book sponsors, Hitchcock says. What Levi’s did get, however, was the reproduction of its logo on the cover of the book, a sponsor page inside, and a promise that National Geographic would mention the sponsorship in all of its promotions for the book. 

 “It really was an easy conversation [over terms],” says Wolsky. “Our brand would be there, with stories about it.”

In exchange, Levi’s committed an undisclosed sum to help defray production costs for an initial print run of 15,000 copies. Levi’s also agreed to buy several thousand of those copies for distribution in lots of 24 to more than 250 retail stores around the world that sell Levi’s skate jeans.

But there was a misunderstanding about who would pay the cost—amounting to tens of thousands of dollars—of mailing all those books to the stores, Hitchcock says. “Because shipping costs were prohibitive, that part of the deal was nixed.”

The print run was cut to 8,000 copies, and in the end, the Levi’s contribution amounted to about 10 percent of the overall production costs—”a relatively small amount of money” for sponsorship of a book, Hitchcock says.

She adds that National Geographic probably would not have published the book, had it known that Levi’s didn’t expect to covers the costs of selling the books through their retail stores. “But we still have faith in the book,” she says, noting that National Geographic’s target for book sales is 20,000 copies within two years of release.

National Geographic is handling promotion for the book, and distributing it to bookstores through an arrangement with Random House. Mehring is helping with the promotion by spreading the word by text and email to his extensive list of contacts in the skating industry. “I felt I should be involved because I personally know the people,” he says. 

Now that his book is coming out, he says he has “a lot of ideas” for other projects, including another book. But for now, he’s celebrating the book that almost wasn’t, while focusing on editorial and commercial assignments that have him shooting portraits, lifestyle, and of course, skating.

article.article_title: High Production Values and Drone Footage Elevate a Humble Video Commercial
article.meta_description: A Long Island, NY agency uses strong storytelling and dramatic aerial visuals to make a short film with slick production values.
article.article_text_abstract: A Long Island, NY agency uses strong storytelling and dramatic aerial visuals to make a short film with slick production values.
article.article_image_caption: Cinematographer William Babcock filmed the moving BMW with a Ronin gimbal stabilizer and a hitch mount built by Keith Ferriera, the key grip.
article.article_text:
The local car dealership TV spot is a staple of American advertising. A salesman in a powdered wig promoting a President’s Day blowout; an athlete or hometown hero awkwardly reciting a pre-scripted pitch; an infectiously corny jingle and bellows of, “Zero percent APR and no money down!” They are big, loud, rife with gimmicks, and yet endearing—exhibitions of local flavor even a cynic can identify with.

But as the financial requirements for high production values continue to drop, local dealerships can now mimic the sleek, luxurious look of national car advertisements. Still, even with 4K aerial footage and the use of RED cameras, a spot is only as effective as the story being told—and for a local car dealership, the regional familiarity they convey. Kyle Doyle carefully considered both as he shot The Grandmaster, a short film assigned by a Long Island BMW dealership. The film and accompanying series of spots promoting the Competition BMW dealership in Smithtown, New York, is a prime example of brand promotion through storytelling, and its success hinges on footage of Long Island’s serene North Fork. 

Doyle produced, directed and wrote the eight-minute film and the spots for Long Island marketing agency Morey Publishing, which counts Competition BMW as one of its accounts. Doyle’s short film centers on a father and daughter’s journey from the New York City borough of Queens to the edges of the rural North Fork in search of information about the father’s own father, who once beat a chess grandmaster in a local tournament.

Jon Sasala, Morey Publishing’s creative director, says the agency wasn’t interested in producing a typical spot touting prices and picturesque cars. “We wanted to generate leads through storytelling. We wanted to connect with Long Islanders and tell a story they would relate with, and hopefully get them to identify with Competition as a brand, as opposed to just thinking of them as another BMW dealer.”

The Grandmaster was Doyle’s most narrative-driven project to date. While chess — a symbol of competition — was always central to the project, Doyle retooled Morey Publishing’s initial idea (about a son skirting an awards ceremony in his honor to play chess with his father) into a road trip tale that more prominently featured the car. 

The film has a classic, cinematic feel. Cinematographer William Babcock affixed re-housed P+S Technick Super Baltars to his RED Dragon, a concession he made after being unable to find any Lomo anamorphic glass (Super Baltars were used on the first two Godfather films, and more recently, the Ron Howard Formula One film Rush). Much of the footage between the father and daughter was handheld, Doyle says, with Babcock seated on an apple box. The look is gauzy and tranquil (several sequences are in slow motion), but the slight shake of the camera grounds The Grandmaster and reinforces the impromptu nature of the trip.

The footage of the car, however, is slick and grand. For a 3/4-angle shot of the BMW speeding forward, Babcock affixed a Ronin gimbal stabilizer to the back of a lead car using a DIY hitch mount built by key grip Keith Ferriera.

“We were able to have a remote head while doing these car shots,” says Babcock. “I was in a car trailing and was able to do this move where you could maneuver the camera while it was hitched up to a car, side-mounted, or on a hostess tray.” The hostess tray, too, was crucial in a standout shot of the car pulling into the lot of the vintage Silver Sands motel as the camera swerves out the window up towards its kitschy neon sign (“Everybody was Instagram-ing that,” Doyle jokes).

But The Grandmaster’s most stunning footage came from above. Until recently, a mammoth budget and a helicopter would have been required to film the BMW darting through the Pine Barrens, or out towards the tip of a peninsula, ocean surf crashing on either side of the road. Now there are drones. 

Doyle hired Jake Salyers to operate his DJI Inspire 1. Neither Doyle nor Babcock had worked with drones before, and while Salyers had practiced all winter trailing the G and F subway trains from the roof of his Brooklyn apartment, this was his first serious gig as an operator. They planned the drone’s route and shooting angles during test shots without the car near the Pine Barrens and Orient Point, but they did not have a specific starting point or speed for the driver when they actually filmed.

“It was more, ‘Come along this stretch and I’ll catch you,’” Salyers says. The crew also battled cold and strong winds, and the Inspire 1’s batteries lasted about 20 minutes. (DJI batteries were backordered, and Salyers only had two). Luck, Salyers admits, contributed to the ultimate success of the aerial shots, but his rooftop practice came in handy during the run-and-gun shoot.

“It’s like maintaining composition on a landscape photograph, while you’re moving through it,” Salyers says of flying the Inspire 1. “There’s not such a tight, specific place that you’re trying to keep on the left third, you’re trying to maintain an elegant landscape photograph for a period of time.”

The stretches of road filmed from above were also relatively deserted, something Doyle—a native Long Islander who’s often explored the North Fork on drives with his wife—knew. Using his own familiarity with the area, and with the help of Google, Doyle was able to track down a number of quaint, quintessential Long Island locales.

“Long Island has a lot of beautiful scenery, but I think sometimes it can be overwhelming because it’s so big,” Doyle says. “And it’s not one thing. I wanted to highlight one area, not get overwhelmed with having them stop at multiple places along the entire length of Long Island, but focus it on one spot so that it felt like it was geographically centered.”

That specificity and familiarity has helped The Grandmaster, and especially its shorter spin-off spots, gain traction amongst Long Islanders. The film was also a component of Morey Publishing’s larger campaign with Competition BMW, which includes a bi-annual magazine, Checkpoint, and a website, Checkmate.CompetitionBMW.com. Jon Sasala praises the film’s high-production values, and notes the film grabbed the attention of the higher-ups at BMW, impressed with the branch’s initiative.

“I wanted to make sure that it was familiar enough to say, ‘Oh I’ve been there,’ or ‘I’ve passed that place,’” Doyle says. “I wanted it to feel not too far away where the audience would feel, ‘Oh I’ve never been there,’ but not too close where it was overly familiar. I wanted it to be some place where they would aspire to take a road trip.”

article.article_title: You've Published Your Photo Book. Now How Do You Market It?
article.meta_description: Interviews with publishing veterans who share their advice on how to effectively distribute and market photo books.
article.article_text_abstract: Interviews with publishing veterans who share their advice on how to effectively distribute and market photo books.
article.article_image_caption: “Walls 11”, from Barcelona by Janelle Lynch, who worked with a publicist to attract press coverage of the book.
article.article_text:
Photographers who publish a book need to market it. That’s true whether you decide to self-publish your book—acting as your own distribution and marketing team—or work with a book publisher. Many publishing contracts stipulate that the photographer has to purchase a certain number of copies, which means that unless you can actively promote your book, you’re likely to end up with a few hundred copies piled in your garage. Having a marketing plan is helpful in other ways: Book editors are more likely to publish a photobook if the photographer understands the potential audience for the book and can organize gallery shows, book signings or other events that will attract buyers. 

A number of veterans of the book publishing business—including many photographers who have self-published books successfully—have shared their advice on how to effectively distribute and market photo books. The articles listed here are available at PDNOnline.com to subscribers. 

WHAT BOOKSTORES BUY

PDN surveyed buyers for five independent bookstores around the country—including stores that specialize in art and photography books, and some with large and respected photography sections. They explain the many factors that influence what they stock and how they display books within their stores. These include the idiosyncrasies of their customer base, the reputation of the photographer, positive reviews, gift appeal and even the color of the book’s cover. Bob Contant, co-owner of New York’s St. Mark’s Bookshop, describes the books that have turned into perennial favorites, while Cathy Langer, buyer at Tattered Cover in Seattle, names some unexpected bestsellers that she wishes she’d purchased in higher volume. 

HOW (AND WHY) TO HAND-MAKE YOUR PHOTO BOOK

Fine artists like Lauren Henkin have found that turning bodies of work into hand-crafted artist’s books has helped them expand the audience for their work by reaching a new base of collectors. “Producing handmade books gives photographers the ability to quickly build and extend their audience beyond the photographic community—to university libraries and rare book and art collectors interested in handmade objects. It can also increase a photographer’s exhibition opportunities,” Henkin writes. In this article, she explains the steps she took to publicize and distribute her book, Displaced, through book festivals and portfolio reviews. 

WHAT CAN A PUBLICIST DO FOR YOU?

Photographers are hiring publicists to perform the tasks that small book publishers or photo galleries don’t have the staff or time to handle. “I’m often working with photographers who are working with smaller publishers,” says publicist Kate Greenberg. At independent publishing houses, Greenberg notes, “There isn’t a whole machine in place” to manage all contact with the press. To meet publications’ deadlines, publicists expect photographers to supply photos and captions as soon as possible, and then make themselves available for interviews. Photographer Janelle Lynch says working with a publicist helped generate “significantly more online press and announcements,” and adds, “I think that anything in that regard has a potential to help promote not just a book, but a career.” 

HOW TO BE YOUR OWN PUBLICIST

Photographers who want to save money on their publicity campaigns can often find freelance publicists willing to work on an hourly basis just to brainstorm ideas for organizing newsworthy events or to think of some publications to contact. But for those photographers willing to put considerable time, effort and energy into running a publicity campaign on their own, PDN asked professional publicists for suggestions on how to research press contacts, plan a calendar, write a press release and follow up with contacts. 

PHOTOGRAPHERS SHARE THE DETAILS OF THEIR RECENT BOOK DEALS

How many books will you need to sell? That may depend on the deal you are able to negotiate with the publisher, as well as the size of your print run. Take a look at the arrangements photographers have made in the last two years with their book publishers, and see how many required that the photographers purchase between 30 and 400 copies of the book.

article.article_title: Pioneering Photographer Barbara Crane on Women in Photography
article.meta_description: Pioneering Photographer Barbara Crane on Women in Photography
article.article_text_abstract: "The matriarch of Chicago photography" discusses the camaraderie she finds at a women’s photo group, and how attitudes towards women in fine-art have (and haven’t) changed during her remarkable career.
article.article_image_caption: “Inner Circles,” 2004, by Barbara Crane, who had her first solo gallery exhibition in the late 1960s. Her awards include two National Endowment for the Arts grants and a Guggenheim Fellowship.
article.article_text:
Of the many groups formed to support women photographers, one of the newest is Chicago Women in Photography (See “Women Photographers Find Strength In Numbers."). It has attracted photographers with a variety of experience, from relative newcomers to established professionals. Among the latter is Barbara Crane, described as “the matriarch of Chicago photography” by one of CWIP’s organizers.

A winner of a Guggenheim Fellowship in 1979, Crane has exhibited internationally, and her work is in the permanent collections of the Amon Carter Museum, George Eastman House, the High Museum and other institutions. She says she attended CWIP’s first gathering for the fellowship it offered. “It was exhilarating to go to that meeting with so many women photographers,” says Crane. Making art requires time alone and can be isolating, she says. “I thought it was very reinforcing and invigorating to meet other women who are very involved in their work.” 

Crane notes that women now outnumber men in MFA programs, a dramatic change from when she studied with Aaron Siskind at the Institute of Design at the Illinois Institute of Technology. “Aaron always talked about his ‘guys.’ I was not one of the guys,” she says. When she joined the faculty of the School of the Art Institute of Chicago in 1967,  “it was pretty much an all-male department.” 

At a speaking engagement years ago, an audience member asked Crane what it was like to work in a male-dominated field. “My answer was truthful but a bit guarded. I said I tried not to be preoccupied by that because I thought it would hurt my work.” Like many women in a workforce surrounded by men, she felt she had to conceal personal details as well as personal feelings. Crane, who raised three children, says, “You didn’t dare talk about your children.” Women were “scrutinized” more than their male colleagues. Crane describes herself as “pretty direct,” but adds, “You had better not be ‘a bitch,’ because that’s what women who were highly motivated were called.” When she brought her work to gallery owners, “I would wear the plainest, most severe suits to look businesslike. I would do anything to avoid giving mixed signals.” She explains, “It was all about having them deal with my work.” 

With more women curators, gallery directors and faculty chairs, the culture has changed, Crane says: “You don’t have to worry about what you wear so much.”  However, most exhibitions still feature men, “or if they’re group shows, there are more men than women,” she says. “It’s discouraging that it still goes on, but things certainly have gotten better.”

Related: End Frame: Remembering Mary Ellen Mark

article.article_title: Stabilizer Roundup: 14 Tripods, Rigs and Gimbals to Steady Your Hand
article.meta_description: Though tripod tech has only seen incremental improvements, camera gimbals have experienced a surge in innovation as electronics bring formerly difficult—or impossible—shots within reach of first-time and independent filmmakers.
article.article_text_abstract: Though tripod tech has only seen incremental improvements, camera gimbals have experienced a surge in innovation as electronics bring formerly difficult—or impossible—shots within reach of first-time and independent filmmakers.
article.article_text:
The development of photography is intimately bound with the development of support gear (those camera obscura were back-breaking). And while tripod technology doesn’t advance at the pace of Moore’s Law, incremental improvements continue. What’s more, the era of DSLR and mirrorless filmmaking has ushered in a surge of innovation around camera gimbals, as sophisticated electronics bring formerly difficult—or downright impossible—handheld shots into the reach of first-time and independent filmmakers. 

TRIPODS


Benro S7 Video Tripod Kit

The S7 kit includes a video head with a 75mm bowl adapter and a flat base for mounting on sliders and jibs. It offers a four-step counterbalance to keep heavy gear (up to 15.4 pounds) properly aligned. You can dial in resistance for both panning and tilting motions so you can achieve the desired amount of tension for a given camera movement. The included panning handle can be mounted on either side of the head, which has a tilt range of -50 through +90 degrees and a bubble level. The S7 tripod has a maximum height of 63 inches and a minimum height of 11 inches. The feet use interchangeable rubber or spiked inserts. The aluminum version of the tripod weighs in at 8.5 pounds, while the carbon fiber edition sheds a pound.

Price: $399 (aluminum); $599 (carbon fiber)

Info: www.benrousa.com

Libec Allex H+S Kit

The Allex is the transformer of tripod kits, delivering both a conventional pan-and-tilt fluid head and a slider in one modular package. The Allex kit includes a 75mm aluminum bowl tripod with three leg sections and a mid-level spreader that telescopes out to the full width. You can extend the Allex to 59 inches or collapse it to 23.5 inches. The head supports payloads up to 9 pounds, can pan in a full 360 degrees and tilt at a +90/-80 degree angle with a handle that can be attached to rosette adapters on either the left or right side of the head. It has an integrated LED-illuminated bubble level too. The final piece of the kit is a 28-inch slider with eight ball bearings to allow for gentle movement across the rail. 

Price: $675

Info: www.libec-global.com/allex

Davis and Sanford Traverse Carbon TR654C-36 

An economical option for still photographers, the Traverse has four leg sections and three independent leg angles for composing your shot. The legs sport foam grips and the rubberized feet have interchangeable spikes for securing the tripod on rougher ground. The center post has a hook for hanging extra weight—you can remove it entirely and replace it with a shorter center post (included) if you’re shooting close to the ground. The Traverse ships with an Arca-Swiss quick release plate and can bear a 12-pound load. It offers a maximum height of 65 inches, a minimum height of 9 inches and folds down to 18.5-inches.

Price: $170

Info: tiffen.com/davis-sanford


Manfrotto 190 Go!

The new aluminum-based 190 Go! is the lightest and most compact member of Manfrotto’s 190 series—and judging by the punctuation, the most excitable too. It’s also the first with twist leg locks that let you open or close all sections of the tripod at once with a single turn of your wrist. The 190 Go! weighs 3.75 pounds, extends to 57.48 inches and collapses down to 17.7 inches when it’s time to pack up and go. It employs Manfrotto’s 90-degree center column, which can be lifted out of the tripod’s top casting and swung into the horizontal position without removing either the tripod head or camera. There are four leg angle options and an Easy Link attachment that lets you connect accessories, like LED lights, that have a 3/8-inch male adapter.

Price: $199

Info: www.manfrotto.us


Sirui W-2204 

When the going gets tough, or wet, Sirui’s W-2204 can keep you going. A series of waterproof rings keeps water from seeping into the tripod’s legs. According to Sirui, the tripod is built from many of the same waterproof and leak-proof materials used in the automotive industry. The tripod’s rubber feet can be swapped out for stainless steel spikes and one leg can be detached as a monopod. There’s a hook beneath the center column for a weight bag for extra stability and a bubble level on the tripod head to guide alignment. The W-2204 extends to 70.9 inches and folds down to 20.5 inches. It can keep up to 39.7 pounds of gear aloft but, thanks to its carbon fiber build, only weighs 3.7 pounds.

Price: $535

Info: argraph.com

MeFoto RoadTrip

Tripods have many virtues, but a sharp sense of style isn’t usually one of them. MeFoto’s RoadTrip injects a bit of panache into the category with a build-your-own option that lets you customize your model with interchangeable colored legs, heads, shoulders and center columns. You have 12 colors to choose from that can be used in up to 792 combinations—enough to satisfy even the most eclectic tastes. No matter your color, the RoadTrip extends up to 61.6 inches and can keep 17.6 pounds of camera and lens in the air. It has two leg angle positions and a recessed center column hook for adding stabilizing weights. The aluminum version weighs 3.6 pounds while the carbon fiber edition weighs 3.1 pounds. The RoadTrip has a removable leg that you can combine with the center column to form a monopod, and a colorful one at that. 

Price: $199 (aluminum); $349 (carbon fiber)

Info: www.mefoto.com

Vanguard VEO 265

The VEO 265 tripod features a rapid column rotation that lets you quickly fold up the tripod when it’s time to hit the road. It offers adjustable leg locks with three different angles and five leg sections with a max height of 59 inches. The tripod ships with a ball head and an Arca-Swiss-compatible quick release plate and interchangeable feet (rubber or spikes). An included adapter lets you collapse the tripod down to 7.3 inches for macro shots or unusual angles. The VEO 265 can support up to 17.6 pounds of camera gear. 

Price: $180 (aluminum); $280 (carbon fiber)

Info: www.vanguardworld.com

Really Right Stuff TVC-34

The big challenge in using the TVC-34 isn’t carrying the 4.4-pound carbon fiber tripod around, but finding enough gear that can actually make it break a sweat. The TVC-34 can hold up to 50 pounds of gear and has the highest stiffness-to-load ratio of any of the company’s carbon fiber tripods. You can extend the TVC-34 to 58.4 inches tall or contract it down to 3.9 inches. It folds up into a carry-on friendly 21.2 inches. It uses Really Right Stuff’s 100mm video bowl adapter and leveling base accessories. 

Price: $995 

Info: www.reallyrightstuff.com

Rigs & Gimbals


BeeWorks BW05

The BeeWorks BW05 is a lightweight, three-axis stabilizer that’s just as easily mounted to a wall or tabletop as it is placed in the hands of a camera operator. It features internal HDMI cabling so you can feed camera video to a separate monitor mounted to the handlebars. It’s light, too, at just over 4 pounds, and can mount mirrorless cameras like the Panasonic GH4 or Sony’s A7 series. The BW05 kit includes a stand, handlebar, mini ball head monitor mount, battery and charger. The optional $999 Kinetic remote lets you control the BW05 through gestures when the gimbal isn’t in your hands, wirelessly transmitting your motion to the BW05. You can even adjust the sensitivity of the BW05 gimbal to your Kinetic remote movements to mimic the impact of heavier or ?lighter cameras.

Price: $2,999

Info: www.beeworksgear.com

DJI Ronin M

The Ronin M is a slimmed down, less-expensive and more approachable version of the original Ronin. It weighs just 5 pounds—half the weight of the original—but can support cameras up to 8 pounds, thanks to a new magnesium frame. You mount your DSLR or video camera and the gimbal balances itself, ensuring that your camera stays steady even as you move about. The M offers three shooting positions—briefcase, upright and underslung—for framing a variety of shots plus a silent mode that reduces the sound of the motors when you need to go stealth. The M’s settings can be remotely adjusted via Bluetooth and a mobile device. The battery is good for up to six hours of use. When you’re done, you can twist off the top handles to shrink down the M for transport.

Price: $1,399

Info: www.dji.com

Freefly Systems MōVI with Mimic

Freefly’s MVI M10 and M5 gimbals are among the most sophisticated you can operate, so it’s perhaps no surprise that the company’s next move took aim at simplifying the popular product. The new Mimic controller, available either as a free firmware upgrade to the existing MōVI controller or as kit with wireless transmitter and carbon fiber handlebars, lets a second operator remotely control a MōVI with just their movements. Rather than move the camera through a joystick or knobs, the Mimic instantly translates your movement into camera movement, positioning the MōVI-mounted camera in whatever direction you desire. It can communicate via line of sight with a MōVI from up to 1,200 feet away.

Price: $7,995 (M10); $3,995 (M5 Adventure Edition); $550 (Mimic controller)

Info: freeflysystems.com

G-Rig Valos

The Valos is a three-axis gimbal that can keep up to 13 pounds of camera gear stabilized thanks to its four motors. It draws power from a single V-mount battery and thanks to its integrated power distribution system, it can power your camera and other accessories as well. Thanks to built-in Bluetooth, the Valos can be remotely controlled from Android or iOS devices and it ships with a wireless remote control as well. A fully loaded, ready-to-film Valos weighs 9.26 pounds.

Price: $11,900

Info: www.g-rig.com

Zacuto Universal Indie Recoil Rigs

Want to position your DSLR or mirrorless camera like an ENG camera? Zacuto’s Universal Indie Recoil properly balances the camera for shoulder-fired shooting. The Indie Recoil rig is built around the VCT Universal baseplate with a built-in shoulder pad and removable, extendable 6.5-inch iris rods. It includes a quick-release riser to lift your camera up to accommodate a matte box. The rig features a fully articulating hand grip with space to add Zacuto’s Tornado grip (pictured here but sold separately). A half-cage rail sports plenty of accessory mounts and connects to the baseplate via a 3-inch Z-rail. A monitor and/or EVF, pictured here, are sold separately.

Price: $1,600

Info: www.zacuto.com

Steadicam Solo

With a name like “Solo” this Steadicam might be mistaken for a one-trick pony, but in fact, it’s two products in one—a traditional Steadicam that can be used with an optional sled, arm and vest, or a monopod that telescopes out to shoulder length. The Solo features an adjustable three-axis gimbal, weighs 4.3 pounds and supports up to 10 pound of camera gear. You can balance the Solo in Steadicam-mode at any length, so you can extend the stabilizer high over your head for difficult angles or bring it close to the ground and skim the floor.

Price: $349 (Solo); $999 (arm and vest kit, Solo not included)

Info: tiffen.com/steadicam
