article.article_title: Can Photographers Be Engaged Fathers and Have Successful Careers, Too?
article.meta_description: Is a photography career compatible with parenting? We asked some dads this question (for a change).
article.article_text_abstract: Is a photography career compatible with parenting? We asked some dads this question (for a change).
article.article_image_caption: Matt Eich with his two daughters.
article.article_text:
When we asked photographer Maggie Steber if women photographers have more flexibility than they once did to have both a family and a career [in our September issue], she challenged us to ask that question of men. 

“Men have a lot to say about it,” Steber said. So we asked several US-based photographers, and indeed they had much to say. Here’s what they told us. 

ALAN CHIN

Brooklyn, NY

One daughter, aged 18 months

I would say that it would have been hard to be both the kind of father I want to be with the kind of photographer I used to be—and would still want to be: the constantly-on-the-road, bang-bang guy--but the work dried up before I ever had a child. So, these days, yes, [fatherhood and work are] compatible, because there's just less work.

I feel very lucky. I had a very good career for when I was very young. I had a hot 10 years between the ages of 25 and 35. I got to do a lot of the things that I always wanted to do. I got the tail end of the days when you could be a globe-trotting photographer. [Publications] would fly you business class on assignments. 

The one thing I have given up, for the moment, is the ability to base myself somewhere where's there's both more work and a low cost of living, which I would be doing if it weren't for parenthood. For example, somewhere like Kiev, Cairo or Guangzhou, all places where there's actually more demand than supply of quality photojournalism and writing.

But I am a native New Yorker, and I want my daughter to have a good childhood. We have very good services here — great schools, great daycare, great parks. It would be hard to get this quality of services somewhere else for so little money. 

If I didn’t have to make a living, and if I had an unlimited amount of money, I would be very happy to not work very much. I could do what a lot of traditionally higher income family mothers do. I’m not saying that there aren’t aspects of [stay-at-home parenting] that I find very troubling. But on a certain level, I really enjoy spending the day with my daughter. 

In an ideal, fantasy world, I’d be with her all of the time.

One thing I’ve also learned is that for men, it’s a luxury to even think about becoming a full-time parent. Even if I did decide to stay home with my daughter, I’d know I was only doing it for a finite amount of time. Once they’re at school, they’re at school. For a man, it’s a lot easier to rejoin the workforce after three or four years. Women can’t necessarily do that.

My partner and I have our daughter in daycare 4 days a week. But sometimes she’s with me. For example, I have an assignment this weekend for the New York Times real estate section. I’ll probably take the baby with me.

Even though she can walk and scream, having her on set makes the shoot better. People are not threatened by a photographer with a child. When you represent the New York Times or Time, it can be intimidating. But with a child on set, people start laughing so much. The only problem is that you have to get them to stop being goofy. But that’s a good problem to have.

Most jobs, you can’t have your child on set. You’re on a deadline, or you’re traveling. But certainly for a small percentage where it’s local and relatively relaxed, it’s possible.

MATT EICH

Charlottesville, Virginia 

Two daughters, aged 3 and 8

It helps that my wife is not a photographer or an artist and holds a normal job with normal-ish hours. [She’s a speech pathologist in the public school system.] My world as a freelancer is relative chaos where I don't know month-to-month if I will have any work or too much work to handle.

I was [talking] with young “successful” photographers in a group earlier this year. Every single one of us had someone in our life with a stable job. This is kind of the reason that I can fuck around and make art. It’s very difficult for people when both folks are artists.

My wife and I end up bringing in about the same amount each year, though much of my income goes directly back into personal work. When I am home from assignments and MFA studies [at the University of Hartford], I do my best to be available to help out with everything I can, whether its picking up kids, doing dinner, bedtime, etc. so that Melissa can catch up on work. When I am gone she functions as a working single mother, so I have total admiration for her and feel the need to repay this to the best of my ability.

As the kids get older it becomes more painful to be away, and more taxing on my wife as she juggles their individual needs and her full-time job. This has necessitated a shift in my work and my life and is part of what led me to an MFA program. My hope is that I can begin teaching as a baseline income and accepting select assignments in order to be home more. In this scenario I would give up traveling and wandering the country on a whim in exchange for some semblance of stability.

That initial joy I derived from being a freelance photographer is no longer there. It’s counteracted by a sense of guilt. “I shouldn’t be here, I should be somewhere else.” Damned if you do, damned if you don’t. If I’m at home, I know I should be pitching so I can go make some money.

I’ve been putting everything I have into the work for 10 years – it’s not enough to sustain a family, or to justify such a sacrifice. A lot of the people I admire manage to balance careers as teachers and artists. It requires a specific kind of focus not to get too sucked into whatever system you’re a part of so that it detracts from the work.

CHIP LITHERLAND

Sarasota, Florida 

Two daughters, aged 7 and 13

Right now I’m the primary breadwinner — my wife is a freelance photographer as well. We worked on the staff of the Herald Tribune in Sarasota, Florida, for about a decade together. I left the paper and went freelance about 5 years ago. She stayed on at the newspaper and kept the insurance while I got my business off the ground. Then, about a year and a half ago, she left the newspaper as well. She helps me run my business, and does the financials.

While she was still at the newspaper, I was the one watching our youngest daughter. She was a toddler. I pretty much had to be on the whole time. From 9-5 I was a stay-at-home dad and at night, I was a freelance photographer, trying to build a business. I took a lot of client phone calls while keeping my eye on my daughter through the window.

I’ve made a really conscious decision to take jobs that are really worth it. I don’t really go after low paying jobs anymore.  I don’t want to be away from my kid for a couple of hundred dollars. If that means I have to work fewer days per year, then I’m ok with that. Before I take a job, I usually have a conversation with my wife. We discuss: “Is it something that will push the business forward? Then yes, let’s do it.”

I usually travel three to four times a month. On average, five to ten nights, I’m in a hotel. A lot of the time the travel is just in Florida. In June, I was gone for three weeks. My wife and the kids took a vacation while I was gone. They went to visit grandma and grandpa. Sometimes my wife comes along with me on shoots to assist on lighting. We’ll connect in a city where my parents are so they can take care of the kids. It’s a group effort for my entire family. 

I don’t see it as the man must go out and work. If my wife told me she wanted to go off for two months, I would be totally supportive. I would not accept work during that time. I absolutely feel like we’re both partners. We fully support each other’s craft. We have to kind of go with the punches.

BENJAMIN LOWY

Northern New Jersey

Two sons, aged 4 and 6

Is my career as a photojournalist compatible with fatherhood? It just depends. You have to decide, are you a responsible parent, or are you a photographer who also wants to be a responsible parent? 

Some things have definitely changed. I am not running off to Syria anymore – or in general running after breaking news events in the same way as the past. I don’t have the kind of lifestyle where I’m sleeping on a couch. I have a house in New Jersey, a mortgage, and a gym membership. I take my kids to soccer practice.

When I met my wife, she was also working as a photojournalist. Her name is Marvi Lacar. She doesn’t do as much travel editorial work anymore. She made a decision that she didn’t want to [pursue assignments] in the same way that I do. We came to the conclusion that if I was going to keep on working with the same high profile assignments, one of the things that I wouldn’t do are personal projects. If someone isn’t sending me to Libya, I’m not going there. 

I take projects based on how much money they pay. I try to take the assignments I get, and make them my own. For example, I was sent by Harper’s Magazine to cover the Sochi Olympics. While I was there, I was able to produce work I'm happy with. 

I’ve definitely also had to branch out into doing other things besides straight photojournalism.  

Marvi and I have started directing television commercials together. I find the joy is still there when I can use my ability to make an image speak. I can get that in many different ways. It’s the experience of doing it that I love. 

I still want to cover the refugee crisis in Syria. It’s the drive in my soul. I’m sure if I went, I could pick up assignments from publications. But it’s a gamble I’ve sort of been unwilling to take.

I’ve definitely lost some opportunities. There was a client recently who wanted to send me to Afghanistan for a fairly dangerous assignment. It seemed dangerous for the sake of being dangerous. It wasn’t for me. They never called me again. I've been doing a lot of adventure work as a way to get that passion I used to get from conflict photography. That adventure is the same, but it’s much safer. 

RUDDY ROYE

Brooklyn, NY 

Two sons, aged 7 and 10

I see myself as a parent first. Photography is how I feed my family, and further down the road, how I feed my soul [such as with projects on Instagram], but first and foremost I am a dad.

I didn’t expect this at all. I thought I could take a couple of months off then run back to photography. But it has not been like that. If you tell yourself that you want to be a parent then there must be an opportunity cost [ie, a sacrifice]. 

I think I might fit different criteria than some of my peers because I don’t get as many assignments. My sacrifice is making my sons [who are 10 and 7] feel like what their dad is going through does not need to be their story. I do that by being present for them. I support all their dreams and I tell them the truth. 

My wife is an assistant principal. I spent the first three years of my eldest son’s life at home because we couldn’t afford daycare. That was difficult. But I prefer to miss assignments rather than moments in my children’s lives. What I have done recently is try to find work between dropping my boys off at 8am and picking them back up at 3pm.

I see a lot of fathers in the park at all hours of the day, which tells me more dads are staying home. I have no idea why this is, all I know is being a dad first has allowed me the distraction--or better yet, the space--where I can recoup my pride and maintain my sanity.

Related Articles: Photographer Maggie Steber on Women, Minorities and How to Nurture Talent

Ruddy Roye on Instagram, Storytelling and Risking the “Angry Black Man” Label

article.article_title: Create Spotlight: Al Jazeera America's Long-Form Photo Essays
article.meta_description: PDN speaks to Mark Rykoff, the director of photography for Al Jazeera America's website, about how the site finds, assigns and showcases photo essays.
article.article_text_abstract: PDN speaks to Mark Rykoff, the director of photography for Al Jazeera America's website, about how the site finds, assigns and showcases photo essays.
article.article_image_caption: From Carolyn Drake’s story about a public bus in Birmingham, Alabama, that serves only to drive housekeepers to a wealthy suburb.
article.article_text:
The website of the TV network Al Jazeera America, publishes breaking news, in-depth reporting, and photo-heavy features on a variety of national and international topics. PDN asked director of photography Mark Rykoff about how he and deputy photo editor Vaughn Wallace find, assign and showcase photo essays. 

Rykoff has more than 25 years of experience in the photo industry. He worked at TIME magazine—putting in four years at its Moscow bureau—and oversaw the picture desk of the TIME website from 2007–2011.

He has worked in book publishing with Against All Odds Productions, managing the photography for the books The Human Face of Big Data and A Day in the Life of China. He joined Al Jazeera America in 2013.

PDN: Who’s the audience for the website? 

Mark Rykoff: I think it’s a diverse set of people. We’ve written about a wide range of topics, and what we’ve learned about the Internet is that topics find their niche. For example, we’ve developed a big audience among Native Americans because we’ve written often about Native American communities. We did a story about the delta of Mississippi where the blues originated, and how that’s become tourist-ified and who’s making money from it. It got picked up by musician Buddy Guy, who posted it on Facebook, so we reached people who didn’t know we existed. We’re hoping to find audience members in places outside the media bubbles on the coasts. 

PDN: How is the website related to the Al Jazeera America network?

MR: Al Jazeera came into the American market two years ago and bought Current TV, Al Gore’s old network, with the goal of bringing the Al Jazeera style of journalism to American soil. Like every TV station these days, they needed a website, but they quickly understood that in the American market a website that just mimics the TV station doesn’t help build an audience. From the beginning we were operating independently of the station. It’s a different medium, and they realized the needs of a Web story and the needs of a TV story are different.

We try to complement each other. We might say to the TV side: We are working on this story that might be interesting for you, and the photographer may be able to provide video, then the television side might use it. Or, they’ll say: We’re going out to pursue a story and we’ll provide written text that might go on the website.

PDN: You run a lot of long photo essays on the site. How do they support the editorial mission?

MR: When we started here, they presented to us an editorial ethos, what we call the DNA of Al Jazeera: straightforward news journalism without a lot of celebrity coverage. They also wanted people to watch the network, so they said we don’t want a lot of videos available on the website. For visuals, that meant we were going to need a lot of photography. I was the lucky soul who was tasked with finding that. At first I was the only photo editor on an organization chart of 60 people working on the website. I pushed to provide photojournalism that matched that editorial ethos. 

When I thought, “How do I do this?” I took inspiration from LIFE magazine from the 1950s: Straightforward storytelling photography, stories that have a beginning, a middle and an end, stories with a human interest at the center of them. I should add that the idea was to do that in color on a digital platform.

A phrase that’s used around here often is that the editorial content is giving voice to the voiceless, so the subjects of the stories would be people in America whose voices aren’t often heard in the media.

That ethos guided the look I described and the decisions about the photographers I hired. I’ve worked in photojournalism for a long time, both at TIME and working with Rick Smolan to photo edit the Day in the Life of books. I had a huge Rolodex of photographers who can work in that style. 

I’m now joined at the photo desk by Vaughn Wallace, who came from TIME, and he has brought another, younger batch of photographers. We’ve developed what I think is a pretty distinctive look. 

PDN: The design of the website displays photo essays well.

MR: One of the nice things about working here is that we’re small and very nimble. When I first brought in some of the photo essays, the team here said that we need to make space for this. So they designed templates to display photography well. The photo-rich stories you’ve seen are on a layout that uses Tarbell, an open-source publishing tool designed by David Eads, who used to be at the Chicago Tribune and now builds news applications for NPR Visuals. We like working with Tarbell so much we have photos of Ida Tarbell around the newsroom. 

Carolyn Drake’s story, “The Route of Division of a Birmingham Bus” [about a bus line in Birmingham, Alabama that carries housekeepers from a poor black neighborhood to a wealthy white suburb] was displayed on a Tarbell template with some additional coding because the photographer shot medium-format and the Tarbell template was designed to accommodate 35mm.

Vaughn brought that story in, and when he first showed it to me, I liked meeting those ladies and I liked hearing their stories. It’s a very human story. 

PDN: Do you think medium-format helped that story?

MR: When we first started we were trying for a traditional photojournalistic look, which is typically 35mm. But now that we’ve established our visual identity, Vaughn and I are trying to expand the vocabulary without losing the vision of storytelling. Vaughn recently worked with a photographer, Danielle Villasana, on a piece about arsenic poisoning in wells in Peru. We liked the story and thought if you go out to do a story in the Peruvian Andes, it’ll look interesting. While she was there, she also wanted to try some double-exposure portraits and we thought that was cool. You can’t see the poison in the water, so the portraits were a way of adding a narrative layer.

PDN: A lot of documentary photographers are trying to expand the vocabulary of their medium, it seems. 

MR: Many of them are doing all kinds of interesting things. We get pitches from photographers shooting in many different styles. As an editor at a news organization, I have to ask: Is this the best way to tell the story? Is it appropriate to the story we want to tell? We’re trying to stay true to a very straightforward newsgathering ethos.

PDN: How much of the photography you publish is assigned, and how much of it is from completed projects the photographer has submitted?

MR: There are a lot of day-to-day, breaking-news stories we’re working on, too. But in terms of the photo-rich stories, we find them in different ways. An interesting thing about working in this newsroom that’s been a great experience for me is that we do some things the traditional way: The editors send a writer to a place and say, “Do you want to send a photographer along?” 

We’ve also had photographers bring us ideas. Many of the photo-heavy stories you see on the site originated with the photo desk. For example, “The Rat Tribe of Beijing,” the story about Beijing basement dwellers: Sim Chi Yin brought that to us, and we helped her find a writer she was comfortable working with. 

About 25 percent of the stories come from a photographer saying, “I’ve been working on this project, I have a few pictures. Would you be interested in taking it to the next stage?” A smaller percentage are already completed, shot and captioned. I have called the photographer and said, “We’d like to run the story but we’d like the voice of the subjects: Can you put us in touch with them?” We would send a writer later to follow in the photographer’s footsteps.

PDN: How do you like to edit? 

MR: I like to get as much material from the photographer as possible. If you want to send 1,000 photos, I’m happy to go through them. They give me a better sense of what the story is and the context in which it happened. And I’ve found that photographers are not the best editors of their own work; there are photos they haven’t sent because they have some personal issue with them but they work well with the story. I’ll pass back an edit of 50 or 60 images and say, “What do you think?”

PDN: I know many people who turn to Al Jazeera for international reporting, and you seem to run a lot of overseas stories. 

MR: At Al Jazeera America we look for stories in America. We have a sister site based in Qatar that has [international] expertise and we can link to them. But quite frequently we get overseas stories that we think will interest the American audience. Monique Jaques contacted me from her base in Istanbul and said, “There’s this Miss Muslimah pageant happening in a week in Indonesia.” We huddled the editors and they greenlighted it in a minute, then they scrambled to find a writer in Indonesia. That story found a huge audience, so that was the right instinct. 

Glenna Gordon is awesome. She pitched us a story about a 14-year-old Nigerian who had been forced into marriage and was accused of murdering her husband. She contacted us exactly when were discussing how to cover forced marriages of underage brides. She also did a story for us about the training of the Liberian army. 

PDN: You seem to have worked with a lot of women photographers. 

MR: Tara Todras-Whitehill did a story about how many women were elected mayor in their villages in Turkey during the country’s previous elections. She pitched and executed beautifully a story about a workshop to inspire tech startups in Gaza, and the winners of its competition. 

Kate Brooks did a story about the human toll of rhino poaching. A kind of mafia has formed in South Africa to provide protection for the poachers and get their goods out. She’s very interested in the poaching problem. 

Katie Orlinsky has done a few stories for us out of Alaska. And very early on, before the mass kidnapping of students in Guerrero, Mexico, she did a story about how villagers were forming militias to defend themselves against drug lords. She captures the spirit of people in a straightforward manner and she’s got a great storytelling sense. 

I love Toni Greaves in Portland, Oregon. She has a wonderful way with people. 

PDN: You seem to work repeatedly with certain photographers. Are you looking for new photographers?

MR: Always. 

PDN: How do you look for them? 

MR: We get agencies calling us. There are cases where I have a story in Coeur d’Alene, Idaho, and I start digging around on Wonderful Machine, Blink, Photoshelter, even Lightstalkers. We get a lot of things over the transom, and I like to keep track of people in unusual locations. I get a lot of pitches from Bangkok and Istanbul, but if I’m contacted by someone in Burkina Faso, I’ll make a note of it.

PDN: How should photographers in Burkina Faso contact you?

MR: “Hi, I’m in Burkina Faso.” They list the media outlets they’ve worked for or send a sample of their work. 

PDN: What makes a good story pitch?

MR: First of all, it fits our editorial ethos. It’s about something in the news but under-reported. It has human interest and it has a beginning, middle and end. And it gives you a handle on what the photographer will see in the field. You get some pitches that are very theoretical and you think: What will you photograph? 

PDN: What makes a bad pitch? 

MR: We get a lot of what we call typologies: “Ten portraits of homeless people.” They’re beautiful, but we need some way to contextualize them. A standalone portfolio like that doesn’t work for us. 

PDN: Can you explain to our readers where you draw the line between keeping you up to date on new work, and stalking you?

MR: I may not respond to an email right away, but I read every email that comes in my inbox, whether it’s “Here’s a shoot I did for Texas Monthly” or “I’ll be traveling to” a certain place.

Related: David Burnett on His Decisive Moment with Abe Lincoln

article.article_title: Maia Flore's Fantastical Images Explore Photography and Memory
article.meta_description: The photographer stages and composites photographs that hint at alternate realities, and toys with photography’s association with reality to encourage viewers to suspend their disbelief.
article.article_text_abstract: The photographer stages and composites photographs that hint at alternate realities, and toys with photography’s association with reality to encourage viewers to suspend their disbelief.
article.article_image_caption: Though Flore uses herself as the model in her photographs, she’s careful to obscure her face so viewers might relate more easily to the work. Above: “Where the Sky Begins,” 2015.
article.article_text:
In her quirky, surrealist scenes depicting a female character, Maia Flore hints at entire worlds beyond the grasp of the naked eye. She uses photography’s association with the real and visible to ask the viewer to suspend their disbelief and consider that beyond or adjacent to what we see, there are alternate stories unfolding.

“In my pictures I always try to think that there are other layers,” says the French-born artist. “Like in people; when you meet them, you always meet the surface and the shape.” Flore is more interested in the “different types of people” she believes we all have in us. “It’s much more this invisible part that I want to explore,” she explains.

In Flore’s images we see her central character, a red-haired girl, with masts growing out of her back, floating from a beach into the air under full sails. In another image she seems to dive from a stage into a set backdrop painted with rolling hills. She buries her head in a field of pristine, white snow. She sits wearing a white blindfold in front of a wall covered in Victorian painted portraits.

Flore uses herself as a model in her work, but she’s careful to obscure her face. “I don’t feel that I’m talking about me,” she explains. “If there is no face [the viewer] can enter into the picture more easily.” While she’s reaching for a more universal character, like any creator of fiction she incorporates elements of her personal life and experience in her images. Those autobiographical connections diminish through her lengthy creative process, she says, as does her memory of her original inspiration for an image.

Flore begins her process by sketching or creating collages, and it can be months or even years between the time she imagines an image and when she actually makes it. To make her composites, she gathers landscape photographs with a Canon EOS 5D Mark II during her travels, then later photographs herself and the props she needs to build the final composition. She often photographs the landscapes without knowing what she will use the images for. To create other images in camera, she’ll stage scenes in a landscape or interior.

When she does stage an image, she prefers to work alone, she says, because she feels more free to experiment. She did collaborate with her grandmother on a series depicting a girl in a red coat, asking her grandmother—who rarely left her home anymore—to scout locations in the countryside near where she lived.

Earlier this year Flore published her first monograph, Rememories, a result of winning the Prix HSBC Pour La Photographie. The book includes images from several series, but it was important to Flore that her book did not simply collect her work like a catalogue. Instead she edited the images together into a cohesive body of work with a subtle, emotional narrative. When she began creating photographs there was a lightness to the work, she says, but she’s begun exploring darker, more emotionally intense images, which she often makes using interiors rather than natural landscapes. “Beauty can also come from these hard moments or ugly times,” she explains. “I would like to be able to speak with many different kinds of feelings.”

A graphic artist and art director by training, Flore came to photography after studying retouching. “I wasn’t really into photography, because for me it was definitely something that was more documentary, more realistic,” she recalls, whereas she didn’t want to see “reality [just] as it is.” She was creating drawings and collages, but wasn’t happy with the result. “Then I studied photography and that’s the way I found that is was possible to make [my ideas] happen.”

Staged and composited photographs appealed to her because viewers might initially believe what they see, rather than noticing the intervention of the artist, as they would with other media. “When you look at a photograph, [especially one] in color, you think that it’s something that happened,” she explains. “It’s fun to play with this: It’s sometimes a quirky situation that could be possible but it’s in some way kind of surreal.”

Flore chose “Rememories” for the title of her book because, for her, it signifies “the idea that we are always playing our childhood memories” over and over again throughout our lives until “at some point you find the end” and move on. “I like this idea that we’re always going through the same path and situation until we find ourselves maybe more open, or we explore something” and move beyond that cycle.

Related: Cynthia Henebry's Series "The Marriage Oaks" Probes the Psychology of Youth and Adulthood

article.article_title: Photographer Zanele Muholi on Fighting Homophobic Violence With Portraiture
article.meta_description: The South African "visual activist" talks about her honest, intimate portraits of black lesbians, and her fearless advocacy for her country's LGBTI community.
article.article_text_abstract: The South African "visual activist" talks about her honest, intimate portraits of black lesbians, and her fearless advocacy for her country's LGBTI community.
article.article_image_credit: © ZANELE MUHOLI/COURTESY STEVENSON CAPE TOWN/JOHANNESBURG AND YANCEY RICHARDSON, NEW YORK
article.article_image_caption:
Lumka Stemela
Nyanga East, Cape Town, 2011.
Muholi's portraits of participants in her ongoing "Faces and Phases" project form part of her "Isibonelo/Evidence" exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum. One of her goals, she says, is "disorganizing the mindset of the homophobe."
article.article_text:
South African gays and lesbians continue to be subject to violent persecution, despite the country’s official policy of acceptance. Homophobes have beaten a number of gays and lesbians to death, and raped lesbians in order to “cure” them. Since 2006, Zanele Muholi has chosen to confront the violence by making more than 250 portraits of queer black “participants” that humanize and empower them. The series, “Faces and Places,” has earned her international acclaim not only for her photography, but for her courageous advocacy and activism on behalf of homosexuals and transgender people in South Africa.

“We are at a period where there’s a high level of homophobia in [parts of Africa]. A lot of people have been killed, a lot of people have been displaced, simply because of who they are,” Muholi explained during a conversation about her work with Aperture executive director Chris Boot at the LOOK3 photo festival in June. “So what I’m bring to do here is to bring about a kind of tool in which we speak about these atrocities…I just want to change visual history in ways that have never been done in Africa.”

Muholi, who was born in 1972, is propelled by her rage, but also by her optimistic belief in the power of her community to gain acceptance by telling their own stories. In 2002, she co-founded Forum for Empowerment of Women. In 2009, she started a media collective called Inkanyiso as a platform for queer “born frees” (the term for South Africans born after the end of apartheid) to document their own history through writing, photography and video. Muholi provides cameras to some of the contributors. “One cannot do these projects alone which is why I invited people to come on board and work with me. And it means it’s not lonely anymore,” she says. 

Most of the Inkanyiso team are black lesbians. Muholi says the project was inspired in part by a particularly brutal murder of a lesbian in Kwa Thema, a township near Johannesburg that has a significant gay population—but also a lot of hate crimes, despite South Africa’s official acceptance of gays. Posts on the Inkanyiso site include photos and stories about art, activism, queer politics, and personal essays. “People get to read about sex, people get to read about anything you will never see in the mainstream media,” she says. 

An important mission of Inkanyiso is to document evidence of so-called “corrective” rape and other hate crimes against lesbians and gays. As she explained in a five-minute documentary film about her work screened before her talk at LOOK3, “Hate crimes have become a binding factor for the LGBTI communities. We come together to give support, or to confirm that somebody has been killed…Do we always go and attend [a] funeral and [then] go home and wait for another funeral? You have to document! You are forced to document!”

Besides documenting crimes against lesbians, though, Inkanyiso’s many contributors also portray themselves and their day-to-day lives in positive ways. Muholi observes in the film, “Projecting positivity can sometimes lead to change. Projecting violations and brutality could lead to further violence. So I think we need to find a balance in which to project these realities.”

Part and parcel of her activism is her ongoing “Faces and Phases” series. It has contributed significantly to her consciousness-raising efforts by drawing international attention. Steidl published Faces and Phases 2006–2014 last March. The book earned her a nomination for the 2015 Deutsche Börse Photography Prize. The project also features prominently in her first major solo exhibition in the U.S., called “Isibonelo/Evidence,” which is on display at the Brooklyn Museum through November. 

“Faces and Phases” is one of several projects undertaken by Muholi to challenge the portrayal of gays in South Africa since she took up photography more than a decade ago. She completed her studies in advanced photography at the Market Photo Workshop in Johannesburg in 2003. In 2009, three years after starting the “Faces and Phases” project, she earned her MFA in Documentary Media at Ryerson University in Toronto. In 2013, she won a slew of international prizes and honors, including Carnegie International’s Fine Prize for an emerging artist, the Prince Claus Award (sponsored by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs), and the Index on Censorship’s Freedom of Expression award. 

The power of Muholi’s portraits lies in the intimacy of the individual images, as well as the collective force of the series. She photographs only people she knows personally, and presents none of them as icons or types, much less victims. Instead she emphasizes their individuality. 

Muholi refers to them as “participants” rather than “subjects” as a way of acknowledging their agency and their role in her success, she says. “The minute you say ‘subjects,’ you are not allowed to connect with the person you photograph. I make sure I connect and try to relate to the people I photograph in my work,” she said at LOOK3. 

She shoots in black and white for its sense of timelessness, and seeks out simple backgrounds and good natural light in the nooks and crannies of the neighborhoods where she photographs. Her participants come as they are, and look directly into her camera, showing everything from shy reserve to defiance.

Muholi takes her time. “I listen, which is what we need to do as photographers, is to listen to the people we photographer, and not rush to take images,” she says. “In an hour’s time, I take maybe ten shots, looking for one that speaks to me, [and I] give the rest to the participant.” She gives the participants the opportunity to write their own story to accompany the portraits, “so when you look at each and every face, you should think of that person’s story.”  The stories of several of the participants are included in the book Faces and Phases 2006–2014. 

Muholi’s plan is to continue the project for life, photographing her participants at intervals to show their evolution as people—hence, the “phases” in the title of the project. But her work—and growing public profile—are not without risks. She is a target of homophobia not only for being a lesbian, but for her unflinching activism. In 2012, thieves stole five years’ worth of work—and nothing else—from her Cape Town apartment. Muholi is undeterred. She presses on urgently, and speaks fearlessly of using her work to “disrupt the perpetrator” and of “disorganizing the mindset of the homophobe.”

And she’s optimistic that she and her fellow activists will prevail. “I’m positive about the future. I was born in South Africa at the height of apartheid. But all the challenges does not mean we can slow down. We cannot delay in any way. But I have hope that hate crime will end, just the way apartheid ended.”

article.article_title: Elena Dorfman's Multimedia Exhibition Focuses on Syria’s Teen Refugees
article.meta_description: While working for the U.N., Dorfman created a project that encourages viewers to connect and empathize with a generation of Syrians whose youth has been stolen by civil war.
article.article_text_abstract: While working for the U.N., Dorfman created a project that encourages viewers to connect and empathize with a generation of Syrians whose youth has been stolen by civil war.
article.article_image_caption: Farman, 20, lives in the Domiz refugee camp in Kurdistan, which is now home to more than 50,000 Kurdish refugees.
article.article_text:
As the Syrian Civil War continues into its fifth year, the statistical measurements of human misery grow apace. According to the United Nations, 220,000 people had been killed as of January 2015, and 130,000 more were declared “missing/captured.” Nearly 4 million Syrians have fled the country, while an estimated 7.5 million citizens have been internally displaced. With the conflict showing no signs of abating, Syria’s situation is made even more troubling by the plight of its youth. UNESCO’s 2015 global report indicates that almost half of adolescents inside the country, and a staggering 90 percent of refugee children, are “out of school.” As Syria’s history is being bombed into rubble, and its present held hostage by war, the future of its people is in dire jeopardy. 

“Syria’s Lost Generation” is a multimedia installation by Los Angeles-based photographer Elena Dorfman on view at the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum through January 2016. The exhibit uses intimate environmental portraits and audio recordings of teenage Syrian refugees to push beyond the grim statistics and bleak images emerging from the civil war. “There is extraordinary [photojournalistic] work being made in the region and about this crisis,” Dorfman explains. “My hope, in focusing on the teenagers, was to entice the viewer to look at the subject not as another staggering number, but as someone they might connect with and have empathy for.”

At first blush, this work seems like a departure for Dorfman, a successful fine-art photographer who has published several monographs and has shown her work at MoMA and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. On closer inspection, however, “Syria’s Lost Generation” follows a persistent thread in Dorfman’s work: marginalized communities.  

Dorfman’s opportunity to create the project arose in 2013, when she reconnected with a former employer from her days as a young photojournalist in the 1990s at the San Francisco Chronicle. Now a spokesperson for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, her former colleague said “they could use my eye” for the work they were doing around the Syrian refugee crisis, Dorfman remembers. “My first thought was no, I’m a fine-art photographer, that’s not the type of work I do.” 

But the more Dorfman thought about the proposal over the next few days, the more she was drawn to it. The urgency of the Syrian situation, combined with her own desire to “get out of her studio and engage the world,” made the assignment difficult to pass up.

In March 2013, Dorfman arrived in Beirut, where she was based until September. The U.N. collaboration also took her to camps outside Lebanon, in Turkey, Iraqi Kurdistan and Jordan. Her assignments ranged from in-depth reporting, such as a three-month study of war widows, to straightforward coverage of specific U.N. projects, like refugee housing. Whether in Jordan’s sprawling, semi-permanent Za’atari refugee camp, replete with street names and bustling commercial hubs, or in a dank, rented basement in southern Turkey, Dorfman found Syrians tormented by the twin plights of unemployment and hopelessness. She was especially drawn to adolescents who, when they should be absorbing new experiences, found themselves marooned in a netherworld of idleness and deprivation. “In the beginning they all thought they could go home and I think now, in the fifth year of the war, they realize that where they are is where they are going to stay...for a very long time,” she sighs.

Dorfman quickly knew that she wanted to do something that would focus on these teenagers. In retrospect, she draws a line from her very first book (1999’s The C-Word), about teen cancer survivors, to the refugee work. Both seek to illuminate the experiences of young people facing dire circumstances. She ran the idea by her contacts at the U.N. and got an enthusiastic response. From that point she worked on it in conjunction with her other U.N. assignments, applying her techniques for creating environmental portraits, honed over a decade of magazine work, to her subjects. “As much as possible, I wanted them to look into the camera so that a connection could be made,” Dorfman says.

Along the way Dorfman began making audio recordings of her subjects. While she found the youths eager to tell their stories, there were some hurdles; males of military age feared retaliation from the regime, and young girls had limited autonomy. “They often had to ask permission of fathers or brothers before they could be photographed,” Dorfman says, “and in one case we had to really rush to get them on audiotape, because they had to do it before the men came back.”

The unrelenting heat and dust of the camps was a constant challenge. Dorfman traveled light, using her iPhone as a recording device and abandoning the portable strobes she had brought from her studio. “Normally my craft is very precise, controlled, and being in a situation like this was almost the opposite,” Dorfman says.

In 2014, Dorfman reached out to the Holocaust Museum about her ongoing work in the Middle East. They showed interest and, in July of the same year, she went to Washington, D.C. Almost as an afterthought, she told the curators about the teen photos and audio. Several months later, the curators told her that they were interested in exhibiting that work. “I worked closely with the museum which included meetings on location in D.C, conference calls and, of course, many emails. Over the course of several months we honed the look, feel, and pacing of the piece,” Dorfman says. Her hope for the work is simple: to create something that allows the audience to connect on a human level with these young people, who yearn to be something more than statistics.

article.article_title: What's Your Niche? Megan Green, Motorsports Photographer
article.meta_description: Green talks to PDN about how she broke into the testosterone-driven world of auto racing and started landing jobs from bloggers, magazines, racing teams and commercial clients.
article.article_text_abstract: Green talks to PDN about how she broke into the testosterone-driven world of auto racing and started landing jobs from bloggers, magazines, racing teams and commercial clients.
article.article_image_caption: Cars in formation under a yellow cautionary flag during the Pirelli World Challenge, Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach, California, April 2013.
article.article_text:
New York-based photographer Megan Green explains how she broke into the testosterone-driven world of auto racing, and started landing jobs from bloggers, magazines, racing teams and commercial clients. 

PDN: How did you get started covering motorsports?

Megan Green: I started in 2010 on a personal project. When I was a kid, my family always went to a track up near Albany called Lebanon Valley Speedway. My sister and I loved it. I remember sitting there with my mom’s Instamatic, watching these cars go by, and thinking, I’m going to take a picture and it’s going to look just like those shots by professionals. I had in my head the picture I wanted to take. I went to art school, and was a fine art photographer for a while. In 2010 my family was going to the races, and I had my gear with me, and from that point on, I was hooked again. I love every minute, out there with these roaring engines.

PDN: Tell us more about why it appeals to you. 

MG: The action is really exciting, and there’s a whole community around it. There’s action on the racetrack, but also in the paddock and in the pits. It’s fascinating watching the engineers and the mechanics. It’s camaraderie between people. Racing is about the race, but it’s also about the people.

PDN: What was the first job you got?

MG: I was in California with a team for Autobytel, and we were covering the Pebble Beach Concours d’Elegance. That was the first time I shot a race professionally.

PDN: What’s the story behind your social media handle, Ponycargirl?

MG: When I first started shooting cars, I ripped a page from the PR book and thought, I need a name, I need to streamline a message, and define who I am in this industry. I love Ford Mustangs, and they’re called pony cars. So I took the name Pony Car Girl and started using it on social media.

PDN: How did you hone your skills at this type of photography?

MG: Trial and error, and a lot of practice. When I was working on it as a personal project, I would go home and look at everything, and go, I can’t believe I missed that shot, this is terrible. How do I make this better?” I went to YouTube and looked up videos on how to pan, and I read different photographers’ blogs about how they do things—settings, for example. I’d go back to read my camera manual, and see, ‘Oh, if I set it on image stabilization #2 I’ll get a better pan. So it was a combination of trial and error and looking everything up online to see what other photographers do. And asking other photographers questions.

PDN: Do you have photographers you consider mentors, whose images you learned the most from?

MG: I love Marshall Pruett’s photos. He’s phenomenal. And then my friend Gary Grant, who is a motorsports photographer in Toronto, took me under his wing and taught me how to work a race.

PDN: What kinds of things did he teach you?

MG: He taught me the basics: Stand back here, don’t sit down, never have your back to the cars because they can crash in the blink of an eye, know the racetrack’s good angles. You want to be in certain places at a certain time of the day because the light is good.

PDN: Are there a lot of women in this niche? 

MG: There aren’t many of us. You go to a race and see the photographers, and more often than not, they’re men. There are a lot of opportunities, but there aren’t a lot of women at the top levels.

PDN: Have you had trouble getting jobs because you’re a woman?

MG: I haven’t felt that. On the one hand, because I’m a woman, I’m slightly more visible. Getting work is based on building relationships, and that can be more difficult because you’re a woman, because guys have friendships, and there’s camaraderie that might not be as accessible for a woman.

PDN: So how do you compensate for that?

MG: I just try to be as visible as possible. I send out promos, I have an online presence, I do a lot of social media, I try to talk to people.

PDN: You mean cold call them, or approach them at races?

MG: You build relationships at races, shake hands with people. You don’t walk up to someone and say, “Hey, will you hire me?” but you have to open your mouth and build those relationships, so it’s easier the next time.

PDN: What are rates like for this niche?

MG: It’s generally a day rate, I would say $1,000 for a day.

PDN: You mentioned that there’s a lot of opportunity for photographers. Like what?

MG: It’s not just publications. For every logo on a race car, there’s a company sponsoring that team, and running marketing programs off of that, so they need photos. And then the team itself needs photos. There aren’t as many magazines, but [everyone] needs photos for social media: Facebook, Instagram, Twitter. So there’s still a need for photographers. 

PDN: How do you reach those brands that sponsor drivers and teams?

MG: I’ve been finding out who the marketing director is, or the PR agency. I send promotional postcards. I’ll follow brands on Instagram, and I follow the teams. When I shoot events, I’ll post images of some of the competitors on Instagram, and I’ll tag them, and more often than not, they’ll either ‘like’ it or comment on the photo. So that helps drive visibility. I don’t know if it’s gotten me a gig yet, but it’s one tool for getting your name out there.

PDN: What’s in your gear bag? 

MG: I’m a little unusual in that I shoot with Olympus equipment. I have an E-5 camera. I also have an OM-D E-M1. It’s good for shooting in the paddocks, but as far as action goes, it’s a bit of a challenge, and I’m probably going to look for another DSLR body, because mirrorless isn’t quite there yet for action. If you’re shooting in burst mode, and you’re following a car, unlike with a DSLR, you can’t see anything [through the viewfinder]. 

PDN: Which lenses do you use?

MG: I have a 12–60mm f/2.8–4 lens, which is good for close-on action and shooting around the paddocks. And I have a 50-200mm f/2.8–3.5 for longer shots.

PDN: Any unusual gear in your kit that’s particular to motorsports?

MG: I always have a monopod. Since you’re out on a track, and you have to carry everything with you, I tend to carry as little as possible. You’re out there all day in the elements, so you don’t want to be carrying around 50 pounds of gear.

PDN: Is this a young person’s niche because of the physical demands? What’s the age range of photographers?

MG: It ranges from people in their 20s to all the old guys, 55, 65. They’re the ones [who] shot racing when it was a roll of 36 exposures in the camera. So they’re good. They can nail those shots. They’re the ones you want to talk to and learn from.

PDN: Any other advice for photographers interested in getting into this niche?

MG: Practice. Know your camera, know your equipment. Go to a nearby street and practice your panning on the cars going by. Outside of that, take care of yourself. Run or bike. Shooting motorsports is brutal, and you need stamina. The better condition you’re in, the better off you’ll be.

article.article_title: How I Got That Shot: Christine Blackburne 'Nails' a Reflective Still Life
article.meta_description: Blackburne explains how she created a lighting setup that balanced shine, texture and a hand model’s skin tones in still lifes for Nail It! magazine.
article.article_text_abstract: Blackburne explains how she created a lighting setup that balanced shine, texture and a hand model’s skin tones in still lifes for Nail It! magazine.
article.article_image_caption: Blackburne set up her overall light to create highlights in the gold balls, adding a second light to provide fill on the hand. One challenge was making sure not to catch the reflection of her camera in any of the shiny elements.
article.article_text:
Client: Nail It!

Beauty Director: Karie Frost

Still-life photographer Christine Blackburne says art directors and beauty editors often come to her with great concepts, then ask her to figure out how to make them work photographically. “I love solving these technical challenges. It’s fun for me,” says Blackburne, whose clients include e.l.f. Cosmetics, Harper Collins, Essence, People en Espanol, Marriott and Hublot. “I think they come to me for how I shape light and how I incorporate color and light.”

Karie Frost, beauty editor at Nail It! magazine, has been a frequent client; she first received one of Blackburne’s first promos seven years ago, and held onto it until she was at a job where she could call on the photographer’s technical and art directing skills. For a story about silver and gold nail polish trends, Frost brought Blackburne an idea to photograph a model’s manicured hand against shiny, metallic backgrounds, such as silver Mylar and a tray of reflective gold Pachinko balls. She wanted to capture the texture of the backgrounds, but keep the focus on the gleaming fingernails. 

Blackburne notes, “The challenge for this image was keeping it from getting too busy, with all the texture created by the Pachinko balls, and keeping the camera far enough away…so it would not be reflected in each one.” Having a hand model in the shot added a lighting challenge: She would need to make the model’s skin look good while also making the shiny elements of the shot stand out. When she lights jewelry, such as the bracelets on the hand model’s wrist, “It takes a lot more contrast to make them look nice,” she says. “But if there’s too much contrast in the hand, it can get creepy-looking fast.” 

Blackburne typically shoots in her 1,000-square-foot studio, located in South Street Seaport, a neighborhood in lower Manhattan. Blackburne often uses the studio’s white walls and 15-foot high ceilings to bounce light around when she’s shooting tabletop compositions. Having her own studio with 24-hour access allows her to experiment whenever she wants. “I’ll come in the day before the shoot and play around with the objects to wrap my head around what we’re going to do on the shoot day,” she says. “I don’t want there to be any surprises on set with a client.”

Logistics

Blackburne decided to pour the Pachinko balls onto a sheet of gold Mylar she had spread in an old darkroom developer tray. She quickly discovered that the balls settled into a neat grid, and wouldn’t provide the texture Frost wanted. She decided to bury some magnets among the balls, so they would bunch together. “Also, I was placing the tray on sawhorses, so I put some strong magnets underneath the tray to keep some balls in place,” she says. She adds, “A lot of what I do is a little of the mad scientist.”

Christina Ambers, an experienced hand model, was cast for the job. “Having a good hand model can make or break a shoot, just as much as a fashion model can,” Blackburne says, adding, “What looks natural to the camera might not be in actuality.” Blackburne had Ambers pose so that the nails were visible at the top of the image. The background and the bracelets helped create a frame that focused the eye on the nail color. 

Lighting

“I used an extra-small softbox to create the overall light that would be flattering on the hand and create highlights in the ball,” the photographer says. The Chimera softbox, which measures about a foot by a foot and a half, was placed over the hand and props, and moved just slightly to camera left. Blackburne also lined up white reflector cards around all sides of the tray to bounce light back onto the reflective balls. 

To provide further fill on the hand, Blackburne set up a Profoto head with a reflector to the right of the tabletop, and pointed it toward the ceiling just above the hand, so light bounced down onto the model’s hand. She set the Profoto Acute 2400R power pack to low power. Blackburne also added another white card right where the model’s arm enters the frame for further reflection. The only problem for the model was that she couldn’t see how her hand looked: The card in front of her obscured her view.

For additional coverage in anticipation of some compositing in post, Blackburne also took another shot of the hand with even more fill. For this shot, she held a white card between the model’s arm where it entered the frame and the camera and angled it so that it caught the light from the softbox but didn’t obscure the camera lens. 

She used a nearly identical lighting setup when she photographed Ambers’ hand on silver Mylar, but she wanted to make sure there was some contrast and areas of darkness in the folds and creases. She moved the Profoto further to camera left and used a large silver card to throw some fill into the crumpled Mylar. 

Camera

Blackburne’s go-to camera is a Fuji GX680. “It’s such a great camera for still life,” she says. “It pretty much has the front movements of a 4x5, but you can look through the lens.” She uses a Phase One IQ digital back and shoots tethered to her computer. She shot each of the still lifes with her camera on a Foba stand, roughly three feet away from the model’s hand. 

She chose a 125mm Fujinon f/5.6 lens, and shot at f/22 at ISO 100. “I made sure I used a long enough lens to be able to get up high enough and not be dealing with camera reflection,” she notes.

Postproduction

If a job requires more than simple color correction or clean up, Blackburne prefers to handle the retouching and compositing herself. She draws the line, however, at retouching skin, which requires delicacy. “With hands especially, the meat of the palm has to be softened or it can become a focus. It’s also about making sure the hand lines are softened so they aren’t too prominent but the hand still has texture,” she says. “There is a fine line between over-retouched, and not retouched enough.”

Blackburne has been collaborating with retoucher Tzveta Stamatova for about two years. She’ll often give Stamatova a mock up of a composite as a guide but, says Blackburne, “after working together for two years, she knows what I like.” She prefers to hand over processed TIFFs rather than RAW files. On the shot of the pachinko balls, in addition to retouching the hand, Blackburne recalls, “We took down a little bit of the saturation and contrast in the background, to make sure the nails stood out more.” The shot of reflective Mylar required more extensive retouching, she notes. “It reflected everything in the room.” When each composite was done, Blackburne got a flattened TIFF she delivered to the client. When the completed images were published as full pages in Nail It!, says Blackburne, “I really liked how they came out.”

article.article_title: Photographer Maggie Steber on Women, Minorities, and How to Nurture Talent
article.meta_description: The photojournalist and mentor offers career advice for aspiring photographers and talks about the state of the photography industry for women and minorities.
article.article_text_abstract: The photojournalist and mentor offers career advice for aspiring photographers and talks about the state of the photography industry for women and minorities.
article.article_image_caption: Maggie Steber.
article.article_text:
Maggie Steber, acclaimed documentary photographer, workshop instructor, and mentor, talks about the state of the industry for women and minorities, while offering career advice for all aspiring photographers. 

PDN: Do you see things getting easier for women in the photography industry?

Maggie Steber: I think so, just by the sheer number of women who are going into photography. I see institutions where it’s still heavily male, and heavily Anglo male. 

But there are more women picture editors, who hire women—and not just women, but good photographers. I think women have made huge headway and now we have to make sure minorities are making more headway. 

PDN: Who are the women picture editors you are thinking of?

MS: Michele McNally (The New York Times), Kira Pollack (TIME), Kathy Ryan (The New York Times Magazine), MaryAnne Golon (The Washington Post), Sarah Leen (National Geographic), Judy Walgren (San Francisco Chronicle). It’s tricky to name names because we could leave somebody out, and that would not be nice.

PDN: There are professions that have been dominated by men, but then become dominated by women as [wages drop in] those professions. Has that happened in photography?

MS: It’s too early to say. What I would say is that women are freer in this country and other countries to be a wife and be a mother and still be a photographer. 

PDN: Do women still have to work harder than men to make it in photography?

MS: I think at this point, everybody has to work really, really hard to be a photographer. It’s just so much harder than it was. What a lot of people don’t understand, men or women, is [that] you just have to be a never-say-die person. If somebody hurts your feelings, have a good cry and get over it. It is a hard, frustrating business, and it takes a lot of thinking, and planning, and it’s exhausting, and never ending, but man, when it works, it is very gratifying. The thing that’s lacking is having grace about it, and wanting it so badly, you don’t give up.

PDN: What do you mean by having grace about it?

MS: After you get kicked in the teeth a few times, you can become very bitter. And I’ve met photographers who’ve received accolades and attention, and as a result have great egos. If you’re one of those people who has had a lot of success, you need to help other photographers. 

PDN: Is there more flexibility for women to have a career and a family now than when you were coming up?

MS: First of all, no one ever asks men this question and I think they should ask because men have a lot to say about it. Secondly, asking anyone at all about this very personal choice of having a family or not gets us into territory that is hugely sensitive.

Some women photographers have a family and a partner and they are testament that it can be done. Some women photographers want to have children and for one reason or another that has nothing to do with desire, they cannot. For people who want to have children and cannot, this is a very hard question. For someone like me, I don’t mind stating publicly that I didn’t particularly want to have children. 

PDN: Do you see young women photographers struggle with whether or not they can have children and a career, and what do you tell them?

MS: Deciding to have a family or not really has nothing to do with photography. People have, for centuries, overcome great odds to do with their lives what they will and they will continue to do so. It’s important for younger women to go into this personal decision and photography with their eyes wide open but also realize that you don’t necessarily have to choose one way of life over another.

I think [having children] does change the way people look at you, and it can [lead] some photo editors to regard you differently. On the other hand, with some photo editors, especially women who have children, they’ll think it’s wonderful and do everything they can to support you because you have children. So it can work both ways. 

What we women must not do is vilify one another for our choices. Have kids, don’t have them, be sensitive to those who want them, but we must respect one another’s choices and decisions.

PDN: Do you think female photographer have any inherent advantages over male photographers?

MS: A mistake that a lot of young photographers make—men and women—is that they get this big idea, and they don’t know how to focus it. Based on my experience, women see the smaller things. That’s why I think they are really well-suited to [photography]: They have this ability to [focus on those smaller things]. 

PDN: Do you think they have advantages of access?

MS: A lot of people don’t take women photographers seriously. That can work in their favor. I’ve worked around male photographers who could have cared less if I was there, because I was nobody. It was liberating. I wasn’t having to compete with these big tough guys who were busy competing with each other. [Also], you’re not threatening, and you can [more easily] go into people’s homes because there’s a lot of things we have in common [with female subjects all over the world]. It’s like, “Oh, she’s like us,” and I think that makes it much easier. 

PDN: What about minorities who want to work in the photo industry?

MS: This [lack of minority voices in photography] is the last mountain we have to climb. We have to all be engaged in that.

PDN: Are there institutional barriers to minority photographers?

MS: There could be. And that’s why there has to be an ongoing conversation. But people have to understand something: You have to be a good photographer. That’s true for anybody no matter what color you are, no matter where you’re from. That said, there are some institutions that are trying to help move [photographers of color] forward. World Press Photo teaches a lot of workshops in Africa, and that’s partly to identify talent. The Open Society Institute is looking for those voices as well. I think there are more and more institutions [cultivating photographers around the world], but it’s a matter of finding them. 

PDN: But isn’t the deck still stacked heavily against photographers of color?

MS: That kind of comes down to personality, but yeah, it’s hard to be black in this country, and there’s a lot of benign racism. I’m mentoring a curator who’s black. She’s working in a museum world where nobody else looks like her. And she calls me some days crying. It’s not that anybody means to be mean to her, but it’s just really hard for minorities.

PDN: What do you tell her?

MS: I always say: You keep your head up high, and remember you’re walking on the shoulders of many people. Be proud of your heritage, and think about how you’ve succeeded to get this far, and how you will continue to go further. I’ve told her to find mentors. And I’ve told her: You could be the smartest person in the room, but you’re going to have to work twice as hard because there’s just a lot of people who don’t expect much of you, or don’t realize things about you. You have to find the person who believes you. It’s amazing what one person can do. 

PDN: Do you have any other parting advice for young photographers about their careers and their work?

MS: I’ve been on my high horse about this: I meet all these young photographers who don’t know a thing about the editorial world. They don’t look at magazines. So they don’t know how to target their work. Go to Barnes & Noble and spend two or three hours looking at all kinds of magazines. Get to know your editorial market.

And how about this? Learn the history of photography, for heaven’s sake! Not only has learning the history of photography influenced my work, but what a wonderful, delicious, extravagant extraordinary knowledge to have. [And] picture editors are excited to meet someone who can speak about photography in an intelligent way, and who, by the way, has looked at their magazine.

article.article_title: Photographer Lauren Dukoff on Collaborating with Celebrities and Couture Designers
article.meta_description: Known for her intimate portraits of Adele and other celebrities, Dukoff explains how she made the leap to creating fashion stories for Vogue Japan.
article.article_text_abstract: Known for her intimate portraits of Adele and other celebrities, Dukoff explains how she made the leap to creating fashion stories for Vogue Japan.
article.article_image_caption: Wedding couture shot for Vogue Wedding Japan.
article.article_text:
Lauren Dukoff’s most widely seen celebrity portraits are intimate and often quiet, capturing something unexpected behind the public personae of musicians and actors. On shoots for Vanity Fair, L’Uomo Vogue, SOMA, Lula and Elle, often working with wardrobe stylists to meet the magazines’ need to show celebrities in certain clothes, Dukoff has to put her subjects at ease quickly and capture “what they’re opening up and giving me.” Her approach to portraiture is rooted in her background shooting documentary-style images of musicians offstage, “trying to find those stolen moments.” She adds, “I’m always trying to give fans a respectful peek into these peoples’ lives, and to get something special that viewers wouldn’t ordinarily see.”

In the past two years, Dukoff has also shot fashion stories for Vogue Japan. On these assignments, she is not eliciting emotion from her subjects, but guiding the models to portray a character. “For me, a fashion story is really about the clothes and the designer, and the fantasy you’re creating,” she explains. “The emotion, the attitude is something I create.”

Photographing celebrities in selected fashions and creating fashion stories from scratch require different skills and planning. Creating fashion stories “wasn’t natural at first,” Dukoff says, “but I think that the transition of shooting so much fashion on celebrities [in my portrait work], under my direction, helped me get comfortable with that.” 

Mayumi Nakamura, the editor at Vogue Japan who gave Dukoff her first fashion assignment, believes the photographer’s ability to create a distinctive image within the constraints of a celebrity shoot—limited time, the needs of fashion editors and hovering publicists—serves her well when directing complex fashion shoots. “Lauren has got a skill to get over these limitations and manage to make her own statements in these photos.” 

When she started out, Dukoff wasn’t interested in creating stories on “a blank canvas”: “I wanted someone to feed off of,” she says. She benefitted from long collaborations with some subjects. Her photos of musician Devendra Banhart, a friend since high school, and his friends and collaborators were collected in The Family, published in 2009. Dukoff spent weeks observing and photographing singer Adele during the making of her breakthrough 2011 album 21, shooting the cover and all the publicity for the album. 

Work like this lead to assignments shooting similar, documentary-style images for Rolling Stone and advertisers like Nike. More often, however, clients have hired her to shoot portraits that require her to gain the trust of her subjects and establish a rapport quickly. To keep the focus on “me and the subject, and that one moment between us,” she likes to have a stripped-down set and work with a small but trusted crew. She notes that celebrities “feel more comfortable with fewer eyes on them.” She spends a few minutes talking to her subjects before the shoot begins to decide how much or how little direction she needs to give in order to elicit something. “It could be that whatever they’re giving me a lot of, I want to get the opposite,” she says. “Or there’s a lot that I’ve seen in other photos of someone and I want to get something different.”

As an example, Dukoff describes a sitting with actor Adam Driver in New York City. “He’s got a lot of energy, which I love,” she says. She first had him jump around the studio. Then she recalls, “I noticed him pulling at his shirt, and I said, ‘Why don’t you do more of that?’” Driver continued, and ended up with his arms stuck in his sleeves, at which point Dukoff captured him looking serious and vulnerable. “That felt very intimate,” she says. “For him, and his energy, that seemed like a special moment.” 

She began shooting portraits with fashion elements in 2009, when she met a writer for L’Uomo Vogue who encouraged her to pitch stories. She pitched one on Banhart, and that led to assignments shooting “a slew of musicians,” actors, directors, “all different kinds of people.” An editor would suggest wardrobe for these shoots. Says Dukoff, “There was an emphasis on shooting the right kinds of clothing, but I was still approaching it as a portrait.” 

An assignment for Lula called for her to shoot actress Gia Coppola in a long, sheer gown designed by Rodarte. “I realized how beautiful it would be to see that gown backlit,” Dukoff recalls. She had the actress pose on a ladder so the sun shone through the dress. “I wanted to focus on her, and not just the gown, so they influenced and complemented one another.” 

In 2013 she landed an assignment for Vogue Japan to photograph Princess Charlene of Monaco in clothes provided by Akris on location at the royal residence once occupied by Grace Kelly. Says Dukoff, “I remember thinking to myself, ‘Oh my god: Vogue is flying me across the globe to photograph a princess. When did that happen?’” One of Dukoff’s images was used on the cover. 

Vogue Japan’s Nakamura also hired Dukoff to photograph Olympic swimmer Aya Terakawa in clothes by Tory Burch. Terakawa had typically been photographed smiling broadly. Says Dukoff, “I wanted to show something more iconic and goddess-like.” She photographed Terakawa from behind her chin up, wearing a dress with a low back so the tan lines left by her bathing suit were visible. 

Nakamura says she was impressed by “the quiet sense of class” Dukoff had captured. “I wanted her to shoot a fashion story featuring dresses with more formal and elegant touches.” For the fall 2013 issue of Vogue Wedding Japan, where Nakamura serves as creative director, she assigned Dukoff to shoot a fashion story featuring clothes by Prada, MiuMiu, Bottega Veneta, Reem Acra and other designers. 

Just as Dukoff had been inspired by her portrait subjects, she began taking inspiration from the hand-crafted creations of couturiers. “So much time and work goes into these gowns, I really want to do them justice,” she says. For a recent Vogue Japan shoot, which took place in a garden, she scouted locations and planned the lighting and composition of hser images with the fabric and design of each outfit in mind. 

In shooting fashion, Dukoff says, “I’m collaborating indirectly with the designer.” Working with veteran stylist and longtime friend Ashley Furnival, she pores over images from runway shows in New York and Paris, “to see where the designers are coming from and how they present their collections.” Then they build stories around common themes. 

“I never had this dream of shooting fashion, but there’s something really powerful about it,” Dukoff says. “Everyone gasps when the model walks out in the perfect gown with the perfect hair and makeup. There are so many elements that have to come together, there’s a kind of magic about it when it all works.” 

Whether she’s photographing a famous face or a model, Dukoff says, “At the end of the day I’m just trying to make something that’s interesting to myself and the viewer. That’s the goal for all my shoots: To make something that will truly last.”

Related: Lauren Dukoff. Born 1984, United States. Adele, Los Angeles, 2011. © Lauren Dukoff
