article.article_title: Rachel Papo's Look at Homeschooled Children
article.meta_description: The photographer delves into the lives of children being raised and educated outside of the American school system.
article.article_text_abstract: The photographer delves into the lives of children being raised and educated outside of the American school system.
article.article_image_caption: “Homework,” 2012, from Rachel Papo’s “Homeschooled,” which was on display at the Center for Photography at Woodstock this spring.
article.article_text:
“Homeschooled,” a new series by Israeli-American photographer Rachel Papo, is a quiet meditation on the home education movement, a growing practice in the United States. But while much of the discussion around the subject tends to revolve around parents and their beliefs, Papo’s work focuses firmly on the lives and routines of a group of 15 homeschooled children living in New York’s Catskill Mountains. They are a disparate bunch: babyfaced True, with her long hair and rosary; Morgan, clutching a microscope in one image and Thor’s hammer in the next; tiny Grisha and Anastasia enticing a squirrel from behind a window; the playful farmboy Roan bundled in a cowboy’s fringed jacket and coonskin cap, alongside his big sister Iris, whose aloof gaze reminds us that homeschooled or not, teenagers are teenagers. 

Papo moved to the Catskills in the fall of 2010, her husband and five-month-old daughter in tow. The young family had fled New York City in search of a slower pace, and room to find new bearings. “After my daughter, Zohar, was born I went through some hard times adjusting to my new life as a mother. I very soon came to realize that it would take me a lot longer than ‘a few months’ to find a balance between work and motherhood,” Papo explains. “Moving to upstate New York was a relief at the time.” 

They settled in Woodstock, and soon found their place in the small town. It was then that Papo first heard of the home education movement, through a new acquaintance who was homeschooling her five-year-old child. Intrigued, Papo asked the mother for permission to photograph the young girl. Photographs of other homeschooled children soon followed, as Papo found more subjects through word-of-mouth in the tight-knit community. 

At first, she saw the project as a wider series of portraits that could illuminate some commonality between the children. But as the work progressed, two things became clear: “The children were all so different than one another in so many ways that a common thread would be impossible to detect, and, after photographing one child, I just wanted to spend more time with them,” Papo recalls. 

Her approach was simple: To capture the days of these children who were not trapped at desks, surrounded by classmates or furnished with scheduled activities. Her dreamlike pictures speak to afternoons lost in her subjects’ worlds; warm wood-paneled rooms, snowy forests and fecund backyards. For some of the kids, their education was as much about exploring the natural world as it was concerned with textbook learning. Papo says the children were uninhibited in front of the camera. As they went about their days, she would occasionally ask them to pause so she could make a picture when she found something interesting.

Papo followed their journeys of discovery as she was treading her own new ground artistically, having set aside a longtime devotion to the medium of film to shoot her first digital project. It was not a decision she made lightly, but the economics were undeniable. “The world moves forward, you have to move with it,” she says. “In the end, the image is what’s important, not my emotional connection to film.”

Abandoning her Mamiya 645 for a Canon EOS 5D Mark II, she sought to work on overcast days and in soft light in order to replicate the “painterly” aspect of her film work. One luxury of this project was that she often had anywhere from several hours to days to spend with her subjects.

Growing up in Israel, Papo was, by her own description, a “shy and lonely” child. She had three much older brothers and often felt removed from the family dynamic. By the time she was an adolescent, her siblings had already moved out of the house and she spent much of her time alone. Discussing “Homeschooled,” she acknowledges that this project—and in some ways, all of her work—is an interrogation of those “sensitive years” and their complicated legacies.

In her editing process, Papo works alone on her early edits, always revisiting work to pull out images that went unseen on an earlier pass. Only then does she share a loose edit with friends and colleagues before sitting down with a curator to create a specific exhibit. In the case of “Homeschooled,” this last and crucial step was done in partnership with Ariel Shanberg, executive director of the Center for Photography at Woodstock, which exhibited the work this spring. “While my approach to the editing process was artistic and emotional, his was objective and logical,” Papo explains. 

Papo estimates that she photographed 15 families (some didn’t make the cut for the exhibition) but feels like she could have shot many more. The project’s completion was spurred by the family’s April, 2013 move to Germany, where Papo now resides. 

The move, decided upon in late 2012, provided her with the urgency to finish “Homeschooled,” shooting more in the last six months of her time in Woodstock than she had in the previous year and a half. 

Papo plans to publish a book of the work. “I need to spend more time with the pictures. I literally shot until the night I left for Berlin, seven months pregnant, and now I have a baby,” she says, adding that she hopes next year will be more productive because her 20-month-old will be going to nursery school. “That’s why I don’t homeschool,” she laughs. “I respect the parents who do it, I just don’t know how they do it!”

article.article_title: From the Art Fairs: Michelle Dunn Marsh on Kimiko Yoshida's "Brides"
article.meta_description: The founder of Minor Matters Books discusses Yoshida's self-portraits, which feature bridal dress adapted from different cultures and traditions.
article.article_text_abstract: The founder of Minor Matters Books discusses Yoshida's self-portraits, which feature bridal dress adapted from different cultures and traditions.
article.article_image_caption: “The Blue Yoruba Bride, Nigeria,” 2005, by Kimiko Yoshida. M.I.A. Gallery exhibited Yoshida’s series “The Brides” in Seattle last year and at Paris Photo L.A. in May.
article.article_text:
As we were working on our annual Fine-Art Photography Issue, photo gallerists, publishers, curators and artists from around the world were gathering at two big art fairs: The AIPAD Photography Show New York, organized by the Association of International Photography Art Dealers, and Paris Photo LA, which the organizers of the long-standing art fair in Paris have been bringing to the back lot at Paramount Studios in Los Angeles since 2013. These fairs give collectors, photographers, curators and editors insights into the fine-art market and an opportunity to view new work. 

We asked an attendee of both fairs, Michelle Dunn Marsh, what stood out to her. Marsh is the founder of Minor Matters Books and executive director of Photographic Center Northwest in Seattle, and was one of the judges of The Curator competition. 

“One of the most striking booths I saw at Paris Photo LA was that of Seattle-based [gallerist] Mariane Ibrahim-Lenhardt, featuring the work of Kimiko Yoshida,” says Marsh. “‘The Brides’—a series of self-portraits that are mysterious, luscious, and cross generational and cultural borders—made an impact on me when I saw them last fall in Seattle, and they were, if possible, even more distinctive among the vast array of work on display at Paramount Studios.”

In the series, the Tokyo-born artist photographs herself in bridal dress adapted from different cultures and traditions. Her exhibition at Ibrahim’s M.I.A. Gallery in Seattle last year was titled “Something Blue.” The title plays on the proverb about a bride needing to wear “something old, something new, something borrowed, something blue” for good luck on her wedding day, and on Yoshida’s monochromatic compositions in which she, the subject, almost disappears into the background. This year, she has shown her work at the Vitraria Glass +A Museum in Venice, Italy, and she will have a solo show at the International Photo Festival in Kyoto. 

Yoshida, who divides her time between Tokyo, Venice and Paris, is one of many international artists Ibrahim-Lenhardt has shown in Seattle since 2013. Says Marsh, “Over the last two years I have been consistently impressed with Mariane Ibrahim-Lenhardt’s gallery program. A recent transplant to Seattle from France, she has infused the art scene here with a new worldview through powerful exhibitions by contemporary photographic artists such as Yoshida, Maimouna Guerresi, Fabrice Monteiro and Scarlett Coten, among many others. The Seattle Art Museum and Los Angeles County Museum of Art are just two of the many institutions acquiring the work of artists she champions.”

article.article_title: A Skateboarding Wet-Plate Photographer's Year-Long Cadillac Project
article.meta_description: Matt Albert turned an interest in board sports and antique photography into a social media campaign and gallery exhibitions, funded by Cadillac.
article.article_text_abstract: Matt Alberts turned an interest in board sports and antique photography into a social media campaign and gallery exhibitions, funded by Cadillac.
article.article_image_caption: An alumitype of skiing/snowboarding couple Tyler and Kirstin Lindsay in their backyard, Aspen, Colorado. The image is part of “The Seasons Collection,” shot by Matt Alberts for Cadillac.
article.article_text:
Matt Alberts had big plans for a trip down the West Coast with his portable wet-plate studio—a 1973 Airstream land yacht—to continue his “LIFERS” project, a series of portraits of people “who eat, sleep and breathe skateboarding just because they love it.” He had just finished a trip around the south and east, mounting pop-up shows at skate shops along the way. But his truck and trailer were stuck in New York, where his money had run out. 

Then he learned through a social media connection that Cadillac was loaning vehicles to brand ambassadors. So he contacted Fleishman-Hillard, the automaker’s PR firm, to ask for support. “I figured getting a vehicle sponsor would make it so much easier to do what I’m doing,” Alberts says.

He had called at the right time, with the right project, and ended up with a year-long sponsorship. It included funding for three month-long road trips, with an assignment to produce “The Seasons Collection.” Alberts describes it as “a multimedia photography collection of adventure-sports-driven stories about people who push the limits in pursuit of their passion.” They include surfers, mountain bikers and skiers, in addition to skateboarders.

The project is currently under way. While making wet-plate portraits of subjects he finds along the way who have made a lifestyle of their passion for a sport, Alberts is documenting his travels for social media using digital photography and video cameras. He will also mount three exhibitions of his wet-plate photographs.

When Alberts pitched the project, Cadillac executives saw how it could dovetail with Cadillac’s then-new “Dare Greatly” campaign. The campaign is an attempt to revive the struggling brand by associating Cadillac with artists, activists and others who are challenging the status quo. 

“We really admired what Matt was doing, and the network he created,” says Eneuri Acosta, Cadillac’s Lifestyle and Luxury Communications Manager. “We’re looking for new avenues to talk to new customers and new demographics in a way that’s credible. Matt gave us the opportunity to do that. What he was doing lined up perfectly with what we envisioned Cadillac to be doing in the photography space. We’ve always thought we can speak to that particular audience credibly because Cadillac has had influence over pop culture over the years.”

Of course, Alberts is challenging the status quo of photography by embracing a fussy, expensive 19th century photographic process. Six or seven years into a successful career as a wedding photographer, he says, “I just couldn’t sit in front of my computer anymore.”

In early 2013 he took a course with Denver photographer Quinn Jacobson, a master of the wet-plate process. “I was immediately hooked,” says Alberts. He decided to combine it with his passion for skateboarding, and make portraits that challenged the stereotype of skateboarders as ne’er-do-wells. Wet-plate photography gives him a way of “seeing right under the skin. You’re able to capture the soul, and see the real person inside,” he explains.

By chance, he met Chet Childress at an event in Denver, and asked the skateboarding legend to pose for a portrait. “I made three images of Chet on black glass,” and the “LIFERS” project was born, Alberts says. 

He bought an 11 x 14 Chamonix view camera, some antique lenses, and the Airstream. His first road trip was along Route 66 from Colorado to California, supported in part by an Indiegogo fundraiser and “a little bit of backing” from Red Bull and Pabst Blue Ribbon, two clients for whom he’s shot events. Accompanying Alberts were Childress, Joe Fernandez and Coburn Huff—all skaters with extensive connections in the skating community.

“We shot a whole bunch of legendary skaters,” Alberts says. Back in Denver, he mounted an exhibit. “We had an awesome party, but I didn’t sell enough prints to even break even on the framing.” He was $10,000 in debt.

He shot a couple of weddings to get himself through the winter. Then, with $4,000 from a skate community benefactor, he took another road trip through Nebraska, Missouri and Arkansas, then up to Philadelphia, where he parked the Airstream in his parents’ yard. Along the way, Alberts mounted a series of pop-up shows at skate shops. “I sold some prints, got us more gas money, and kept us going,” he says, explaining that the project was never about the money, but about doing what he loved. 

Alberts eventually made his way to New York, where he “made portraits of legendary old-school New York skateboarders.” Among those he traveled with was skater Nate Fantasia, who is sponsored by Mighty Healthy, a skate clothing line. Alberts ended up photographing Mighty Healthy owner Ray Mate. “He posted a picture of a Cadillac on Instagram, and I said, ‘What’s up with that?’”

That’s how Alberts learned of Cadillac’s brand ambassador program. “They’re trying to get influential social media people into their vehicles” to talk the brand up to followers, Alberts says. He wanted a vehicle for the next leg of the “LIFERS” project, from Portland to L.A., so he made a pitch.

“I put together a plan to do a month-long skate trip called Northwest Passage,” he says. The 18-page document described Alberts’ social media following for “LIFERS,” the press the project had received and a summary of the costs. “It answered the questions: What have we done, where have we been, and what are we trying to do,” Alberts says. He also produced a video re-capping the Route 66 trip, to demonstrate his video production skills. 

“I pitched this one-month trip, and they said, ‘How about if we make it a year?’” Alberts says. The automaker also asked him to expand the scope of the project beyond skateboarding, to include a broader spectrum of adventure sports. 

Acosta says Alberts’ ability to document the journey for social media was essential. But the photographer’s social media following—which is small—was less important. Acosta explains that Cadillac planned to use its own social media channels, and expected the project to get social media traction through the networks of adventure-sports athletes that would be featured in the project. 

Alberts says it took seven months of discussions to nail down all the details of the project, which were finally spelled out in a 20-page contract. He isn’t discussing the budget details, but says that in addition to providing two vehicles for the road trips, Cadillac is paying travel expenses, including gas costs and some hotel expenses. (The crew will sleep in the Airstream and camp out most nights.) Alberts hinted that his fee was modest, covering his debt for the “LIFERS” project to date, but not much more. “I’m just about breaking even, but I have cool art, exposure and awesome experience.”

Alberts and his crew completed the first trip in March; it focused on skiers and snowboarders. A private exhibition of wet plate images from the trip was held in April in L.A. The second and third trips were scheduled for May and August. Alberts is chronicling the trips on Tumblr (thelifersproject.tumblr.com/) and Instagram (@thelifersproject). Videos are being archived on the project’s website (thelifersproject.com) as well as on YouTube.

article.article_title: Q&A: Joshua Chuang, Chief Curator of the Center for Creative Photography
article.article_text_abstract: As the collecting institution founded by Ansel Adams prepares to celebrate its 40th year, its chief curator reimagines the museum’s role, creating dialogues between masters, contemporary image makers and artists working in other disciplines.
article.article_image_credit: Lucas Blalock, "Untitled," 2012, courtesy the artist and Ramiken Crucible.
article.article_image_caption: Blalock's work, along with that of contemporary photographers Owen Kydd and John Lehr, is part of CCP's summer show, "The Pure Products of America Go Crazy," which is showing through September 13, 2015.
article.article_text:
In 1975, photographer Ansel Adams and University of Arizona president John Schaefer established the Center for Creative Photography (CCP) on the university’s campus in Tucson. Unique for its time, the CCP was chiefly concerned with acquiring the archives of masters like Adams, Wynn Bullock, Harry Callahan, Lola Alvarez Bravo and many others. A lot has changed in photography, and in how museums present images, since then. In April 2014, when Joshua Chuang joined the CCP as chief curator from Yale University Art Gallery, he was tasked with shaping the future of one of the medium’s most important museums. In May of this year, CCP’s 40th, PDN spoke with Chuang about his first year at the museum, about what we can expect from the programming there, what kinds of photos he wants to acquire and how he plans to present the work of contemporary photographers.

Photo District News: You’re a little over a year into your tenure there. What’s been most interesting for you thus far?

Joshua Chuang: Before I came here I had some basic familiarity with the collections. What I’ve tried to do is become more intimately familiar with them, thinking that I could make some headway in a year. And in fact this is going to be a long endeavor, because the collections are so deep, so rich and so relatively untapped.

PDN: Have you found anything particularly exciting or surprising?

JC: There are the things people know about: We’ve got the Ansel Adams archive, we’ve got Wynn Bullock and Harry Callahan and Aaron Siskind and Frederick Sommer. But maybe not that many people know that one of the early acquisitions of contemporary photography was the original set of prints from Larry Sultan and Mike Mandel’s “Evidence.” We’ve got the archive of that project—all the letters they wrote to the various companies and archives to get access. We have the history behind these objects and the context. For instance, before the CCP acquired the show, Mike Mandel and Larry Sultan had debuted this body of work at SFMOMA, and it was their choice to present the works as artifacts, so they were simply sandwiched between glass and pinned to the wall. No frame, no mat; they were meant to be understood as art objects. When the CCP acquired the work it agreed to keep the [exhibition] tour going. Here at CCP, everything was properly matted and framed. The next venue after CCP was Harvard, the Fogg Museum, whose curator said yes to taking the show on the basis of seeing it at SFMOMA. So when he got the crates he was really chagrinned because he expected to see what he saw at SFMOMA. There’s a whole series of correspondence between him and the CCP about how the CCP just totally ruined the conceptual conceit of the work by framing it. There’s letters from Mike Mandel and Larry Sultan in there, too. Those are the stories that you don’t typically get at a museum that might just have a portfolio of work. You get the original flashpoints around the body of work. You’re able to see what was at stake at that time and are able to use that information to think about the work anew. It’s not just what we have in the collection, it’s this larger sweeping context, a fabric if you will, that you can weave about an entire scene, an entire generation of photographic activity.

PDN: Who is the CCP audience? Is it the general public, or do you draw a more specialized viewer?

JC: For the whole history of the CCP we have not charged admission, and typically museums use admission or membership to learn more about their audiences. I’m new here, and I’m still learning who our core audiences are. There are the obvious constituents like the MFA photography students here on campus, and the various groups of photographers and photography clubs that come and see our exhibitions. But I think that your audience constantly evolves. Before I came here the CCP hadn’t had a full-time curator for its collection in place for a number of years. I don’t think there was necessarily a cohesive vision for the kinds of exhibitions to expect from the CCP. That sort of thing can effect your audience too, and their expectations, so I see my job as resetting those expectations and reaching out again to our audiences and finding out more about what they like, what they don’t like, what more we can do. In a sense we’re starting again.

PDN: What should audiences look forward to from CCP programming?

JC: When I first came on board we had a fairly blank slate in terms of exhibitions. What I thought I would do was to, for the first four exhibitions, create a kind of menu or primer for the kinds of things that we might be able to expect from the CCP going forward. The first show, which was actually already on the books when I came on board, was called “Performance.” These were contemporary photographs from the Douglas Nielsen collection. Doug Nielsen is one of the most prominent collectors of photography in Tucson, and a very well respected modern dance professor here on campus. We pretty much just emptied out his loft, and he brought his dance classes in to respond to the work as part of their assignments. There was a cross-disciplinary engagement there, [and we demonstrated] that [the CCP] can collaborate and start conversations with some unexpected partners.

The first show that I conceived is called “Astronomical: Photographs of Our Solar System and Beyond.” I knew coming in that one of the strongest academic units here on campus is the science department. In fact, there’s a unit here called the Lunar and Planetary Laboratory that is instrumental in helping NASA develop its space exploration. I would go so far as to say that without this unit, NASA wouldn’t have accomplished nearly as much. One of the things that I found out when I got here is that NASA actually has one of its image archives right here on campus. They’ve given the U of A, a complete set of vintage Lunar Orbiter pictures. So [I] quickly put together an exhibition that I’m really quite proud of. We were able to reach out to the scientists and there have been astronomers all over the region who’ve been coming to see the show. [It’s] certainly not a strictly fine-art photography exhibition, but that’s one of the messages I wanted to send.

This year is the CCP’s 40th anniversary. My colleague Becky Senf and I are co-organizing a 40th anniversary exhibition. It’s been a wonderful excuse to really dig into, not only the collections, but into some of the stories behind the collections. We’ve issued invitations to former [CCP] directors, curators and archivists, to ask them to choose a print or a suite of prints to include in the exhibition, and also to write the wall text and some kind of anecdote about why this piece is important to [him or her]. When the collection started to take form in the mid-70s to the early 80s, there was incredible excitement in the field, because it was really unique in the world at that point. And now of course you have other institutions that are starting to collect archives and starting to collect photography in great depth. But the things that came in those first several years are amazing, because there was a concerted effort on the part of the entire field to enrich this place.

The next show after that is going to be a monographic, Lee Friedlander Western landscape exhibition. In the early 1990s, he turned to the square format, the Hasselblad Superwide, and he stuck with that for the next 25 years. He’s no longer using it, but it became the dominant form of his work and really changed the look and feel of his work. He started using that camera right here in Tucson; he was photographing the Sonoran desert, so we thought it was fitting to look [again] at that whole body of work here. That’s a sampler of the kinds of exhibitions that we hope to do here going forward.

PDN: Have you started acquiring work?

JC: Yes. We’re chiefly in the business of acquiring archives. It’s not as easy, clean or straightforward as going to a commercial gallery and buying a print. It’s a series of negotiations and relationship management, and sometimes it takes years to finalize these negotiations. But we have been making discrete purchases of works that aren’t part of larger archives. My emphasis for the past year has really been on conceptual work. Not necessarily because it’s a particular favorite area of mine—it is—but because the Center really doesn’t have very much of that material. That Larry Sultan–Mike Mandel “Evidence” body of work is an exception in our holdings. I would say the majority of the work here is classical, fine-art photography (I don’t think contemporary photographers even use that term anymore). Of course now is also a time to look at conceptual work, because you can still find good values, and you can’t find good values in things that are already established. That’s been my focus. So just to name a few things: We acquired a suite of unique works by Ray Metzker, who recently passed away, and on the other end of the spectrum we acquired a diptych by Matt Lipps, a San Francisco-based contemporary artist.

We’re doing a summer show for the first time in a while. It’s focused on the work of three contemporary photographers: Lucas Blalock, Owen Kydd and John Lehr. The title, “The Pure Products of America Go Crazy” is taken from a William Carlos Williams poem written in 1923. It’s going to be a visual conversation between their bodies of work, but I’m spiking that conversation with about a dozen objects from the collection—old-school things, quite unexpected. If you can imagine it’s like a movie credit line, it would be Owen, Lucas and John being the headline stars, but also featuring works by Ansel Adams, Brett Weston, Harry Callahan, Frederick Sommer, Charles Sheeler, Paul Outerbridge, Jan Groover—people like that.

I’m going to be acquiring at least a work each [from Blalock, Kydd and Lehr] because I think that it’s really important for the CCP not just to add strength to strength, but to extend the scope of its collection to address what’s being produced now.

PDN: Why did you choose Blalock, Lehr and Kydd for this exhibition?

JC: Of this generation of the, quote unquote, new American photographers, the work of these three artists stands out. The meaning of their work goes beyond the means used to make the final works. Process is certainly an important part of their work, but I think that each of them have gotten beyond that to deal with real meaning. The other thing that they have in common, and this is the reason for this overarching title, is that they each deal with an aspect of American retail or consumer culture.

Lucas is photographing things he gets from the dollar store, cast-off things from junk shops, really cheap materials that don’t usually get the kind of large-format-camera scrutiny. He’s applying pressure that way and really playing around with that mismatch. He’s able to create, for me, some quite insightful work not just about photography, but about our culture and society. Owen is largely looking at storefronts, things in storefronts, so we’re going to be focusing on that particular aspect of his work. And John is looking at disused, boarded-up shops and surfaces that have a kind of palimpsest aspect to them. All of them have totally embraced the digital, but know that their work needs to be about more than just the digital. And I think that they’re doing it each in different ways.

PDN: By “beyond process,” do you mean that they reach beyond the contemporary concern of “What is a photograph?”

JC: That’s right. As a museum person, I’m thinking about the now, but I’m also thinking about the future. How is this work going to resonate 15, 20, 50 years from now? If you are another kind of institution like a Kunsthalle and you don’t have a collection and you’re trying to put together shows that resonate under current circumstances, you’re perhaps not thinking so much about these other questions. But since we're a collecting institution and we’re trying to create ties in-between what has happened and what is happening, I would hope that any work that I feature in this prominent a way could stand up to that scrutiny over time.

PDN: How is the work of the contemporary photographers going to be in dialogue with the work of masters like Callahan and Friedlander and Siskind?

JC: It’s going to be this iterative, back and forth visual conversation between [the contemporary photographers’] work, and I’m going to punctuate those conversations with these older voices; but it will not be the expected sort of thing. For instance, Ansel Adams: I’ve never seen it published before, but it’s a still life that he did as a young photographer. It actually looks very contemporary; it’s got a glass bottle, a triangular rule of some sort. There’s a string running through it. It’s a collection of objects and it looks kind of like a Lucas Blalock. The Westons, Brett and Edward, were incredibly interested in surfaces and in objects that have surfaces, and so I think it’s a chance to put their work in a new light. Because often when you see their work it is in the context of their own work. It doesn’t often have the chance to dialogue with what’s going now, so I’m hoping that this interaction helps both parties—the old and the new.

PDN: What’s exciting to you about presenting photography to contemporary audiences?

JC: If art is good, it’s really fulfilling and it shouldn’t be that difficult to make it matter. I think that that’s really the job. The job is to make whatever it is that you believe in, and that you see quality in, relevant. Whether it’s something from the 19th century or even something totally obscure from the mid-twentieth century. If the seeds of the object or the work’s relevancy are there, if I could play some part in planting them, cultivating them, helping them to grow, I’ll feel I’ve made some sort of contribution to the field. That’s the crux of the job.

“The Pure Products of America Go Crazy”

article.article_title: How I Got That Shot: Carlos Serrao's Blend of Sports and Fashion for Nike
article.meta_description: The photographer was tasked with shooting Nike's Tech Pack apparel autumn/winter campaign, and referenced thermal imaging for his red-hued multiple exposure images.
article.article_text_abstract: The photographer was tasked with shooting Nike's Tech Pack apparel autumn/winter campaign, and referenced thermal imaging for his red-hued multiple exposure images.
article.article_image_caption: Serrao wanted to shoot the multiple exposures in camera, capturing the models as they moved and posed with the jackets both zipped and open. He used a fast flash duration to freeze the action for each exposure.
article.article_text:
Client: Nike

Art Director: Andre Simmons

For about ten years, clients like Nike, Puma, Speedo and ESPN the Magazine have been hiring Carlos Serrao to capture action. He and his crew are used to finding creative solutions to technical and logistical challenges, particularly when they involve professional athletes or Olympic competitors who can spare only a few minutes for a shoot. Clients who know him and his long-time crew “know that we like to experiment,” he says. “A lot of what we do involves technical lighting, color, motion.” 

A job shooting the fall/winter line of Nike Tech Pack sportswear required him to shoot movements, but presented few constraints. “That division [of Nike] has more leeway to be fashionable and experimental,” Serrao explains. The challenge was not about locations or scheduling, but how to make the sportswear look interesting. “The fun part is solving not the logistics, but: How do we light this? How do we shoot this?” he says. “These types of jobs are basically dream jobs.”

The art director on the shoot, Andre Simmons of Nike, first worked with Serrao in 2004 and has hired him many times since. In describing the look he wanted, he referenced some of Serrao’s recent fashion assignments, some thermal imaging, and one of Serrao’s earliest sports ad campaigns in which he added “an element of red color to demonstrate the heat and speed of [the athlete’s] musculature,” Serrao recalls. He would do something similar with the Tech Pack images, using red tones “to symbolize the heat that was retained or expelled by the apparel,” contrasting it with a bluish tone on the models and clothes. 

Simmons wanted the models to pose with the jackets both zipped up and unzipped to show the lining. Says Serrao, “We thought it would be fun to do that as multiple exposures. You can do it in post, but I wanted to experiment with doing it in camera.”

Logistics

The shoot took place at Siren Studios in Los Angeles, on a cyclorama wide enough to give the models room to move. Serrao suggested one model he had worked with before because her movements in front of the camera were fluid and graceful. For the male model, Serrao’s studio manager did a small casting session. “I like to meet them in person,” Serrao says. “I ask, ‘What sport did you play in college?’” 

Some of Serrao’s crew members, including his chief lighting technician, Ron Loepp, have been working with him for ten years on both his still and video shoots. While film crews often have rigidly defined roles, on Serrao’s sets, he says, “They wear many hats.” He’ll typically show them references to explain the look he’s after, and they all work on lights and gear to make it happen. 

Lighting

Serrao wanted to illuminate a large area of the cyc in which the models would be free to move around while he shot from different angles. “I like to use an overall wash of light from above,” he says, “so often what we’ll do is put a framed 20 x 20-foot silk above the set and shine a strobe head through that.” Though Serrao no longer recalls whether he and Loepp used Profoto or Broncolor strobes on the shoot, he knows he needed short flash duration and fast recycling time to freeze the models’ movements. “For me what works is to put a bi-tube head into a single power pack. It provides more power, and speeds up the flash duration.” By adding a CTB gel to the overhead light, Serrao says, he was able to get a “subtle blue tone” in the highlights. 

To light the back wall of the cyc, which was about 12 feet from the model, he and his crew placed two strobes just behind the models and out of the frame, positioned at a 45 degree angle. On the grids, Serrao used theatrical blue gels, for a deeper, more saturated blue tone.

For frontal lighting on the models, he set up grids about waist- or chest-high to the model; on these he used deep red gels. He experimented to get the right output. “You have to turn the power down so it doesn’t become the keylight or the brightest light there,” he adds. “With the gel on it, you have to be careful—if you go too bright it’ll go pink, but if you go too low it won’t show.” Once he had the palette he wanted, he worked with his digital tech, Damon Loble, to create a color profile to work with while previewing shots on the set. 

About getting the multiple exposures, Serrao says, “It’s an old strobe trick.” He popped the strobe, then moved the camera or had the model get into a new position while the lights were out, popped the strobes again, then did it a third time to capture the model in another pose. Between pops of the strobe, Serrao says, “I’m moving the camera a little bit, so I’m capturing him in different parts of the frame.” He slowed the shutter speed to two to three seconds, giving the model time to zip or unzip the jacket. 

He notes, “We were trying to get as fast a flash duration as possible, so we shot between 1/1600th and 1/2000th,” which allowed him to freeze the action. Serrao says that he’s used to being very precise about the output on each of his light sources when he needs to freeze motion on an athlete—say, a basketball player going for a jump shot or a sprinter coming out of the starting blocks—in order to eliminate any motion blur. On the Tech Pack shots, however, the models’ movements were slower, and “we had more leeway.” 

Camera

Serrao used a Nikon D800 with an 85mm prime lens, and an 105mm to capture small stitching details on the apparel. 

Serrao recalls, “We were shooting at maybe ISO 400 to 800, and maybe f/8 or maybe f/5.6.” 

Serrao always shoots handheld to follow the action, and likes to shoot fast, which worked well because the client wanted many variations and lots of material. Serrao was pleased with how his in-camera multiple exposure experiment worked. “When it comes up on a monitor, it’s a surprise for everyone,” he says. While he knew a retoucher would work on most of the shots, he says, the in-camera multiple exposures provided a useful reference for how they should look. “The retoucher knows it has to have a certain organic quality.”

PostProduction

“I usually like to look through my favorites,” Serrao says, but on this shoot, Simmons had wanted to bring back a lot of variations to show other creatives. An edit “would have taken weeks,” Serrao says. So instead of waiting for an edit, Simmons left with a hard drive, and Nike handled the retouching. 

On a typical shoot, Serrao likes to arrange his selected images in groups, “to let you see the narrative of the story or an overview of the shoot.” When he sends his selects or a rough edit of a video, he labels his work because he knows it’ll be passed around the client’s office. “We’ll do our own edit with credits, my name, my partner’s name. Then you’ll hear from someone else at the agency that you haven’t heard from in a while saying, ‘I’ve just seen that thing you did.’”

article.article_title: Lens Roundup: 18 Lenses for Any Need
article.meta_description: PDN canvasses the market for the latest great glass for video, mirrorless, DSLR, rangefinder and medium format camera systems.
article.article_text_abstract: PDN canvasses the market for the latest great glass for video, mirrorless, DSLR, rangefinder and medium format camera systems.
article.article_text:
The famed photographer Yousuf Karsh said that the “heart and mind are the true lens of the camera.” Unfortunately, those tend to be a bit difficult to upgrade. Getting the latest precision ground glass with optical coatings, tiny motors and microcircuits, however, is pretty straightforward. No matter what camera you shoot with, you’re spoiled for choice. We’ve highlighted some recent intros along with some old favorites below; for full-size images, see the photo gallery above. 

For Mirrorless



Olympus M.ZUIKO ED 14–150mm f/4–5.6 II 
With a 28–300mm full-frame equivalent focal length, this 10.7X lens boasts a dust- and splashproof construction to match the durable build of Olympus’ OM-D series of Micro Four Thirds cameras. It updates a 2010 lens with the use of ZUIKO Extra-low Reflection Optical Coating on the surface of the lens to eliminate scratches as well as reduce ghosting and lens flare. A versatile zoom, it can focus on subjects up to approximately 13 inches from the end of the lens.

Price: $599
Info: www.getolympus.com



Panasonic Lumix G Macro 30mm f/2.8
The Lumix Macro G 30mm f/2.8 lets Micro Four Thirds shooters get close, with a focusing distance starting at 4.13 inches from the glass. The lens features a maximum aperture of f/2.8 with a 1:1 magnification. The lens has an aspherical element to reduce chromatic aberration, a coating to prevent flare and ghosting and offers a 240-frames-per-second Drive AF system and optical image stabilization. 

Price: $398 
Info: www.panasonic.com



Samsung 50–150mm f/2.8 S ED OIS
The second lens in Samsung’s premium S series, the 50–150mm offers a full-frame equivalent focal length of 77–231mm and an aperture range of f/2.8–22. It employs an Ultra-Precise Stepping Motor (UPSM) that Samsung claims is three times more precise in acquiring and controlling focus than a conventional stepping motor. Multi-axis image stabilization keeps blur to a minimum. The lens is also dust- and water-resistant. 

Price: $1,600
Info: www.samsung.com



Sony Zeiss Vario-Sonnar T* 24-70mm f/2.8
This new zoom lens for Sony’s A-mount cameras updates the previous all-purpose zoom by improving the performance and durability. Among the enhancements are dust and moisture resistance and improved AF tracking with the use of a new Supersonic Wave Motor and lens processing LSI chip. The lens’ AF system was built to exploit the 4D focusing system being rolled out in new Sony bodies, including the A77 II. The 24–70mm f/2.8 features Zeiss’ T* coating to reduce flare and ghosting when shooting in bright sunlight. 

Price: $2,098
Info: www.sony.com



Fujifilm XF 16mm f/1.4R WR
The compact new Fujifilm XF 16mm f/1.4R WR delivers a 24mm full-frame equivalent fixed focal length with a maximum aperture of f/1.4. You can focus on a subject as close as 6 inches away from the lens. Weather-resistant, the XF 16mm boasts nine sealing points in eight different areas of the lens, so it can withstand the same tempests as Fujifilm’s X-T1. It supports high-speed autofocus and has depth-of-field markings to guide you while you shoot.

Price: $1,000
Info: www.fujifilmusa.com



Voigtländer Nokton 10.5mm f/0.95
This unique prime lens for Micro Four Thirds cameras has a super-wide aperture with a Selective Aperture Control System that allows users to alternate between clicked stops for still shooting and de-clicked operation when shooting video. It offers a 21mm equivalent focal length and weighs in at 1.3 pounds. The aperture stops down to f/16, and you can focus on objects as close as 6.7 inches from the lens, too.

Price: $1,099
Info: voigtlaender.com

DSLR & Rangefinder



Canon EF 11–24mm f/4L USM
Canon went back to the drawing board for its ultra wide angle 11–24mm, incorporating a new optical design to deliver straighter lines and fewer curves despite the space-swallowing focal length. It boasts a minimum focusing distance of just 11 inches from the lens (at 24mm) and uses an internal focusing mechanism to maintain a consistent size during operation.

Price: $2,999
Info: www.usa.canon.com



Nikon AF-S Nikkor 400mm f/2.8 FL ED VR
For sports or wildlife photographers who require range at any cost (and we do mean any cost),Nikon’s recently refreshed 400mm f/2.8 is worth a look. While it’s still a beast in the size department, Nikon has managed to shave almost two pounds of weight from the original design. It offers Nikon’s Vibration Reduction to deliver up to four stops of image stabilization per CIPA standards. VR is available in a new sports mode that recognizes panning, preserving intended motion blur while keeping camera shake at bay. An electromagnetic diaphragm helps keep the lens stable during high-speed shooting.

Price: $11,997
Info: www.nikonusa.com



Zeiss Distagon T* 1.4/35 ZM
With a maximum aperture of f/1.4, the Zeiss 1.4/35 ZM is the fastest member of the company’s M-mount, rangefinder lens family. This manual focus 35mm prime delivers shallow depth-of-field for portraiture or low-light environments, like city streets when the sun dips below the horizon. Its all-metal barrel should hold up to years of use. It stops down to f/16 in 1/3-stop increments, and has a minimum focusing distance of 28 inches. The glass elements are coated in the company’s T* anti-reflective coating to minimize flare. 

Price: $2,290
Info: www.zeiss.com



Leica Summarit-M 75mm f/2.4
Late in 2014, Leica refreshed its Summarit-M lineup by introducing redesigned models that were lighter and better-performing than their predecessors. The new Summarit-M 75mm f/2.4 now delivers a focusing distance of 27.5 inches. The 75mm—along with the other lenses in the revamped series—is now sold in either a black or silver anodized finish. The 75mm is assembled by hand in a process Leica describes as “painstaking” so you can rest assured you’re not the only one suffering for your art.

Price: $2,150
Info: us.leica-camera.com



Pentax DA 16–85mm f/3.5–5.6 ED DC WR
A 5.3X zoom for Pentax K-mount cameras, the DA 16–85mm f/3.5–5.6 covers a full-frame equivalent focal range of 24.5–130mm, making it a nice general-purpose zoom. HD coating reduces flare and ghosting and the lens boasts 11 seals for defense against the weather. Autofocus is driven by a quiet DC motor, and the lens uses Ricoh’s “quick-shift” system to switch seamlessly from AF to manual focusing when the camera is set to AF.

Price: $747
Info: www.us.ricoh-imaging.com



Sigma 24mm f/1.4 DG HSM Art
The new 24mm f/1.4 Art lens is designed for full-frame DSLRs. It features nine rounded aperture blades and a maximum magnification of 1:5.3. The minimum focusing distance is 9.8 inches. The lens incorporates both “F” Low Dispersion (FLD) glass and Special Low Dispersion (SLD) glass in 15 elements in 11 groups. According to Sigma, this construction minimizes chromatic aberration during magnification especially in the edge of the image field. By placing aspherical elements in the rear of the lens, Sigma said it was able to improve performance when shooting wide open, keeping distortion, flare and chromatic aberration to a minimum. A full-time manual focusing mechanism lets you switch into manual focusing during autofocus by rotating the lens ring. It’s sold in Canon (EF) and Nikon (F) mounts.

Price: $849
Info: www.sigmaphoto.com



Tamron 28–300mm f/3.5–6.3 Di VC PZD
Targeted at owners of Canon, Nikon and Sony full-frame cameras, Tamron’s new 28–300mm lensfeatures a smaller design than its predecessor, plus optical image stabilization for Canon and Nikon cameras (Sony handles that in-camera). Focus is driven by a standing-wave ultrasonic motor system and you can override autofocus any time you want to manually tweak your composition. The lens is moisture resistant and uses Tamron’s Broad-Band Anti-Reflection coatings to minimize flare and ghosting. 

Price: $849
Info: www.tamron-usa.com

For Medium Format 



Phase One Alpa HR 5.6/70mm
Phase One and Swiss lens maker Alpa paired up in late 2014; soon after, they announced the first fruits from their partnership, Phase One’s A-series. The series mates Alpa’s lenses with Phase One’s new IQ2 A-series digital camera back. The big difference from the existing IQ back is that the three Alpa lenses for the system have been specially calibrated and profiled for the back. After the lens is attached and selected in the back’s menu, lens corrections are automatically processed when importing photos into Capture One Pro 8.1/2. The 70mm Alpa HR delivers an aperture range from f/5.6–32 and can focus on objects as close as 31.5 inches from the lens.

Price: $4,520
Info: www.phaseone.com



Hasselblad 80mm f/2.8
The backbone of the company’s medium-format H system, the 80mm f/2.8 lens offers a minimum focusing distance of 2.3 feet. The lens stops down to a minimum aperture of f/32, and the lens has depth-of-field scale markings plus a distance scale on the exterior to aid focusing. 

Price: $2,970
Info: www.hasselblad.com

Video



Rokinon Cine DS 50mm T1.5 AS UMC
This manual-focus prime lens for full-frame cameras is capable of focusing on objects as close as 17.7-inches away. It features a de-clicked aperture for smooth operation during filming. The aperture is calibrated in the more accurate t-stops—not f-stops—as is standard with cinema lenses. You’ll enjoy an aperture range from T1.5 wide open down to T22. All lenses in the Cine DS family are color-matched by Rokinon so they’ll provide consistent color reproduction across focal lengths. They also share a common design with the focus and aperture rings in identical positions so you won’t have to reposition a follow focus when changing lenses. The aperture and lens rings have industry standard gearings to fit follow-focus accessories and focus distance and t-stop scale markings are duplicated on either side of the barrel. It’s sold in Canon EF and Nikon F mounts, as well as Sony A and E mounts.

Price: $599
Info: rokinon.com



Schneider Xenon FF-Prime 25mm T2.1
Available for Canon and Nikon full-frame DSLRs as well as PL- mount camera bodies, the Xenon FF Prime 25mm T2.1 sports focus markings on both sides of the lens. As on the other lenses in the company’s Xenon FF line, the focus and iris gearing are unified for easy interchange with follow-focus gearings. The lens boasts a 14-blade diaphragm for circular bokeh when shooting at a shallow depth of field and anti-reflection coatings to reduce sun glare. The lens can stop down to T22.

Price: $5,750
Info: www.schneideroptics.com



Tokina Cinema AT-X 50–135mm T3.0
Tokina’s Cinema AT-X 50–135mm T3.0 sports a de-clicked aperture calibrated in t-stops, and an industry-standard 114mm front barrel for matte boxes and a 112mm filter thread. It uses a parfocal design for keeping accurate focus during zoom. You’ll enjoy a constant aperture throughout the zoom range. Zoom, iris and focus markings appear on either side of the lens barrel. It’s sold in either PL or Canon EF mounts.

Price: $4,499
Info: www.tokinalens.com

article.article_title: Is The Art World Biased Against Commercial Photographers?
article.meta_description: Though some gallerists, curators and collectors may look down on photographers with commercial careers, others say those photographers develop skills that can help them succeed in fine-art careers.
article.article_text_abstract: Though some gallerists, curators and collectors may look down on photographers with commercial careers, others say those photographers develop skills that can help them succeed in fine-art careers.
article.article_image_caption: “Metro Pictures,” 2006, from Andy Freeberg’s series “Sentry.”
article.article_text:
If you’ve been to a portfolio review, you’ve probably seen photographers with successful commercial and editorial careers sharing their personal work with curators and gallerists. For myriad reasons, many photographers who first established themselves by shooting assignment work want to build fine-art careers.

While there are several examples of commercial and editorial photographers who’ve also shown and sold their work in galleries, it’s more common to see “artists” doing commercial work. And the path to a career that balances both art and commerce is elusive. While they aren’t as entrenched as they once were, biases in the art world against photographers with commercial backgrounds persist. “The quote unquote art world can be full of very snooty, elitist people,” notes gallerist Peter Fetterman.

“There are some galleries that won’t take on an artist that has a commercial component to their career; it’s just something they can’t see past,” says Sarah Hasted of Hasted Kraeutler Gallery.

But aspiring fine-art photographers shouldn’t let those biases deter them, several gallerists and photographers tell PDN. On the contrary, commercial careers can actually benefit aspiring fine-art photographers in a number of ways: by providing them income and the financial means to produce personal work; and by affording them opportunities to develop their craft. Many gallerists are open to representing photographers with commercial and editorial careers, and value their skills and experience.

“I think a lot of commercial and editorial photographers think that [all] gallerists are opposed to representing them based on that decision they’ve made [to build a commercial career],” Hasted says, “but that’s really not the case.”

“It’s of no concern to me the backstory or the history of the photographer,” states Fetterman. “It’s about whether the photographer has created something special.”

The first and most important step for a photographer breaking into the fine-art market is to create original work that interest gallerists and their clients. 

Andy Freeberg began his career as an editorial photographer and has spent the past eight years building a fine-art practice. He recalls speaking with a photo editor friend several years ago as he contemplated doing fine-art work. “‘Andy, do you know any magazine photographer that has ever become an art photographer?’” the friend asked. “We couldn’t really come up with anybody,” Freeberg recalls.

When Freeberg first took his personal work—black-and-white street photographs—to the Houston Fotofest portfolio reviews, “people liked it, but it wasn’t going to get to the next level,” he recalls. Freeberg did learn something, however. He saw the work of photographers who “got picked up” he says. “You really need to have something unique.”

Freeberg observed something else in Houston that was encouraging: “If you have something [great], there are people here who are interested.... These are people that are really passionate about photography and they want to see what’s out there.”

A couple of years later, Freeberg started to photograph the desks and gallery assistants at the entrances of art galleries because he “thought it was funny.” He showed a few of the images to his photo editor friend, who told him he was onto something. The “Sentry” images depict the white, tall front desks in major art galleries. Behind the desks the viewer can just make out the tops of the heads of the gallery workers who tend them. The work pokes fun at the unapproachability of the art world.

Through contacts he’d made at Fotofest, he showed the work to gallerists in New York; Jörg Colberg shared the work on Conscientious, his photography website; then gallerist James Danziger reached out and said he wanted to exhibit Freeberg’s photographs.

One show does not a career make, however. Freeberg recalls that despite good press and interest in the work from curators and collectors, “They were like, ‘Who is this guy?’ They weren’t ready to buy.” Feeling the need to quickly come up with another body of work to build on his first, Freeberg went to Russia and created “Guardians,” a series that depicts women who monitor galleries in Russian museums. He’s since followed that with a series depicting gallerists in their booths at art fairs. “It’s now eight years since I had that [first] show in New York and I’m just getting to the point where I feel like I can do this full-time,” Freeberg says.

Lack of time can be a problem for commercial and editorial photographers interested in creating fine-art projects: “It is like having two careers,” Freeberg says.

Though she had studied art at the Rhode Island School of Design and interned at Pace/MacGill gallery, early in her career Jill Greenberg chose to build her commercial career “so that I could support myself,” she recalls. “I really wanted to do both,” she says, but felt she needed “to make a decision.” As her commercial career grew, it trumped her personal work. “I was working nights and weekends to establish myself as a commercial photographer,” she says. “It is sort of hard to do both.”

Commercial success eventually afforded Greenberg the resources to do the personal work that established her as a fine-art photographer. One of her first solo exhibitions, “Monkey Portraits,” opened in 2004 at Kopeikin Gallery in Los Angeles. “I wouldn’t have been able to do the [portraits of] monkeys or the bears or the horses if I didn’t have a commercial career,” she says. “Those are really expensive shoots.”

Brian Paul Clamp, who shows Greenberg’s work in New York, says he likes “that an artist may be doing commercial work” for a number of reasons. “If they’re a successful photographer, it helps financially to fuel their fine art,” Clamp says. Commercial work also helps get the photographer’s name out there, and “takes a little pressure off me not being their sole source of income,” he adds.

Technical ability and professionalism are other benefits commercial and editorial photographers can bring to their fine-art work. “[Assignment work] makes them more knowledgeable about lighting, it makes them more knowledgeable about color palette and it in a lot of ways makes them more professional when you’re working with them,” explains Hasted.

Because she is “used to getting a lot done in a day,” Greenberg says, “I’ll work really hard when I’m my own boss…because that day is on me. If I’m spending $30,000 to do a shoot, I am going to make sure I get lots of pictures.”

“Being able to make work on tight deadlines forced me to think about how to make my artwork better,” says Kevin Cooley, who simultaneously built art and editorial careers after he graduated from the School of Visual Arts in 2000. “When you’re sent somewhere you have to make a picture no matter what the context is…. That is a skill that I think as an artist is pretty hard to obtain.”

Thanks to editorial assignments, Cooley also was able to travel on his clients’ dime and make personal work while on location. He also learned how to work as hard on his personal work as he does on his work for clients. “There’d be lots of time where I’d say to myself, ‘Why don’t I always treat my own artwork as seriously as I would treat the assignment?’ That sort of discipline really benefitted my artwork.”

As Cooley’s career has grown, his assignment work has often been “based on my artwork,” he says. For instance, Avinor—the Norwegian airport authority—hired him to create work based on his “Nachtfluge” series of long-exposure images that show commercial airline flight patterns at night.

Many commercial photographers make the mistake of thinking they have to create art that is completely unlike their assignment work. “They have this expectation of what people going into a gallery want to see, and the truth is, what people going into a gallery want to see is an artist’s voice and their vision,” Hasted says. “It’s when they’re trying too hard that is comes across as insincere or inauthentic.”

“If I see another image of a nude on a rock, I’m going to throw up,” Fetterman says. 

Hasted points out that Erwin Olaf, one of the artists she represents, has “always had a successful commercial career, but they always look like Erwin Olaf photographs.” Collectors have even requested to buy certain of his commercial images, she says.

Martin Schoeller, another of the artists Hasted represents, has also found a home in the fine-art world. Some of the first work he showed was close-up portraits of celebrities he made for himself while shooting magazine assignments. “Martin has a unique way of seeing,” Hasted says. “I don’t think people hold it against him that he has taken these great editorial images of these famous people. I think they embrace it with certain artists.”

Hasted admits that “some” collectors and curators may still look down on photographers with successful commercial careers, but, Fetterman notes, “real collectors want to collect what moves them, whether it comes from Madison Avenue or Timbuktu.”

The reality is that commercial and editorial photographers who want to build fine-art careers don’t face a more difficult road than any other aspiring artist. But “scoring big success in the fine-art world is like going to Vegas,” Fetterman says. “You may win or you may not win.”

“[Great work] can come from left field,” he adds. “What keeps all of us engaged in this field involved and excited [is the idea] that we’re going to find the new, great, original voice. And it can happen.”

Related: On Showing Both Commercial & Fine-Art Work: Emily Shur's Advice

article.article_title: How to Negotiate Prices for Commissioned Prints
article.meta_description: PDN talks to artists, gallery owners and curators about the criteria to consider in order to get the most out of your print sales.
article.article_text_abstract: PDN talks to artists, gallery owners and curators about the criteria to consider in order to get the most out of your print sales.
article.article_image_caption: Cleveland Clinic, the non-profit network of hospitals and research facilities, commissioned Catherine Opie to create 22 images of Lake Erie in all four seasons. Above: “Fall, Untitled 5.”
article.article_text:
Though it may seem counter-intuitive, it can be less expensive for a collector or curator to commission an artist to create a new photograph than to walk into a gallery and purchase an existing image. Of course that depends a lot on who the client is, what they want the artist to create, and how they plan to use the commissioned artwork.

Joanne Cohen, the executive director and curator of the Art Program at the Cleveland Clinic, the nonprofit medical center, frequently commissions art in all media. The Cleveland Clinic has an art collection of more than 5,400 pieces, including major photography-based commissions by artists such as Ray Charles White, Peter Newman and Catherine Opie. Between 2010–2011, Opie, an Ohio-born artist whose photos are in the collections of numerous museums including the Museum of Modern Art, created “Somewhere in the Middle,” a series of 22 large-format inkjet prints of photographs of Lake Erie in four seasons. The images—made for Hillcrest Hospital, one of the Cleveland Clinic’s community hospitals—maintain a consistent horizon line that runs the entire 100-foot length of the concourse of a new addition to the hospital. 

“I could not have gone out and bought 22 photographs by Cathy Opie,” says Cohen. “It would have been cost-prohibitive. We worked out a fee for her to produce the work, plus production costs.”

One reason the commission she negotiated was less expensive than a straight purchase was that, rather than making the images in the series available only to the hospital, Opie editioned some of them: She made numbered prints of the images available for purchase and exhibitions. “We paid her to create the work,” says Cohen, “and she was then able to monetize it.”

Cohen first approached Opie through a New York gallery that no longer handles her work, but was referred to Regen Projects, Opie’s Los Angeles dealer. Regen Projects suggested Cohen negotiate the commission, the contract and the price with the artist directly.

Commercial photographers are used to shooting an image to the specifications of a client and negotiating a licensing fee. When a fine-art photographer is asked to shoot a particular subject for a collector or curator who wants to own a print, establishing a price is more problematic. 

“Commissions are a little bit of an anomaly, but occasionally we do have them,” says Yancey Richardson, a New York City-based photography dealer and gallerist. “It’s always very difficult to price, because it’s difficult to find out what’s expected. Generally I approach commissions in terms of whether they are good for my artists. Is it something that is interesting for them to do? Is it something that will add to their body of work?”

Some artists who accept commissions choose not to publicize them. As one artist contacted for this article replied while declining to be interviewed, “Honestly, I’d rather keep the commercial commissions I do—even if it’s related to my own work—separate, especially in print.”

Many of the artists and dealers PDN spoke with for this article agree with Debra Klomp Ching of Klompching Gallery in Brooklyn that when it comes to settling on a price for a commissioned print, “Everything is on a case-by-case basis.” (Editor’s note: Klompching Gallery is co-owned by PDN creative director Darren Ching.)

Ching explains, “If a client of the gallery wants to commission one of our artists, we serve as a liaison between the artist and the client. We broker the general terms and come to an agreement that both are happy with.” 

She adds that if the commission is editioned, “that can bring the price down for the person commissioning the photograph.”

She cites two photographs that Seattle-based photographer Doug Keyes created for writer Andrew Solomon. “Andrew Solomon is a client of the gallery,” explains Ching. Solomon was interested in Keyes’s “Collective Memory” series, which consists of multiple-exposure photographs of books. “He came to an exhibition of Doug’s work, liked what he saw, and wanted to know if it was possible for Doug to make work with his two books.”

Keyes agreed to photograph Solomon’s The Noonday Demon and The Irony Tower, and added the images to his “Collective Memory” series. 

He issued the prints in an edition that he sold at stepped prices—increasing as the edition sells out. Keyes says of his sale to Solomon, “To make it affordable for him, he got the first one at a tiered price. The first two or three are one price. The final two are a higher price.”

Keyes says he would set a higher price for the print if a commission required him to shoot something he wouldn’t normally, but in the case of the Solomon commission, “He just picked the book for me really. It was pretty easy.”

Philadelphia-based artist Jessica Todd Harper creates intimate photographs of families and friends that explore the social and emotional nature of domestic relationships. Because her fine-art work lends itself readily to portraiture, she is frequently approached to shoot private portrait sessions. She says she can tell after talking to a potential client whether or not to take the commission.

“My clients appreciate art and don’t want a portrait of themselves in matching khaki pants and white shirts on the beach,” says Harper. “I’m not dissing that, but there are photographers who do that very well. They don’t need me.”

Her commissioned portraits of clients’ families and her photographs of her own family and friends are indistinguishable in style. A photograph of a little girl being lifted from the bath by her mother, for instance, was made for one of her collectors. It appears on Harper’s website both in the section set aside for commissioned portraits and in her series entitled “The Home Stage,” which was exhibited at Rick Wester Fine Art in New York City last fall. 

The image has the maternal warmth of a Mary Cassatt painting. Says Harper, “Before we were even making the portrait, they were in the bath and the light was so beautiful, I took the photograph. That was the one we used. The shoot was over before it even started.”

As to how she prices a commissioned photograph, Harper says that depends on the client. “I work with people in different economic situations, so I have a sliding scale,” she explains. “If someone is excited enough about my work, I try to find a way to make it work. There are no packages. It’s a very individual and a very personal process.”

She also considers what the client wants. “If a portrait is public, and 99 percent of the time it is, it just goes into my repertoire and gets included in exhibitions and published in books,” Harper says. “I print in editions of ten.” 

There are exceptions, however. “Some people are very private and don’t want their pictures in public, so I make something just for them.”

Not being able to edition the images—or use them in promotion—changes the negotiation. “If someone wants the work to be exclusive,” says gallery owner Yancey Richardson, “you have to charge more because the artist doesn’t have the opportunity to receive the revenue from the sale of prints.”

When the assignment is for a commercial or editorial client, artists still need to consider whether the commissioned photo is something they can sell to collectors. 

Richardson helped negotiate editorial assignments for Boston-based artist Rachel Perry Welty. In one example, Vogue was interested in the artist’s “Lost in My Life” series of self-portraits in which she shows herself camouflaged or overwhelmed by the incidental clutter of consumer existence—twist ties, take-out boxes, fruit stickers, receipts. Vogue, however, wanted her to photograph herself in designer accessories. 

In deciding whether to take the shoot and how to price it, Richardson and Welty considered the opportunity to work with props and stylists. The collaboration “allowed me to surround myself with the stuff of a luxury life,” Welty says, and to expand her “Lost in My Life” series with an image she couldn’t create on her own.

Related: Selling Prints to Fund Books: It's Complicated

Three Great Print On Demand Sites To Consider For Your Photo Business

article.article_title: Letha Wilson's Landscape Installation Art
article.meta_description: By incorporating her photos of the American West into her sculptural works, Wilson encourages a thoughtful reexamination of landscape photography.
article.article_text_abstract: By incorporating her photos of the American West into her sculptural works, Wilson encourages a thoughtful reexamination of landscape photography.
article.article_image_caption: Installation view of “Landmarks and Monuments,” 2013, by Letha Wilson.
article.article_text:
Visitors to Letha Wilson’s exhibition “Sight Specific” at Light Work in Syracuse can see photos she took in the canyons and deserts of the American West. But rather than transporting viewers to those wide-open spaces, Wilson’s work constantly reminds them that they are standing in an enclosed space, glimpsing only a portion of the vistas she captured. She mounted one print behind a partition she built, cutting holes in it to expose portions of the image. She hung a photo of a sunset by squeezing the edges into parallel slits she sliced into the wall, so the photo bows outward. “It does nice things with the light,” Wilson notes. “It works like a sundial.” Other prints are partially covered by pieces of drywall. Looking down, a viewer might notice a photo of lava rock that Wilson has molded around the gallery’s baseboard. 

The exhibition, which Wilson created specifically for the gallery, is a study in contrasts: between the pristine landscapes she’s photographed and the manmade material she uses to distort or obscure her photos; and, Wilson says, “between the actual experience of being in these spaces and looking at these photos afterwards in a wholly different place and time.”

Wilson, a sculptor, has incorporated her photographs into her work since 2003, but she’s been photographing landscapes for much longer. When she was growing up in Colorado, her family would go on long camping trips and hike into the wilderness. Her dad would pass around a disposable camera. “Looking back, all our family photos are of trees and rivers. There are no people in them,” Wilson says. 

When she attended Syracuse University, where she majored in painting and took classes in darkroom printing, and later when she moved to New York City to get her MFA in mixed media at Hunter College, she brought along her 4 x 6 snapshots. Far from the places where they were made, the photos evoked very different feelings. Wanting to “dig deeper” into that gap between the place and its representation, Wilson decided to treat the prints as sculptural elements. At first, she painted on her photos, “to abstract them.” In time, she developed a daily practice of pouring concrete and laying the shapes over her images. “I called them ‘Extrusions,’ because it was taking form from photos and extruding them out into three dimensions,” she says. 

Working in concrete is physically demanding, but she enjoys the hands-on process. She gets a similar pleasure from printing in the darkroom—something she does almost every week. Wilson, who typically shoots with a Yashica twin-lens box camera an ex-boyfriend gave her years ago, used to scan her negatives and then have them printed, but found making her own prints was liberating. “Going into a darkroom to make a whole bunch of prints made them less precious and more portable,” she says. She also likes handling an image through every step of her process: “Because it’s mine, I can destroy it.” 

For Wilson, bending, cutting and obscuring photos is, in part, a reaction against “the rules of photography—of which there are so many,” she says. Still, no matter how much she obscures or covers her images, each of her sculptures retains a trace of evidence that she was in those awe-inspiring places. She considered at one point using an image appropriated from the Internet, but decided against it. “I need to take those photos.” Her work is a record of her experience—both in observing the landscape, and in manipulating her representation of it later. At the same time, she values landscape photography and hopes to encourage people to reconsider the genre by showing it in a new context. “It’s become so ubiquitous through calendars, and the proliferation of landscape images used on the Internet. It gets written off as a cliché: ‘Oh, it’s a pretty landscape.’ But there’s something that makes people want to take those photos, and be in that landscape.”

Though she made photos in Maine while studying at the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture, and during artist-in-residency programs in Hawaii and the headlands of Marin County, California, Wilson frequently returns to the Western landscapes photographed by Carleton Watkins, Ansel Adams and other greats. “I like going to these places that photographers like to go—for good reason,” she says. “There’s a weird timelessness there. You feel like you’re the first person to work there, because it’s just you and the land.” 

When Light Work director Shane Lavalette invited Wilson to exhibit, she decided to leave her concrete mixer at home and test a variety of new materials with help from the nonprofit gallery’s technicians. A Light Work staffer, for example, found a local company that could cut metal, enabling her to mount prints on aluminum that she could then have cut and folded to fit her designs. Light Work also let her redefine the exhibition space—cutting walls and pasting prints directly on the plaster and the molding. 

After the show closes July 18, most of the work she made for the space will be peeled off the walls and destroyed. “Actually I like that,” Wilson says. “It’s nice that it’s only there in the moment. And, I don’t have to worry about storing it.”
