article.article_title: W.A.G.E. Advocates for Artists Working for Fair Pay
article.meta_description: Working Artists and the Greater Economy (W.A.G.E.) is an artist-led advocacy organization fighting for the rights of artists to be fairly compensated for their work.
article.article_text_abstract: Working Artists and the Greater Economy (W.A.G.E.) is an artist-led advocacy organization fighting for the rights of artists to be fairly compensated for their work.
article.article_image_caption: An exhibition of CENTER award winners at Colorado Photographic Art Center (CPAC). CENTER is a Santa Fe-based nonprofit arts organization that is working towards W.A.G.E. Certification.
article.article_text:
Working Artists and the Greater Economy (W.A.G.E.) is a nonprofit advocacy organization pushing for the rights of artists to be fairly compensated for their work. In October 2014, the organization introduced W.A.G.E. Certification, a program that establishes a standardized artist fee structure that can be used by nonprofit arts institutions of all sizes, from small, artist-run gallery spaces to major museums like the Museum of Modern Art and Whitney Museum. In order for an institution to be certified, that institution must compensate artists they work with according to the pay standards and guidelines established by W.A.G.E. Fee categories include solo exhibitions, two-person exhibitions and group exhibitions; performances of existing work or new, commissioned work; film screenings; lectures, readings and other appearances; and written texts. W.A.G.E. created a calculator that determines these minimum fees using a formula that takes into account the size and annual operating budget of an organization.

The introduction of W.A.G.E. Certification followed three years of planning and research by visual artists, educators, curators, sociologists, writers and others with experience and expertise in the art economy. W.A.G.E. was initially established in 2008 through a series of informal meetings in New York between artists, performing artists and independent curators. Among the core group of people leading the organization early on were artists who “had a lot of cultural capital and were always being asked to perform and exhibit but found that they were always broke. It occurred to them that it was a strange and inequitable equation,” recalls Lise Soskolne, who is presently the “core organizer” of W.A.G.E.

CENTER, the Santa Fe-based nonprofit arts organization whose mission is to support photographers, is among a group of institutions currently seeking W.A.G.E. Certification. “I want artists to be clear that we’re there to support them,” says CENTER executive director Laura Pressley. Because CENTER charges entry fees for some competitions, Pressley believes that people who don’t know the organization might assume they are for-profit. Certification, she says, “would help anybody who doesn’t know CENTER understand that we are mission-based and not profit-driven.” Pressley adds that she wants to advocate for other nonprofit photography institutions to do the same. “[Paying artists] is something that the other non-profits, if they can, should move towards,” she says.

PDN recently spoke with Soskolne to learn more about W.A.G.E. Certification and how the organization is working toward a “tipping point” that would see proper compensation for artists become the norm.

PDN: It’s interesting that in the texts about Certification published on the W.A.G.E. website, the organization acknowledges that artists have played a role in the current situation. Why is it important to acknowledge that artists have contributed to the exploitation of cultural labor?

Lise Soskolne: It’s important because we represent artists and we’re trying to, as it says in our manifesto, develop an environment of mutual respect between artists and institutions. All the blame for our current condition can’t be put exclusively on the shoulders of institutions, because we’re all complicit in perpetuating the myth that art is exceptional in its relationship to the market economy. There is plenty of denial among artists that art and commerce are or should be totally autonomous from one another. Artists also have a role to play in advocating on their own behalf. Because there has never been any collective bargaining in the field it’s up to individual artists to use their own agency in getting paid. I think many people would love to join a union if it were possible, but since there isn’t such a thing yet they need to be prepared to make a sacrifice by saying, “No, I’m not going to work for free.” W.A.G.E. can only do so much by certifying institutions—we also need artists to step up and help us put pressure on them.

PDN: W.A.G.E raised more than $50,000 last year in a crowdfunding campaign, and many of the donors were artists. Why do you think so many people supported the organization?

LS: I should say first that crowdfunding as a fundraising tool is likely to have been a one-time event for us—it was a stopgap measure more than it was a strategy, but it was successful in a way that we were not expecting. Early on in the campaign we sent out an appeal that included a list of those who had donated thus far because we were genuinely moved by the generosity of our peers and proud of the support they were showing. We noticed that people seemed to give when the list went out and it became a kind of ritual throughout the campaign: watching it grow longer week-by-week and seeing who had given. Wanting one’s support to be visible was a way to join with one’s peers in solidarity; in this case it was in support of W.A.G.E. as an entity and potentially as a representative. Not to overstate things, but it looked and felt like coalition building, or at least something more than just a fundraising campaign. Our community showed genuine support and love for W.A.G.E. by getting behind our work and our goals.

PDN: As you’ve spoken with nonprofit arts organizations, have they expressed concerns over any particular requirements for W.A.G.E. Certification?

LS: At the beginning there was one organization that just couldn’t understand the importance of a minimum wage or “compensation floor,” which is a key component of the program. I think that was an anomaly though, because I suspect that a lot of organizations are already paying fees close to the minimums we’re recommending. The primary problem has been the number of organizations contacting us to be certified but who don’t fit into the current model, which is for a visual arts presenting context. There was a magazine that wanted to be certified, there were service organizations that wanted to be certified, residency programs, so we’re currently trying to work on other fee schedules, which had always been the plan. There’s a lot more work to be done.

PDN: Should artists use W.A.G.E.’s fee calculator as a point of reference in their discussions with institutions, even if those institutions aren’t certified?

LS: Yes and they already are. I know someone who negotiated a higher fee with the Whitney Museum based on it, so it’s definitely being used by artists as a negotiating tool. It’s also being used as a guide by festivals and juried art exhibitions. In fact I noticed that the Filter Photo Festival based their stipend on our guidelines and cited W.A.G.E. in their application. Another valuable thing about the fee calculator is that institutions can use it in grant applications to ask for “X” amount of money to pay artist fees, which they’ve never been able to do before. There’s also another level to this on the grant making side: W.A.G.E. has work to do in putting pressure on funders and government agencies to hold the organizations they fund accountable for paying fees. Funders could also make grants available specifically for fee payment based on our guidelines. There have never been any guidelines or standards for artist fees before so there are a lot of uses for them.

PDN: As part of certification, organizations can’t pay artists more than the “Maximum W.A.G.E..” which specifies that organizations with total annual operating expenses of more than $5,000,000 should not pay an artist more than the average salary of the organization’s employees. Why was it important to include a ceiling in the W.A.G.E. Certification fee schedule?

LS: It’s important that “nobody unduly profits from the redistribution of wealth—including artists.” Here I’m quoting directly from the program’s policy. To frame it that way makes absolute sense. It’s not equitable for an artist to make more than an employee of the institution.

PDN: There are currently ten organizations that are W.A.G.E. Certified or have Certifications that are pending. What will it take to grow the list of certified organizations?

LS: I think it’s going to take building a critical mass, after which there will be a tipping point. We’re not close to that yet, but maybe when we hit 20 or 30 we will be. People are already taking it seriously because we’ve managed to certify five, but of course that’s not a huge number. Ten I think shows some consistency, 20 or 30 shows a movement of some kind. What it’s really going to take is getting a larger institution on board, like a museum. Ninety percent of the time people have been reaching out to us to get certified, which makes sense because the program is predicated on institutions self-regulating: They initiate the process because they want to be certified. But it wouldn’t hurt to start reaching out and inviting institutions to engage with us. I think that will help too.

PDN: Is the endorsement of top-tier institutions necessary to make the Certification project a success?

LS: I think it’s really important, because that’s the level at which most exploitation happens. Large institutions can use the exposure argument better than anyone can. Exhibiting at that level is fundamental to an artist’s critical and market success so it’s very easy for them to say, “Here’s this opportunity, but you don’t get a fee,” and that message gets sent all the way back down, or all the way up from the smaller institutions to the largest if there’s no floor or minimum. If there’s no minimum, there’s no place to start from, and thus nowhere to go.

PDN: Presumably it would be easier for major institutions to gain certification.

LS: You would think so, but I think at that level… they’re often not paying fees, and are very likely not paying the kinds of fees that we’re expecting them to pay based on our calculator. We did a survey of visual and performing artists in 2010 that gathered data on artists’ experiences with the payment practices of New York City nonprofits between 2005–2010, and while we didn’t gather enough data on the big museums, there is enough anecdotal evidence to indicate that artists are more likely to not get paid by the large institutions than the small ones. This is in part because most of the smaller ones were founded to support artists, which is why the institutions we’ve certified so far tend to be smaller. It’s important to them—it’s why they exist, and they want their commitment to artists to be acknowledged by their community. As institutions get larger, they have a tendency to become further removed from the reasons for their founding, or from providing support to artists, because they incur many other additional expenses. A lot of money tends to be spent on perpetuating themselves institutionally.

PDN: What are the future plans for W.A.G.E.?

LS: Plans include potentially expanding the program to include some of the categories mentioned previously, but there’s also a possibility of certifying individual artists, which is really exciting to us. We haven’t decided definitively, but it would involve certifying artists on the basis of their commitment to show either only with institutions that are W.A.G.E. Certified, or to show only on the basis of receiving fees that meet our standards. This goes back to my earlier comment about artists taking more responsibility for their role in perpetuating non-payment. They would have to be prepared to make a sacrifice and say, “I’m going to say no to this exhibition,” and certifying them on that basis would make their agency visible. If we don’t start saying “no” more collectively then change will happen more slowly. Artists have to see themselves as part of a larger community in which it’s in everyone’s interest to individually turn down unpaid offers so that everyone will get paid. As work refusal it’s not dissimilar to a strike, but because it’s not coordinated and in relation to a single employer, it may function more like a boycott. We’re thinking about both.

Related: Brian Ulrich: On Creating, Funding and Sustaining a Long-term Fine-Art Project

article.article_title: From Lads to Men: The New Maxim Magazine
article.meta_description: Facing financial ruin in 2014, Maxim recently acquired a new owner, editor and redesign. PDN asks Andrea Volbrecht, the magazine's director of photography, about the magazine's new look and the photographers who helped define it.
article.article_text_abstract: Facing financial ruin in 2014, Maxim recently acquired a new owner, editor and redesign. PDN asks Andrea Volbrecht, the magazine's director of photography, about the magazine's new look and the photographers who helped define it.
article.article_image_caption: Maxim’s March 2015 issue, the first since its redesign.
article.article_text:
In early 2014, Maxim was in trouble; the once-profitable lad magazine that Felix Dennis had brought over from the U.K. in the 1990s was losing millions each year and in danger of folding. Since the restaurant and real estate magnate Sardar Biglari purchased the title in March of that year, however, Maxim has matured. Kate Lanphear, the former style director at T: The New York Times Style Magazine, was brought on as editor-in-chief, and installed a new team to supervise a redesign in hopes of making Maxim relevant again.

Maxim’s director of photography, Andrea Volbrecht, has been at the magazine since 2011, and helped it transition from the loud, bright pinups it was famous for to a more natural, grown-up esthetic. Debuting with March 2015’s “Raw” issue, each month now has a single-word theme, which Lanphear and creative director Paul Martinez hope to explore as the magazine finds its new voice. Here, Volbrecht tells PDN about making the first three issues of the new Maxim, and the photographers who helped define its new look.

PDN: What’s new about Maxim’s approach to photography?

Andrea Volbrecht: I would say that the biggest difference is...things used to be very poppy, a lot more on-camera flash, really loud imagery. It was bright and very colorful throughout the whole design. Once the new owner came on, we started paring that back, and when Kate came on board and our whole new team was in place, it really came to fruition in the March issue. Our reader has grown up, so it’s about talking to him in a more grown-up way, as well. Visually, we are trying to go to a place more based in classic photography, way more natural light, wherever possible. Making the women feel super natural, very healthy, happy, alive—like women are in their natural state, versus as an object. Instead of making it feel very flash-in-the-pan, [we want] something that’s gonna hold up. Something that’s gonna be arresting, hold your gaze and make you feel something. 

PDN: Who are some of the new photographers you’ve worked with, and how does their work embody the new Maxim?

AV: Gilles Bensimon [who shot Candice Swanepoel for the cover of the debut issue] is definitely one of those people. We did our second cover with him as well. The thing that Gilles is so good at is he knows how to make a woman come to life. Let her be herself, comfortable in front of the camera, relaxed. He makes them look beautiful in a very natural way. There’s not piles of makeup and huge hair and tons of jewelry. Kate [Lanphear] has a history with him, so he was someone that we really wanted to collaborate with.

Jamie Chung is somebody that I’ve worked with for a handful of years, and he’s just brilliant, I love collaborating with him. We shot probably three or four different versions for that “Raw” opener that he did. He’s great at pumping out ideas and being open to collaborating, so it’s wonderful to have a dialogue with someone who’s got such creative talent. He’ll continue to be a part of the book for a long time. Similarly, we knew we [needed] a gear story and really wanted to come out strong with that, so we worked with Dan Forbes for our gear feature. And he’s just phenomenal, super nice, crazy talented, and lovely on top of that. 

We’ve been really fortunate that we’ve had a lot of positive experiences with a lot of different photographers. Sigurd Grünberger was lovely, super sweet, incredible to work with. He made the most out of what was a freezing-cold, windy, dark, gloomy day in Malibu, and Bianca [Santos], our talent, was such a trooper, never wanted to complain, though she was shivering the whole time. 

For fashion, Robert Nethery shot our Mads Mikkelsen story in our May issue. That was the story that came in that we were like, “This is what we want Maxim fashion to be. He’s the kind of guy, he’s rugged, he’s masculine, he’s interesting, he’s a character.” And the light was really classic, gorgeous natural-looking light. That is the touchstone of where we’re at with our fashion.

PDN: The boxing portraits by Andreas Laszlo Konrath seemed like a notable departure from the old Maxim. Had you worked with him before?

AV: No, I hadn’t, and I was so excited to work with him on that boxer story; that was one of the shining stars of the debut issue. I wish we could have given him 20 pages, because he brought back so much film that we could have done it easily. He shot the ones that we ran [in print] that were on black, but he also did similar ones on white, and he also did action shots of each of the guys, and some of those ran on the extended iPad edition.

PDN: How would you describe the book’s new esthetic? 

AV: The goal has been that as you move through the book, you’d hit on different volume levels throughout. There’s going to be moments that feel way more aggressive, visually… and then there’s going to be moments that feel more reflective and quiet. It gives you a little bit more range as you look through it so you don’t feel like every single page feels the same. It’s been a really interesting transition.

I think the most difficult thing that any magazine has when they’re re-branding—and we’re talking about re-branding from a point where the book was really on the brink of not existing anymore, before it was bought—there’s a lot of people who haven’t picked up the magazine in a really long time. They have no idea what the content is, but it’s a brand that’s been around for so long, that there’s a built-in notion of what that thing is. And it has a lot of negative connotations, unfortunately. But there’s a great staff here that’s really committed to turning it around to being a product that men will want to pick up, that women will feel comfortable picking up and looking at, and that has more to say than just, “Oh here, look at some girls.” It’s really about a man’s lifestyle and all that encompasses: There are food, gear, travel, fashion, profiles and business stories. The biggest struggle sometimes is getting on the phone with every single agent and photographer and saying, “No no, really, the magazine wants to be different, and we would love for you to be a part of it, this is where we want to go.” We feel like we’re really off to a strong start. And there’s so much more that can be done. 

PDN: Has Kate Lanphear’s name helped convince people to work with you?

AV: She’s got a really strong visual eye, which has been really exciting for me as the photo director. I feel like she and I are very aligned in terms of what we like, and that helps a lot, because she’s very visual. And people are familiar with her, and that always helps when you feel like there’s someone helming a magazine that has always been committed in her career to striving for something that’s quality.

PDN: What, if anything, about the old Maxim has survived?

AV: I think the old magazine served its reader: Young guys that have a sense of humor and wanted some place where they could be themselves and not be judged. And that idea has carried over, for sure. We’re not trying to be the authority on everything and tell guys exactly how they have to live. We’re providing suggestions of things that we feel like they should check out. We’re trying to give them a place to feel inspired and something to aspire to. 

PDN: What interests the “grown up” Maxim man?

AV: In terms of fashion, it used to get handled with a service approach, and for a few years, there was almost no fashion to be found anywhere in the book. And that’s a real part of men’s mags, and more and more every year, men are engaging in fashion in a way that they haven’t previously. And our readership...we haven’t actually gotten to the point where our readership is in their 40s and 50s. It’s still very much in their late 20s, 30s, young guys who are making a decent living, doing well for themselves. So we are still trying to feed those age groups, and what you’ll notice in the approach to the fashion is, it’s more about stories, or choosing a specific theme. Like a double-breasted suit, or “camel is the color for fall,” or a denim story. It’s a very specific through-line, so ideally it’s digestible for the reader. Versus being extraordinarily servicey, like, “These are the ten things you have to buy this month.” It tends to be a little more broad, so it’s easier, ideally, for people to get into and have a takeaway. We want it to be aspirational too, but we don’t want it to be so far-fetched that a guy can’t see himself realistically in it. We see the Maxim man as a masculine dude in America. So reaching that reader is important to us.

Related: Print is Not Dead: A Look at New and Redesigned Magazines

article.article_title: A Photographer Explores Climate Change on North Carolina's Outer Banks
article.meta_description: Greg Kahn explores the social and environmental landscapes of North Carolina's Outer Banks, on the front lines of the climate change debate.
article.article_text_abstract: Greg Kahn explores the social and environmental landscapes of North Carolina's Outer Banks, on the front lines of the climate change debate.
article.article_image_caption: Ernie Foster, who lives in Hatteras, runs the Albatross Fleet, a deep-sea fishing business on the Outer Banks. Foster’s family can be traced back several generations in Hatteras.
article.article_text:
Scientists predict that rising sea levels will inundate significant portions of North Carolina’s Outer Banks within a century. But flooding and shifting sands are already chronic nuisances. Beach houses are falling into the sea. Deeply vested in the culture and economy, residents are arguing over what, if anything, they should be doing about it.

The slow-motion crisis is the subject of a feature story titled “Slip Sliding Away” in the March/April 2015 issue of Audubon magazine (and on Audubon.org). It was reported by Mac McClelland and photographed by Greg Kahn, who says the challenges for him were to build rapport with wary subjects, and bring attention to the story without sensationalizing it.

“What I didn’t want to do was try to make this more catastrophic than it is, because it is happening at such an incremental level that it is ignored. The idea was to show it for what it is, and the power it has,” says Kahn.

He got the assignment on the basis of a personal project called “3 Millimeters,” which he’s been working on since 2012. That project is a visual study of the environmental and social consequences of the three-millimeter rise in sea level each year along Maryland’s eastern shore. “Climate change is something I’m passionate about, and wholeheartedly believe in and want to tell the story of,” the photographer says.

Sabine Meyer, photography director for National Audubon Society (NAS), had seen Kahn’s ongoing “3 Millimeters” project when she was doing research for an NAS website dedicated to climate-change issues. “I liked his approach. He’s a photojournalist, but his photography is quiet. He has a little bit of a fine-art approach. He could do portraits, he could do landscapes. The choice was really obvious,” Meyer says. 

His assignment was to approach the four-day shoot much the same way he has shot the “3 Millimeters” project, using a combination of portraits and landscapes to tell the story. “It was kind of left up to me to find exactly what I wanted to shoot, and the kinds of stories I wanted to tell.”

But he had to follow the basic framework of McClelland’s story. On the basis of the people she had interviewed and places she had scouted while reporting the story, Meyer gave Kahn a short list of subjects. “I told him I wanted portraits that tell us about the person, but also about the place they live and come from,” Meyer says. “And second, we talked about how to show sea-level rise in a visually telling, compelling way so people want to look at it. Climate change is a polarizing issue. So we were navigating the question: Can you prove with a picture that this is happening, so you have visual evidence?”

Kahn started calling people on Meyer’s list to ask them about their activities, and probe their local knowledge in preparation for his trip.

“Talking to them [in advance] was crucial,” Kahn says, explaining that they gave him ideas for what to shoot. For instance, an environmental scientist who has been studying the Outer Banks for years told Kahn about the Salvo Campground Cemetery, a secluded graveyard that was slowly washing away. A photograph Kahn made of the cemetery was part of the final edit. 

Kahn made the trip to the Outer Banks in late October, and worked from sunrise to sunset looking for images. “I travel very light. I want to be very mobile in these situations. All I took was my medium-format digital camera [Pentax 645z] and one lens [35–55mm f/4.5 AL].” He also kept a close eye on phone apps for the weather and tides, to track wind direction and times of high and low tide.

Kahn was looking for subtle signs of encroaching seas, rather than extreme signs that climate change skeptics could easily dismiss as abnormal or misleading. “Showing the little things—the little pieces that add up—is way more effective than going during a storm and showing dramatic images that don’t really tell what’s going on.”

Kahn photographed condemned beach houses, using the horizon to show how much they’ve shifted on their foundations. He showed the relentless encroachment of sand borne inland by waves. The opening image shows a backhoe scooping sand, Sisyphus-like, off a roadway. Another image shows workers shoveling mounds that threaten to bury a house.

Kahn also shot portraits of the main subjects of McClelland’s reporting. “I wanted to immerse myself in [the] community,” and show the culture, he says, because it is as threatened as the environment. “The way people live, you can’t just move a culture inland and have it exist the way it was.”

One of Kahn’s subjects was Ernie Foster, whose family has lived on the Outer Banks for generations. He can’t easily pick up and leave. “That’s what I was trying to get across: [the issues are] more complex than [saying] everyone needs to move,” Kahn says.

He photographed Foster in his office at a marina he has run for years. “You get a sense of who he is, through the pictures kept under the glass table there, [by the way he] keeps the books by hand, all this stuff piled up in the glass case. It’s an accumulation of his life.”

Kahn says he was simply having a conversation with Foster about what was happening around the Outer Banks, and what the future might bring. Kahn took a photo as Foster gazed out a window. “We kind of had a moment. Instead of positioning him, I let him operate in his own space.”

Kahn made a portrait of another subject, Stephanie O’Neal, sitting at a picnic table on an overcast day behind the motel her family owns. Her contemplative, worried look suggests the collective anxiety of the locals.

She was reluctant to have her portrait taken for the story because she didn’t want to get into the middle of the emotional argument over climate change. But she finally agreed after Kahn engaged her in a conversation. “It was a matter of building up a little bit of trust, hearing what she had to say, and [talking about] where I came from.”

After the trip, he sent about 100 images to Audubon. “We had a discussion about what I liked, what I was feeling. They were receptive, and everything I thought should be in there, was.”

Looking back on the project, Kahn says the only thing he might do differently would be to go at a different time of year, when there are more tourists and activity. “That was not in my control,” he says. “But I’m really happy with how the story turned out. I was able to find the right people and have them in genuine, honest situations.”

Kahn is continuing work on “3 Millimeters,” but he’s trying to expand it to examine the effects of climate change in other places. He predicts he’ll return to the Outer Banks at some point to do more work on his own. For now, he’s planning a trip for next winter to Australia, where drought threatens to drive people off the land in some parts of the continent.

article.article_title: Zalmaï's "Dread and Dreams" Captures the Toll of Conflict on Afghans
article.meta_description: In his new photobook, the Afghanistan-born photographer mixes black-and-white images with flashes of color to portray the hardship and hope of Afghan citizens.
article.article_text_abstract: In his new photobook, the Afghanistan-born photographer mixes black-and-white images with flashes of color to portray the hardship and hope of Afghan citizens.
article.article_image_caption: Afghanistan-born photographer Zalmaï’s new book mixes black-and-white images with flashes of color to portray the hardship and hope of Afghan citizens.
article.article_text:
In black-and-white images, spare as bone but thick with texture, we see an underrepresented Afghanistan: Beyond baby-faced coalition soldiers and their cagey Taliban opponents, behind the glad-handing politicians and their cynical enablers, live ordinary Afghans who struggle to survive and dream of a better tomorrow. In the photographs in Dread and Dreams, a new photobook by Zalmaï published in May by Daylight, peasants eke out a living against a barren moonscape, their simple mud homes scarred by war. The corrugated tin of the shantytown, the sodden muck of the slum, the abasement of the beggar—the images reveal the terrible mundanity of Afghanistan’s degradation. And yet, within this sea of bleak truths, there are flashes of color and subtle moments of beauty and joy. 

Zalmaï was born in Kabul in 1964. The Afghanistan of his birth was a sleepy country growing restive, in the midst of transitions that would exact a terrible price on this land and its people. A reformist program begun by Afghanistan’s monarch in 1964 foundered, setting in motion a string of coups that would culminate in the event that changed the course of Zalmaï’s life and his nation’s future: the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in the last days of 1979. “When the Russians invaded, my father had been a high ranking [official] in the government for many years,” Zalmaï remembers, “and for him it was unimaginable to continue working there.”

The family ended up in Lausanne, Switzerland, and Zalmaï studied at the School of Photography of Lausanne and the Professional Photography Training Center of Yverdon. After finishing school, he embarked on a freelance photography career that fulfilled his childhood dream of traveling. “Growing up, I remember looking at National Geographic and other magazines, and seeing how mysterious the world was,” he says. For the next 12 years he traversed the globe, shooting images that were published by The New York Times, La Repubblica and Harper’s Magazine, or on assignments for the United Nations or NGOs such as Human Rights Watch. But he did not return to Afghanistan.

“I was so traumatized by my experience when I left, I didn’t want to go back,” Zalmaï explains. “In my mind, I thought that I lost my country, lost everything we had, but also that I had gained the planet.... I was not Afghan, I was not Swiss, I was just Zalmaï.”

Then came the September 11 attacks and, suddenly, the eyes of the world were on Afghanistan. Unable to resist, in 2001 he entered Afghanistan from Tajikstan on assignment for Newsweek, as the Taliban was swept from power by the U.S. and its allies. For the first time since the Soviet invasion, an Afghan diaspora scattered by successive wars began returning home in droves. Trying to capture the “hope of the country,” Zalmaï shot in color, delving into the stories that were going untold; the lives and dreams of Afghans scarred by violence and buoyed by sudden winds of change. Having grown up a middle-class “Kabuli” in a time of relative prosperity, Zalmaï returned to a land beggared by conflict and deprivation. 

“It was very interesting to be in a country where I understand the language and kind of understand the culture, but it is [also] very foreign,” he muses. “I did have experiences where people would say, ‘When the country needed you, you were gone. You didn’t see all this misery we saw, lucky you.’ And sometimes they would be angry, sometimes envious, sometimes happy.” Aperture published a book of that work, Return, Afghanistan, in 2004.

The rich and vibrant palette of that book stands in direct contrast to the stark, monochrome imagery that forms the backbone of Dread And Dreams. As he traveled in and out of Afghanistan on assignments for the United Nations High Commission on Refugees and various media outlets, Zalmaï took note of another, darker change in the air. “After 2005 the situation got more complicated; more Taliban, more [foreign] soldiers, and of course the corruption in the government. More people started losing their hope,” Zalmaï says. 

By 2008, Zalmaï had begun shooting Afghanistan primarily in black-and-white as a contrast to the optimism that he saw earlier in the decade. “For me, war steals the color from life, so the black-and-white is about the suffering and misery that war visits on people,” he explains. “But when you dream, you dream in color, so the color section of the book is the dreams of Afghan people. And that is important to me because it is those dreams that are driving the country forward, not the war.” 

Zalmaï had already completed the book when he connected with Daylight Books at the 2014 Mt. Rokko International Photo Festival in Japan. He had insisted on editing the project himself, not wanting to risk diluting his vision. By the time he finished shooting in 2013, there were thousands of images to go through and attempt to fuse into a cohesive work that spoke to the dualities of Afghan life. The book is notably light on text, with only a short introduction by the author and no captions. Zalmaï wrestled with this decision but felt that the images must speak for themselves. “It’s very important to me that people can look at a picture and take something from it, without [a description] having to be written at the bottom,” he says, “I just want to provoke something, so that people ask questions.”

article.article_title: Frames Per Second: Characterizing the Fence at the Center of the Immigration Debate
article.meta_description: For Charles Ommanney's first video, the experienced photojournalist and Newsweek contributor tells the tale of the U.S.-Mexico border fence with video, stills and recorded interviews.
article.article_text_abstract: For Charles Ommanney's first video, the experienced photojournalist and Newsweek contributor tells the tale of the U.S.-Mexico border fence with video, stills and recorded interviews.
article.article_image_caption: After an initial trip gathering video, stills and audio along the fortified fence that runs along the U.S.-Mexico border, Charles Ommanney got permission to spend time with border patrol agents at work near the fence.
article.article_text:
An experienced photojournalist and former Newsweek contributor, Charles Ommanney had never shot any video before he pitched MSNBC an idea for a multimedia piece—combining video, stills and recorded interviews—about life along the U.S.-Mexico border. “I hadn’t even turned on the video button of my DSLR,” he says. The Fence, which was published in three parts on MSNBC.com last summer, won 2nd prize for long feature at the World Press Photo Multimedia Awards. The Fence breaks many of the conventions of a video documentary: Ommanney’s interview subjects rarely appear on camera; their words are heard over the footage and stills he shot. Rather than shooting sequences that combined footage of action with B-roll, Ommanney shot long takes of the subject that is central to the film: the barrier wall that now spans about 700 miles of the nearly 2,000-mile border. Cutting across deserts and backyards, the snaking fence is a monumental presence in all the footage Ommanney shot and in the stories he gathered. Editor Andrew Hida, who had the task of shaping Ommanney’s sound and visuals into three coherent pieces, says of The Fence, “In a way it’s a character-driven narrative, but the main character never speaks.” 

Ommanney had pitched his former Newsweek colleague, Richard Wolffe—now executive editor at MSNBC.com—on an idea to talk to people near the U.S.-Mexico border about the issue of immigration reform. With Wolffe’s approval, Ommanney recalls, “I flew to Texas in January of 2014, and then drove in an old car from Brownsville all the way across [the] country, keeping as close to the U.S. border as I could until I got to Friendship Park near San Diego.” As he talked to people, however, he decided the story was not about immigration but about the impact of one measure taken to stop it. “It’s about the absurdity of this fence that’s been built for millions and millions of dollars that’s doing absolutely nothing,” he says. Since construction began in 2006, the barrier along the U.S.-Mexico border has cost $3 billion, and in some spots there are gaps 15 miles wide. Ommanney shot video of the fence while driving along in his car or after stopping to set up a tripod. In some footage, he shows the fence stretching across vast, inhospitable terrain, but he notes, “The fence is stopped for golf courses because high-paying golf club members didn’t want to see the fence.” 

Soon after he arrived in Brownsville, he met and interviewed a man on Boca Chica Beach who sits and watches for immigrants. But he’s not a vigilante: He told Ommanney that one day while camping he encountered “one of the prettiest women I’ve ever seen,” who said she had walked across Honduras, Guatemala and Mexico and was planning to walk to Florida. In hindsight, he regretted he hadn’t asked her to marry him; he now watches each day, “hoping it’ll happen again,” he told Ommanney. 

Other people Ommanney met in his travels referred him to other subjects. He conducted interviews with a diverse group of people, including an environmentalist concerned about the fence’s effect on natural migration patterns; a clergyman near San Diego who ministers to families divided by the fence; and an Arizona man who, while hiking, had come upon the body of a young woman who died crossing the border, inspiring him to research her identity and the story of her perilous journey. Ommanney notes, “One of the arguments against the fence is that it just makes people walk miles out of the way into remote areas where they die of dehydration.” 

He conducted his interviews off-camera, inside the quiet of his car, using a Røde microphone and Zoom H4N sound recorder he had purchased before his trip; he also bought a Zacuto eyepiece and an MD filter for his camera. “I didn’t want talking heads in my film,” he explains, and says that letting the viewer imagine what the speakers look like “keeps you more interested, I think.” It also prevented any one subject from dominating the documentary, keeping the attention on “the central character” of his piece, which he calls “this serpent that runs across the country.” 

Working by himself, Ommanney often felt frustrated “juggling such different media.” He says, “I’d be recording sound and then cursing myself for ballsing it up.” After recording what he calls “the best interview of my life,” he drove to a motel for the night, checked his gear and discovered he had forgotten to turn on the “record” button. In the morning, he drove back and re-did the interview, “but it wasn’t the same.” 

After two and a half weeks on the road, he had a lot of material, but decided he needed more information about the border patrol agents. He spent weeks seeking permission, and in May returned to Texas to spend time with border patrol agents, shooting stills and footage when they rounded up several young men who had tried crossing the border near McAllen, Texas. 

In June, he reviewed his roughly eight hours of footage and 3,500 stills with Andrew Hida, the editor MSNBC had suggested. Ommanney had envisioned the film as a 10-minute piece, but MSNBC insisted on showing it in three short parts to maximize viewership. “I fought that,” says Ommanney. “I said no, you’re going to water it down or weaken it.” MSNBC wouldn’t budge, so he outlined for Hida some themes that each chapter could highlight: the social cost, the economic and environmental cost, and alternatives suggested by people along the border who feel the fence is both a damaging presence and ineffective at stopping people hoping to reach the U.S.

Ommanney felt the story of the man on Boca Chica Beach watching for his future wife made a natural, attention-getting opener to the piece. He and Hida agreed to end the third chapter with words of hope, spoken by the pastor in California who leads weekly worship for people standing on both sides of the fence, and says he looks forward to the day the wall comes down. 

“I loved some of those stories people shared with Charles,” Hida says. “Anyone can relate to them, even if you don’t live in El Paso or near the border.”

Hida organized Ommanney’s stills using Adobe Lightroom, and used Adobe Premiere to review video and audio clips. Then he began looking for similarities in the visuals, and organizing clips that shared similar themes.

Ommanney’s shooting method presented “both an advantage and a challenge,” Hida says. Not having to match audio interviews with footage of the subjects gave him “the poetic liberty” to show any footage he liked while using the testimonials as voiceovers that provide “a guided experience along the fence.” He notes, however, “Editors love sequences and love details,” and his job is easier when directors shoot scenes in a logical order: “You shoot tight, medium, wide, and then you move,” Hida says. Ommanney “definitely broke that rule,” he says. “He shot video [clips] like a photographer shooting stills: They’re static, the light is gorgeous, they’re composed very deliberately.” When he first saw Ommanney’s footage, he recalls, “I said, ‘Oh, man there are no sequences.’ But the way we ended up structuring the project, it didn’t matter.” 

Ommanney says, “People seeing it have said, ‘That’s a great picture’ and I say, ‘Actually that’s not a still, that’s video.’” That similarity made it easier for Hida to interweave stills with moving footage without jarring breaks. Hida says, “I like to use two or three still images in a sequence. It allows the viewer to settle emotionally and it helps to smooth the transition.” 

To introduce each chapter, Hida cut one short intro that would “engage the viewer in the first 10 seconds.” 

Hida’s first cut hit most of the points Ommanney had wanted, and they continued to make adjustments. Though it was Ommanney’s first time editing video, Hida says, “Charles was good at articulating visually what he had issues with and where he wanted to try something different.” 

Though he had balked in the beginning, Ommanney says the three-chapter structure worked, “and people really did watch all three.”

Despite the accolades The Fence has received, Ommanney has not yet shot another video. Still, he says he’s pleased with his first effort, and what he learned from the experience. “As much as it was amateur hour, I found it invigorating and freeing,” he says. While handling all the tasks on his own was challenging, it was an experience he valued. “The solitude of being out in the wilderness was very special.”

article.article_title: Keep It Safe: 16 Storage Solutions for Preserving Your Photos
article.meta_description: These physical and cloud-based storage solutions will help keep your digital negatives safe for years to come.
article.article_text_abstract: These physical and cloud-based storage solutions will help keep your digital negatives safe for years to come.
article.article_text:
To appreciate how digital storage is progressing, consider this: You’re reading the first hard drive roundup in PDN history to use the word “petabyte” (that’s 1,000 terabytes, or 1,000,000 gigabytes). And while a petabyte might seem extravagant today, we’re confident that with the advent of 4K video and 50-megapixel DSLRs, it won’t be very long before such a staggering number starts to seem increasingly reasonable for at least some users. Until then, we’ve assembled a variety of sub-petabyte options to house your digital files instead, including desktop, portable and cloud options.

For Desktop


G-Technology G-Speed Studio XL 

The G-Speed Studio XL builds off the G-RAID Studio we reviewed in the December 2014 issue ofPDN, only instead of the RAID’s two drive bays, the XL makes room for a total of eight removable enterprise-class 7200-RPM hard drives. The result is a system that offers a maximum 64TB of storage with data rates topping off at 1350MBps. Hard drives are loaded through a door on the front panel. The Studio XL has several RAID modes, including RAID 0, 1, 5, 10, 50, 60 and JBOD (Just a Bunch Of Disks), and like other products in the Studio line, it can be daisy-chained via dual Thunderbolt 2 ports to boost speed and capacity.

Price: $3,600–$7,000
Info: www.g-technology.com

LaCie 5big Thunderbolt 2

The 5big delivers ample capacity for long-term photo storage with 10-, 20- and 30TB options. Thanks to a pair of Thunderbolt 2 ports, it has the speed you need for 4K video editing. You’ll enjoy data-transfer speeds of up to 1050MBps, but if you leverage Thunderbolt 2’s daisy-chaining capabilities, you can bump up both your capacity and speed by adding more 5bigs into the mix. In fact, if money and studio space are no object, you can link a total of 36 5bigs together and enjoy a full petabyte (there’s that word) of storage with transfer speeds reaching a toe-curling 3000MBps. The 5big supports several hardware RAID modes, including RAID 0, 1, 5, 6, 10 and JBOD. You’re not stuck with a single RAID configuration, either. With five hard drives to choose from in a single enclosure, you can assign one RAID setting to, say, three drives and another RAID setting to the remaining two drives. The hard drives are hot-swappable in all but RAID 0, so you can replace drives on the fly without gumming up your workflow. The seamless aluminum-cast enclosure dissipates heat and keeps audible clicks and whirs to a minimum. 

Price: $1,299–$2,999 
Info: www.lacie.com

Glyph StudioRAID

The StudioRAID is available in capacities from 2–10TB using fast 7200-RPM hard disks. You’ll have the option to configure the drives in two RAID settings (RAID 0 or 1). If the drive is already connected to AC power, the StudioRAID will automatically power on whenever it’s connected to a PC via USB 3.0 or FireWire 800. If you use the eSATA port to connect the drive, you’ll enjoy transfer speeds up to 600MBps. On-board disk monitoring will trigger a warning light if it senses that drive failure is imminent. A $59 rack-mount accessory lets you secure two StudioRAIDs to a single steel rack using eight screws.

Price: $339–$729
Info: www.glyphtech.com

Buffalo TeraStation  

It may sound like a remote research outpost from a sci-fi novel, but Buffalo’s TeraStation series is really a haven for your digital files. It’s a Network Attached Storage (NAS) device that offers remote access to stored files from web browsers and mobile phones, provided the drive is connected to the Web via Ethernet connection. The 1200 series drives can be set in several RAID configurations—RAID 0, 1 or JBOD—and you’ll get 11 free licenses of NovaBACKUP Business Essentials backup software for Windows-based PCs and servers. The TeraStation 1200 series offers a pair of hot-swappable 2.5-inch hard drive bays for between 2–8TB of capacity. The 1400 series sports four drive bays for between 4–16TB of storage, with two additional RAID configurations: RAID 5 and 10.

Price: $320–$600 (1200 series); $550–$1,100 (1400 series) 
Info: www.buffalotech.com


iOSafe 1515+

One of the virtues of cloud storage is that having files stored off-site can save them from natural disasters like fires and floods that would otherwise destroy a hard drive in your studio or home office. The ioSafe 1515+ goes some way toward mitigating those risks. It’s a drive system enclosed in a fire- and water-resistant housing. It can withstand temperatures up to 1,550 degrees Fahrenheit for up to 30 minutes and can be submerged in up to 10 feet of water—including salt water—for up to 72 hours. Port access can be padlocked for extra protection. Beyond its bombproof exterior, this NAS drive has five drive bays with hot-swapping capability, USB 3.0 connectivity, four Ethernet ports and user-upgradeable RAM to improve encrypting speeds. Out of the box, the drive’s 2.6-GHz quad-core processor delivers encrypted transfer rates of up to 448MBps when reading and 191MBps when writing. Forgo encryption, and transfers hum along at 450MBps read and 396MBps write. The 1515+ offers a capacity range from 5–30TB. The N513X expansion unit will give you a total capacity up to 90TB for your digital archiving.

Price: $3,000–$6,400 (20TB)

Info: www.iosafe.com

Lexar Professional Workflow HR2

The HR2 is a compact storage hub that blends memory card readers with storage drives to streamline image transfers and archiving. It sports four bays that you can load with storage drives (256GB or 512GB capacities are currently available) and/or card reader modules, in any combination you wish. The HR2 features a pair of Thunderbolt 2 ports and a USB 3.0 connection.

Price: $256 (hub only)
Info: www.lexar.com

Storage to Go 


Connected Data Drobo Mini 8 TB 

If you need a portable storage solution that offers more generous capacities, Drobo’s Mini 8TB bundle could fit the bill. It features four hot-swappable 2.5-inch drive bays pre-loaded with four Samsung Spinpoint M9T 2TB hard disk drives. It uses the company’s BeyondRAID technology, which preserves your data even if one or two drives fail simultaneously. If a drive does fail, the Mini automatically repairs itself and returns to a protected state while providing full access to all data. It connects via Thunderbolt or USB 3.0 and weighs just 3 pounds.

Price: $1,000
Website: www.drobo.com


WD My Passport Wireless 

Western Digital’s My Passport Wireless is a versatile travel companion. With its Wi-Fi capability, it can receive images from wireless FTP transmitters from Nikon and Canon. It can also connect up to eight mobile devices to view and share images stored on the drive, including streaming HD video to up to four devices simultaneously. There’s an SD card slot on hand for transferring images, too. The internal battery is good for about six hours of continuous use and about 20 hours of standby time and capacities range from 500GB–2TB.

Price: $130–$220 
Website: www.wd.com

Rocstor Hawker 

If you’re worried about the security of your images as you travel, the Hawker HX should thwart all but the most determined hackers. It sports a shock-resistant aluminum enclosure and uses hardware encryption with access provided by a secure digital key, in the form of a USB drive (three are included with the Hawker). The drive is available in 1- and 2TB capacities using hard disks and 500GB and 1TB capacities in SSD. The 1TB hard disk model is available in either 5400 RPM or 7200 RPM versions, while the 2TB drive will only be sold in the slower 5400 RPM class.

Price: $260–$950
Website: www.rocstor.com

Transcend Portable ESD400K SSD 

At 3.6 x 2.4 x 0.4 inches, Transcend’s ESD400K portable SSD is slightly larger than Samsung’s T1, but it’s still a featherweight relative to a traditional hard drive. The drive connects via USB 3.0 and delivers up to 1TB of storage capacity in its shock-resistant build. A free software download (Elite Data Management) lets you back up your computer files to the portable SSD drive with the touch of a button. 

Price: $83–$699 
Info: www.transcend-info.com

Samsung T1 SSD

This slender solid state drive (SSD) crams up to a full terabyte into a miniscule enclosure that’s just about the size of a business card—2.8 x 2.1 x 0.4 inches. It boasts transfer speeds up to 450MBps and employs AES 256 encryption and password protection to keep files secure. It’s available in capacities ranging from 250GB–1TB.

Price: $180–$600
Info: www.samsung.com

Barracuda Networks Copy

Copy is an attractive alternative to OneDrive and Box, since there’s no file-size limitation and the service saves 180 days worth of your file revision history. Where you do face limitations is in storage. While Copy has a 1TB option that’s cost-competitive with Dropbox, to enjoy unlimited file storage you need to opt for a “Copy for Companies” plan with a 10-user minimum license, driving up the cost to $900 a year. Still, if you have employees, this option provides the ability to control folder privileges, plus offers an unlimited file revision history and much more. 

Price: $99/year (1TB)
Info: www.copy.com




Backblaze

While services like Dropbox and OneDrive work on the basis of synced folders, Backblaze is more automated. It provides backup for your entire computer, so in the event of a crash, every program, document, email, and music, video and photo file is preserved, no matter where it’s stored. What’s more, Backblaze also automatically backs up the contents of any external hard drive connected to your computer, so photo and video files stored on those drives can also be secured. There’s no storage limit and there’s no limit to individual file sizes, making Backblaze a great value for still and video shooters alike 

Price: $5/month
Info: www.backblaze.com

box

Box’s best storage tier is the business plan that offers unlimited file storage, although the largest single file you can upload is 5GB. Box saves access to up to 50 versions of a file, so you can retrieve prior versions if you lose—or are just unhappy with—a current edit. Unlike some of its competitors, Box has been honing its cloud service for use in enterprise and government, so its uptime and security is one of the best among cloud providers.

Price: $15/month 
Info: www.box.com

Dropbox

Last year, Dropbox consolidated its Pro membership around a single, 1TB offering. Beyond more generous storage, the company has introduced view-only permissions for shared folders which will enable users to share files without worrying that their recipient will make unwanted changes or edits. Shared folders will come with three permission levels (owner, editor and viewer) to better control who can do what with Dropbox files. The company has also added password protection for shared links, as well as an expiration feature that will disable a shared folder after a set date. Users will have the option to set a custom expiration date or choose between 7 or 30 days. Dropbox Pro users will now be able to remotely wipe Dropbox data from any device linked to their account. There is no limitation to the size of a single file you can host on Dropbox, either.

Price: $10/month (1TB); $15/month (unlimited)
Info: www.dropbox.com

Microsoft OneDrive

If you subscribe to Microsoft Office 365, you’ll enjoy unlimited file storage on the company’sOneDrive (formerly Sky Drive) cloud service. Another way to look at it is paying for unlimited OneDrive storage and enjoying free access to Microsoft Office. The largest single file you can upload to OneDrive is 10GB—which will hamper this service as a destination for video files—but it’s still a good value for high-res RAW and JPEG images. 

Price: $70/year
Info: onedrive.live.com

article.article_title: Alice Gao's Advice for Building an Instagram Following
article.meta_description: The lifestyle, travel and food photographer leveraged her placement on Instagram's Suggested Users List to the tune of 900,000 followers.
article.article_text_abstract: The lifestyle, travel and food photographer leveraged her placement on Instagram's Suggested Users List to the tune of 900,000 followers.
article.article_image_caption: Images from the Instagram feed of Alice Gao, who is represented by TINKER*MOBILE. Gao has nearly 900,000 followers on Instagram, and shoots a variety of travel, food and lifestyle images.
article.article_text:
Alice Gao is a lifestyle, travel and food photographer who has worked for Refinery29, Club Monaco, Gap, Conde Nast Traveler, Crate & Barrel, T: The New York Times Style Magazine and Tiffany & Co, among other brands and publications. Gao was an active member of the Flickr community when she downloaded Instagram on her phone in 2010. Initially, she didn’t have much interest in the app.

She began cross-posting her lifestyle and food images from Flickr, rendered in muted tones with deep shadows, onto Instagram. For the first year, she had a very small audience—around 200 followers. Then, she suddenly began accumulating followers at a rapid pace. “I tweeted that I thought I was hacked or there was a bug in the program!” she explained to PDN via email. A friend told her she was on Instagram’s Suggested Users list. “I didn’t even know something like that existed,” she recalls. Before long, she had hundreds of thousands of followers—today, she has nearly 900,000, and brands pay her to promote them on her feed. 

Gao says she is able to build her following—and keep it—because users like that they don’t feel as if they’re being sold something. She is careful about how she integrates the products of the brands that hire her into her feed. “The campaigns are usually very exciting, because it’ll be something that challenges me creatively while also allowing me to express my personal esthetic, since it’s a collaboration.” 

Gao’s followers also like being along for the ride when her assignments take her to places such as the Galapagos Islands, Lima, Tokyo and Copenhagen. In these locations, she often visits top-notch restaurants and hotels. 

She posts images at least once a day. “I don’t spend that much time on the photos,” she says. “I will know quickly if I like something and will have it up on my feed almost instantly.” Like the other photographers interviewed for this series (see related links below), Gao believes an active presence keeps her followers coming back, and compels others to recommend her feed.

Related:
Keith Ladzinski's Advice for Building an Instagram Following
Katie Orlinksy's Advice for Building an Instagram Following

article.article_title: What Should Photographers Charge for Social Media Usage?
article.meta_description: The growing market for social media imagery has given many photographers a new revenue stream, but inconsistent pricing standards threaten to cause a race to the bottom. PDN spoke with reps to find out how they're determining what they charge.
article.article_text_abstract: The growing market for social media imagery has given many photographers a new revenue stream, but inconsistent pricing standards threaten to cause a race to the bottom. PDN spoke with reps to find out how they're determining what they charge.
article.article_image_caption: This image by Anna Williams—who is repped by Sarah Laird & Good Company—was shot for a Michael Kors digital and social media campaign.
article.article_text:
The emergence and growth of the social media market has offered photographers new opportunities to earn money. They’ve done so by shooting for brands that need images for channels like Instagram, Facebook and Pinterest; and by promoting products or companies on their own social media channels. 

Questions persist about how to price photographs for social media use. Standards have yet to emerge, perpetuating a “wild west” pricing situation that harkens back to the early days of digital advertising. “I’ve tried to ask other reps what they’re doing,” says Beth Johnson of Friend & Johnson. “There isn’t anybody talking about it in a big way so we can all get in line with each other.”

Part of the problem is lack of clarity about terms. “A lot of times we’ll have clients call us and say, ‘We want digital use, Web use,’” Johnson adds. “We’re having to really drill down on what that means.” 

Contributing to an already challenging situation, photographers who have large social media followings are entering the market with little professional experience. “Somebody might charge $50, another person might charge $5,000,” Johnson says. “There’s huge value to the imagery, but we haven’t quite figured out what it is yet.”

Jennifer Haysler, managing director at Sarah Laird & Good Company, says they’ve used the same criteria they use to price traditional advertising—like audience size, territory and term—as a starting point. “It’s something that’s known and existing, and it’s something that all the art buyers and us as reps have our heads wrapped around already.”

As a base for pricing, Haysler says, she’ll “look at the client’s social media platforms, and look at their followers and their engagement on each platform.”

Brian DiFeo, who founded The Mobile Media Lab, a company that creates Instagram influencer campaigns for clients, says that reach, engagement and client demands all factor into how they determine pricing. The Mobile Media Lab contracts with a client, then subcontracts with photographers who meet the needs of the client, paying the photographers on the day they do the work. They’ll increase the price—and what they pay the photographer—DiFeo says, “if the client has an ask, like the product’s got to be front and center [in the image] or the photographer has to feature a URL in the caption.”

Included in their pricing is the client’s right to “regram” the photographer’s images on their own social channels and use them in perpetuity on social platforms as long as they credit the photographer, DiFeo says.

Johnson, Haysler and DiFeo all say they ask for credit to the photographer in negotiating social media usage. “Photographers should understand how valuable presence on social media can be for themselves,” Haysler says. “If they’re being associated with a great client and they’re being credited on that company’s social media platform, it has its own big value.”

The term of the license is another important factor in determining pricing. Johnson says that for the past eight years “the first thing that anybody asks for is unlimited use for an unlimited period of time.” Convincing clients that an unlimited term should cost more, and that a limited buy makes more sense, is difficult, she says. “In their mind they don’t want to ever have to worry about it again, but many times [the image] goes on a shelf [after time]…never to be thought of again, so they’re paying for usage they don’t need to pay for.”

Haysler says that clients have begun shortening the length of the usage term “as a bargaining piece in trying to get the usage fee lowered.” She’s seeing clients ask for “one month or three months, sometimes three weeks.” Even though an image will stay on a social feed for a long time, she considers the term the period of time that the client can actively post and repost an image to their social media feeds. “In theory that image may only be seen once even though they have it for a three-month usage because social media is so quick…. How many people are digging back through months of a company’s Instagram feed to find an image? They probably aren’t.” 

The specter of work-for-hire agreements and copyright buyouts has also carried into social media. Johnson says clients are “many times asking for the copyright.” Haysler says “some brands have requested that,” but adds, “I think they’re the same brands that have always tried to go that route. I don’t see it any more than we did before.”

Johnson says, “We don’t sell the copyright,” and emphasizes the importance of  “educating the younger group of people who are new to this industry about why copyright is so important. We’ve fought so hard to make that a very big part of our conversation and it’s falling away quickly, so my rule is that you should never sell the copyright. And if you’re asked to sell it, you should make the price so incredibly high that they don’t want it.” The problem, she says, is that some people are selling their copyrights inexpensively, or offering unlimited, perpetual use for low rates. “It’s a difficult place to be because it’s hard to negotiate what most people feel are fair rates with realistic usage attached when there are so many people just willy-nilly giving rights away.”

“We all have to remember that there has to be a minimum at some point,” Haysler says. “A lot of clients try to undervalue images because of how quickly things are used and gone on social media…. I think it’s a different minimum for each photographer, but there has to be something in place that protects that.”

Haysler says she doesn’t think fees for social media usage will ever reach those for traditional advertising usage. “You could argue that social media is perpetually going to be bigger and bigger usage because it’s going to be more users everyday,” she says. “But on the other side you could argue that it’s smaller, because with print or out of home, an audience can be passive and still be reached.” Audiences have to actively follow brands to see what they’re putting out on social media, she notes. Targeted ads that allow brands to reach people who don’t follow them, however, could help social media fees reach those commanded by print. “I feel like that is going to be the next delineation that we as agents have to look into: Is this social media usage for a company’s channel, or is it going to be sold through into advertising on a social media channel? I think those would be different usage fees.”

article.article_title: How Cornerstone Uses Photography to Tell Brands' Stories
article.meta_description: Jeff Tammes, the agency's head of creative and strategy, tells PDN what Cornerstone does for its clients, how they use photography and what they look for in photographers.
article.article_text_abstract: Jeff Tammes, the agency's head of creative and strategy, tells PDN what Cornerstone does for its clients, how they use photography and what they look for in photographers.
article.article_image_caption: Cornerstone hired Daniel Dorsa to document the Converse Rubber Tracks pop-up at SXSW 2015. His portrait of Wolf Alice frontwoman Ellie Rowsell appeared in a feature on Converse Chuck Taylor All Stars on Nylon.com.
article.article_text:
For the last 14 years, Jeff Tammes has worked at Cornerstone, a multi-disciplinary agency based in New York City. When he started in 2002, the agency had only eight employees; now they count the likes of Budweiser, Diageo and Converse among their roster of clients. As the head of creative and strategy, Tammes says a large part of what he does is help his team develop stories around a client’s brand, and find innovative ways to share them throughout the life of a campaign. Here he tells PDN about what Cornerstone does best, how they use photography and what they look for in photographers. 

PDN: What kinds of services does Cornerstone offer?

JT: We started early on creating projects inspired by music, projects telling the story of fashion and music culture that inspired us. Brands started coming to us to help them identify how we can tell their story for them: how we can create this credible story of who they are and how they can connect with the consumer through that. For Converse, specifically, we are their lead agency on all lifestyle music activity. Budweiser is a client of ours; we work for many different spirits brands within Diageo. We do some work on some other interesting campaigns a little bit outside of that; one is called Families for Excellent Schools, which is creating a movement, rallying people around the education crisis in New York City. We do work for Bit Torrent. In most cases, photography starts to really play a role in not only what you would call traditional advertising, but how we’re integrating [it] into point-of-sale materials, to even the kind of daily storytelling we’re doing through digital channels. 

PDN: What are some of the ways you utilize photography?

JT: We’re taking photography and then making a lot of social media communication with it, around it and inspired by it. Especially in the case of spirits, the drink shots, [we’re making] a variety of point-of-sale materials, and are constantly looking for new ways to do that in a more beautiful way. Then we’ll often look at above-the-line, more traditional advertising; out-of-home, print, those mediums. That photography ends up being part of the finished product. So even if we’re telling a lifestyle story in an ad communication, product always becomes an important part of that story, and it will be used there. Taking a step beyond social media, there’s press outreach, and that photography becomes really important; to supply editorial photography, beautiful photography that properly represents the story we’re sharing.

There’s also Rubber Tracks, something we created for Converse. It’s a global platform now, but it started and is headquartered in the recording studio we built in Brooklyn, which serves as a community center, where we give away free studio time to aspiring bands. Photography helps us tell the story of what’s happening in there day-to-day. We don’t do canned shoots or above-the-line photography in the studio. It’s much more about the constant capture of what’s happening within the studio and around the studio, events and experiences we do around it. 

We have an editor in there full-time who is capturing a lot of that photography. When we have specific initiatives, we might bring in [photographers] to stay in there for a kind of a “photography residency.” 

PDN: How do you find the photographers you hire to document what happens in the studio? 

JT: We get to know them from their own hustle; a lot of them are photographers that are already showing up at the types of events that are relevant to Converse Rubber Tracks. They are documenting the music experiences, they are very much a part of that culture. So when we want to tell a story through photography, and get someone that we know understands that scene, understands what’s being created there, we’ll typically go back to them and ask them to come in and [shoot] that for us. Daniel Dorsa recently shot all the Converse South by Southwest stuff for us. 

PDN: Who are some other photographers you’ve found this way?

JT: Jonathan Mannion, who we’ve worked with for years on different campaigns, is a guy from back in the early days of the company that was really active in documenting New York’s music scene—specifically the hip-hop scene—and built incredible relationships throughout that industry, and became a supporter of a lot of the projects we were doing at that time. We started a magazine out of Cornerstone called The FADER, and Jonathan was a photographer who was very active in shooting for that magazine. As we’ve grown as a company, we’ve brought him on to help us tell those stories. One example is the campaign we did for Bushmills Irish whiskey: The photography that was needed for that [included] a lot of product photography, which has its own nuances and a different approach. But a big part of the Bushmills storytelling was bringing in people who were ambassadors for the brand who were somewhat recognizable: Aaron Paul, Chromeo, Elijah Wood. Knowing Jonathan over the years, his great skill is that he connects with his subjects in an incredible way, and can always get the most authentic, realest vibe going with them when they’re in a studio. He can take any situation and make it relaxed, and we knew we needed that for the Bushmill’s photography. We saw his passion, and got to know him and gave him a shot based on that. 

PDN: What do clients find attractive about Cornerstone as an agency?

JT: When we started, music led a lot of what we were doing. We’ve played a very active role in music since the inception of the company. So a lot of brands do come to us for our expertise there. A lot of brands and clients come to us because they think we have an ability to connect with the consumer in a more authentic way, frankly. Our approach has always been, “How do we take who you are and identify what’s going to be special about you to your consumer, and start to further entrench you in their lifestyle?” People don’t come to us to just get the word out that, “Here’s the commodity, and it costs X.” For the spirit brands, Converse, Budweiser, the Families for Excellent Schools, or the NBA’s Milwaukee Bucks, a new client of ours who wanted to tell a new story about the team and new ownership: In all those cases, we don’t want to just advertise [on behalf of the client]...essentially, we want to create a movement. 

PDN: How do you find new photographers?

JT: We’re always looking for photographers who can demonstrate an ability to capture real life, and not so much a composed lifestyle. We’ve identified that in two ways: The first is what I was talking about before: people we see actively participating and telling stories on their own. Then of course in a more traditional sense, it’s people who meet with us and share their work and share their books. You can see it come through in their work, obviously. 

The other type of photography which we’ve been doing more recently is “hero” product stuff, and it’s a whole different animal for us. We’re working with drink stylists because we’re looking to create unique, classic visuals that can stand alone, but be highly adaptable because we’ll end up using them in multiple forms, multiple layouts. Gentl & Hyers are people we’ve worked with a few times who have been great. 

We’ve also been looking more and more at people doing interesting things with GIFs. Because of that, we’re more actively looking at social media profiles of photographers to figure out if they’re the right person to talk to about a particular project. We’ll do that a lot for some of the social media feeds of our clients; some of that [is shot by] our in-house production staff, and other times we’ll bring in other [artists] with a bigger audience in that [social media] space. For example, with Rubber Tracks, we’re starting to bring in guest GIF artists like Mr. GIF, GIFRIENDS and Golden Wolf to do some storytelling for a prolonged period of time [in] the studio; in that Families for Excellent Schools example, we’re also in the process now of creating different tools just to play with some of the numbers and stats we’ve been talking about [in relation to education].  

PDN: What advice can you give an emerging photographer who wants to work with you?

JT: The hustle that I was referencing earlier—being there—is still important. Now it’s even more important to figure out how to get your story out there through photography in digital environments. More and more we’re looking at social media, and looking at Instagram pages for photographers. We’re looking to see if they’re telling a story that’s connecting and building an audience. That’s always incredibly compelling to us, maybe more so than the [technique]. If they have a unique perspective, and when they shoot something they tell a story with it, and it seems to be resonating and people react to it—that’s where social media audience is an interesting gauge of [whether a photographer] would be worth bringing into a campaign.
