article.article_title: Will Global Safety Standards Cause Publications to Take More Responsibility for Freelance Photographers?
article.meta_description: Unprecedented threats to the lives and livelihoods of freelance conflict journalists have lead journalism organizations and news companies to collaborate on safety standards. Will they help?
article.article_text_abstract: Unprecedented threats to the lives and livelihoods of freelance conflict journalists have lead journalism organizations and news companies to collaborate on safety standards. Will they help?
article.article_image_caption: In this photograph by Nicole Tung, men carry Hatem Qureya, 15, who was trapped under rubble following an airstrike in the neighborhood of Bustan al Qasr in Aleppo, Syria, on Monday, August 6, 2012. The strike claimed at least eight lives, including five children from the same family. Qureya later died en route to a field hospital.
article.article_text:
“I would say without question I was completely unprepared,” says Ron Haviv of his first forays into war reporting as a young freelancer. Haviv began his career covering civil conflict in Panama and “grew up during the war in Yugoslavia,” which he covered for a decade from 1991–2000.

During his early career, Haviv says, “I made many mistakes that I was lucky enough to survive, while colleagues of mine who made the same mistakes were either wounded or killed.”

Nearly 30 years later, photojournalist Nicole Tung bought a plane ticket to Egypt to cover the Arab Spring. Her experience with, and training for, reporting in hostile environments was “pretty much zero,” she says. Tung had contacts with journalists on the ground and “relied on my own wits and instinct.” Later she went to Libya on her own, connected with other journalists and “started picking up assignments with the writers who were reporting from there.”

The paths Haviv and Tung took into conflict reporting—going to report a story they felt compelled to tell and working at times without assignments or guarantees—have been trod by young, committed journalists for time immemorial. The assumption is that a reliable, serious freelance journalist who does good work will find assignments and/or a home for their stories with news organizations.

Yet in the past two years, as record numbers of journalists have been targeted, kidnapped, imprisoned, and murdered in videos broadcast across the world, the news business’ already complicated relationship with freelancers has become increasingly fraught. Questions of safety—and of who is responsible and liable when things go wrong in the field—have caused editors to shy away from assigning freelancers, and even from picking up stories photographers produce on their own. They fear that publishing the work will encourage more freelancers to travel into conflict zones.

In response to the murders of freelance journalists James Foley and Steven Sotloff, a group of volunteers drafted a Global Safety Principles and Practices document, which was released publicly at a gathering at Columbia University’s DART Center for Journalism and Trauma on February 12. The drafters included members of the AP, The DART Center, Frontline Freelance Register, Human Rights Watch, the Overseas Press Club, Reuters, The New York Times and other organizations.

The standards advocate that freelancers on dangerous assignments complete first aid and hostile environment training; seek adequate medical insurance for conflict zones or infectious disease areas; and use “protective ballistic clothing, including armored jackets and helmets.”

The standards also urge that journalists both on assignment and working independently conduct risk assessments before traveling to conflict zones; plan routes and daily check-ins with editors or colleagues; and “take appropriate precautions to secure mobile and internet communications from intrusion and tracking.” (To see the full Global Safety Principles and Practices document visit dartcenter.org/content/global-safety-principles-and-practices.)

The document also lists principles for news organizations to follow. It specifies that editors and news organizations recognize that freelancers and local journalists “play an increasingly vital role in international coverage, particularly on dangerous stories”; that editors and news organizations should “show the same concern” for local journalists and freelancers as they would for staffers; and that, for freelancers and local journalists they work with regularly, news organizations should help with safety training and equipment, and take “responsibility in the event of injury or kidnap.”

The document also says, “News organizations should not make an assignment with a freelancer in a conflict zone or dangerous environment” unless they are prepared to take responsibility for the well-being of the freelancer, calling it a “moral responsibility.”

Agence France Press, The Associated Press, the BBC, Guardian News and Media, Newsweek, The Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, Overseas Press Club of America, Reporters Without Borders, Reuters and USA Today were among organizations that had signed on to the document as we went to press. Journalist David Rohde, one of the document’s drafters, told PDN via email that he hopes more organizations will sign on after a follow-up meeting on April 23 at the National Press Club in Washington, D.C. But there are still several major news organizations that have not signed on. The New York Times, Wall Street Journal and TIME are reviewing the standards, Rohde says. Photo agencies such as VII, Magnum Photos and Noor are also missing from the list.

“Our overall goal was to spark a conversation in the news industry regarding freelancer safety,” Rohde says. “Some organizations have signed onto the guidelines. Others have started internal reviews of how they handle freelancer safety. Either way, we’re happy the issue is being discussed.” To produce something that satisfies both freelancers and news organizations and their lawyers is no easy task, and the document is worded less strongly than freelancers might like. 

VII Photo is among the organizations still discussing the standards internally, says Haviv, one of the founders of the photo agency. He has worked with the group that drafted the document. “Speaking for myself, I personally feel that the language is not strong enough to protect us,” he says. Haviv says he’s “very appreciative of the ideas that are presented,” and that heads of the signatory news organizations acknowledge that “these are real issues that need to be addressed by the entire community.” The organizers have touted this as a starting point for broader discussion and stronger standards, he says, “and I’m hoping that’s correct and that’s why I’m working with them.”  

Tung, who is on the board of directors of the Frontline Freelance Register, an organization that advocates for freelance journalists, saw earlier drafts of the standards. She says that the initial wording “was a lot stronger.” For instance, it addressed a publication’s responsibility if they pick up work a journalist produced on spec. “This document is really addressing the on-assignment stuff,” she says.

“A lot of people have criticized this whole document, saying that it’s an exercise in hand-washing and that no more responsibility is being taken by the publications, but I think it was an important step to recognizing the responsibilities of both sides,” Tung adds.

Haviv says that the training and equipment necessary to prepare freelancers properly for dangerous assignments are readily available, but they’re costly. “Obviously budgets are an issue,” he says. While organizations including the Rory Peck Trust subsidize some training for journalists, “there’s not enough of that, especially for the freelance photographers, to automatically be able to go and get this training before going into the field.” Freelancers in the field are responsible not only for themselves, but the people they hire, like drivers, fixers and translators, Haviv says. “It’s getting to the point where it can be considered a criminal act to go into a conflict zone and not have the correct training, equipment and insurance.”

Tung points out that safety and fair pay are connected. “If you don’t pay us enough or fairly, we’re more likely to cut corners,” she says. For instance, rather than hiring a trusted driver for a weeklong assignment, a freelancer might take cabs, she says. “In a dangerous environment, you don’t know who you can trust and that becomes a safety issue, so we want people to understand that.”

If publications take more responsibility for freelancers, Tung says, they may want to “pick up a freelancer who they know they can trust, who’s been through some security training, which is a good thing.”

While the Global Safety Principles and Practices may or may not lead to “a shared commitment to safety and a new spirit of collegiality and concern” between freelancers and news organizations, as the document states, both Tung and Haviv believe young freelancers will continue to travel independently into conflict zones.

“If they believe in the story and have something to say, people should cover conflict, but with the proper tools,” Haviv says. “Where there’s a will there’s a way,” Tung adds. Despite her lack of experience and training, experienced journalists took Tung under their wing because she proved she was serious.

Says Haviv: “I tell this to every student in my workshops and I tell it to any photographer that talks to me about wanting to be a conflict photographer…. I’m not going to go anywhere with you or even stand next to you in the field if I don’t believe that you know what you’re doing. Because I’ve seen what can happen when people are not properly trained.”

article.article_title: Q&A: How to Get Funding From The Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting
article.meta_description: Nathalie Applewhite of The Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting describes the projects the non-profit supports, and it seeks to bring stories to new audiences.
article.article_text_abstract: Nathalie Applewhite, managing director of The Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, explains the projects the non-profit supports, and how its grantees to help reach an audience beyond readers of a single media outlet.
article.article_text:
In 2010, as newsrooms were cutting budgets and a shrinking number of media organizations were sending photographers to cover stories overseas, PDN reported on the opportunities that new, non-profit journalism organizations had been providing for photographers. In this 2010 interview, Nathalie Applewhite, the managing director of The Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, which was founded in 2006, spoke to us about her organization's support of photographer-writer teams.

Below is our full interview with Applewhite, in which she describes the role photography plays in the work The Pulitzer Center supports, how photojournalists can strengthen their applications for funding, and how the organization expects its grantees to help reach an audience well beyond readers of a single media outlet.

PDN: What function does the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting serve for journalists?

Nathalie Applewhite: We cover the hard costs associated with international reporting. We're trying to fill the gap between what the media outlets can no longer afford on their own when they are willing to run a story.

PDN: In addition to a project proposal that fits the Pulitzer Center mission, what should journalists who are looking for funding have when they apply?

NA: We want them to have a strong interest [in publishing the story] from media outlets. The idea is that the media outlets should still pay the journalists for their work, and we're committed to making sure the journalists, as much as possible, are getting revenue for that.

PDN: Do you assist with distributing the work as well, or is that left to the journalist?

NA: We need to see enough of a distribution plan in line for us to take something on. We don't want a plan where it's just completely in the abstract, but once we do commit to a project then we're really invested in seeing the project get to as many people and in as many media outlets as possible, so we'll work with the journalist to try to find additional venues for it.

PDN: On the Pulitzer Center site it says the organization is trying to focus on "multiplatform." Why is that a focus?

NA: Our overarching mission is not just to support the work, it's to raise awareness for the issues that the journalists are covering, and the best way to do that is to use as many different platforms as possible to generate interest.

To have short video on YouTube linked to a blog, which links to an article that has photographs—having many different pieces gives us the opportunity to spread that [story] across all these different outlets, so different audiences can ideally follow the full path through all of the mediums and explore that and really get as much as possible out of the reporting that we've supported in the first place.

PDN: You also encourage partnerships between journalists working in different medias. Why is that important?

NA: There's been somewhat of a trend of print reporters being expected to become videographers, and everyone's trying to be this one-man band, but I strongly believe that people have areas where they have their strongest skills and they should really focus on that. If we have to pay a little extra money to have the quality video along with the print, or the quality photographs along with the strong radio piece [we do that]. You can end up lessening the quality of everything overall if you try to do too much.

PDN: How important is photography to telling and distributing a story?

NA: We live in a visual culture and in order to grab people's attention it really helps to have a strong image to draw people in. It's definitely more universal, it translates across cultures and across languages, and it gives us a way to have greater reach overall.

PDN: As an organization that is supported through grants and funding from donors, does visual reporting also contribute to Pulitzer Center fundraising?

NA: Absolutely. We struggle sometimes with the photography-only projects, because those are harder to place in as many mainstream outlets. We've had excellent proposals from photojournalists that we haven't been able to support, because we get such a volume of proposals in the first place, and they're harder for us to place across as a wide range of outlets than some of the other pitches that we get. But what we have found is that all of our projects where we've had strong photographers, those materials become very precious to us in putting out our brochures and annual reports and things like that. There's a second phase of value there.

PDN: Are you seeing proposals from photojournalists who want to produce both stills and video, and if they want to do both does that help their chances of receiving funding?

NA: Yes, absolutely.

PDN: How important are multimedia pieces to distributing a story and building momentum for a project?

NA: The format definitely helps. My background is in video production, so I know putting together a solid five-minute documentary can be a really involved process and it takes a lot of different skills to do that, but putting together a Sound Slides show...certainly not everybody can do the same quality show, but even print reporters who don't have the experience can be able to put together something very strong where they're combining their narrative with some of the images they've captured, which can be a really great introduction to the issues for the audience.

One of our requirements for most of our grantees is to produce an audio slideshow. It's dependent on the specific project… We also ask them to produce a blog with photography. Grantees have to do Wikipedia entries [for their stories]. We want to make sure that they're putting whatever they've found out in the mix.

PDN: Do you help grantees who don't have multimedia skills with production?

NA: [Grantees] have done a lot with Time.com and just worked directly with the producer there. If they are producing just for our site and want to put together a Sound Slides show, we've worked with them on formatting and structure. We have a small staff managing a huge volume of projects, so we want people to do it on their own but [our staff] ends up mentoring people.

It is rewarding because you see people, who may be resistant to creating a multimedia piece, and they come back with these 15 strong images and they can do it and they have a strong story. With some good guidelines you can create something very strong that can draw people into the larger print piece or video production.

PDN: Do you support projects that are undertaken by photojournalists alone, or do they generally work with partners?

NA: We've had several projects where we have just worked directly with photojournalists. We may have helped them editing some of the writing they were doing, but they had enough confidence [to create a multiplatform story]. In general it's more likely that they would be paired up with a writer or radio reporter.

PDN: What is the biggest mistake journalists make when applying for funding from the Pulitzer Center?

NA: The same mistake that anybody makes. Not taking time to look at the site and the work that the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting is supporting. I get a lot of questions that would take five minutes to answer if people looked at our site. It's kind of insulting; if you want us to support the work and you're a journalist I would think [you could do the research].

Sometimes people think of us just as a funder, but we're really more than that. Yes we're supporting the reporting, but we really take these projects on as campaigns, so we want to have a relationship with the journalist that we're working with and see that they're committed to seeing the story through.

It's not just about the publication or about placing it in one big outlet, it's about drawing attention to this issue over a long time. In some cases we've seen photojournalists and videographers who think [the project is] done when it's published and so their job is done and just walk away. We'd like people to be more committed to continuing that process.

PDN: Is it difficult to place stories in a number of outlets if the work has also been published elsewhere?

NA: Outlets were really exclusive, and once they ran the picture they had ownership of it. Because of the crisis in the industry, media outlets are less willing to put those restrictions on it unless they're really willing to pay for it, and that's good news as far as spreading awareness of the kinds of crises that we're trying to draw attention to because it means that people can take that story elsewhere.

PDN: What should journalists seeking funding take into account when they apply?

NA: See what else we've covered. We are only funding a maximum of 50 projects annually, and we're trying to scale that down so we can give more attention to each one. [Applicants should] take geographic diversity into consideration.

People often misinterpret our organization title and think we're looking for conflict coverage. We're not looking for conflict coverage. We're about looking at underlying causes, what leads up to the crises, what follows the headlines.

Generally the proposals are very much in tune, [applicants] seem to have done the research. The photographers are really struggling to get their stories out there because they're not covering things that are making headlines, so they need support to cover that kind of in-depth story.

PDN: Are journalists who are working in partnership at an advantage in terms of their application for funding?

NA: It does tend to help on the distribution end of it and for us. If [a print reporter] comes to us and has a relationship with the Christian Science Monitor, and a photographer has a relationship with Time.com—whatever the outlets are—this to us is a stronger guarantee that it's going to reach an audience. That's just a really key component because we have such limited funds we need to make sure that the dollars we spend are going towards something that's going to reach the public.

article.article_title: How I Got That Shot: Gary Land's Dramatic Action
article.meta_description: The commercial photographer and director uses moody backlighting and hard light sources to capture athletes in action.
article.article_text_abstract: The commercial photographer and director uses moody backlighting and hard light sources to capture athletes in action.
article.article_image_caption: To edge light both sides of the athlete’s body, Land used strobes with Magnum reflectors on high stands. More illumination came from lights with smaller reflectors and a beauty dish on a boom.
article.article_text:
Client: HeadOn
Agency: StrawberryFrog
Creative Directors: Shayne Millington and Tim Kang
Art director: Craig Love

To introduce the sports drink HeadOn, creatives at the ad agency StrawberryFrog wanted to show believable images of athletes in moments of intense exertion, rather than highlighting celebrity endorsements from star players. “They wanted to show athletes in peak action,” says commercial photographer and director Gary Land, who’s known for his gritty, dark sports imagery. He submitted an estimate for the job and wrote a treatment explaining how he would capture the look and convey the message the creatives wanted. Writing a successful treatment, he says, is about demonstrating an understanding of the client’s idea, “then writing about how I plan to execute it.” His treatment landed him the assignment, and his estimate convinced the client to focus on just four sports: soccer, football, basketball and CrossFit. 

The creatives had referenced images in Land’s portfolio that they liked that were in the style he describes as “augmented reality.” Based on the references, he says, “I knew they wanted the key light to be behind the subject.” He also suggested bringing in a hazer to create a mist in the background of each shot: “It helps add drama to the scene. It is especially nice when your lights shine through it.”

Logistics

Land, who is based near Boston, had suggested doing all the shots in a sports complex in Hanover, Massachusetts, with 40-foot-high ceilings and no sources of natural light: The facility has multiple basketball courts, soccer pitches and a small gym. Land always budgets a day for tech scouting. For the HeadOn shoot, he worked with a crew of ten, including a hair and makeup person, a wardrobe stylist, a digital tech, a producer, production assistants, his long-time gaffer Jeff Douglass and two other assistants. Land’s production company, GLP Creative, owns a grip truck equipped with all the lights he needs for both film and still productions. 

To cast the shots, Land suggested some athletes he had worked with on previous shoots, including a soccer player from Brandeis who had been in a Coca-Cola commercial that Land directed, and a woman who works out at the same gym Land goes to. Before he hires real athletes, he always does video casting. “I’ve been burned many times when someone has said, ‘Oh sure, I can run.’” 

When he’s directing sports shots and needs to get peak performance out of his models, Land notes, “Before the shoot, I’ll have a little pep talk with people and say, ‘This is why you were chosen out of 300 people. I need you to bring it.’” 

Lighting

Land says that when he set up the lights for the shoot, the first shot provided the template he followed to keep the look consistent throughout the campaign. He starts by setting up the key lights, then moves on to the fill, he says. “In this case, considering we were shooting sports in action, we decided on using harder lights, such as Magnums, 7-inch reflectors and dishes.”

Land uses Profoto Pro-8 packs. “I use those because they have fast flash duration and recycle times,” he says. He typically uses bi-tubes for extra power “when I have to stop action.” His preferred light modifier is a Profoto Magnum, a large strobe reflector with a 50-degree-angle beam spread, because he likes the control it gives him. “It’s great for sports, and for re-creating sun.” To give him the freedom to move his lights around from set to set, or to adjust to an athlete’s movements, he set most of his lights on medium rollers. The rollers are sturdier than C-stands, and Land uses them often on film productions, or when he needs flexibility. 

For one of his shots of a basketball player driving towards the net, he set up his camera under the basket. Land wanted to backlight the athlete to match the rest of the shots in the campaign. He also wanted edge lights on both sides of the player’s body, to make sure he stood out dramatically from the black background. Land had one Magnum on a medium roller set at its maximum height—about 15 feet high. To the left he had another Magnum high on a medium roller to rim-light the athlete. Lower on the roller’s stand, he also had a second light with a 7-inch reflector. Set at lower power, this smaller reflector hit the player’s legs and feet. The DF-50 hazer was placed on the floor between the rollers, casting a mist over the back of the hall. 

At camera right, he had another 7-inch reflector at the top of a medium roller. This added additional edge lighting, and also shone through the mist from the hazer. Behind the camera, he had a silver beauty dish with a grid to provide some fill. The dish was attached to a medium roller by a mega boom. As Land changed angles, looking for the perfect positioning of the athlete in the air, he could move the beauty dish, keeping it behind the camera. 

Land continued his use of backlighting in his photo of a woman doing pull ups in a dark gym, where the gaffer attached one light and Magnum to a beam on the back wall, and another on a highboy stand. For his front lighting, Land diffused the light by setting up a silk and using strobes with 7-inch reflectors behind her and to camera right, to light her lower back. 

Camera 

Land shot with a Hasselblad H4X with a 28mm f/4 lens and a Leaf Credo 50 digital back. “I shot pretty much at 1/500th of a second at f/9,” and was usually shooting at ISO 400. Land adds, “The good thing about the digital back is that it’s awesome with low light now.” Shooting at a low angle, with the camera on sandbags or on a low tripod, Land shot tethered to his digital tech’s iMac, which has a 27-inch monitor. The digital tech, Max Gordon, also screen-shares the images to a MacBook Pro that Land places near his camera as he shoots, so he can check that he’s captured the action he wants. While Gordon reviewed the shots in CaptureOne software, zooming in on details, clients flagged the shots they liked. Land notes, “That’s the other thing about the camera: Not only is the file size huge, but the dynamic range is incredible.”

Postproduction

Land’s retouching is handled by Trident Post Production, which he owns and which operates out of his studio. A member of the Trident team came to the shoot and was on hand when the client signed off on the look and images they wanted. After a hard drive is delivered to Trident, Land likes to check the retouching and color correction, he says, “like a director being involved in the film-editing process."

Related: End Frame: Why Shooting Personal Work Pays Off

article.article_title: Print is Not Dead: A Look at New and Redesigned Magazines
article.meta_description: In which we take a look at magazines and websites that got a fresh coat of paint in the past year, as well as some new kids on the block.
article.article_text_abstract: In which we take a look at magazines and websites that got a fresh coat of paint in the past year, as well as some new kids on the block.
article.article_text:
PDN takes a look at a handful of magazines and websites that got a fresh coat of paint, as well as some of the new kids on the block. 

The New York Times Magazine

Jake Silverstein was lured from Texas Monthly to oversee the transition of the 119-year-old magazine’s new look and website, which will feature a regular column on photography by Teju Cole. The new site will feature photos run large, from edge-to-edge on both mobile and desktop browsers, more Web-only galleries and extended photo essays from the print magazine. The first issue had four covers, featuring work from Matthew Pillsbury, Hannah Whitaker, Sara Cwynar and the duo Maurizio Cattelan and Pierpaolo Ferrari, whose work is on this month’s cover of PDN.


Self.com

After a 2013 print redesign, Conde Nast installed new editor-in-chief Joyce Chang, who oversaw a redesign of the brand’s website. Brooklyn-based Athletics NYC was tasked with the site’s image-centric redesign, which Chang told fashionista.com “is, in itself, an Instagram feed writ large.”


Maxim 

Kate Lamphear, the former style director at T: The New York Times Style Magazine, was hired as editor-in-chief to implement a more mature version of the lad magazine. The debut “Raw”-themed issue featured original photography from Jamie Chung, Sigurd Grünberger, Lorenzo Agius, Dan Forbes, Robert Nethery, Gilles Bensimon, Edwin Tse, Andreas Laszlo Konrath, Anuschka Blommers & Niels Schumm, Bobby Bruderle and Michael Piazza.

Paper

The 30-year-old downtown New York art, fashion and culture magazine got a redesign in the fall, with new typefaces and a new bordered cover format that eschews full-bleed photos. Jean-Paul Goude’s cover shoot for the Winter 2014 issue recreated his infamous Carolina Beaumont “Champagne Incident” shoot with Kim Kardashian-West, which PAPER declared to “Break the Internet.”


Condé Nast Traveler

Looking to find its footing in the age of Instagram and TripAdvisor .com, the Conde Nast travel title got freshened up, though the most prominent change is likely the redesign of its logo. The new magazine features the occasional two-page spread, but much of the photography is oriented vertically, especially in the front of the book. 


Eater.com & Racked.com 

Since Vox Media acquired the Curbed network (which includes Curbed.com, Racked.com and Eater.com), both Racked (fashion retail) and Eater (food) have been redesigned, and the sites now use Vox Media’s vaunted content management system. Eater, redesigned in September, has rolled out a longform features page edited by Helen Rosner, which gives a home to large-scale, image-centric narrative storytelling.

Office 

Office is the brainchild of Simon Rasmussen, the New York-based stylist who recently helped the Danish agency Dyhr.Hagen launch FAT Man magazine, and Jesper D. Lund, a creative director at Bergdorf Goodman. The debut issue of the hefty 13 1/4 x 9 3/4 -inch glossy fashion magazine has three covers, with photos from Marc Hom, Marcelo Krasilcic and Kira Bunse, and features work from Julia Noni, Asger Carlsen, Tom Allen, Jason Kibbler, Kathy Lo, Fumi Nagasaka and Dario Catellani. 


Eclectic 

A biannual art and fashion magazine based in the U.K., Eclectic is run by Anna Barr and Charin Chong, who mix art projects and interviews with the standard fashion editorials. The most-recent third issue features photography from Lucilla Bellini, Robbert Jacobs, Samuel Colombo, Margaret Nowak, Corinne Stoll, Andrei Zozulya-Davidov, Lucio Aru & Franco Erre, Isshogai, Hanako Whiteway, William Ferchichi, Sam Ssefa, Hubert Crabières, Rankin, Cary Fagan and Cédric Bonnard.


Avenir 

Avenir (the French word for “future” and also the name of a typeface) is a quarterly art and culture magazine based in London. Issue 4 features a review of 2014 British graduate art school exhibitions, an editorial by Eliöka Kyselková showcasing clothes designed by British fashion students, and photography from Louise Donohue, Zoe Lower, Charlotte Rutherford, Paul Franco and Jacob McFadden.


GQ Style 

A bi-annual fashion offshoot of the general-interest monthly, GQ Style is produced by GQ’s staff, and comprised mostly of pickup art as well as clothing still lifes from contributing photographers Josephine Schiele and Stuart Tyson. A single commissioned shoot—the Spring/Summer 2015 issue’s was shot by Tom Schirmacher—runs on the cover, and throughout the issue. 


The Great Discontent 

Ryan & Tina Essmaker raised more than $100,000 on Kickstarter to launch this quarterly culture magazine, composed mostly of interviews with creators. Ryan Lowry’s image of Tavi Gevinson from the debut issue was featured in April’s PDN’s 30 issue. Issue No. 2 features photography from Lowry, Eric Ryan Anderson, Amanda Jasnowski, Collin Hughes, Ren Rox, Clayton Cubitt, Catalina Kulczar, Amy Dickerson, Josh Goleman and Hannah Kristina Metz. 


Sugar & Rice 

This new Houston, Texas-based quarterly food magazine is run by formerly New York-based book editor David Leftwich and is backed by Down House, a local restaurant. Issue No. 2 features photography from Chance Hunter, Lou Vest, Debora Smail, Chuck Cook, Khalil AbuSharekh and Richard Knight.

article.article_title: Daniel Morel and the High Cost of Copyright Infringement Claims
article.article_text_abstract: The lawyers who took Daniel Morel's case are out $2.5M in fees. One explains why the law disincentives lawyers from taking copyright cases.
article.article_text:
The law firm largely responsible for helping photographer Daniel Morel win a $1.2 million jury award for copyright infringement—the maximum amount allowed by law—spent more than twice that amount to prosecute Morel’s case. And now, that law firm has to write off its costs as a loss. 

The reason is because a federal court has rejected a motion by Morel and his attorneys to recover $2.5 million in legal fees and costs incurred during his five-year copyright battle against Getty Images and AFP. The decision underscores the high costs—and disincentive—of pursuing copyright infringers.

Morel won the $1.2 million damage award in 2013 for willful infringement by the two photo agencies of eight of his images of the 2010 Haiti earthquake. Willkie Farr & Gallagher, the law firm that tried Morel’s case on a contingency basis, will get 15 percent of the jury award. But that amount—less than $200,000—doesn’t come close to covering the firm’s fees and costs.

In addition, the court ruled that Morel owes $164,583 in legal fees and expenses to Barbara Hoffman, the attorney who originally represented him in the case. 

“Morel fought a fair fight and won. The fact that this was a close case on the merits, involving novel legal issues, persuades the Court that the purposes of the Copyright Act are not furthered by awarding [attorneys’] fees and costs,” Judge Alison J. Nathan of the U.S. District Court in New York City wrote in her decision rejecting Morel’s request.

Nathan explained in her decision that the “interests of the Copyright Act are furthered by encouraging the raising of objectively reasonable claims and defenses, which may serve not only to deter infringement but also to ensure that the boundaries of copyright law [are] demarcated as clearly as possible.” For that reason, she added, “district courts are disinclined to award fees in cases that are close calls or which present novel legal issues or theories.”

Morel had asserted that the defenses of Getty and AFP were “objectively unreasonable”—the standard for awarding fees and costs to the prevailing party in civil cases. The judge disagreed. “Morel primarily objects to Getty and AFP’s litigation tactics,” which had little to do with the merits of their legal arguments, the judge wrote in her decision. She added that the legal arguments of AFP and Getty “were objectively reasonable.” 

Moreover, the court said, the defenses “raised a relatively novel issue” and “helped define the contours of copyright law in the digital age” by testing the application of copyright law to social media. (Morel’s images were copied and distributed without Morel’s permission after he posted them on Twitter, and the question of infringement in the case turned in part on the language of Twitter’s terms of service.)

Morel had sought $2,357,608 in attorney’s fees for 3,829.5 hours of work performed by Willkie Farr & Gallagher between May 2011 and September 2014. He sought an additional $33,698 in fees fronted by the law firm for work performed by outside legal consultants, plus $166,688 in legal costs. That included $74,745 in costs incurred by the Hoffman Law Firm, which represented Morel from March, 2010 until February 2013, when Hoffman was, according to the court ruling, discharged without cause.

When he took the case, Joseph Baio of Willkie Farr & Gallagher says he knew Morel wouldn’t be able to pay the legal costs. Baio also anticipated the risk of not being able to recover costs from the defendants, even if Morel eventually won a decisive victory. That’s because the principle of forcing losing parties to pay the winner’s legal costs “is alien to the system” of U.S. law, he says.

Moreover, Baio says, the costs of pursuing copyright claims—especially against well-funded opponents—can far exceed the maximum damages that plaintiffs can recover under the law. So attorneys can never count on contingency fees to cover their costs.

Morel’s decisive victory sent a message to would-be infringers and made the world “a little bit safer” for copyright holders, Baio says, but he adds, “The law is structured so there’s little incentive” for attorneys to take on a copyright case even if it appears to be “a drop-dead winner.” 

But Baio is sanguine about the write-off. “I had a gas trying the case,” he says. “I got my own rewards, and we do enough other business at this firm so it won’t break the bank.”

Meanwhile, Morel’s first attorney, Barbara Hoffman, had sought $1.1 million in fees and interest, but the court ruled that she was basing her claim on an $665 hourly rate that was unreasonably inflated, and that her records were “scattershot,” so the court could not rely on her claim that she had worked 1,250 hours on the case. The court determined that 416 billable hours at a $395 hourly rate were more reasonable.

Morel, who was awaiting payment of the $1.2 million jury award at press time, declined to be interviewed about the legal costs of the case. But he said in a statement that Baio helped him prepare: “I am proud that my five years of effort on this case have helped to eliminate some of that ‘havoc’ and to give my fellow photojournalists an important tool to protect their rights and fight against those who would try to trample on those rights…. May the next generation fight on and persevere.” 

Related Articles

Court Rejects Daniel Morel's $2.5 Million Claim for Legal Fees Against Getty, AFP

article.article_text:
THE YEAR IN PHOTOGRAPHY

Career Launch: Wynn Myers
Austin, Texas-based lifestyle photographer Wynn Myers has taken an unconventional path to shooting editorial and advertising assignments for national brands. 
By David Walker

By David Walker

Copyright Watch: Court Rejects Daniel Morel’s $2.5 Million Claim for Legal Fees Against Getty, AFP

More than 20 percent of the photos that advanced to the penultimate round in the World Press Photo contest were disqualified for image manipulation. Here’s how they were caught.

Advice For Building An Instagram Following
Four photographers with different styles and interests explain how their Instagram audiences grew. 
By Brienne Walsh 

What Should You Charge for Social Media Usage?
The growing market for social media imagery can provide a new revenue stream, but inconsistent pricing standards threaten to cause a race to the bottom. Reps explain how they’re determining what to charge.

Fresh Takes
PDN takes a look at magazines and websites that got a fresh coat of paint in the past year, as well as some of the new kids on the block.

Visual Storytelling Platforms Abound. Are They a Good Thing for Photographers?
Options for self-publishing photo essays and multimedia projects online are growing. We ask photographers who use them about the pros and cons.

The Photo Annual 2015
The juried selection of the best images of the year.

Spotlight: Cornering the Market
Jeff Tammes, head of creative and strategy at the multi-disciplinary agency Cornerstone, explains how the team develops stories around a client’s brand, and what they look for in photographers.

How I Got That Shot: Dramatic Action

Keep It Safe: 16 Storage Solutions for Preserving Your Digital Negatives
From your desktop to the cloud, these storage solutions will safeguard your files.

article.article_title: How to Win Grants That Support Your Photo Projects
article.meta_description: Photographer Sara Terry, founder of the Aftermath Project and a professional grant writer, estimates she has won grants over the last 15 years totaling nearly $1 million. She recently shared some tips and advice for successful grant writing.
article.meta_keywords: Sara Terry, Aftermath Foundation, Aftermath Grant, Guggenheim Fellowship, Alicia Patterson Foundation, Alicia Patterson Fellowship, Dorothea Lange-Paul Taylor Prize, Lange-Taylor Prize, photography grants, photography grant
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer Sara Terry, founder of the Aftermath Project and a professional grant writer, estimates she has won grants over the last 15 years totaling nearly $1 million. She recently shared some tips and advice for successful grant writing.
article.article_image_caption: From "A Ukraine Runs Through It," for which Mielnikiewicz won the 2015 Aftermath Project grant.
article.article_text:
Sara Terry, photographer founder of the Aftermath Project and a professional grant writer, estimates she has won grants totaling nearly $1 million over the last 15 years. PDN recently asked her for her practical tips and advice for successful grant writing.

PDN: Are there good resources for identifying available grants for photographers?
Sara Terry: Every once in a while you see someone post a list of available grants. You can Google "grants available for photographers" and one of those lists will pop up. I just discovered the Ernest Cole Award in South Africa that way.

PDN: Do you follow any kind of roadmap when applying for grants? Can you break it down into manageable steps?
ST: Number one, research the grant you think you want to apply for. Carefully read the website and the FAQ page. Look at who has won it before. Read very carefully the application questions, and figure out what they want to fund. Is it a year-long grant? Are they giving you cues that there's a specific hook to this grant? That's where you start.

Then you need to understand what makes your project different, and what makes it worthy. What do you think is going to grab somebody's attention about it? It could be that nobody has done it. It could be a historically overlooked issue. You may have a personal connection to it. I'm thinking of Jessica Hines, who has been a finalist for the Aftermath Grant. Her work is about her brother, who was a Vietnam vet who committed suicide.

If you're not a good writer, give yourself a week to write the heart of your application—your statement—and then share it and get feedback on it. I think the next step would be to select the photos that you want to support it, and then have people check that edit for you. That's the order I would do it in.

PDN: How do you determine if a grant is a good fit for the work you do?
ST:  You have to understand that a grant has a specific purpose, mission or intent.  You need to read carefully what the mission statement is. Aftermath Project has a mission in documenting post-conflict stories, and an outcome—a book. I make those things clear, but I get applications every year from people who propose environmental aftermath stories, or from people who try to twist the meaning of conflict to fit their own agenda, for instance, [saying] domestic violence is post-conflict. I guarantee you any funder with a specific mission statement will look at that and disqualify it.

PDN: What are other common reasons applicants get disqualified or rejected?
ST: I think a lot of people have never had anyone take a critical look at their work and say, “You are not up to par here.”

A really important thing to do is go back in and look at what [the grant sponsor has] already funded. With the [Dorothea Lange–Paul Taylor Prize], it looked like an unwritten rule that if a national project won, you wouldn't win with a national project the following year [because] for many years, the awards went national, international, national, international.

With Aftermath Project, we're not going to give a $20,000 grant for the same project that won the previous year. We have a limited landscape, and limited finances, and we're trying to draw a big picture. So if last year's winner was Stanley Greene on Chechnya, we won't give another grant for a project on Chechnya.

PDN: When you're trying to figure out what projects an organization wants to fund, what other cues do you look for?
ST: I got [The Alicia Patterson Foundation Fellowship Award] for work in Bosnia in 2005, I think. I read the Alicia Patterson guidelines. They so clearly stated they wanted to support production of journalism stories, so that's what I wrote, and I won. It was the wording I used to make sure I was meeting their interest. You have to incorporate it so you're not just parroting what they want. It takes some thinking, and maybe talking to someone who has won the grant before, if you know somebody.

There are little tricks. The Guggenheim Foundation doesn't tell you why you won, but they want to feel like they're supporting you at a pivotal point in your career, and almost all the writing I've seen for Guggenheim fellowships reflected a measure of confidence on the part of the photographers—a sense of self-awareness, and why the work mattered. There was Robert Frank's legendary one-pager [application].

Sometimes people pitch [projects on grant applications] as a photojournalism assignment, but you look at that and go, “You could get that done in a month. And you want a grant for a year?” It's not going to happen.

PDN: It sounds like you can look at past winners of different grants, and reverse engineer the winning applications?
ST: It's something you can do. You would look for patterns of what's been awarded, and look at what they've funded in recent years. With Guggenheim, you can look up who's won, and try to find their project work online. And you can maybe look for what the photographer has written about that work, and how they've framed it, to give you a sense of their individual thinking. You’re never going to see a Guggenheim grant application [online because] it's very private. We do publish the [application] statements that come in with our winning grants [for Aftermath Project], so you can see how grant winners and finalists framed their stories. But you've got to learn as much as you can, and then you have to free yourself from thinking you have to copy anybody, because that won't work.

PDN: What tips do you have for writing the grant application?
ST: If you're not a good writer, I think it's really important to find a friend who is a good writer—preferably a journalist. Your project statement should have, fairly high up, a succinct sense of what it is you want to do and why it matters. If you’re a really good writer, you can probably get people to wander with you for three or four paragraphs, before you get to [what you want to do and why it matters.] But if it sounds like a college history assignment, and you talk about the history of the civil war in Sri Lanka, you've wasted half of your up-front pitch talking about the past, and not about what you're going to do. In the end, the photos and the written statement are equal. You're not going to get through with strong photos and a lousy proposal.

PDN: Do have any other tips for writing that proposal?
ST: I think one of the best tips ever given to me as a writer was: If you have just been to an event, or if something just happened, and you picked up the phone and called your grandmother, what's the first thing you would tell her about what you just saw? You're not writing for Congressmen or bankers. You want to be able to communicate in a clear and dynamic way to someone you care about. That's an amazing writing tip, in terms of keeping it conversational, intelligible, dynamic and human.

PDN: That applies to grant-writing, too?
ST: Yeah, you don't want to quote a Doctors Without Borders report for the first couple of paragraphs. You might cite reports and statistics. But a really well-written, successful grant application—at least for the types of grants we're talking about—just has a compelling conversational quality to it. Not an academic quality.

The other thing that gets noticed is whether your story is unusual. Every year I write a letter saying [to potential applicants], "This is what's interesting to us this year." And at the end, before the grant is announced, I write a letter to all of the applicants with notes about how the judging went, so they get a general sense of things that worked or didn't work.

PDN: What's an example of something you said?
ST: It's so interesting how trends develop. Like right now, that whole object-as-storytelling thing that Glenna Gordon did so beautifully with objects [that kidnap victims] brought back from captivity, and with her project called Abducted Nigerian School Girls; all of the sudden everybody's [photographing] objects [as stories]. That's going to become like beating a dead horse pretty soon. There was a period of time [three or four years ago] when everybody tried to tell news stories through portraits. And I would write to people and say, we had so many proposals [for that type of story], and they just weren't strong enough.

PDN: We so often hear from jurors that people try to imitate what won previously.
ST: Somebody gets recognized, and immediately everybody adopts that style. Know what's been awarded, but don't copy it, because that's really boring. Amplify it or go do something new.

PDN: Can you solicit feedback if you don't win? Can you call afterwards?
ST: If they say do not call, DO NOT call. They've said they don't want to hear from you.

PDN: What if you know a juror? Is it kosher to ask where you fell short, or how your application could have been better?
ST: Not really. It depends. At Aftermath Project, we don't have the manpower for feedback. You don't have headspace for 180 applications in your mind. None of my friends have ever asked why they didn't get that Aftermath grant. They respect those boundaries. But we don't prohibit judges from talking to applicants. You might ask a juror if you know them. But if the funder says no feedback, that's it.

Related Article

How I Got That Grant: The Aaron Siskind Foundation Individual Photographer's Fellowship


I would make a really important point: If an applicant is fortunate to have communication from grantor, like a feedback note, like, "You're not framing it in a way that fits our goals," you want to be respectful and appreciative. You do not want to argue with the grantor about what it is they're doing, or how they see the issue that they are funding. You snap to and be appreciative that someone tried to give you a helping hand. [Don't] get defensive and argumentative.

Related:
Chasing the Money: How to Fund a Documentary Project
How I Got That Grant: The Aaron Siskind Foundation Individual Photographer's Fellowship

article.article_title: Shadowing Photographer David Burnett on the Trail of Chile's History
article.meta_description: "Behind the scenes of a Roads & Kingdoms assignment to follow photojournalist David Burnett as he searched for sites and people he had photographed during Chile's 1973 coup.
article.article_text_abstract: Behind the scenes of a Roads & Kingdoms assignment to follow photojournalist David Burnett as he searched for sites and people he had photographed during Chile's 1973 coup.
article.article_image_caption: David Burnett photographing with his Speed Graphic on a street in Santiago, Chile, 40 years after he photographed the early days of the country’s bloody coup.
article.article_text:
In this month’s interview with Nathan Thornburgh (“The High Roads,” page 42), the co-founder of Roads & Kingdoms says his favorite collaboration with a photographer was the story he and Michael Magers did in 2013, when they traveled to Santiago, Chile. The pair followed photojournalist David Burnett as he looked for the places and people he had photographed immediately after the country’s military coup in 1973. Magers recalls that Thornburgh asked him to follow Burnett “and to be his shadow.” Says Magers, “It was a treasure hunt through Santiago to find people and places he had photographed during the coup, and it was quite emotional for Dave at times as well, to be connecting with these subjects.” Burnett photographed the tearful reunion of two women who had not seen each other since they were teenagers, when Burnett had photographed them mourning at the funeral of poet Pablo Neruda just days after the coup. He also photographed people who had been rounded up by the military in the days after General Augusto Pinochet seized power. 

As Burnett hurried through the city, he attracted attention wherever he went thanks to the gear he hustled along with him, including an old Pacemaker Speed Graphic on a tripod, several other cameras, and a holster-like fanny pack he has customized to carry the Speed Graphic’s film holders. “It was a combination of madcap caper and serious subject matter,” Magers says. Hunting for a location, Burnett would stop people on the street, show them his old photos and ask for directions. “As soon as you talked to someone about it, you might find yourself in an hour-long conversation,” says Magers. Chile was in the midst of hotly contested presidential race among three candidates whose fathers had been key players on both sides of the political battles of 1973. The wounds of that period still felt raw, Magers notes. A documentary series airing each night on Chilevisión featured previously unseen footage and images of the bloody coup. 

Many people were surprised to meet the photographer who had taken the photo that came to symbolize the dictatorship’s abuses. In the notorious soccer stadium where thousands had been detained and tortured, Burnett had captured the frightened gaze of a young man—his name, Burnett later learned, was Daniel Céspedes—in a group of prisoners being corralled by soldiers with guns. Burnett and another American photographer, Bob Sherman, had been arrested trying to take photos in the stadium; they were held at gunpoint for two hours. Moments after they were released, Burnett caught sight of the prisoners and captured his famous frame, which was later published in Paris Match. Céspedes was eventually released—possibly because of the international attention the photo brought him. 

A section of the stadium has been preserved as a memorial. There, Magers took Burnett’s portrait. “What I saw was the past rushing into him and over him,” Magers says. “There was a great solemnity to it all, and a feeling of loss.” 

Magers says of watching Burnett interact with his subjects, “For me, it was just an incredible experience to see how he works, and what a great guy he is.”

article.article_title: How to Land Photo Assignments from Audubon Magazine
article.meta_description: Sabine Meyer, photography director of Audubon, the national environmental magazine, explains how she assigns photo essays and portraits covering nature, the environment, and conservation.
article.meta_keywords: National Audubon Society, Sabine Meyer, Audubon Magazine
article.article_text_abstract: The photography director of the national environmental magazine, explains how she assigns photo essays and portraits for its coverage of nature, the environment, and conservation.
article.article_image_caption: Audubon Magazine, May-June 2015.
article.article_text:
Audubon Magazine is the bi-monthly publication of National Audubon Society, an organization dedicated to conserving and restoring natural ecosystems, with particular focus on the habitats of birds and other wildlife. Since January 2014, Sabine Meyer has served as the society's photography director, overseeing photography in Audubon Magazine and on the NAS web portal. She was previously director of photography at National Geographic Adventure, and has held photo editing positions at several other magazines, including New York Magazine and Conde Nast Traveler.  Meyer, who recently worked with photographer Greg Kahn on a story about climate change affecting the Outer Banks, talked to PDN about how she assigns photo essays and portraits for its coverage of nature, the environment, and conservation.

PDN: What are you looking for in the photographers you hire?
SM:  I have portraits, landscapes, and stories that blend ecology and science. We often have stories that blend science and ornithology, so of course I need [photographers] who can photograph birds, who know about the proper ethical handling of bird photography and how to handle wildlife and how to work with researchers.  

PDN: What are you looking for esthetically? Is there anything in particular you favor?
SM: I don't know there's anything I favor, but my creative director and I (Kevin Fisher) are trying to move toward documentary and wildlife photography mixed in with a slightly fine-art approach.  For instance, Camille Seaman does beautiful landscapes and climate change stories with wildlife in her pictures.

PDN: Who are some other photographers you've hired recently?
SM: I hired Jon Lowenstein last fall to do a story on a group of hunters/duck chasers in the Dakotas. We did a story [for the January-February 2015] on the soon-to-be-dug-out Nicaragua canal. Ivan Kashinsky did that story for us. He's not specifically a bird photographer, but he does tackle environmental issues. Richard Barnes, who does architecture, just did a project for us about the Rhode Island School of Design.

PDN: Do you have particular examples of photographers who have recently delivered on assignments way beyond your expectations? What did that do that impressed you?
SM: Tristan Spinski went to a very remote atoll in the South Pacific to cover "crazy ants," which spray acid on birds, and the team from US Fish and Wildlife  that works on eradicating the ants. Tristan shot photos and videos of the work and daily life on the atoll, but also set up a mini studio with white  and black backdrops to shoot "portraits" of the ants as well as the birds, which we ended up using in the magazine throughout the story. 
    Last year, Tom Fowlks photographed Brooke Durham, who rehabs parrots in southern California. Tom impressed us by coming back with reportage, portraits, a cover and a series of mini still lifes (of the tools used to rehab the parrots), all executed beautifully and produced in a super clean and super graphic way which really pushed the envelope for us on how we can approach bird photography.

PDN: Where do you find photographers? What's your best source of leads?
SM: Everything. There's my own personal rolodex, photo blogs, the world of photographers in the conservation arena. I look at photographers who belong to the International League of Conservation Photographers. I look at the group of photographers who shoot for National Geographic.

PDN: What are the photo blogs that you mention?
SM: Lens, Lightbox, BJP, Rob Haggert's blog, Conscientious. Those are the big ones I pay attention to.

PDN: Do you ever give assignments to emerging photographers? If so, who are recent examples?
SM: Connor Stefanison is a young wildlife shooter based in British Columbia. We published some of his images of loons on our site, then an assignment came down to shoot loon scientists in the field in Montana. Connor also just graduated with a degree in ecology, conservation and evolution, which made him the perfect match for this job.  
    My colleague Mike Fernandez met Esther Horvath this year at the International Center of Photography's career day. Her work on Kemp's Ridley sea turtles really impressed us. We got the opportunity to send a photographer to the Arctic on a US Coast Guard ship for two weeks to report on their work collecting oceanographic data and we jumped at the opportunity to get Esther on the ship to shoot photos, videos, and also post on Instagram for us.  

PDN: Do you follow anyone on Instagram or other social media? Who has your attention right now?
SM: Right now I'm following Matt Black, because the work he's doing is of high interest. I loved his California [drought] project in black and white. Clearly the drought is affecting the habitat of birds, so I look at his pictures. And I follow all the National Geographic photographers.

PDN: Whose self-promo have you kept in the last month, and why?
SM: I don't get a ton of mailers. But Matt Slaby of Luceo Images sent me a fun marketing kit, "Break this glass in emergency for creative call." We have worked together before. That's on my radar.

PDN: What's the best way for photographers to get meetings with you?
SM: The first thing to do is probably to send me an e-mail with work that falls in line with what Audubon does. It doesn't have to have birds, but portraits, landscapes, habitats, photojournalism--everything we do. I don't have a ton of time for meetings. I tend to spend more time looking at portfolios online.

PDN: If you could tell photographers in advance how best to present their work to you, what instructions would you give them?
SM: Show me stories. Unless you're a portrait photographer, I'm not interested in individual images. Show me stories that have a long narrative arc. Show me some personal projects. Show me things that touch on environment, conservation, wildlife, social issues--domestic or international. It's perfectly acceptable to show the work on an iPad or a laptop as a slideshow.

PDN: Are you judging the photographers you hire on factors other than the quality of their work?
SM: Yes. If I hire photographers to go into the field and represent the National Audubon Society, I'm looking for people who understand that there are some very particular rules about photographing wildlife. If a researcher says you can't get close to that bird because it's going to affect the nest and the baby birds, you've got to stop and not do it. And I'm looking for photographers who understand how a story is built.

PDN: What's the line for you between a photographer helpfully staying in touch and a photographer annoying you too much?
SM: Send an e-mail to say, "Hey, look at my work," and if I really like the work, I will answer, even if it takes me two weeks. If after two e-mails I haven't answered it's because there's no interest.
    The other thing that's critical for me, is we re-launched a website in January that's content rich, with lots of room for photos and photo galleries. We're constantly looking for content, so someone who has a project that's ready to go, and it's content we're interested in, I'm happy to look at it. Often that's the first step [toward] an assignment for the photographer.

PDN: Which photographers have graduated from contributing existing work to landing assignments?
SM: Gerrit Vin is a very seasoned wildlife shooter. We have been publishing a lot of his photos on our site and in our magazine and annual reports over the years. I had a shoot in Alaska, photographing Gyrfalcons in nests and tagging along with scientists studying them— Gerrit  was the obvious choice for this project as he had been in Alaska previously shooting Gyrfalcons. The story is scheduled to be published in 2016.    
    Greg Kahn's 3 Millimeters project on our Climate Change site led to an assignment documenting the  effects of climate change in the Outer Banks.

PDN: Is there anything that you think photographers don't understand about how you work, that would be helpful to you if they understood?
SM: I think what's important to us is the fact that going on assignment requires a lot of different skills and a keen journalistic mind. I'm after the esthetic, too, but I'm looking for people who are journalists.

PDN: Do you have any pet peeves about photographers, and if so, what?
SM: Yes. [Poor] captions. [You have to include] detailed, accurate captions in the metadata of the photos when they're delivered. Too often I get a set of images, and the captions aren't detailed. We live in a world of particular bird species. We need to know what species the bird is, we need to know where [it was photographed], we need to know the circumstance, we need to know when it was photographed. it seems very basic. But it's one of my biggest pet peeves.
