article.article_title: How to Sell Your Fine-Art Prints: A Primer
article.meta_description: Advice gleaned from interviews with collectors, gallery owners and photographers on pricing and selling fine-art prints in limited editions.
article.article_text_abstract: Advice from gallery owners, curators, photographers and collectors about the market for fine-art prints.
article.article_text:
The world of fine-art photography has its own vocabulary, and its own methods for assessing value and price. To better understand the workings of the fine-art market and how it's changing, PDN has interviewed numerous gallery directors, private dealers and collectors, and also talked to photographers who have succeeded at selling their prints themselves. Their advice, gleaned from articles in PDN’s archives, provides a guide for photographers trying to navigate the market for fine-art prints.
These articles are available to PDN subscribers.  

A Guide to Pricing Your Prints
Gallery owners agree: You can always raise prices, but you can never lower them. In addition to pricing their work too high before they’re established, emerging artists make the mistake of issuing editions that are too large. Keeping editions small—ideally six prints or fewer, she says—is increasingly important, as more contemporary art collectors used to investing in one-of-a-kind paintings begin collecting photographs. “I beg artists to issue one edition of three to five,” says New York gallery owner Andrea Meisin.
Raising your prices depends on many factors, gallerists say, including not only how well your prints have sold, but who has bought them.

What Does "Limited Edition" Really Mean?  
Twenty years ago, an edition of less than 20 prints was rare; now galleries rarely sell work by a photographer who prints in editions of more than ten. Collectors expect that the photographic prints they acquire remain scarce so they hold their value. But many photographers have issued new editions at a later date in larger sizes, or using different print processes, or both: Sometimes it’s for creative reasons, but often it is to cash in on the rising value of a work for which the existing limited-edition prints have sold out. New York, California and other states have statutes defining a “limited edition” and restricting what a photographer can do to capitalize on a single image. Philadelphia-based photography dealer Alex Novak, for one, minces no words. “Whether it’s illegal or not, it’s unethical” to issue new editions that previous buyers had no warning might be created, he says. “It hurts the people you’ve sold to previously.” And photographers hurt themselves by diluting the market value of their work and their name.

Managing Your Inventory of Limited-Edition Prints
By limiting editions, artists also limit the inventory they can sell. When the last print in an edition sells, “You can’t just print one for posterity,” says private dealer Lee Marks of Lee Marks Fine Art. Whether to sell or to save for the future—when you may need equity, or give it to an institution or heir—is a highly personal decision each photographer PDN interviewed considered differently, depending on their career, their prospects and their view of their legacy.
Managing your inventory also depends on accurate record-keeping. That's particularly important for dealers who use stepped pricing: In an edition of ten, for example, prints 1 through 3 sell for the lowest price and numbers 4 through 6 cost more, up through the last print. Keeping accurate records about how many prints they’ve sold, given away, or lent for an exhibition is essential for every photographer to prevent pricing mistakes—such as selling the fourth print at the third print’s price. “If someone calls and says, ‘I like this image. Where is it in the edition?’ we know,” says Michael Foley of Foley Gallery.

What to Expect from the Photographer/Gallery Relationship
Who pays for production, promotion, shipping? What exactly does “exclusivity” or “consignment” mean? “A written document is essential,” insists noted photography consultant Mary Virginia Swanson, author of “Finding Your Audience: A Guide to Marketing Your Photographs.” “Many galleries don’t use one, so artists need to sit down with a dealer if they don’t provide a contract to discuss what the expectations are.”
Dealers, photographers and gallery owners discuss some of the terms to be negotiated-- and explain where misunderstandings commonly occur.

What Collectors Want
PDN interviewed five veteran photo collectors to tell us about the print they bought most recently, and where they look for new work. We also asked them how much they are influenced by edition size, print size, price, or the reputation of the artist or the artist's gallery. Their opinions on these criteria  were as individual as the collectors themselves.

How To Sell Your Work Direct to Collectors
Photographers who choose to sell prints on their own—without the help of gallery representation—can face some wariness from collectors. However, by prudently promoting their work to select collectors and institutions, building a network of supporters and being professional about their pricing and record-keeping, several artists PDN interviewed said they have been successful at marketing their prints privately. It occupies a lot of time, however, and balancing selling one’s work with creating new work can be very difficult. “There are times when I get completely frustrated that I haven’t made anything and I just get fed up with it,” says Lauren Henkin.
 
The Growing Market for Fine-Art Videos  
Technological developments are helping collectors get comfortable with the idea of purchasing video-based art. Buying video works no longer means committing to the installation of a bulky television or finding the space for a projector; video art and multimedia can now be displayed seamlessly on slim monitors hung cleanly on a wall. The photographers-turned-video artists PDN interviewed explain that collectors of video work now include individuals, as well as large institutions.

Representing video artists like Gregory Scott has “completely expanded our market,” says Catherine Edelman who owns a gallery known for selling photography. These collectors are primarily collectors of contemporary art. "There is something about video that is so accessible today," adds Edelman. "We're all looking for that person who gets our heart going, and [video] is the one avenue that I'm definitely seeking."

S[edition]: Selling Fine Art Photos for the Screen  
As flat-screen televisions become more affordable, a relatively new company, S[edition], foresees collectors exhibiting their art on multiple screens displayed like sculpture and paintings in their homes.  

S[edition] collectors, who range from traditional fine-art collectors to art lovers who cannot afford the original art they flock to see in galleries and museums, are actually buying access to a computer code and the right to stream the encoded digital information on as many screens as they like.

article.article_title: Reality Check: Randy Olson on The Glamour of Shooting for National Geographic
article.meta_description: It’s easy to fantasize about the globetrotting life of a National Geographic photographer. It’s a different matter to live it, explains National Geographic contributor Randy Olson, in this excerpt from Lessons in Great Photography by The Photo Society
article.meta_keywords: Randy Olson, National Geographic, career advice, Lessons in Great Photography, The Photo Society
article.article_text_abstract: It’s easy to fantasize about the globetrotting life of a National Geographic photographer. It’s a different matter to live it, explains long-time National Geographic contributor Randy Olson, in this excerpt from Lessons in Great Photography, published by The Photo Society.
article.article_image_caption: Bird hunters, Indus River, Pakistan.
article.article_text:
It’s easy to fantasize about the globetrotting life of a National Geographic photographer. It’s a different matter to live it, explains long-time National Geographic contributor Randy Olson, in this excerpt from Lessons in Great Photography (www.ThePhotoSociety.org/ebooks).

People have a fascination with travel and equate that with a glamorous lifestyle. Because National Geographic has been exploring the world for so long, our jobs are linked to that stereotype. When the former CEO of NG explains where he works and people say, “Oh are you a photographer?” And when he says he just runs the joint, they seem disappointed. Regardless of the stereotype, it is not glamorous.

Three months in Sudan with no facilities greater than a bug net in someone’s courtyard and bucket baths being the only relief from 120–130° heat is not my idea of fun.

But... just recently I’ve understood that this job is an escape from the relative wealth, apathy, and pursuit of consumer goods of our culture. I’ve had many fixers in many different cultures explain that we are so wealthy we don’t need each other anymore and that they still need each other to survive. I am lucky to be out in the world.

And there are moments I wouldn’t trade for anything. This job means you get on a plane, leave your comfy, little life. And when you land it always seems like the same third-world airport (in the dark) with the same fluorescent tubes at weird angles flickering on and off, ballasts almost dead, whining away into the night.

When you step off the plane something is going to hit you: extreme heat, extreme cold, a certain smell or set of smells that lets you know you aren’t home anymore. Then you remember that wheels on bags don’t really work in some places as you try to roll your bag over broken chunks of concrete and rebar. It takes a while to get your bearings, but you adjust because wherever you go in the world there are people around you doing extraordinary work that they think is perfectly normal.

Once you are inside an assignment, you adjust to whatever it is. It’s always the edges that are the most difficult. Trip logistics are usually difficult. I never know when I will encounter some Idi Amin-like character, screaming at me to put all 600 rolls of film (when I shot film) through some 1950s X-ray machine the size of a semi that looks like it was actually built for time travel or for Willy Wonka or something, and part of the machine is battered because when the belt stops moving they beat it with a stick to get it going.

Usually by the next morning you’re excited to be in a new place and ready to get to work. But this first morning in Sudan I was greeted with this editorial in the local paper:

Photography is Prohibited
Dear Sudanese tourist, our country and its unique exotic beauty may entice you; you may elatedly walk about the Nile Avenue, attracted by nature and its grace, which is evident on the riverbank. A sinful hand of yours may then reach for the camera to take a snap of the breathtaking scene, having the Nile as a magnificent background. You must realize then that you have violated an officially impermissible action, that you intentionally and openly subject your own self to criminal interrogation.

From the right angle, being paid to shoot pictures in 50 countries in 20+ years is the ultimate glamour job. But taking pictures for National Geographic is rarely glamorous. It is often awe-inspiring. It can be scary, life threatening, and, with many weeks spent on the road occasionally, lonely.

The truth is that mostly I wait. For flights, the right light, official okays, for helpers to find one instant that will make a worthy photograph. From weather to accommodations, food, drink, and travel, my assignment conditions can be miserable. In the Acacia forest, I worked amid sand fleas, carriers of flesh-eating parasites whose greater flaw was transferring an often-fatal disease.

On another assignment I accompanied a group of Russian explorers to the Siberian Arctic. To determine if nine people and many days’ worth of camping supplies were more than the helicopter could carry, the pilot hovered 5 feet above the ground. If we didn’t crash on the tarmac, we were good to fly.

From Lessons in Great Photography, published by The Photo Society, an independent non-profit organization of 135 photographers whose work has been published by National Geographic Magazine. (Instagram.com/thephotosociety or @ThePhotoSociety)

article.article_title: Nathan Thornburgh on What Makes His Online Magazine Roads & Kingdoms Unique
article.meta_description: Roads & Kingdoms—an independent online publication of travel culture, politics, food and music—publishes feature stories from around the world and regularly highlights photographers working on international projects.
article.article_text_abstract: Roads & Kingdoms—an independent online publication of travel culture, politics, food and music—publishes feature stories from around the world and regularly highlights photographers working on international projects.
article.article_image_caption: A Rohingya woman at a camp for Internally Displaced Persons in Sittwe, Myanmar, photographed by Andrew Stanbridge.
article.article_text:
Roads & Kingdoms, the independent online publication of travel, culture, politics, food and music, publishes feature stories from around the world and regularly highlights photographers working on international projects. Roads & Kingdoms was founded by Nathan Thornburgh, a former foreign correspondent and editor at TIME, and Matt Goulding, who worked as a food editor for Men’s Health, is the co-author of a travel book and has contributed to several publications. The two met in 2008 in Mexico City. Thornburgh was there doing follow-up reporting after having been arrested and briefly jailed in Cuba; Goulding was writing an article titled “There Are No Nachos in Mexico.” Over a meal of goat tacos, they discussed ideas for a publication that would combine their talents and interests. After Thornburgh left TIME in 2011, the publication he and Goulding had imagined took shape as Roads & Kingdoms.

Thornburgh recently spoke with PDN about the publication’s work with photographers, the kind of pitches that interest him, and the magazine’s approach to surviving financially while caring more about storytelling than clicks.    

PDN: What’s the editorial mission of Roads & Kingdoms?

NT: It’s foreign correspondence but with a big, healthy dose of food, music, culture and photography. We want to make it interesting and more about life and the experience, with less of the dryness that sometimes comes from dutiful foreign coverage. 

PDN: And you and your co-founder Matt Goulding run it?

NT: We are the editorial founders. Our third partner is our designer, Douglas Hughmanick. Instead of taking on a business partner we took on a designer, which has been a great decision. We would undoubtedly be further along in our business development if we had taken on a business partner, but I think it’s important to who we are as a publication that we try to make it look as beautiful as possible. 

In 2012 we had our soft launch on Tumblr, as Matt and I were testing out our voice. In 2013 we launched as a full magazine online. Since then, Medium and other long-form treatments have come along with a similar look, which is phenomenal; 2014 was a very good year for being pretty on the Internet. 

PDN: The pages have no sidebars, no links to related headlines. How does the design support your editorial mission?

NT: I think it’s important to have no distractions. We have great photographers who contribute, and you can do important work by making sure their work is front and center. You send a message to the reader that you care about these things.

PDN: Do your photographers also write?

NT: We are pretty loose when it comes to saying, “This is a photo essay” or “This is a story with photography.” For example, Cengiz Yar is a photographer who was in the Kurdish region of Syria. He wrote, I thought, a pretty brilliant 2,000-word piece. I’ve found photographers to be a little rawer, way more passionate, but willing to state an opinion and say to hell with what everyone else thinks. That’s a voice I’m attracted to, and for Roads & Kingdoms, it works very well. 

PDN: Roads & Kingdoms isn’t a typical travel magazine. 

NT: For me, travel is never the story; it’s what happens when you’re going after the story. It’s not the end; it’s the means. When we work with photographers and writers, we say: It’s not just that you’re in Sri Lanka. Tell us a story we haven’t heard before, and if you can explain Sri Lanka to us that way, that’s great. 

I’m definitely not interested in travel for travel’s sake, and I’m not interested in news for news’ sake. When we wanted to talk about the security situation in Mogadishu a couple of years ago, we asked correspondents who were there to tell us about getting ice cream with the defense minister. There had been all these stories about Mogadishu getting back to normal, but of course [getting ice cream] took a convoy of four armed cars. That, to me, is how to tell a story like that, not with a fill-in-the-quote from a talking head. 

PDN: How do you find correspondents and stories?

NT: When I was at TIME, I saw a lot of foreign bureaus shutting down, but not everyone went home. People are out there. Frankly, given our rates, we can’t pay for travel. Because of our fledgling business model, we pay everyone, but not enough to make a living. Correspondents have a story in their notebooks, or they’re working off a grant. I also really like it when we get local voices into Roads & Kingdoms as well. It’s amazing to see the level of reporting and photography that’s out there. 

PDN: So most of the photographers and writers you’ve worked with seek you out? 

NT: It’s rare these days to get edited. There’s such a crunch, and online editors don’t have time to spend making a story better. We’ve been approached by people who say, “Hey, I hear you guys edit.” If you’re a photographer trying to figure out the best way to show a subject, it can be great to have [an editor] to talk with. That’s why it can be great [for photographers] to have [director of photography] Pauline Eiferman helping them work through those things. 

PDN: Can you give an example of a successful pitch?

NT: One photographer I have loved working with is Eduardo Leal, a young Portuguese photographer who’s very enterprising. When he was in Venezuela [in 2013], we talked about the country’s politics, and he said, “You wouldn’t believe the [Hugo] Chávez gear that people are rocking. People have got Hugo Chávez on their sunglasses.” We said yes, that’s how you cover politics, with a burst of color and energy. The story was called “Chávez Chic.”

At TIME I got to work with some incredible photographers. It’s a privilege to work with someone like Yuri Kozyrev. [For Roads & Kingdoms] he and I traveled in Abkhazia, where there had been a resort area under the Soviet Union that got blown up about 20 years ago. He had the idea to show this apocalyptic landscape that was still a functioning resort. It was a great mix of a bizarre post-conflict world and a beach vacation experience. 

Amanda Mustard is great. We ran her piece on the pigeon coops of Cairo and she did a piece about the Umbrella Revolution in Hong Kong by embedding with protesters. We were lucky to publish it. 

Andrew Stanbridge is a favorite. He was our first photographer on our Instagram feed. While he was in northern Burma, he shot a story about a drinking god that was great, and he did a story from São Tomé and Príncipe that was pegged to Martyr’s Day but was also exploring the idea of post-colonial African governances.

The single best photography piece I’ve ever done…was when photographer Michael Magers and I went to report on the legendary [photographer] David Burnett’s return to find the subject of his famous 1973 Chilean coup picture.    

PDN: What makes a good pitch?

NT: I want a very specific, narrow window into a larger problem. The smaller your focus is, the bigger the story you can tell. 

We did a story about preachers of the prosperity gospel in Lagos. The number of people who do motivational speaking has just exploded. People in Lagos have envisioned a wealthier self and say God helped them get rich. It’s a great way of talking about Nigeria. 

PDN: Why doesn’t Roads & Kingdoms have any advertising?

NT: We don’t want to sell Google ads. We were lucky that when we started, display advertising rates were already in the tank. That made it an easy decision to choose design over serving ads. 

PDN: How do you pay your bills?

NT: We have a studio model. We act as a creative agency for brands. We don’t have giant name recognition but we’re catching on. We can choose brands we like, and go out and do storytelling for them. Brands involved in food, travel, and cars have big audiences they need to feed content to. You can call it “branded content.” We’re taking what we do and producing it for them. Video is a huge part of that, because they’re interested in making the best video products that they can and they need help. We did a video series with Breville and director Kate Kunath that we’re really proud of.

PDN: You also have content that appears on Slate. 

NT: That’s an editorial partnership. We curate and edit the Friday dispatches for them. It’s great for them because it bolsters their international coverage and for us it’s great to have a distribution partner who is more established but sees the value in what we do. 

We did a partnership with Sports Illustrated leading up to the World Cup in Rio. I loved the stories we did around the world. I like using football as a way to talk about the world. 

PDN: And you’re surviving? 

NT: I’m the publisher as well as an editor, and I’m learning a lot about the business. 

I want to build a publication that will sustain writers and photographers. I’m suspicious of the wave of tech money being invested in media. It gets you to scale really fast, but there are certain protocols you have to follow. We publish one story a day, and that’s antagonistic to the way you get to scale. Raising money from Silicon Valley investors is contingent on having an exit strategy: The idea is that you make your money and we’re all laughing on our boats in a few years. [But] we have no plan B. We purposely built a publication that we really like. I’m doing what I want to do. 

I think the world is an amazing place. I’m interested in telling stories about the things that make the world better. We want to tell the story about people enjoying food and music. That’s the deeper moral for me.

article.article_title: How Photographers Meet The Demands of the Travel Editorial Market
article.meta_description: PDN talks with editors about the nuances of today's travel editorial market, in which "experiential" imagery—featuring more personal, authentic travel stories—is en vogue.
article.article_text_abstract: PDN talks with editors about the nuances of today's travel editorial market, in which "experiential" imagery—featuring more personal, authentic travel stories—is en vogue.
article.article_image_caption: Layouts from “The French Connection,” a travel story about Montreal photographed by Alexi Hobbs for AFAR magazine.
article.article_text:
Travel photography has always been about capturing the beauty and uniqueness of a locale. But there’s a new word in town: “experiential.” In tune with our social media-driven times, travel publications are looking for more personal, authentic travel stories. The emphasis is on down-to-earth reality, with stories containing environmental portraits of locals and funky close-up details alongside more typical landscapes and streetscapes. 

“A lot of travel photography is well-conceived and lit, but there’s nothing insightful about it,” says Leila Courey, photo editor of Air Canada’s award-winning En Route magazine. “I like it when photographers are more voyeuristic, reacting to moments that are honest and genuine.” Tara Guertin, photo editor at AFAR, a San Francisco-based travel magazine that launched in 2009, agrees, saying, “There should be a freshness there.”

Although they might have a looser and more authentic feel, the stories are still carefully planned and executed. After all, it requires good preparation, technique and interpersonal skills to capture life on the fly—or, as composer Stephen Sondheim once said, “To make art look effortless takes a lot of effort.” So how are photographers delivering the images that satisfy today’s travel editorial market?

FIRST STEPS

Guertin and Courey both say they prefer to have a story written first, if possible, but there are times when a photographer and writer might travel together. For example, Montreal-based photographer Alexi Hobbs was hired by AFAR in 2011 to document travel writer Matt Gross’s reunion in Montreal with his estranged younger brother. “That’s hard, because the story is unfurling as you go and could be anything,” says Hobbs. “But it’s also fun because you get to discuss things with the writer.” 

If the written story precedes the photography, the photo editor will typically give the photographer a shot list of places mentioned in the article, but also ask them to shoot around it. “I tell every photographer that I’m hiring them for their eye,” Courey says. “They’re the ones on the ground; they’re the ones who are going to find something interesting. If they’re sitting having coffee and the place looks great, shoot it—it will add to the story.”

Hobbs remembers departing from a shot list on an assignment for En Route about modernist architecture in Phoenix, Arizona. One day, he went for a walk in the desert and, coming across some cactus plants lit gold by the setting sun, shot them. “There’s just something about that image—the light and mood encapsulates the feeling of being there,” he says. Sure enough, the image was featured prominently in the article. 

“Having the photographs match directly with the text doesn’t interest me,” says Courey, “but there’s usually something about the tone of a piece that a photographer can hone in on.”

“When I’m on location, I always re-read the story and refer to it,” says Los Angeles-based photographer Amanda Marsalis. However, she says, many travel stories these days are “intimate, first-person journey stories” that can’t be directly illustrated. That was the case for a story she shot in spring 2014 in Merida, Mexico, for Condé Nast Traveller (UK). “There wasn’t really a shot list with that story, they just wanted me to capture the essence of the place, which was terrific.”

Some photographers pitch stories too—but that usually doesn’t work, say the editors. Guertin estimates that writers pitch 80 percent of the stories in AFAR, while editors generate most of the remainder. Timing is a factor: A photographer might pitch a story about a place she’s visiting next month, but since travel magazines work about six months ahead, the seasonality won’t line up. But Courey says it’s not impossible. “Occasionally there’s a hole in the book, and we’re looking to fill it. A photographer’s pitch might work then.”

Along with their regular contributors, the editors look for newcomers: “I love working with young people getting started, because I think they give 150 percent,” Guertin says. She advises aspiring travel photographers to put a relevant image prominently in their emails to her. “Make the email short and sweet, and have an image up front. If it makes my heart palpitate, you’ll be bookmarked immediately.”

HITTING THE GROUND

Photographers who do their research get high marks. “It’s in your interest to do as much research as possible: the story will be better if you go to a place informed,” says Courey. Hobbs, who now shoots regularly for AFAR and En Route, says he always looks up a country’s history and culture, and looks at maps. “But I prefer not to look at photographs, so that I can arrive with fresh eyes,” he says

Hobbs, who typically travels alone, will go out walking soon after arriving at a destination. “If it’s a town or city, I try to hike up to a high spot to find a wider view—not just for a photograph, but to get my bearings and get to know the place,” he says. “It gives you a sense of where you are, where the sun rises and sets, what the sounds and smells are.” He also advises eating at the bar at local restaurants. “You’ll meet locals who’ll give you great tips,” he says.

Marsalis, who has shot travel stories for GQ, Outside and Islands, says she tries to absorb as much local culture as possible. “It’s about figuring out the essence of a place, conveying what it feels like to be enveloped in that place,” she says. When shooting her 2014 story on Mérida for Condé Nast Traveller (UK), for example, she went to a Mezcal bar to hang out with locals, and returned with an intriguing, moody portrait of a local woman. 

Of course, travel assignments can be unpredictable: The average trip lasts three to six days, involves multiple locations, and can be challenged by weather. Photographers PDN interviewed advised not burdening yourself with complicated gear (though Hobbs recommends taking three cameras—he once had two fail on a trip) and above all, anticipating worst-case scenarios. “If you get bad weather, you might need to spend a day shooting interiors, or wait until dusk, when the clouds can be pretty,” Marsalis says. 

Hobbs remembers getting to Martinique in 2013, finding it not as photogenic as he’d imagined, and having to think outside the box. “If you walk around and keep looking, you can always find something,” he says. On one walk, he came across a man weaving a hat from palm fronds. “He was standing in an oasis of light, by the water—I stayed there for 40 minutes, until the sun set, then we went to grab a drink together.”

Both Hobbs and Marsalis say they often stay on after an assignment, to unwind and photograph for the client under less pressure. “I’ll often stay a couple more days on my own dime—usually, hotels will give you the same discount they gave the magazine,” Marsalis says. Hobbs, who has also lengthened trips, points out that the most charming shots often happen when you’re not actively searching for them. “It’s like when you’re single and really want a girlfriend or boyfriend and nothing happens—then as soon as you stop looking, one comes along!”

KEEPING THE EDIT IN MIND

Guertin and Courey say they don’t micro-manage a shoot, preferring to trust the photographer’s instincts and “not poke in,” as Guertin puts it. Sometimes, though, guidance can be helpful. When assigning Marsalis to shoot features on Los Angeles and Brooklyn, GQ photo editor Justin O’Neill says, “I requested that she edit as she went along, for the sake of maintaining cohesion.” He advises photographers to “keep in mind images and moments that have potential as ‘opener’ art [principal art featured on the title page of a story].” 

“The imagery on the opening spread tends to be clean and graphic,” says Guertin. “After that, I want to see faces and details.” For Courey, it’s important to “story-tell in a way that has a human quality, that’s palatable and relatable.” 

In the Internet age, that immediacy is important: travel magazines are competing with social media and sites like Airbnb. To deliver that immediacy, photographers should have an eye for the quirky environmental detail (“Let the design of the destination speak for itself,” says Courey), and a comfort level with approaching locals. “I can be shy about approaching people when I’m home, but I find it easy in other places,” says Hobbs. 

Marsalis, who grew up flying the globe as the daughter of a pilot and a flight attendant, certainly believes in the power of the travel image. “Wherever I go, I try to keep the wanderer vibe alive,” she says. “If someone sees your story and decides to spend their money going to that place—and then if they get the experience they’re looking for, you’ve done your job.”

article.article_title: Eater.com Finds Unique Ways To Tell Food Stories With Photography
article.article_text_abstract: Since Eater's site was re-launched in September 2014, features editor Helen Rosner has been commissioning features and original photography, producing image-heavy longform stories.
article.article_image_caption: Melanie Dunea's photo of an Italian truffle hunter from Eater.com's feature “Off the Map with Italy’s Best Truffle Hunter” (December 2014).
article.article_text:
Helen Rosner is the features editor at Eater.com, a food-centric website under the Vox Media umbrella. Since Eater’s site was re-launched in September 2014, she’s been commissioning features and original photography, producing image-heavy, longform stories and expanding the site’s coverage beyond day-to-day restaurant news, gossip and blogging.

PDN sat down with Rosner at Vox’s Manhattan headquarters to talk about what she looks for when choosing new photographers, the kinds of stories she likes getting pitched and the cliches she tries to avoid when assigning feature stories.


PDN: What’s unique about the Eater’s features section?

HR: Features at Eater—at least in the format that I oversee—have existed since the site re-launched at the end of September. The redesign went hand-in-hand with a port onto Vox Media’s proprietary content management system, which we call a “modern media stack,” called Chorus. Chorus has incredible tools for building these beautiful, rich, multi-faceted features. It’s a really phenomenal, content-forward way of approaching story building. It relies on a lot of visual and design elements to keep you happy staring at a screen for a really long time, to get you through what’s often a 5,000-word story. So the photography becomes a really big part of it.

PDN: What’s one of your success stories?

HR: Visually speaking, [“A Wild Goose Chase,” by Wyatt Williams] has been one of our most successful stories. The writer pitched it; he had worked with the photographer, Andrew Thomas Lee, before.

For quick reporting trips, I don’t always feel like it’s necessary for the writer and photographer to be there at the same time. But for something like this—which was such an intimate story [about a chicken farmer producing “ethical” foie gras]—Andy was clearly the right choice from the beginning. He’s a really experienced food photographer, but he also has a tremendous understanding of how to shoot in the field, and how to go on location and create something that feels very formal in a very natural space. For a story like this one that was about blood and guts, I really liked the idea of imposing Andy’s sense of visual formalism onto something that has a lot of built-in dynamism and grotesquery. 

PDN: How do you find photographers for remote locales?

HR: If you go into Photoshelter and you do an advanced search, you can do it by city, state, and country. “Ghosts in the Ham House” is a profile of a woman who runs a country ham facility in Western Kentucky. And it was written by a Chicago-based writer, who was driving down from Chicago to report the story over the course of a couple of days. From a purely budgetary perspective, this isn’t something that required a three-day photo shoot. So I decided to see who I could find who was within 150 miles.

Through that, I found Rick Smith. I went through his portfolio and he had this incredible style that I thought was really interesting. We’re shooting a massive country ham curing facility, there’s a tremendous amount of inherent visual regularity to the way this works. The curing houses are just giant wooden structures with thousands and thousands of hams stacked on them, so there’s a lot of pattern, there’s a lot of repetition, and I really wanted to find a photographer who could speak to that, and do something that would feel abstracted and geometric. I had total faith in him as a photographer, and what he wound up doing worked really beautifully for the story, which was actually much more of a texture story than a pattern story. I didn’t want your standard “here’s the shop, here’s the portrait.” I wanted something that felt a little bit exciting or different. 

PDN: What makes a successful pitch from a photographer?

HR: Melanie Dunea’s truffle-hunting story is a great example. Melanie is a very successful food and portrait photographer. We’ve known each other from the food world for a number of years, and she came to me with a pitch. She had shot this while she was on assignment for something else; this was a side trip for her. She went out with a truffle hunter and had this extraordinary experience, and got some really remarkable, very rarely seen, intimate access to the real world of truffle hunting. You know, your truffle is presented in a satin-lined box, it’s an incredible luxury, and she went out with this guy at five in the morning, in the dark, down this treacherous, weird, terrifying mountain valley, and it’s dirt and shit and gross and it was amazing. She pitched this to me as a complete package. All I had to do was negotiate the price and sit down with her to make selects. 

What I’m particularly looking for is a narrative. It’s really easy to fall back on the frequently visited trope of “one day in the life of X.” Chronology is not the same as narrative.

PDN: What kind of stories are you not looking for? 

HR: I get these day-in-the-life pitches, of a dishwasher, or a busboy. I think it’s really good to tell the stories of the people whose stories are not being told. We don’t need another set of photos following whatever celebrity chef who’s already being covered in 15 other magazines. But I also think that a dishwasher is not interesting just because he’s a dishwasher; I want there to be more than that. Why this guy, at this moment? I get a lot of pitches for travelogues, which are difficult for Eater, because we’re not a travel brand, we’re a food brand, and telling the story of travel through food is interesting, but it’s not a story. 

PDN: Any tips about pitching you stories if a photographer hasn’t worked with you before? 

HR: What’s much easier for me to take with a new photographer would be an ongoing project. I don’t want to tip my hand too much to upcoming stories, but I have a really great photographer I’m working with who I have not worked with before who’s following a group of people over a multi-month process. The story is less dependent upon these gasp-inducing, perfect, beautiful, formalist shots. And it has a built-in chronology.

PDN: Do writer/photographer teams often pitch you? Do you prefer to be pitched by a team?

HR: I’ve had writers and photographers who have pitched me as a team before where I’ve had to do this very delicate work of saying, “I really like this story but I think I want to take it in a different visual direction…. Are you guys willing to break up?”

When it comes to a story that the photography has to occur at the same time as the reporting, or the credentialing is just a giant pain in the ass, it can be very, very helpful for a writer to have a photographer lined up. And when it is something about exclusive access or having to have a source’s trust, that’s often a “yes.”

PDN: How do you vet new photographers?

HR: It’s not like I run them through an algorithm. You look at the portfolio, but I’ve asked photographers before, “I totally love these three selects that you showed me from this one story that you shot, do you have the full film?” It’s helpful for me to understand how much is this a photographer who isn’t just great at Photoshop and benefitted from great photo editors at great publications, but is a photographer who does his research ahead of time, really thinks about the shots ahead of time. I try not to be too micro-managey, but I also don’t want to be surprised when I see the film, and I don’t want the photographer to be surprised when they get my reaction to it. 

PDN: What does it take to fly someone to a location, as opposed to hiring a local? Budget?

HR: I think it’s equal parts budget and style. I am a really big fan of using local photographers, not just because I save on travel costs, but because I think that frequently the same bylines show up again and again and again. And I love that I’m in a position to use my platform and my budget to elevate people who might not have shown up on the radars of other New York-based people assigning photography. It’s just sort of the visual terroir. If I’m telling a story that takes place in Western Kentucky, why not use a photographer that already knows the landscape? Who has that sense of intimacy, and who isn’t going to fall back onto the visual tropes that you see when an outsider comes in and photographs a new place.

PDN: Any specific goal for your site?

HR: I just want really awesome photos. And I want to push the envelope a little bit. 

PDN: How do you do that?

HR: It depends a lot on the photographer. If there are photographers who are doing weird or cool or slightly skewed things, something different, I would love for them to come to me. I love this idea of helping amplify somebody who is getting started, or is late in their career but at the beginning of a new idea. We have a great platform. On Eater, we have 8 million readers a month, that’s a lot of eyeballs. We have amazing photographers on staff, who shoot the hamburger or shoot the restaurant interior. What I’m basically looking for is either photojournalism or art, or both.

article.article_title: PDN’s 30 Photographers On Building Support for Their Work
article.meta_description: PDN’s 30 photographers explain how they handled some of their biggest challenges in launching their professional photography careers, and share useful lessons they learned about confidence.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographers featured in PDN’s 30 discuss the biggest challenge facing a photographer at any stage: sharing work and building support for projects.
article.article_image_caption: Schoolgirls look out to sea in Galle Port, Sri Lanka, an image Malin Fezehai took in 2007, before she took a break from photography.
article.article_text:
When the emerging photographers selected for this year’s PDN’s 30 described the steps they took to launch their careers, many talked about the challenge of taking the first, crucial stride: They had to learn to believe in themselves before they could seek support from clients or mentors.

“The only advice I really remember getting was from my uncle when I was quite young and started photographing. He gave me my first camera and told me plainly, ‘Do you want to be a photographer? Then you have to just keep making pictures,’” Antoine Bruy recalls. “Perhaps simple, but it is something that I have always remembered.”

Here, some of the PDN’s 30 photographers profiled in PDN’s April issue share other valuable lessons they learned—from colleagues, clients, friends or from their own experimentation—that helped them find their photographic voices and build support for their work.  

Seeking Advice – And Deciding What’s Worth Following
Many of the PDN’s 30 photographers have learned from peers, teachers, portfolio reviewers and advisors. “Having people critique your work over and over is one of the best things you can do for yourself as an artist,” says Pascal Shirley. “I feel a lot of people don’t ever get much critique and a lot of people are scared to give it. Having a place for this kind of dialogue is crucial in developing your photographic vocabulary.”

Paul Colangelo, who spends months working on projects, says his mentors have been invaluable not only for the advice they shared but the reassurance they offered about the difficulties photographers inevitably face. “One of the greatest challenges was working in the field on a long-term project when no one knows or cares that you’re there, you have no sponsors, no assignment. All you have is your belief in the story. No matter how strong that belief is, after living on a mountain for two months by yourself, you end up desperate for some support to go along with that belief. I have a mental list of photographers’ most desperate moments to keep me warm and reassured: Crying in a McDonald’s parking lot, your dream editor saying you’ll never make it as a photographer.” He explains, “These have happened to some of the best photographers of our time, and I’m grateful to know these stories.”

Sara Naomi Lewkowicz, who says she's benefitted from the advice Donna Ferrato and other established photographers, notes, “It can be really hard to see people who have achieved so much in their careers and think, ‘How am I going to get there?’ You don’t. They’re at the top of the mountain. What you really need to do is to look 10 feet away, and get there in a few steps and then a couple more steps. You figure out your own path.”

Amanda Mustard says that when she began to work as a photojournalist, she learned a lot from the guidance of more experienced photographers, and some helped her build connections; she tries to pay the favor forward.  “I got some of my first gigs because of contact or job referrals by generous, more established journalists, and I was incredibly grateful for that. In turn, I’ve always been open to my close colleagues and willing to share what I can, when I can. Freelancing is a constant hustle, and it takes the edge off if you’re looking out for each other’s backs.”  

About Hustling Your Work
Malin Fezehai observes that seeking assignments takes gumption. “What you should be asking yourself is if you should be doing this, and if you should, then you should be doing it,” she says. After shooting photos for NGOs, traveling, and working in a lab, Fezehai took two years off from photography.

“Then just something snapped in me that said: ‘You know, you have to go out and ask people for work.’ Before that, I was holding myself back. I think some women do this thing of, ‘Here are my pictures and I’m sorry I’m alive,’ while some of my male colleagues are like, ‘I’m a fantastic photographer. Look at me.’ Learning from them a bit was helpful. I think the main thing is to own what you do. People talk about entitlement as if it’s a bad thing, but I think it’s something everyone should have.”

Mustard observes, “I’ve always believed that if you’re hitting the pavement and pushing forward hard, something will come of it. And when the inevitable kick-to-the-groin will and does happen, whether it be a harsh review or assignment gone wrong, always be ready to pull something constructive out of it and move forward.”

In February 2013, the long-term project Lewkowicz had shot while at Ohio University, on a couple named Maggie and Shane, was published on TIME Lightbox, under the headline, “Photographer as Witness: A Portrait of Domestic Violence.” The project later won Lewkowicz the 2013 Ville de Perpignan Remi Ochlik Award, but the post on Lightbox put her in the center of controversy about her role in witnessing, rather than intervening in, an incident of domestic abuse. The lesson Lewkowicz learned: “Never read the comments. Ignore the comments. When you make work and put it out there, you lose a degree of control, and control over how it’s perceived. It’s frustrating because your work is so personal to you.”

Finding an Audience
Fezehai, who shares selected images from her projects and assignments both on her own Instagram feed and on Everyday Everywhere says, “Because the nature of distribution is changing all the time, it’s making people scared but it’s also liberating, I think. Think about other ways of sharing your work. Because the old gatekeepers are not there, it’s a more democratic market now. If you’re able to do a really great project, you have certain outlets you can access.”

"Over time I’ve realized, through critique, that those images I used to take 'for myself' can speak the loudest, moments that are a very personal interpretation of what is happening, and I’ve been working to hone in on that,” says Mustard, who started out shooting news stories while living in Cairo, and has moved into shooting features and long-term projects. “This is something I’m still very much figuring out, but when the work I do is more personal and something I greatly care about, it’s very clear that those pieces translate best to an audience.”

article.article_title: The 2015 PDN's 30 Share Advice From Their Mentors
article.meta_description: This year's PDN's 30 photographers share the valuable feedback and advice that helped them the most when they were starting out.
article.article_text_abstract: This year's PDN's 30 photographers share the valuable feedback and advice that helped them the most when they were starting out.
article.article_text:
Every PDN’s 30 photographer has had to find their own path into the professional photography business, but along the way, they were lucky to find experienced colleagues who gave them words of encouragement, useful insights and, when needed, honest critiques that kept them pushing forward. A common theme in the PDN’s 30 profiles is how much the photographers benefitted from advisors who were both caring and candid. 

We asked PDN’s 30 photographers to tell us about the feedback and advice that helped them the most when they were starting out. 

Peter Bohler 

Greg Miller “said that photography has an emotional side and a technical side. People have strengths in one area or the other, but it really needs to be a balance. You need to work toward cultivating both.”

Clarissa Bonet

“I was really nervous that life was going to take over and my work was going to fall by the wayside. I’ve seen it happen to so many photographers…. They get out of school and don’t do anything, because everyone needs to make money right out of school.... One thing [Columbia College faculty member] Ross Sawyers said was that you need to make your artistic practice your second job… and dedicate at least 20 hours a week to your practice. Grant writing, website updates, promotional stuff, research, writing—all of that stuff falls under the umbrella of your artistic practice.”

Paul Colangelo 

“Frans Lanting advised me to work on one story I’m passionate about, and continue working it for years, from every angle, until I’m an expert on the subject, until I have something to say about it. And when I think I’ve finished, start working on it again.”

Anna Beeke 

Elinor Carucci “was very critical and intelligent and always had handy references of work to look at, but she was also very motherly and we just had a great [relationship]. She would tell you if you sucked, or an image sucked.” 

Alejandro Cegarra

“[A]t Últimas Noticias, a local newspaper, I learned a lot from Iván Gonzalez and Joaquin Ferrer. They taught me to see beyond the news and to always try to find a new perspective.”

Michael Clinard

“I recall Alex Hayden delivering sermon-like lectures on the benefits of marketing oneself early.” 

McNair Evans

“In the Bay Area, a local critique group known as Library Candy fosters engaging dialogue concerning each member’s projects and trends in the medium. I’ve grown tremendously through discussing work with these more experienced photographers: Lucas Foglia, Jason Fulford, Eric Carroll, Nigel Poor, Chris McCaw, Meghann Riepenhoff, and Richard Misrach…. Of them all, Richard Misrach has set a beautiful standard of generosity and engagement, including my work in lectures, introducing me to potential book publishers, and overall demonstrating a genuine interest in my work and success as an artist.”

Sara Naomi Lewkowicz

James Estrin, of The New York Times Lens Blog, “always says to me: It’s a marathon not a foot race. You have to find a pace that will sustain you or you’ll burn out.”

Benjamin Mcmahon

“I remember [Julian Broad] saying, ‘Never worry about chasing a particular job. Don’t start changing your style.… Just get on with what you want to do and make the pictures you want to make, and the right people will come to you.’”

Annalisa Natali Murri 

About her partner, photographer Edoardo Agresti, photographer Giancarlo Ceraudo and photo editor Diego Orlando, she says: “They pushed me, and encouraged me, calling me: ‘What are you doing? Go take your camera and go take pictures.’ 

Amanda Mustard

“David Degner, a photographer based in Cairo before me, was a great mentor to me while I was trying to get my footing both in Egypt and the industry…. His work is meaningful and honest, and his humility and ethics as a photographer are qualities I always greatly respect and take to heart.”

Erin O’Keefe

“Wendy Richmond, who was an instructor for a course I took at ICP, told me to make the work that only I could make.”

Yeong-Ung Yang 

“I’ve worked in [Paula Allen’s] studio managing her archives and retouching. She has been documenting the whole world and has been going back to her subjects for decades. Her commitment and her enormous warm heart has inspired me to pursue long-term projects.”

Related: PDN'S 30 2015

article.article_title: Why a Confrontation Between Photographers and Locals Turned Ugly in Appalachia
article.article_text_abstract: When citizens in Appalachia confronted out-of-town photographers taking photos without permission, the encounter threatened to turn violent. Photographer and West Virginia native Roger May talks to people involved, and looks at the difficult relationship between photographers and an often stereotyped community.
article.article_image_caption: A photograph of a road sign in McDowell County, West Virginia, by local photographer Alan Johnston. Johnston says he was once confronted by local resident while making landscape pictures, and that a lot of people in McDowell County are "skeptical of anyone doing anything around here."
article.article_text:
On Monday, March 23, in McDowell County, West Virginia, photographer Marisha Camp and her brother Jesse found themselves confronted by an angry and hostile group of folks, who accused them of taking photographs of children without permission. The Camps, who were on the road gathering material for a television show they hope to pitch later this year, were detained and threatened with physical violence by these local citizens. After a 45-minute confrontation, the Camps were escorted out of the county by the West Virginia state police.

The story was picked up by local news stations and by national photography magazines and blogs. As is usual when Appalachia is the subject, the story was told primarily by and about one group—outsiders visiting the area. That’s not to say the Camps’s accounts of what happened aren’t valid, but they’ve been given a platform not afforded many of the others involved. The locals have been portrayed as vigilantes, as mob- or gang-like. One national photography magazine titled their story, “West Virginia Mob Reportedly Detains Photographers for Looking Out-of-Town.” Let’s be clear: the Camps weren’t detained for looking “out-of-town.” They were detained, illegally this West Virginian and photographer believes, because parents thought they'd photographed their children without their permission.

Knowing that I am from West Virginia and that I have a professional and personal interest in work being made in and about Appalachia, a friend posted the news story on my Facebook wall. Several other people contacted me to ask what I thought about the situation. After watching the local news story, I knew there was much more to the story. I knew there would be fallout, and feared that locals would bear the brunt of it.

Searching for a greater understanding of the incident and the actions that caused it, I began reaching out to those directly involved. I contacted Marisha Camp on Thursday, March 26, and over the next few days I exchanged calls and dozens of text messages with her and her brother. On April 2, I spoke with Jennifer Adkins, the woman who accused the Camps of photographing her children and threatened them with a gun.

I also contacted journalists and filmmakers who have worked in Appalachia, and a local photographer, to gain as much perspective as possible about what happened that day. I asked them to comment on the situation in McDowell County because none of the reporting thus far attempts to look at the long history of misrepresentation in Appalachia. Sure, this could’ve happened anywhere. But it didn’t. It happened in McDowell County, West Virginia. And although the Camps may not have been intentionally seeking out “poverty porn,” many local residents view photographers, both insiders and outsiders, with understandable suspicion.

“You don’t look like upstanding citizens.”

The Camps had been on the road for months, working their way across the country filming and making photographs. On Sunday, March 22, they filmed a church service in McDowell County. The following day, they decided to collect B-roll footage. “We noticed these three obese kids playing with sticks in [a] driveway,” Jesse Camp recalls. “When we drove by I asked them if they were having a stick fight. They sort of laughed and that was that. We drove on.” On their way from Jolo to Raysal, the Camps parked their Volvo station wagon with Massachusetts license plates at a gas station and crossed the road to photograph some houses and talk with some folks. Soon thereafter, Marisha Camp heard someone yelling across the road and noticed a van blocking in their vehicle. The van’s owner, Jennifer Adkins, was upset because she thought the Camps were photographing her children without her consent, and she demanded the pair hand their cameras over. The situation escalated quickly.

According to Marisha Camp, Adkins immediately threatened them. She opened the door of her van and pointed to what she said was a gun, stating that the Camps weren’t leaving until they handed over their cameras and the police arrived. Afraid and panicking, Camp tried to call for help, but had no cell service. Camp was able to record audio of the incident on her phone. “Have you all looked at yourselves in the mirror? You don’t look like upstanding citizens,” Adkins can be heard saying on the recording. For nearly 45 minutes, the situation intensified. An angry crowd grew around the Camps, despite Marisha Camp showing Adkins’s husband the images on one of their cameras in an attempt to prove that none of the images were of their children.

Local parents were already on edge due to the disappearance of a young child in the area: The same day the Camps were filming the church service in Jolo, less than a hundred miles away in Pulaski County, Virginia, five year-old Noah Thomas went missing. The sheriff’s department received more than a hundred tips, many of which identified suspicious vehicles in the area. (Sadly, Thomas’s body was found on his parents’ property in a septic tank Thursday, March 26, five days after he was reported missing. His parents have been charged with felony abuse and neglect.)

Finally, West Virginia state police arrived on the scene. After assessing the situation, they escorted the Camps out of the area and lectured them about how they “ought to be careful about not making ugly pictures about the people of West Virginia,” Marisha Camp says. Later that day, she contacted the McDowell County sheriff’s department and was told by a deputy, “You’re lucky you weren’t shot.”

“We love West Virginia.”

“I’m a gypsy, self-admittedly,” Jesse Camp told me on the phone on March 31. “I love traveling every nook and cranny of America. My sister and I have been road tripping forever, man. We’ve been everywhere, all over the South, and 99 percent of the people we meet are cool.”

Jesse Camp says he and his sister had been all over West Virginia. “Logan, Omar, Iaeger, War, Jolo and Bradshaw. You know man, West Virginia is like the most outlaw place. We love West Virginia.”

Marisha Camp echoes her brother, and she’s been actively responding via Facebook to inaccurate claims from McDowell County residents about the incident. “We really love West Virginia, and it was utterly heartbreaking to think about not going back,” she says. “I know not everyone [there] is like that.”

Also upset by the behavior of the police, Marisha Camp wrote a letter to West Virginia Attorney General Patrick Morrisey, detailing the events. In the letter she writes that she “strongly believes” in combatting “negative stereotypes of the region,” but calls the actions of the police “absurd and about as counterproductive as it gets.”

“It is for everyone's benefit that incidents like this are taken seriously,” she writes. “I would have been encouraged to press charges anywhere else rather than be run of town like a ‘long haired hippie’ and then told by law enforcement that I'm somehow lucky because I wasn't murdered.”

Despite all this, the Camps say they’ve received overwhelming support from residents of McDowell County. Many have contacted the Camps via Facebook apologizing for the actions of a few people and offering them places to stay if they make it back.

“We had no choice but to question their motives.”

Jennifer Adkins was on the phone with a neighbor when her 13-year-old son walked in the front door and told her, “there was a guy out there taking pictures.”

Adkins hung up the phone and immediately called 911 to report the incident. She, her husband and their two sons got in their minivan and drove after the Camps in order to get a license plate number. (As a parent, I understand the fear and concern Adkins must have felt for her children in the moment, especially considering the missing child in the news.) Once they found the Camps's vehicle at a gas station in English, they called 911 again to report the tag information.

“I was floored by their appearance. They looked like bums. I don’t mean that to sound derogatory, but they did,” Adkins told me. “I saw [Marisha Camp] put one of her cameras away and then she started showing my husband pictures from the other one.”

Both Jesse and Marisha Camp deny making photographs of the Adkins’s children. But the family didn’t know what the Camps were up to because they never came to their door to ask if it was OK to talk to their children or photograph them. Therein lies the problem for me, and for Adkins. “I can understand them [the Camps] being scared, but we had no choice but to question their motives,” Adkins says. “I wouldn’t have ever given them permission to take pictures of my kids, let alone talk to them, but they never gave me the chance.”

Adkins admits she threatened the Camps. “I mean, I said I had a gun, but I didn’t. I wanted them to know I meant business and that they weren’t leaving until the police showed up. I told [Marisha Camp] that she could leave by ambulance or by a police car, but she wasn’t going nowhere until I saw that she didn’t have pictures of my boys,” Adkins recalls. Soon thereafter, Adkins says, residents she didn’t even know began to gather around. She says the other residents, who must’ve felt they were looking out for their own, "sort of took over."

I asked Adkins about judging the Camps by how they looked when for so long West Virginia has been the butt of so many jokes about appearance. I had a really hard time with this one. “I know,” Adkins says, “but if I go to New York City, I’m going to stand out and possibly be stereotyped. Anybody who knows me knows that I’m outspoken. We [West Virginians] always get portrayed bad. And we didn’t know what they were up to.”

A few days after the confrontation, Adkins was interviewed by WVVA, the local news station, after they saw her Facebook posts about the incident. Adkins has taken down most of the posts, but I had taken screenshots for my notes. In one post, she wrote, “They are from Mass. and said they were doing a ‘documentary’…. All I can say is they best NOT COME BACK TO RAYSAL!!!!!” Someone commenting on Adkins’s Facebook page posted the Camps’s license plate number, and several commenters also included pictures of the Camps’s vehicle.

“We don’t get to choose who makes work in Appalachia.”

Elaine McMillion Sheldon, a native West Virginian, spent more than three years on and off working on Hollow, an interactive, community-driven documentary project about McDowell County’s past, present and future from the perspectives of local residents. When I reached out to her, she was beside herself about the incident and didn't understand why residents would react as they did. “What is the goal here? I think it's a question of how we want to be seen,” she says. “Do we want to be seen as a threat?”

Sheldon says residents she talked to in the County are divided about the incident. She was surprised that local photographers told her they don’t agree with the kind of work the Camps were making. Sheldon says: "We don’t get to choose who makes work in Appalachia. We can’t police who makes pictures here, but we should try to educate those who want to come in to document, and encourage a more nuanced story. We all need to stand together as artists, regardless of whether we like a specific artist’s work or not. You can't pick and choose whose rights you support based upon whether you like or dislike their work. All artists have the same legal rights, regardless of the art they create."

“The visual equivalent of hate speech.”

Kate Fowler has worked in West Virginia extensively and was recently hired by the Magnum Foundation in New York. Her film, Nitro, chronicles the complicated relationship between a small West Virginia town and the chemical plants that both provide jobs and impact the environment in West Virginia’s “Chemical Valley.” Fowler also spent a great deal of time in McDowell County working on her film With Signs Following, about the late Mack Wolford, a preacher and serpent-handler from southern West Virginia.

Fowler views the actions of the Camps and the reactions of the local citizens as part of a long, complicated history of photography in Appalachia.

Many in West Virginia, Fowler says, recognize that outsiders who’ve photographed their communities without consent have participated in the “dissemination of classist and bigoted rhetoric—the visual equivalent of hate speech.” Fowler also points out that when a small group of citizens decided to speak up for themselves, “the Internet...mobilized to discredit and to once again, deny the subject’s capacity for critical engagement.”

“No person deserves to be threatened with violence” or held against their will, Fowler adds. But, she says, “We [as photographers] must not presume that our intentions are clear, nor deny the trauma we may invoke through our actions, tools or intentions.”

“Am I supposed to go and knock on each and every door?”

Alan Johnston is a native and lifelong resident of McDowell County, West Virginia. He’s a musician and landscape photographer I met several years ago through Sheldon’s Hollow project. I reached out to him to get a local photographer’s perspective on what happened and he was kind enough to talk with me.

Johnston says he was “genuinely concerned” when he heard about the incident, especially when he considers what it might mean for his ability to work locally. “I really don’t understand what I’m supposed to do,” he says. “Do I tell somebody at the mouth of the holler that I’m taking pictures of barns and landscapes? How will the people in the head of the holler know what I’m doing? Am I supposed to go and knock on each and every door and report to people who I am and what I’m doing?” He notes that he rarely photographs people he doesn’t know, but rather photographs landscapes of McDowell County for his own pleasure.

Johnston recalled a time a few years back when he was out making pictures in the county and pulled off on the side of the road to photograph a horse in a barn. “All of a sudden this woman came out on her porch and started yelling at me. ‘You better not take any bad pictures on this mountain,’ she yelled.”

He staunchly defends his right to make pictures on public property, but confided that there are a whole lot of people “skeptical of anyone doing anything around here.” So it’s clearly not just outsiders that are met with suspicion.

Cultural insensitivity and privilege

Jesse Camp says this could’ve happened anywhere. It’s true. It could’ve. But it didn’t. It happened in West Virginia. And if you’re not familiar with the long history of visual misrepresentation of the region, then close your eyes and think about the first thing that pops in your head when you hear the words “West Virginia.” See what I mean?

Understanding the very real history of misrepresentation in Appalachia—particularly McDowell County, West Virginia, which is often portrayed as a hopeless pocket of rural Appalachia (a depiction I take great issue with)—by no means implies that it’s justifiable to hold people against their will and threaten physical violence. It’s also unreasonable to judge anyone by his or her appearance or how they talk, no matter who they are or where they’re from. But it’s important, although not easy for everyone, to understand where the anger comes from. It’s only through self-awareness that both photographers and local residents can hope to prevent incidents like this.

West Virginia is in my DNA. It’s a huge part of who I am. I’m also a photographer, which is an equally huge part of who I am. Often when these two meet it can be a challenge to find a balance, to reconcile history with the present, to challenge what we’ve been shown with what we know. I’m all too aware of how we’re portrayed, joked about and stereotyped. I’m also aware of how important listening is, and how making work in Appalachia isn’t as much about me as it is about honoring, respecting and searching for home. I’m not saying the way I work is the right way, if there is such a thing, but I am saying I don’t want to be another taker in a long line of takers.

Without a true understanding of the long history of takers in Appalachia, it can be hard to understand why locals reacted the way they did. The Camps deny both their privilege and a lack of understanding. They stated to me several times that they’ve been living out of their car, wearing the same clothes over and over again, and doing so with little to no money. But there’s nothing that pisses underprivileged people off more than privileged folks blind to their own privilege. Does that make the Camps bad people? I don’t think so. Does being threatened, blocked in, called names, yelled at and held hostage until state police arrived seem warranted? Again, I don’t think so. The Camps are likable people and I’ve found nothing in the time I’ve spent communicating with them that would lead me to feel otherwise, but I can raise concern over their cultural insensitivity.

Does that mean they can’t make work in Appalachia? Absolutely not.

Privilege can be tricky. I know this all too well. But photographers should be aware of it and sensitive to it. Marisha Camp was quick to counter my mention of this via text. “I’ll bet that lady [Jennifer Adkins] makes more money than me.”

This isn’t a situation in which it’s easy to either support the photographers or support the community. It’s much more complex than that. What would’ve happened if the Camps had knocked on the door of the Adkins house? What would’ve happened if Jennifer Adkins had simply left after seeing no pictures of her children had been taken? If the Camps were more apologetic and disarming in their responses, would the situation have escalated?

This isn’t just a place in a road trip documentary. This place is my home. It’s true that we can’t police who does and doesn’t make work in Appalachia. But when I reflect on this situation, I’m reminded of a saying by my granddad, “Enough is enough and too much is nasty.”

Thanks to Marisha Camp, Jesse Camp, Jennifer Adkins, Elaine McMillion Sheldon, Kate Fowler, Joy Salyers and Alan Johnston for their time in contributing to this article.

Roger May is a photographer currently based in Raleigh, North Carolina. In 2014, he started the crowdsourced photography project "Looking at Appalachia" (www.lookingatappalachia.org). He frequently speaks about his work and about issues of Appalachian representation, and photographs on commission.

Related: Shelby Lee Adams: An Ode to Appalachia
