article.article_title: Photo Archiving: In the Digital Age, Longevity Is No Sure Thing
article.article_text_abstract: How to make sure your photos are safely preserved for years to come.
article.article_image_caption: Inside the Mivitec datacenter in Munich, Germany. To keep digital files safe, preservation experts advise treading cautiously with the cloud and instead trusting images to open formats and hard disk storage.
article.article_text:
For photographers with an archive brimming with slides, contact sheets, negatives and prints, the future of that work looks bright. Basic defenses against the corrosive agents of time, a dollop of good fortune and those photos have an excellent chance of surviving for potentially a hundred years or more.

Digital photographs? Not so much.

“We’re living in an unprecedented time,” says Henry Wilhelm, co-founder of Wilhelm Imaging Research and a photo permanence expert. For all of human history, we’ve created “human-readable” records—like your archive of prints—that require nothing more than a working set of eyes to be accessed and understood. Now we are in an age of “machine readable” records. In such an age, it’s a question of whether future software and devices will be able to able to access, read and display the bits of digital information that represent your images. As anyone who’s held an 8-inch floppy disk knows, that’s no sure thing.

To shepherd your digital photos through generations, three major factors have to be considered.

The Security of Your Files

The ideal solution, says stock photographer and image preservation expert David Riecks, is known as the “3-2-1 approach.” That’s three copies of a file, stored in two different places with one of those locations off-site. Wilhelm prefers hard drives as cloud since services like Dropbox are only good archival solutions as long as they’re in business. As the history of technological disruption attests, today’s well-capitalized empires may collapse into tomorrow’s business school case studies.

The life of any given hard drive is variable, but a study from the cloud provider BackBlaze based on a comprehensive examination of drives used in their servers, found the average to be six to seven years. Migrating data to new drives on a five-year basis may provide extra insurance.

Moving large amounts of data back-and-forth introduces plenty of opportunities for file corruption. Fortunately you can run the equivalent of a “DNA test” on files that are being transferred from one media to another to ensure they arrive intact. Riecks uses a hashing program that creates a checksum file that examines the bit structure of all his archived files. If there were any errors introduced during the transfer process, the checksum file will flag them. AV Preserve offers a variety of file-checking tools, some of them free, to verify the integrity of image collections across storage platforms.

The recently introduced Mylio software is another very effective method to keep files synchronized multiple platforms, including offline devices, Wilhelm said. While Mylio is new, it is “cloud agnostic” and preserves the file structure in a Mac or Windows environment so that in the event it is shut down, a user would still be able to easily locate images on stored devices, says company founder David Vaskevitch. Unlike other image organizers, “Mylio has protection baked in,” since it also adheres to the 3-2-1 approach and offers a visual guide alongside each image to alert users to its protection status, Vaskevitch says.

One shouldn’t overlook the value of printing as an archival method either, Wilhelm says. Properly produced and cared for, printed images can last for hundreds of years—far longer than any contemporary digital storage media. What’s more, a signed and dated print is the currency of the fine art photographic market, Wilhelm says. “You don’t see people spending $5.6 million for a file.”

The Readability of Your Files

Second, and more challenging, is choosing an image file format that has the best chance of being machine-readable in the future. “A primary characteristic for an archival format is that the structure and nature of the format be openly documented and understandable by any reasonable software engineer in the imaging field,” says Tom Hogarty, Director of Product Management at Adobe.

JPEGs and the Adobe-championed DNG format fall under this umbrella. "Support for JPEG codecs will remain part of photographic software years from now," says Peter Schelkens, PR chair for the JPEG Committee. "I do not see main photo software vendors discontinuing support in the near and not so near future. Moreover, the fact that JPEG is an official ISO/IEC and ITU-T standard guarantees that it is well documented and generally accepted. Such standard specifications are well archived and should in principle allow you to decode these images even thousands of years from now, assuming of course we did not move out of the digital era." 

A “plain vanilla TIFF” file, while proprietary, is also very well documented and is Riecks’ archival format of choice. For Riecks, “plain vanilla” means an 8-bit TIFF file in the AdobeRGB color space.

The Library of Congress uses bitmaps in a TIFF wrapper to preserve their digital photo files, says Carl Fleischhauer, project panager in the Office of Strategic Initiatives at the Library of Congress. This approach prioritizes long-term readability over the ability to make future edits to a file, but photographers may want the emphasis on the latter. In that case, formats like DNG make sense, Fleischhauer says.

What our experts were less confident in was the ability of proprietary, camera-specific RAW files to offer as high a degree of longevity and readability.

Preserving the Metadata

Ensuring a photo has accurate and thorough metadata is critical to digital photo preservation, argues Riecks, because it enables future programs to find and organize a photographic collection. It also ensures critical copyright data travels with the images as they migrate from old storage solutions (like hard drives) to new ones that haven’t even been conceived of yet. It also protects images that are discovered online from being deemed “orphaned” works.

A first step to preserving metadata is to make sure it’s input early in your workflow, otherwise you’re “throwing images into a black hole,” Riecks says. Given the sheer number of images you’re likely managing, it makes sense to discriminate. Riecks will batch process all photos with a minimum amount of metadata to ensure basics like location, copyright, time and date, and captioning details are represented. For images he cares more about, he’ll input even more information such as tags, ratings and keywords. Riecks offers a series of detailed keywording guidelines on his site, Controlled Vocabulary.

Like image files, metadata files come in a variety of flavors and not all will be viable as a long-term preserve of valuable image information. Adobe, for instance, backs the open-source XMP (for Extensible Metadata Platform) format. News and photo agencies use the IPTC Photo Metadata Standard, which is built off of Adobe’s XMP and an older IPTC standard to ensure long-term interoperability (it also comes with its own manifesto). Another virtue of using widely available image file formats as opposed to proprietary RAW files is that they support embedding metadata into the image file.

Whatever method you adopt, it’s clear that for images to survive for decades in a machine-readable age, image-makers have to keep preservation at the forefront of their workflow.

“There’s a paradigm shift in that preservation used to be the end of the process,” Fleischhauer says. “Now, preservation actions have to start at the very beginning of your workflow.”

See also: The Best High Capacity Hard Drives for Your Digital Archive

article.article_title: How I Got That Shot: Still Lifes (And GIFs) For Refinery29 and Nasty Gal
article.meta_description: Photographer Stephanie Gonot typically does her own propping, styling and art direction on shoots; she tells PDN how she put together photo illustrations for Nasty Gal and Refinery29.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer Stephanie Gonot typically does her own propping, styling and art direction on shoots; she tells PDN how she put together photo illustrations for Nasty Gal and Refinery29.
article.article_image_caption: An image Stephanie Gonot prepped, styled and photographed for Nasty Gal.
article.article_text:
Client: Nasty Gal

Director of Photography: Anouck Bertin

Client: Refinery29

Photo Editor: Julia Finch

On most of her assignments for editorial and commercial clients, still-life photographer Stephanie Gonot does her own propping, styling and art direction. “I think that clients like that I can do the whole thing myself,” the Los Angeles-based photographer says. “I enjoy shooting solo on the smaller jobs, because I can get into a zone and move quickly.”

Her long-time clients often give her a subject, then let her figure out how she wants to shoot it. That’s true for Nasty Gal, the online fashion retailer Gonot has been shooting for since 2013, when Sarah Kissel, the senior art director at the time, hired her to shoot a photo illustration for the Nasty Gal magazine. Typically, Nasty Gal sends her some fashion accessories to shoot, sometimes with suggestions for a color scheme or materials to use. A few days later, Gonot delivers the images she has created, which Nasty Gal typically uses in its email promotions.  

When the assignment called for her to shoot a white shoe, Anouck Bertin, Nasty Gal’s director of photography, said she had in mind one of Gonot’s earliest still lifes, which showed a meal from McDonald’s that Gonot had spray painted white and shot on white seamless. Gonot, who had studied painting, made the image in 2010, shortly after she began experimenting with photography. It inspired her to begin her best-known series—on the ingredients of fad diets—shot on colored backdrops. Her playful imagery is a good fit for the Nasty Gal brand, which Gonot describes as “colorful, and a little bit irreverent. Or maybe a lot irreverent.” 

Her assignments for Refinery29 are even more open-ended. The first time the fashion and lifestyle website hired Gonot in 2014, she sent the editors some PDFs to show her ideas and get them approved. After that, she’s been given free rein to come up with her own treatments. “They would come to me with a story and say we need six pictures that illustrate this story, here are the six points we’ll cover, do you have any ideas?”

For a story called “The Truth about Tripping: How Psychedelics Made a Comeback,” Refinery29 photo editor Julia Finch asked her to come up with four trippy images, and suggested it would be fun to show them as animated GIFs. Though the compositions were very different from the shot of the white shoe she created for Nasty Gal, on both assignments Gonot used the same lighting and camera setup, making only slight modifications. 

Logistics

Gonot shoots most tabletop setups on 4-foot-wide seamless, and has a variety of colors and materials to choose from. She does most of her own prop shopping, “which keeps costs down,” she says. 

For the Nasty Gal white-on-white shoot, she pulled some seamless from her collection, and bought some fruit for propping and some spray paint. For the Refinery29 story, she bought some colorful children’s blocks, which she set on a sheet of black Plexiglas, which absorbs and disguises shadows. After some experimentation, she decided to use some white pegboard she had in her studio as her backdrop. The pattern of holes in the pegboard, which she leaned against the wall behind her table, was reflected in the black Plexi. 

To photograph the reflected pattern, she says, “I was on my tiptoes, looking down on the Plexi to capture that weird effect of the dots trailing away.”

Gonot puts time and attention into her compositions, so she finds it satisfying to work on images that will appear online: “It’s nice that the images aren’t cropped,” she explains.

Lighting

Though she rents bigger lights on some productions, when she’s shooting on her own, Gonot likes to use a simple setup so that she can move quickly and easily as she shoots. This setup usually combines two Calumet Travelites with a Canon Speedlite 430EX II on her camera, which she’ll turn up or down to adjust the flash. She’ll also use the speedlight to trigger her strobes. “That’s the general setup when I’m in my studio, then I modify from there, depending on what I’m shooting.”

For the white shot for Nasty Gal, she used one Travelite on a stand about seven feet high, to the right of the table. Shooting white objects on white seamless, she wanted to soften the light, so she fired it through a white umbrella. The Speedlite provided some fill. “It gives it a little bit of extra kick of light,” she says. “It takes away dark shadows.” 

For the shot of colored blocks, the strobes were bare, and positioned so they hit both the blocks and the white pegboard background at the same time. For this shot, she powered the Speedlite down. “It’s used almost as a trigger, more than a fill, but it adds a little bit of something.”

Camera

Gonot used a Canon EOS 5D Mark III with 24–70mm f/2.8 zoom. She notes, “These are small objects. I’ve got to zoom in to get the details.” Shooting with the Speedlite turned up, she’ll typically shoot at ISO 160, and rarely uses a tripod. “I like to move around and try different angles and move things around.” 

Postproduction

Gonot began making still-lifes before she learned Photoshop, “so I had to make sure I got everything in-camera because I didn’t know how to clean things up.” These days she’s more experienced, but she typically has to turn a job around in only four or five days, which leaves little time for retouching. “I try to shoot these so that not much post is needed.” 

Gonot typically shoots a lot of variations, modifying her lights or position as she goes, and may produce up to 200 images on a shoot. “It’s like I’m doing a lot of sketches,” she explains. She reviews the take, noting everything she likes.  She’ll typically send about 20–60 low-res images to Nasty Gal; when they choose the finals, she’ll clean up the selection then send high-res files; Nasty Gal has their own retoucher for more extensive retouching. For Refinery29, she typically edits the story herself, and forwards her final selection to Finch. “That’s just how Julia and I work,” Gonot says. “I’m choosing this image from this set because it looks good with the image from that set.”  

The Refinery29 tripping story was Gonot’s first experience making animated GIFs. Once she figured out the process in Photoshop, she delivered four subtly reverberating GIF files, which were published on the site in August 2014.

article.article_title: 11 Camera Bags For Every Assignment
article.meta_description: Whether you're at home in the urban jungle or out in the real thing, these camera bags will keep your gear safe and sound.
article.article_text_abstract: Whether you're at home in the urban jungle or out in the real thing, these camera bags will keep your gear safe and sound.
article.article_text:
Whether you’re at home in the urban jungle or out in the real thing, these new camera bags will keep your gear safe and sound through your next photographic adventure.


LowePro Pro Trekker 450 AW

When it’s time to leave civilization behind, LowePro’s Pro Trekker 450 AW backpack might just be your go-bag. It can store a pair of DSLRs with lenses attached, plus up to four additional lenses, speed lights, batteries and an action cam. The bag uses the company’s ActivLift System harness, which LowePro claims sends the bag’s weight from the waist to the hips, following the natural curve of your back. It is constructed with 630D nylon with a 1000D Cordura base that’s both durable and weather-resistant. You can stave off dehydration with a seam-sealed side pouch that can store 70 ounces of liquid in an optional hydration reservoir. The internals offer the usual padded, adjustable dividers. A laptop sleeve sits in the front pocket and you can clip a tripod to the bottom of the bag. You’ll find a rain cover at the bottom of the bag, for when the skies open up. 

Price: $380
Info: www.lowepro.com


Tamrac Apache Six

Tamrac’s Apache 6 photo messenger bag is capable of transporting a DLSR with a 6-inch lens attached, two or three extra lenses, plus all the requisite photo accessories. Tablets or small laptops up to 12 x 9.5-inches can be stowed in an interior foam compartment as well. Expandable side pockets can accommodate phones, water bottles and other personal items. A zippered front pocket features numerous organizers for neatly stowing memory cards, batteries, notebooks and more. The Apache 6 is made from waterproof sailcloth and features a bottom lined with Hypatex, a scratch- and water-resistant synthetic rubber. There’s also a pocket for slipping the bag over a luggage handle, and the interior Velcro flaps can be “silenced” using built-in flaps.

Price: $150
Info: www.tamrac.com


Jill-E Jack Hudson

The unobtrusive yet impeccably styled Jack Hudson can fit a DSLR and up to two lenses and basic accessories in its padded interior. You’ll find a few other nooks and crannies to store gear, such as a zippered pocket inside the bag’s flip lid, plus a rear pocket on the outside of the bag. The Hudson is clad in Colombian leather, with a leather top handle and an adjustable, removable cloth shoulder strap. It’s available in brown or tan (pictured here). 

Price: $120
Info: www.jill-e.com


Kelly Moore Jude

The Jude is eerily reminiscent of a classic doctor’s bag, but even if house calls aren’t your thing, working photographers should find much to like about this handy case. The interior can be sub-divided by using seven adjustable Velcro dividers. The sides and bottom of the bag are padded to protect your gear, and the bag will stay upright when you place it down. You can fit a DSLR body, 10-inch lens and a 13-inch laptop or 10-inch tablet, and an armful of odds and ends inside the Jude—the dividers come out to make for more space. Both the front and the back offer a zipper pocket and a snap pocket for quickly accessing smaller items. The Jude is stitched from gray canvas and trimmed with leather.

Price: $299
Info: kellymoorebag.com



Manfrotto Off Road Back Pack 30L

Manfrotto’s first foray into outdoor photo backpacks is the appropriately named Off Road. Half of the bag’s carrying capacity is devoted to photo gear; the other half dedicated to personal items. And in those rare moments that you don’t want to carry your camera, you can convert the bag to carry just your personal items. Manfrotto says the Off Road can stash a pro DSLR with a 70–200mm f/2.8 lens, plus additional lenses and accessories, in its interior. There’s a removable insert with handles that you can pop out of the bag. You can also clip a tripod and a pair of walking sticks to the back of the bag. Manfrotto will offer a color-coordinated pair of walking sticks—made by the Italian firm Fizan—that have a removable cap at the top to double as a monopod with a max payload of 5.5 pounds. The sticks are sold separately for $100. 

Price: $200
Info: www.manfrotto.com


Mountainsmith Andy Mann Spectrum

The Spectrum is a lightweight bag capable of toting a DSLR and lens plus accessories onto the trail. Your camera and lens are stored in a compartment at the bottom of the bag that can be quickly accessed through a side panel. You can slip laptops as large as 17 inches into a compartment in the back, which also has a quick-access side zipper. Accessories can be placed into the top compartment of the bag, or into the side-slip pocket. The Spectrum features a detachable waist belt, an air-mesh back panel, a waterproof fabric coating and a removable rain cover.

Price: $99
Info: mountainsmith.com


Think Tank Urban Approach 15

The Urban Approach 15 is roomy enough to accommodate up to two mirrorless cameras with lenses attached, between five and eight additional lenses, plus a 15-inch laptop, 10-inch tablet, smartphone and your personal ephemera. APS-C-sized DSLRs, like Canon’s EOS Rebel t5i with an 18–55mm f/3.5–5.6 lens, will also feel at home. Your laptop is secured in a zippered compartment while camera lenses and bodies are held in place by removable foam inserts. A plush-lined front pocket keeps your smartphone secure. The back of the pack has a pass-through so you can slide it over a rolling luggage handle, and you can dangle a tripod off the side of the bag with the included strap. Stretchable side pockets accommodate a water bottle, flash or modest umbrella. The bag is water-resistant, and there’s a rain cover, should the going really get tough.

Price: $170
Info: www.thinktankphoto.com


Tenba Switch 10

Are you the indecisive type? Tenba’s Switch bag offers a choice of interchangeable covers so you can switch up your style on a whim. Your choices include red faux leather, blue mélange, pink mélange, blue/grey geometric and black/grey camoflauge. Each sell for $20, and Tenba promises that more color options are forthcoming. The bag is designed to carry a mirrorless camera with lens attached, and up to three additional lenses and other accessories. Its front flap has a magnetic clasp, so you’re not loudly tearing open Velcro straps and catching dirty looks, plus a secondary snap enclosure for added security. It also features a top-access zipper so you can dip into the bag without having to open the main cover. There are side loops for attaching additional pouches plus MOLLE loops on the bottom for carrying a tripod. A rear padded sleeve houses a 10-inch tablet. The bag is made from water-repellant nylon, but for a serious deluge, there’s a rain cover provided as well. 
   
Price: $110
Info: www.tenba.com



Clik Elite Luminous

If you’ve got some serious hiking and gear-toting on your agenda, Clik Elite’s Luminous pack could fit the bill. The internal camera compartment can hold a DLSR, 70–200mm and 24–70mm lenses, a flash and other accessories. As you’d expect, the camera compartment has removable and customizable foam dividers for keeping gear separated and secure. Reinforced compression straps on the exterior of the bag can hold skis, a snowboard or large tripod, and you can slip your camera strap over the bag’s Clik Draw gear loop when you need to free your hands. You also get a foam-padded waist belt with a bi-directional buckle to redistribute the bag’s weight around your waist. 

Price: $289
Info: www.clikelite.com


Domke Chronicle

Part of Domke’s Journalist line of photo bags, the Chronicle has three dividers that let you stash your DSLR and 70–200mm lens, plus up to three other lenses and a 9.7-inch tablet. An expandable zippered side pocket gives you room to throw in notebooks (the good old-fashioned paper kind) and voice recorders. There’s space on the outside, too, with a pair of expandable front pockets and two expandable zippered pockets for tucking away memory cards, business cards and the like. It comes in canvas, Cordura, and RuggedWear versions. 
   
Price: from $217
Info: www.tiffen.com/domke

Ona Prince Street

Capable of stowing an 11-inch laptop or tablet, a DLSR with small lens attached, two additional lenses and a variety of small personal items, the Prince Street camera messenger bag looks as good as it feels. A thin back pocket can hold documents, while a pair of front pouches stores memory cards, batteries and other accessories. The main compartment is clasped shut using two brass buckles, while a pair of side flaps help keep inclement weather at bay. The exterior is made from weather-resistant waxed canvas and detailed with full-grain leather, while the interior’s padded compartments keep your gear safe from the inevitable bumps and bruises. You can sling the bag around your torso or use the removable top-grab handle to carry it, briefcase-style, to your next assignment. 

Price: $389 (Leather); $279 (Waxed Canvas)
Info: www.onabags.com

Related: 8 Camera Bags For Every Photo Shoot

article.article_title: How Christopher Grimes and Olson Make Custom Content for Target, General Mills and More
article.meta_description: Christopher Grimes, a producer at the Minneapolis-based advertising agency Olson, tells PDN how he works with photographers to create integrated campaigns for a variety of platforms.
article.article_text_abstract: Christopher Grimes, a producer at the Minneapolis-based advertising agency Olson, tells PDN how he works with photographers to create integrated campaigns for a variety of platforms.
article.article_image_credit: © WET N WILD/PHOTO BY MEREDITH JENKS
article.article_image_caption: For wet n wild, Olson assigned fashion and beauty photographer Meredith Jenks to create both stills and video for the Steal the Look app.
article.article_text:
Christopher Grimes has worked in the advertising business for 15 years, both as an art producer and as a photo agent. While at The Martin Agency and Crispin Porter + Bogusky, he worked with numerous photographers and produced photo shoots around the globe. In 2013, he joined Olson, an advertising agency in Minneapolis, as a senior integrated art producer creating custom content for clients such as Target, General Mills and the Baylor College of Medicine. In an email interview with PDN and an Olson publicist, Grimes discussed his work with photographers in creating integrated campaigns for a variety of platforms.

PDN: What can you tell us about Olson?

CG: Everyone here is like family; to me, that is everything. As far as a company and our offerings, we have three divisions—brand & digital (Olson), loyalty (Olson 1to1) and PR (Olson Engage). For clients, we’re a one-stop agency.

PDN: Olson’s slogan is “revolutionizing engagement.” How so?

CG: Olson is a unique agency in that, in addition to its advertising and digital capabilities, we have really strong, industry-leading practices in areas like loyalty and PR that allow us to offer our clients a broader range of ways to engage their customers. 

We also believe that marketers are only starting to grasp what’s now possible thanks to evolving technology and emerging media. 

PDN: What does the “integrated” part of your title mean?

CG: It means we don’t exclusively work on photography or illustration projects. Since I’ve been at Olson, I have produced a range of artwork for social media, websites, events, video productions, installations and of course, traditional photography and illustration for print.  

PDN: What role do you think photography can play in integrated solutions for a brand? 

CG: Visual storytelling gets more important all the time, wouldn’t you agree?

PDN: What are some projects you’ve worked on that you are proud of? 

CG: One of my favorite projects so far has been a photo shoot for the Baylor College of Medicine. The creative team created a beautiful campaign that used black-and-white photography from Nadav Kander to focus on the hands of the doctors at BCM. The BCM project used gallery-quality photography to convey the elite status of the Baylor College of Medicine doctors. 

Another favorite was the Steal the Look app for the beauty brand wet n wild. That included both still and video assets. It’s a bright, brassy, well-designed app and it’s fun to use…even if you don’t wear makeup! For wet n wild we needed to convey edgy and bold style that screams L.A. [Photographer] Meredith Jenks was the perfect choice.

PDN: Why were the photographers you chose right for the assignments? 

CG: For BCM, we vetted so many brilliant photographers. They all brought a unique approach to the project, however in the end Nadav Kander brought a sophistication that we loved. 

Meredith Jenks’s [photography] is stylish, colorful, fun and irreverent—exactly what the wet n wild brand is. Also, her energy made her stand out both in the creative calls and on set.

PDN: Do you have favorite ways of finding photographers, or being approached by photographers? 

CG: Through building relationships with their agents over the course of many years. Personal visits to the agency from the photographers is also a nice way to have an idea of their personalities and how they will work with the creative teams prior to putting them up for an assignment. 

Meeting the photographers...is not essential to me suggesting them or assigning them a project. Their work is first and foremost. However, a personality that you click with is definitely a good thing.

PDN: Are you looking for new talent, or do you tend to rely on a stable of freelancers you trust? 

CG: Both! I love my trusted partners (most have become friends) and always throw them into the mix if possible. At Olson I love meeting with new photographers and have worked with quite a few that have come to visit us.

I guess 80 percent of the photographers I have worked with since I have been at Olson have been new to me. Perhaps I knew of them but it was my first time partnering with them. Both Nadav and Meredith were new.

Many of the local Minneapolis photographers I have worked with have been new as well.

PDN: What skills or talents does a photographer need to have to convince you to entrust him or her with an assignment? 

CG: They need to do their homework prior to the creative calls—spend time getting to know both the client and agency brands. 

PDN: Have agency or client expectations about your role changed?

CG:  Yes, I think mostly with timelines and budget. Clients want more…with fewer resources. They need to react to trends quicker.

PDN: You worked at a photo agency for a while. What did you learn from that experience? 

CG: Being an agent is a tough job! Agents and producers are in this together—the more information you can give agents, the better they can help you to get what you and your client need.

PDN: Is there anything you wish photographers understood better about advertising today? How should they not approach you? 

CG: Two things: First, when you contact us, please do your homework. There are too many times I get emails or calls saying ‘I’m perfect for such and such a client’ and their style isn’t even close to the current creative or we’re not working on that client anymore. Second, it’s nice to have occasional follow-up, but please know we can’t personally answer everything. Art producers are inundated with emails, mail and calls, and answering them all on top of our workload is nearly impossible. Show us your latest work, add a few lines personally tailored to the recipient and don’t make the email open-ended.

gallery_slide.gallery_image_credit: © BAYLOR COLLEGE OF MEDICINE/PHOTO BY NADAV KANDER

article.article_title: How To Preserve Your Photo Archive For The Future
article.meta_description: How To Preserve Your Photo Archive For The Future
article.article_text_abstract: Photographers, appraisers and other experts explain the steps you can take now to make sure your heirs get the most benefit—and least trouble—from the photographic legacy you leave behind.
article.article_image_caption: Morton Beebe (left) and his assistant working in his archive. Beebe has chosen to set up a revocable living trust for his work.
article.article_text:
It’s an inescapable fact: At some point, all of us will die. And we all hope that when we do, we leave our loved ones with minimal mess and maximum gain from our assets. But for various reasons—lack of time, confusion about the options, or denial of our mortality—we may not be planning accordingly. 

For photographers, bequeathing archives can be especially complicated. During the course of his or her career, the typical photographer will make hundreds of thousands of images. What value does the work have, and who should inherit it? How should it be organized so that it will continue to be relevant, and how can its tax liability be minimized?

What happens to a photographer’s estate after death, and the amount of tax levied on it, can vary according to the estate plan the photographer puts in place. And while death (we hope) seems a distant prospect, it can pay to start planning early.

In order to distill some of the best practices, we spoke to several photographers who are putting estate plans in place now, and to professionals in the field. They outlined simple but effective ways of dealing with large bodies of work, and deciding what should happen to them posthumously. 

Organization

According to almost everyone we interviewed for this story, by far the most important step all photographers can take to secure their legacies is to edit and organize their work well. A messy, overloaded archive creates a physical and emotional burden for your heirs or executor, and can lead to extra expenses, such as storage and appraisal. 

“I’m often called in because a widow or widower is overwhelmed with the amount of material that has been left by a creative spouse,” says Oregon-based fine-art photography appraiser Jennifer L. Stoots. “I’ve walked into huge messes where there’s no discrete inventory, no cataloguing system, just box after box of chaos.”

Even when an archive is well-organized, it can still be overwhelming if it’s large. Mary Engel found this out in 1985 when her mother—the photographer Ruth Orkin—died, leaving Engel as her executor. “She was a conservative shooter, but she kept everything, from articles and pictures she liked to her own writing,” Engel says. “Although it was all very organized, I’m still going through it 30 years later and throwing things out.”

This experience—and her later experience inheriting the archive of her father, photographer and filmmaker Morris Engel, in 2005—inspired Engel to found the American Photography Archives Group (APAG), an organization that advises photographers and their heirs about estate issues. “Everyone always asks, what do I keep and what do I throw away?” says Engel. Her advice to photographers thinking about their estate is: “Try to de-clutter before you pass on.” Meanwhile, to heirs, she says: “Don’t try to inventory and digitize absolutely everything: Most likely, you’ll never need to know every single image. Instead, prioritize: Look for the signature photos and the important series.”

For Charles O’Rear, a former National Geographic photographer and book photographer who doesn’t have a history of fine-art print sales, organization means digitizing his best material. “I can’t think why anyone would want to keep old transparencies around,” O’Rear says. Instead, he scans his images and keeps them on two hard drives, one located at each end of his house. “If the house catches fire, it’s likely one will survive,” he says.

One exception to de-cluttering could come if you have a well-known image, or images that have sold well. In that case, making prints of the images before death could create potential value for your heirs. The prints should be signed to prove provenance: either that they are lifetime prints (made during the photographer’s lifetime) or vintage prints (made close to the time the negative was exposed). Renowned civil rights photographer Bob Adelman makes a point of doing this on a regular basis. “Taking time every now and again to make prints, and putting them aside, is an important way to increase the value of your work,” he says. 

The Legal Mumbo-Jumbo

Once you’ve got your archive organized (or even before), you’ll want to set up the legal framework for your estate. The options for this include a standard will, various kinds of trusts or a foundation. Your decision on this will be determined by the type and value of your estate, and your intentions for its use.

Value is a key point. In the last few years, the exemption on estate taxes has gone up considerably: from $1 million for an individual in 2002 to $5.43 million today. In other words, if your estate is worth less than $5.43 million (or $10.86 million if it’s jointly owned with a spouse), you don’t have to worry about estate tax. In which case, “a good will, naming the person who is inheriting your copyright, might be enough,” says appraiser Ellen Boughn. 

However, some photographers are choosing to set up a revocable living trust in addition to a will. (Needless to say, estate planning requires the help of a lawyer.) The major advantage of a revocable trust is that when you die, your assets pass directly to your beneficiaries without going through probate—which can be costly and lengthy. “Some states, like California and Florida, have very cumbersome probate processes,” says estate attorney Sarah Johnson. “If you live in one of those states, you really do want a revocable trust.”

San Francisco photographer Morton Beebe, known for his extensive surveys of San Francisco, Miami and Seattle, is currently in the process of winnowing down his archive. He also set up a revocable living trust in order to avoid probate. “I chose this trust because it avoids my possessions becoming a ward of the state,” he says. 

Another kind of trust, the irrevocable living trust, might be suitable for photographers with a taxable estate (over $5.43 million) and assets that are expected to appreciate. Under this kind of trust, you give away assets during your lifetime so that they are no longer part of your estate, and therefore estate tax is avoided. If the beneficiary sells the work later, he or she will have to pay capital gains tax (CGT) on the appreciation—but since CGT is lower than estate tax, it’s still a net gain. 

Another option is to set up a private, charitable foundation. “This is something I’d suggest if an artist wants to keep a body of work alive and has no heirs, or the children aren’t interested,” says attorney Sarah Johnson. The advantages of a foundation are that a body of work is secured and can be slowly distributed after death, with no estate tax due. When works are sold, the proceeds are used for charitable purposes. “Typically, you need at least $1 million of value to make a foundation viable,” says Johnson. “You’d need to sell some work or fund it with cash to provide for operating expenses.”  

Working With An Institution

For many photographers, the main reason for preserving an archive is so that their images will continue to be seen. That’s especially the case for photojournalists and others with bodies of work that may be historically rich but don’t have strong sales histories. 

If your work falls into that category, part of your estate plan might be to approach a library or museum with an interest in your work’s subject matter. Such institutions might occasionally buy an archive or accept it as a donation. “For a lot of photographers who don’t have huge established markets, regional institutions are a good choice,” says Edward Yee, a photography appraiser with Penelope Dixon & Associates. 

However, it’s not as easy as choosing an institution and informing them of your choice. “People should know that it’s very expensive for us to house photographers’ negatives, prints and tearsheets,” says Jack von Euw, curator of pictorial collections at U.C. Berkeley’s Bancroft Library, which specializes in collections about California and the West. Von Euw estimates that a third of the library’s photography collections have been purchased, and two-thirds donated. Even when he purchases a collection, he says, “We can’t purchase it at market value. The main thing is to be able to reassure a photographer that his or her work will have a place and be preserved.” 

For photographer Doug Menuez, that reassurance was a key factor in donating his work to Stanford University. Menuez, who documented Silicon Valley in the 1980s and 90s, began talking to Stanford’s library after a history professor invited him to give a talk at the university. “Originally they were going to buy the archive, but then they had budget cuts; we settled on my donating the physical material while keeping the copyrights,” he says. Stanford created a collection in his name, and presented a plan to develop the archive as a resource for scholars. “It was and is a tremendous honor,” Menuez says. “I know how hard it is for photographers to find a home for their work.” 

University libraries have approached Adelman about his extensive collection of Civil Rights-era imagery, but he has not signed a deal with any yet. One library did pay for him to have his archive appraised, a complicated process that typically costs upward of $10,000. Adelman anticipates that since his archive is “a unique body of work,” it will end up in an institution. “I’ve always tried to photograph things I thought had historic significance, to make the work valuable,” he says. 

Clarity

Whatever your estate plan, being clear about your wishes will make that plan easier to accomplish. In addition to organizing your work, setting up a legal framework, and possibly finding a home for your archive, talking to your heirs and leaving clear instructions can reduce confusion.

“I often advise photographers to talk into a microphone,” says Engel, “not just about your will, but other things. Do you want your archive split up, or kept together? How do you want your work to be remembered?” Intention is important, she says: for example, her mother’s most famous image, “An American Girl in Italy,” has sometimes been used without permission to illustrate sexual harassment. But since “it was the 1950s when my mother shot it, and that’s not how she or the woman in the picture felt,” Engel doesn’t allow the photograph to be used that way. 

Stoots, who says she’s witnessed “a lot of sad stories of overburdened family members and friends,” has brought together and moderated panels of attorneys, curators and tax specialists in Los Angeles and Portland. On April 15, 2014, she will moderate a similar panel at B&H Photo Video in New York. (See details at photostoots.com/upcoming-lectures-public-talks.) “It’s about finding best practices, and making life easier for those who inherit the work,” she says. 

If all this seems morbid, it’s important to remember that there’s a silver lining. Though photography estates can be complicated, they can also be a source of great joy for heirs—especially when they’re set up well. “It was hard for me in the beginning—just emotionally, hard to get started,” says Engel. “But to get positive responses from people, and to see my parents’ work still known and loved—well, that’s wonderful.”

article.article_title: Frames Per Second: The Interactive Projects of the National Film Board of Canada
article.meta_description: A pair of recent projects funded by the National Film Board of Canada borrow from video games to push the limits of visual storytelling.
article.article_text_abstract: A pair of recent projects funded by the National Film Board of Canada borrow from video games to push the limits of visual storytelling.
article.article_image_caption: A still from Way to Go. Players control the blockheaded character from a third-person perspective. Because the video was captured with a pole-mounted 360-degree camera rig, the camera operator appears as a similarly shaped (but black) figure, holding a pole.
article.article_text:
In a sense, Way to Go is a film. It has a beginning, an end, and moving images captured by a camera. But it’s also a game, where the player controls a blockheaded animated figure, deciding whether to walk, run, stop, jump, fly or investigate elements in the 360-degree live-action environment. And as part of the newest crop of interactive filmmaking on display at 2015’s Sundance Film Festival, it’s helping change the way we think about storytelling with moving pictures. 

“The way we move around when we’re traveling is very different than when we move around in everyday life,” says Hugues Sweeney, the project’s executive producer. In Way to Go—which is free to play at a-way-to-go.com—the speed with which players move along a path changes what they see and the music they hear. “Some things might happen that might never have happened if you walked super-fast,” Sweeney says. “The idea was creating these moments and giving this context for moments of hyper-lucidity.”

Way to Go mixes video footage shot with a DIY pole-mounted 360-degree camera rig comprised of six GoPros and hand-drawn animation, rendering graphics in your Web browser in real-time. The interactive video is the brainchild of AATOAA, a Montreal-based digital studio led by Vincent Morisset, an interactive filmmaker with video credits for musicians like Sigur Ros and Arcade Fire as well as commercial clients like Google and Red Bull. Way to Go is also funded by the National Film Board of Canada (NFB), which dedicates 25 percent of its yearly allocation to interactive productions. 

Sweeney has overseen all the projects produced by the NFB’s Montreal branch for the past five years. When he and Morisset spoke to PDN via Skype, they were in Park City, Utah, demoing a Virtual Reality adaptation of the project at Sundance’s New Frontier Story Lab, an incubator for interactive and VR storytelling. And while they got some attention from the tech world for demoing the interactive video on the Oculus Rift headset, Way to Go is just the latest of several innovative interactive projects from the NFB.

The NFB is government-funded, but that hasn’t kept Sweeney from green-lighting productions that investigate the actions of the government. In 2013’s Fort McMoney, David Dufresne uses first-person video to take a micro view of Fort McMurray, a boomtown that has sprung up near Alberta’s massive tar sands reserve. The extraction of tar sands oil—which is sent to refineries in the Midwest and on the Gulf of Mexico via pipeline—is a hot-button issue involving government interests, so diligent fact-checking was crucial. But making Fort McMoney would prove to be more complicated than just getting the facts straight. 

Dufresne had just moved to Canada when he pitched Fort McMoney as an interactive “docu-game,” hoping to combat what Sweeney calls Canada’s “green fatigue”—public apathy towards environmental issues brought on by media saturation. Sweeney had been a fan of Dufresne and Philippe Brault’s Prison Valley, an interactive documentary that explored the prison industrial complex in Cañon City, Colorado. Not unlike Prison Valley, Fort McMoney uses a first-person perspective to let players explore the town and hear interviews with residents and business owners about how the local industry affects the town, the country and the rest of the world. The filmmakers’ goal is to stoke educated discourse without pushing easy answers.

“The proposal of Fort McMoney is really about the audience taking control of the city, and making decisions about the city as they go through it,” Sweeney says. “I think it’s easy to just say ‘oil is bad,’ to get in a very polarized discourse about the exploitation of oil. The real issue is, on the one hand, the equilibrium between the economy and the environment. But to me the most interesting thing is how we behave as individuals.”

How the audience behaves and the decisions they make while playing Fort McMoney determine the outcome of the game. Individual players are in control, but only partly; the control is collective. While the interface is single-player, the experience is anything but. If you decide to turn Fort McMurray into a ghost town, but the rest of the audience wants to make it the Las Vegas of the north, the neon lights are inevitable. 

“This is a collective game, because you cannot change the world alone or a city alone, you need other people to do it,” Dufresne explains. “That’s the reason why on Prison Valley or in Fort McMoney, you can always see how many players are playing the game at the same time.”

Dufresne got to watch the collective discourse play out in real-time, thanks to a partnership with the Canadian newspaper The Globe and Mail, which assigned two journalists to play the game and featured the project on the front page of its website.

“They talked to the leaders of government [for the paper] each Sunday,” says Dufresne, “like, ‘What’s going on in Fort McMoney? If what happened in Fort McMoney was reality, what could it be?’ You know, The Globe and Mail is more conservative than progressive, and it was very interesting because they posted a lot of investigation about the tar sands in parallel with the game.” 

Now, with legislation looming concerning the proposed Keystone XL pipeline—which would increase the flow of oil from Alberta’s tar sands to refineries in the U.S.—the global influence of Fort McMurray is even more prominent. 

Fort McMoney is reality-based, while Way to Go lives in the realm of the senses. Both projects have creative teams that come from the film industry, but Dufresne also found inspiration in video games, which have exploded into a multi-billion-dollar business. 

“The video game industry changed the narrative 20 years ago,” says Dufresne, whose next interactive project will be on FIFA, the international governing body of soccer. “It’s very interesting, as a filmmaker, to see how the video game industry tells its stories. So we can borrow, we can take some aspects from the video game industry. It’s not an obligation to make a game. But you can use one or two ideas.” 

With Way to Go, Morisset says he wants “someone that’s five years old to dig it, but also I want my mom to be able to press the button and see how it works, but I also want my geek friends to be like ‘Oh, this is amazing!’” It’s the same diverse demographic that the video game industry now serves. 

When Dufresne spoke with PDN via Skype, he was looking out his window at Ubisoft, one of Montreal’s largest game studios. He imagines interactive filmmakers someday providing research and development for the multi-billion-dollar video games industry; if that happens, Dufresne thinks there could be more money for the filmmakers working in tandem with gamers. 

“We are on the same bridge, maybe one of these days we meet,” says Dufresne. “I think it could be very interesting. Because if we can get the skills, the money, the budget from the game industry, that could be very, very interesting for the documentary.”

article.article_title: What's Your Niche: Stephanie Berger, Performing Arts and Culture Photographer
article.meta_description: Photographer Stephanie Berger captures the decisive moments of performances at NYC's cultural and performance institutions.
article.article_text_abstract: Photographer Stephanie Berger captures the decisive moments of performances at NYC's cultural and performance institutions.
article.article_image_caption: Benjamin Millepied’s L.A. Dance Project performs “Quintett,” choreographed by William Forsythe (1993) at Montclair State University, New Jersey.
article.article_text:
Stephanie Berger helps cultural and performance institutions around the New York City area sell tickets to theater, dance and classical music events by capturing decisive moments of performances. 

PDN: Who are some of your clients, and how do they use your images?

Stephanie Berger: I get hired by major cultural institutions like Lincoln Center, Brooklyn Academy of Music, Park Avenue Armory and Carnegie Hall, and directly by dance companies, orchestras, and theater companies. They want photos [for promotions] to get people to buy tickets. 

PDN: How did you get interested in performing arts as a photographic subject?

SB: I’ve always been interested in music and dance. When I was growing up, we used to go to a lot of concerts. When I was in college, I was on the concert committee and photographed live performances. 

PDN: How did you start photographing performing arts and artists professionally? 

SB: When I first got out of school I worked at AP as a photo researcher. [Later] I became a photographer for the New York City Department of Transportation. I had great access to everything in New York City.

PDN: You were photographing performances on the side?

SB: Yes, I did it without getting paid for it. But my photographs started getting published a lot, and I started working for the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival. I showed work to The New York Times because I’d always wanted to work for their culture desk, and they started hiring me as a freelancer in 1991 or 1992. From there it all just sort of blossomed. 

PDN: What’s most appealing to you about photographing performing arts?

SB: You get to see the sweat, you get to see the muscles, you get to see artistic beauty and photograph it. I feel this engagement with performers. New York City has the greatest artists coming through, so it’s amazing, and I get to photograph it.

PDN: What is your goal?

SB: It is to make a dynamic photograph at the decisive moment. I’m not just trying to document it, but I’m trying to bring it to another level, and hopefully I’m making another piece of art.

PDN: Do you have to know the work being performed to accomplish that?

SB: No, I usually walk in cold.

PDN: How did you learn to anticipate the decisive moments?

SB: It’s an instinct. You can see and feel that it’s coming. I have a good sense of rhythm and a good eye, and I’ve been around in this world long enough so I can feel when that moment’s going to come.

PDN: What’s the most challenging thing about this type of work?

SB: There are two things. One is the lighting. It can be extremely dark, and people are moving fast, and you have to use available light.

PDN: How do you handle that?

SB: It’s much easier than it used to be. I work at ISO 4000 sometimes. You can hand-hold a lot more than you could with film, and I don’t mind blur. Sometimes that enhances a photo. What I’m trying to capture in a photograph is the feeling of movement. But I also try to get it so there’s a sharp edge to it. 

PDN: What’s the other challenge?

SB: You can’t make noise and often you can’t move around very much. So I have a sound blimp, and I’m often stationed in one place. Carnegie Hall is limited. You can sit in the back of the house, but sometimes you miss a shot because [the performance] is too quiet and you can’t shoot at that moment, even with the blimp.

PDN: The blimp isn’t quiet enough?

SB: It’s a soft blimp, so it’s not totally silent. Those audiences are tough. I’ve had people turn around and yell, “You’re disturbing me!” and I’ve been thrown out of theaters. But things are getting better now because the cameras have a quiet mode, and now some cameras have silent modes.

PDN: What’s in your camera bag? 

SB: I’m a Nikon girl. I always carry two bodies: a D3 and a D800. I have two lenses I use all the time: my 24–70 f/2.8 and my 80–200 f/2.8. I use a tripod a lot with a heavy-duty ball head. I also have a 300mm lens that I use when I have to shoot from the back of the house. 

PDN: Do you do other kinds of work besides performing arts? 

SB: I’m known in this world [of performing arts], so I’m busy all the time. It could be a portrait, a dress rehearsal, a performance, or a benefit event. I also shoot a lot for PBS. I recently shot a Downton Abbey event in New York for a social media campaign, and I’m going out to Los Angeles to shoot promotional photos for PBS’s spring program lineup.

PDN: What’s the competition like for performing arts work?

SB: I’ve been lucky. I’ve had many clients for a long time, but there are really talented people coming up, getting work you thought you would get, so you have to play the game, and make a deal [on fees].

PDN: What are the rates?

SB: Usually it’s a day rate, but I’m not comfortable discussing my fees. I have different scales for different clients and [what I charge] depends on many factors so I don’t want to state what my minimum is because that can be misread.

PDN: Are there secondary markets for your work?

SB: Yes, I sell a lot of prints. Performers and set designers sometimes want pictures for their own portfolios, so I will license photos for that. And I sell to textbooks—not a lot, though. 

PDN: What advice would you give to photographers who aspire to make a living photographing the performing arts?

SB: You have to have [credentials] to shoot in major venues, but there are many different small venues that you can shoot in [to start]. Photograph what you love so you show your passion…be it for dance, music, hip hop, ballet, electronica, experimental theater. Find young performing artists that you can collaborate with, who need cool photos for their press and websites. And don’t give [your work] away!

article.article_title: How To Get Repped By Getty Images
article.meta_description: Getty Images VP Aidan Sullivan explains how he scouts and selects new photographers for Reportage, Getty's photojournalism division.
article.article_text_abstract: Getty Images VP Aidan Sullivan explains how he scouts and selects new photographers for Reportage, Getty's photojournalism division.
article.article_image_caption: Sonya, now 13, stands on her street in Carbondale, OH. Photo by Maddie McGarvey, who is on the Emerging Talent roster at Getty Images.
article.article_text:
Distribution is one of the paramount challenges for photojournalists, and some seek help from photo agencies. Getty Images, one of the industry’s distribution powerhouses, represents about 50 photojournalists through its Reportage division. They rely on the agency for editorial assignments as well as distribution of their personal projects in publications all over the world. 

So who are those photographers, and how do they get on Getty’s roster?

Aidan Sullivan—Getty’s vice president of photo assignment, editorial partnerships and development—says the Reportage division offers opportunities for photojournalists at different career stages. His staff of 12 editors is constantly looking for talent. “It’s all about preparing the next generation [of photojournalists], and looking for new approaches to photojournalism,” he says.

He emphasizes that Reportage is a separate division from Getty Images Editorial, a wire service that employs staff and contract photographers for breaking news, sports and entertainment coverage. Reportage is also distinct from Getty Images Assignment, which represents photographers for corporate and commercial work.

Reportage photographers work on a variety of assignments and personal projects. Last year, their coverage ranged from the Ebola crisis in Africa to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and the rise of ISIS to civil unrest in Ferguson, Missouri, to name just a few examples.

Getty divides Reportage photographers into three categories: a small, elite group of seasoned photojournalists with exclusive contracts, called Represented Photographers; a second, larger tier of so-called Featured Contributors on non-exclusive contracts; and a third category called Emerging Talent. 

The latter is a one-year opportunity for photographers at the very start of their careers to prove themselves, showcase their work and learn from a Getty editor assigned as a mentor. Getty invites up to a dozen or so photographers into the program each year. Currently, the Emerging Talent roster includes Alejandro Cegarra, Antoine Bruy, Maddie McGarvey, Corinna Kern, Sebastian Montalvo Gray, Elyor Nematov and Andrew Renneisen.

To be eligible, photographers must be under 30 years of age, with few publications, no major awards, and no agency representation. Photographers may apply for admission to the program. This year’s deadline is May 13, 2015 (see imagery.gettyimages.com/getty_images_grants/Emerging.html for details).

Sullivan and his staff are on the lookout all year long for emerging talent. They find eligible photographers on social media, at portfolio reviews held at events such as Visa Pour l’Image (in Perpignan, France) and at the Ian Parry Scholarship competition, which supports promising photographers age 24 and younger. 

“We often [invite] five or six photographers every year from the Ian Parry Scholarship” entries, says Sullivan, who is chairman and founder of the Ian Parry Foundation. 

Cegarra, for instance, won the 2014 Ian Parry Scholarship. Sebastian Liste—represented until recently by Reportage—began as an Emerging Talent photographer after winning the Ian Parry Scholarship in 2010. Ed Ou, a Featured Contributor, also started in the Emerging Talent program after winning an honorable mention in the Ian Parry competition in 2010.

Getty doesn’t actively promote the work of Emerging Talent photographers, but the agency watches to see which ones produce. Sullivan says that overall, about 20 percent of Emerging Talent photographers are invited to continue working with Getty as Featured Contributors.

Besides Ou and Liste, others who have been promoted recently include Diana Markosian, Sara Naomi Lewkowicz, Shannon Jensen and Natalie Naccache.

“The Emerging Talent program is about how much effort you put in,” says Naccache, who was invited into the program in 2012, after showing her portfolio to Getty editors at Visa Pour l’Image. “I was always busy with photo projects, and I updated Getty every week. I would also update them on any assignments, and show them tear sheets, just so they’d know my progress.”

Her efforts eventually led to an invitation last year to join Reportage’s roster of Featured Contributors. As a result, she says, “I have been getting more assignments, and more assignments abroad. The support network is important as well. Patrick Llewellyn, my editor, used to work for the Sunday Times Magazine, so he gives me perspective from a picture editor’s point of view.”

Sullivan describes the Featured Contributors as those who are “very established, able to find their own work and just need our help with syndication.” He notes that Reportage is responsible for all the story packaging and marketing, freeing contract photographers from all of those tasks. “What they need to do is give us the tools” to market their work—specifically, strong visual narratives with a wide edit, Sullivan says.

Currently, there are about 30 Featured Contributors. Besides those already mentioned, they include veterans David Hume Kennerly, Charles Ommaney, Robert Nickelsberg and Reza, to name a few. 

Photographers may remain on the Featured Contributors roster as long as they continue to produce, Sullivan says. “We review the roster once a year to see how things are progressing.” He also says the Featured Photographer program “is rather like dating and then seeing if you want to get married”—that is, to advance to Represented Photographer status, with an exclusive contract. (Currently there are 16 Represented Photographers, among them Lynsey Addario, Benjamin Lowy, Daniel Berehulak and other top photojournalists.) 

Reportage editors find Featured Contributors in much the same way they find Emerging Talent: at contests, portfolio reviews, and photo festivals. Edouard Elias, for instance, was recently invited to join after he showed his work from Syria to a Getty editor at the Visa Pour l’Image festival.

Sullivan also encourages interested photographers to contact him by email. “I’ve always said: Just ask. When photographers email me to ask me to look at their work, I always do,” he says.

Competition for representation is stiff, though. Editors “speak to many hundreds of photographers throughout the year,” Sullivan says. They’re looking for “extraordinary talent,” reflected in photographers’ depth of knowledge, their experience, and their ability to create a visual narrative.

Getty also considers the geographic location of applicants in order to avoid conflicts among its contributors. “North America would be less open because we have a lot of photographers we represent here,” Sullivan says. “But South and Central America are open. We also look [at photographers from] Eastern Europe.”

His parting advice for photographers who want representation is: “Look at the standards we are working with,” by studying the work on Getty’s Reportage website. “Look at the features, and how we edit them so they’re ready to be packaged and sold. Study photographers we have on board, and emulate what they’re doing—but do it in your own style, in your own way.”

In short, if you want distribution, start by doing outstanding work. Did we say this was going to be easy?

article.article_title: Donna J. Wan Addresses Suicide in Her Challenging Series "Death Wooed Us"
article.meta_description: Wan's photographs of landscapes where people have committed suicide contemplate how people choose the places they end their lives.
article.article_text_abstract: Wan's photographs of landscapes where people have committed suicide contemplate how people choose the places they end their lives.
article.article_image_credit: © DONNA J. WAN/COURTESY RICK WESTER FINE ART
article.article_image_caption: “Golden Gate Bridge #7,” 2014, from Donna J. Wan’s series “Death Wooed Us.”
article.article_text:
In June 1995, after the 997th confirmed suicide from the Golden Gate Bridge, the city of San Francisco stopped keeping an official tally. If they hoped this might stem the tide of people who come to the bridge intending to end their lives, they were wrong. Unofficially, the death toll surpassed 1,600 in 2012, making it the second most popular “suicide destination” in the world, trailing only China’s Nanjing Yangtze River Bridge. 

“Death Wooed Us,” landscape photographer Donna J. Wan’s beautiful and unsettling new project, was borne out of a moment on the Golden Gate Bridge Bridge in 2012. “My husband and I were driving across and I was looking out at the beautiful views of the bay and landscape,” she explains, “I knew it was one of the most famous places for committing suicide, so I began to think about why suicidal people choose the particular places that they do to end their lives.”

Wan was recovering from postpartum depression following the birth of her daughter in 2011. Her memories of that time are still foggy, but Wan says that while she had faced depression before, nothing prepared her for the “blinding desperation” of that experience. In the depths of her illness she began to experience suicidal ideation, often centered on the idea of traveling to specific places on the California coast off of Highway 1 and jumping off a cliff into the water below. These were places she had long thought of as exceptionally beautiful and peaceful, so in that moment on the Golden Gate Bridge, Wan had a new understanding of what, perhaps, drew so many people to end their lives there. 

That night Wan told her husband the ideas she was mulling over for the new body of work and was taken aback when his initial reaction was negative. “Partly this was due to the fact that he didn’t want to revisit that traumatic time in our lives,” she remembers, “but he was also concerned that others wouldn’t understand my intentions.” Eventually he came around, which Wan says was crucial not just for moral support, but because her husband is the only person she shares her work with before it’s completed. 

Her previous two projects were also centered on human interaction with the natural world. Still, she knew going in that this would be a very different sort of project. “This is the most personal work I’ve ever done and that means I am a lot more vulnerable [as a result],” Wan says.

Pragmatism dictated that Wan shoot locally, given that she had a young child. She did venture outside the Bay Area, but as the project progressed she came to feel that shooting in areas she could visit repeatedly—and consistently develop a connection to—produced better images than “helicoptering in” somewhere. In order to find the locations, Wan would do research online, using news stories about traffic jams caused by jumpers and reports of bodies found on beaches. 

“I didn’t have preconceived notions of how the photos would turn out, I just knew what I wanted to explore,” Wan says. “I didn’t understand my own attraction [to the places and to the project], I was trying to understand it all and going to these places, I felt...almost a chill. But then there was also a beauty and grace.” She scouted and shot all the locations alone, not wanting anything to distract from the connection she sought with her subject. 

As emotionally draining as the shoots were, Wan’s greatest challenge came after she shared the work. Images from “Death Wooed Us” were featured on Wired.com in May 2014, and some of the comments were caustic. She had been prepared for accusations of romanticizing suicide but not accusations that the work was exploitative, or, in a sad bit of irony, that she didn’t know what it was like to be suicidal. Wan admits she let it “get her down.” But as she’s shown the project in other venues, she has seen more positive reactions, and learned how to better absorb the negative ones. 

Sharing the project with people in person has also given her valuable perspective. Often, whether with friends, colleagues or perfect strangers, people have divulged their own experiences with suicide. “I realized that this project gave some people the space to feel like they could talk about their experiences with someone who would not shy away from the subject,” Wan explains. “Even after I had gone through the worst of my postpartum depression, I felt like I still couldn’t really talk to others about my experience.... When people who have seen this work suddenly open up to me and tell me about their experiences, I feel honored that they feel comfortable enough to tell me something that they hold so close to them.”

At press time Wan was preparing for an exhibition of “Death Wooed Us” at Rick Wester Fine Art in New York City, which runs from March 19 through April 25. Wan still doesn’t know if the project is finished. She becomes emotional when talking about the last picture she took for the series, on a beach where a young man drowned himself. As a new parent, it was an especially difficult shoot, she says. “It was just so sad. Maybe that was the last one.”

article.article_title: Iraqi-Palestinian Artist Sama Alshaibi's First Book Explores Imperiled Water Resources
article.meta_description: In her series "Silsila," Sama Alshaibi utilizes the deserts and bodies of water in the Middle East and North Africa to explore humanity's common struggle for land and resources.
article.article_text_abstract: In her series "Silsila," Sama Alshaibi utilizes the deserts and bodies of water in the Middle East and North Africa to explore humanity's common struggle for land and resources.
article.article_image_caption: A page from Sama Alshaibi’s monograph Sand Rushes In, which combines images from “Silsila” and other series into a new, unique work.
article.article_text:
Few issues encompass the challenges facing humanity in the 21st century like water scarcity. Food production, climate change, forced migration, military conflicts and other critical issues are connected by anxiety over water supplies. Life simply can’t exist without fresh water, and billions of people are struggling for access. Further, our increasingly inhospitable world has shown through drought, flooding and other ecological disasters just how quickly livable land can be snatched away from large populations.

Imperiled water resources is one of the themes in “Silsila,” a series of photographs and videos by Sama Alshaibi that will be exhibited this spring at Ayyam Gallery, London, and which are included in a new monograph, Sand Rushes In, published this spring by Aperture. 

“Silsila” is an Arabic word meaning chain or link. The series grew from Alshaibi’s interests in “the root causes of war.” An American citizen of Iraqi and Palestinian heritage, Alshaibi has lived in Arizona since accepting a teaching position at University of Arizona in 2006. Early in her tenure there, she noted that experts from states in the Middle East were traveling to Arizona to study water management and city planning. Through research she understood that water is a factor that shapes political and social conflicts. “It’s really about a hoarding practice,” Alshaibi says. “It’s human nature to try to survive for yourself and the immediate group around you.”

To create the “Silsila” photographs and videos, Alshaibi retraced the route of 14th century Muslim traveller Ibn Battuta, working in major deserts and critical bodies of water in North Africa and the Middle East. Battuta’s travels through the Muslim world and subsequent stories “gave voice to communities and shared values, linking their stories with his,” Alshaibi explains in an interview in Sand Rushes In. While resources have caused conflicts—and will continue to do so—Alshaibi notes that the struggle for them is a commonality that transcends political borders, religion and other points of difference. “If anything,” she says, “‘Silsila’ is a sort of plea for us to look beyond these [divisive] issues.”

The images and videos, some of which were exhibited at the Venice Biennale in 2013, often depict a lone figure in deserts and oases. Clad mostly in black and often wrapped in green, blue, white or red scarves, the figure moves and gestures within the stark landscapes. In both the photographs and video pieces, we see the figure holding or releasing feathers into the wind, a reference to “migration and people in flight.”

Through reflections in bodies of water, or through postproduction mirroring effects, Alshaibi plays with themes of repetition and cycles of history, turning her photographs and videos in on themselves. At times her process results in complex geometric images that reference Islamic Art, mathematics and science. 

Alshaibi’s decision to work in harsh desert environments is particularly apt. Desertification, defined as “the persistent degradation of dryland ecosystems by variations in climate and human activities,” is chief among water-related concerns facing global populations. “The effects of desertification are increasingly felt globally as victims turn into refugees, internally displaced people and forced migrants or they turn to radicalization, extremism or resource-driven wars for survival,” notes a 2014 report issued by the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification.

While Alshaibi is the figure in the photographs and videos, her face is mostly obscured, making her more of a universal character. “The land is the protagonist and the water is the protagonist,” she explains. “There is a figure that may come into these images that has to negotiate and live with harmony in this space,” a reflection of human experience on earth. “Throughout time, that sort of relationship to land has always been there,” she says. “In harmony or disharmony, you’re always subjected to it.”

Alshaibi was traveling in areas to which she had no connection and which were essentially unknown to her, where it was difficult to communicate. She was often dropped off to do her work, trusting that her drivers would return for her eight or nine hours later. “What amazed me was that I found that the very simple ideas of being human, of gratitude, of graciousness, of caring, of alertness, of paying attention to difference but actually working on commonalities, is what made it work in all that migration through all those spaces,” she says.
